HEADLINE: Alaska Is Top Oil State

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Alaska has surged ahead of Texas as the nation's leading oil producer, topping the two million barrels-a-day mark for the first time since Prudhoe Bay production began to decline in 1988, state officials said this week. Texas, with daily output of 1.7 million barrels, is now the No. 2 producer. Last summer, Alaska's crude oil production dropped to a low of 1.6 million barrels a day. But nearly every oilfield in the state has increased production in the last month, said Dudley Platt, petroleum economist with the Revenue Department.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
The Merc's New Nikkei Futures

BYLINE: By Eric N. Berg

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THE Chicago Mercantile Exchange, in its latest bid to provide the broadest array of tools to help investors control risk, introduced a new futures contract last month based on the level of the Japanese stock market. Market professionals say the new contract could be a welcome addition to the investment scene given the increasing amount of investment in Japanese stocks by institutional investors in this country.
At the same time, however, they say the new futures contract has a number of problems that give it only about a 50 percent chance of survival.
The contract is based on the Nikkei 225, the counterpart to the Dow Jones industrial average. The Japanese index, calculated daily by the publisher of the Japan Economic Journal, is derived from the price of 225 blue-chip stocks like Nissan Motor and Fuji Bank. 
Investors who buy Nikkei futures in Chicago are betting that the Nikkei index will increase; sellers are betting that it will go down. So, institutional investors could sell Nikkei futures here as a way of hedging the value of a portfolio of Japanese stocks.
Such ''portfolio insurance'' seems to be a likely use for the new contract, and Merc officials hope it will appeal to pension funds, bank trust departments, insurance companies, ''any firm that has exposure to the Japanese market,'' said Angelo Calvello, a senior director at the exchange.
The Merc officials also say their new contract should be viewed as part of the much broader trend toward global, 24-hour trading. The New York Stock Exchange, they noted, is working on a system for trading stocks around the clock. The Merc is working with its crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade, on an after-hours trading system for futures called Globex. And the American Stock Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange are working on a project with Reuters Holdings P.L.C., the British news and financial information service, to develop an after-hours system for trading stock options.
Outside experts say the new Nikkei contract in Chicago could be used for both hedging and speculating, but they see certain obstacles to the contract's long-term success. For one thing, similar futures contracts are already trading in Osaka and in Singapore. The Merc has gone to great lengths to make its contract different - the Merc contract, for instance, trades only when trading in Osaka is closed and is denominated in dollars, not yen.
Still, the history of futures exchanges trying to compete against other exchanges that already dominate the market for a specific contract is discouraging; most efforts have failed. Experts say the roughly 800 contracts a day that have traded in Chicago are not enough to sustain the contract over the long term.
''It's a decent start, very respectable for the first few weeks,'' said John McCormick, a former market maker at the Merc. ''But it's still not clear whether the contract will make it or not.''
Also, some people consider it a liability that the Merc contract trades only when the Japanese stock market is closed. That is because many investors like to arbitrage between the two markets, buying in one market and selling in another to try to exploit price differences. Indeed, one reason the Merc's Standard & Poor's 500 stock-index futures contract is so successful is that it allows investors to arbitrage between the futures market in Chicago and the New York Stock Exchange, which operate concurrently.
Then, too, there is concern about the Nikkei 225 itself. The index is ''price weighted,'' meaning that it does not take account of the number of shares outstanding for any given company. On the other hand, the ''capitalization weighted'' indexes, like the Topix index of some 1,100 shares generated by the Tokyo Stock Exchange, does take account of shares outstanding. Most money managers assemble portfolios of stocks whose value more closely tracks indexes like the Topix than the Nikkei.
''That's why, if I wanted a proxy, I would probably buy futures based on the Topix,'' said Eric Seff, a managing director at the Chase Investors Management Corporation, a New York money management firm. A futures contract tied to the Topix recently began trading at the Chicago Board of Trade.
Although the Topix contract could prove to be stiff competition for the Merc's contract, many market experts remain hopeful that Nikkei futures will do well. The Nikkei contract has been designed so that it is relatively easy for local market makers in S.& P. 500 futures to switch pits and begin dealing in Nikkei futures.

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Mostly Lower; Dow Up 6.68

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Nervousness over quarterly earnings, conflicting news on the Persian Gulf and the budget impasse combined yesterday to drive stock prices through a choppy day.
By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average rose just 6.68 points, to 2,387.87. Trading volume rose to 161.3 million shares, from 149.6 million on Tuesday.
But 833 stocks fell and 659 rose. Only 6 reached a new high while 248 fell to new lows. 
Among the lows were Citicorp, in a weak bank group; Sallie Mae, which is under investigation by the FBI; American Express, and American General, the big Texas insurer that took itself off the block last month.
 
Mainly Blue-Chip Gains
While the rise in the Dow was a weak three-tenths of 1 percent, the S.&P. 500 declined slightly, suggesting that what little gain there was came from the blue chips.
Smaller stocks slid, with the American Stock Exchange market value index down four-tenths of 1 percent, while the Nasdaq composite index was up four-tenths of 1 percent.
One trader remarked the other day that people were buying just blue chips and that ''even if they go down, they've got good stuff.''
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said heavy computerized buying programs raised the Dow 22 points. Close to half of the gain came in buying during an eight-minute wave just after 11:30.
Stocks fell initially, rose a bit, fell back again, but began rising sharply just before 11 A.M. as traders became convinced that Congress and the President would finally be able to work out their differences on a budget package by Friday.
 
Traders' Expectations
Traders seemed almost certain that once the budget is set, the Fed would lower interest rates, pushing up stocks sharply.
Except for weakness against the yen, a steady dollar plus narrow bond gains and declining oil prices gave the market a brief lift. But by 12:30, after the Dow had climbed 32 points from its low, it began falling.
Explaining what happened, Peter J. Canelo, investment strategist for Bear, Stearns & Company, said: ''The market's trying to make a low. It's testing the lows of late September. But having just made a new low last week, it's not going to run away.
''Fundamentally, there's good reason to think the market will test that low successfully - and head higher over the next several weeks.''
He said that because of ''ample supply,'' oil prices reached a trading peak last Wednesday of $41.15 a barrel. By yesterday prices had dropped almost $5 a barrel. to $36.25. Yesterday alone it dropped $2.17.
Moreover, Mr. Canelo said, ''bond yields are coming down,'' standing unchanged yesterday at 8.88. The implication was that with rates falling, investors would be less likely to switch more money from stocks.
And, he said, ''We're seeing some stabilization in the dollar after coming down for the last three weeks.''
 
Nike Joins the Big Board
Nike, the athletic shoe producer, which began trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, ended unchanged at 26, with 1.03 million shares changing hands.
Citicorp, which fell 1 1/8 Tuesday after reporting a 38 percent drop in profits, topped the Big Board active list again yesterday, falling 1/4, to 12 3/4, after a new low of 12 1/4. Arthur P. Soter, analyst for Morgan, Stanley & Company, downgraded the stock.
Some 11.3 million shares changed hands, including a million shares in 79 blocks of at least 10,000 shares each, suggesting that practically all of the activity came from wealthy investors or big financial institutions.
First City Bancorp of Texas, headed by A. Robert Abboud, plunged 2 3/4 in heavy trading, to 5 7/8, after hitting a new low of 4 7/8. It reported a third-quarter loss of $101.9 million.
Sallie Mae, the second-most-active Big Board stock, fell 3/4, to 35 3/4, with 4 million shares changing hands and the stock hitting a new low of 33 1/2. It rejected loan-fraud allegations in Kansas as ''without merit.''
 
Rockefeller Center Surges
Rockefeller Center Properties rose 1 3/4, to 17 1/8, after The Wall Street Journal reported that David Rockefeller had more than doubled his investment in the real estate trust.
General Electric, which fell 2 7/8 Tuesday after a 9 percent rise in profits, bounced back 1 1/8, to 52 5/8.
Household International fell 2 3/8, to 21, and Georgia-Pacific 2, to 26, after a new low of 25 3/8.
MCI headed the Nasdaq list, down 1 1/8, to 29 5/8, on 5.8 million shares after reporting a loss of $168 million.
In a strong high-tech group, Apple Computer rose 1 1/2, to 26 1/2; Microsoft 1 7/8, to 56 1/2; Sun Microsystems 2 1/8, to 21 1/2, and AST 1 1/2, to 16 1/2. Intel rose 1, to 32; Novell 1 3/8, to 20 7/8, and Quantum 1 3/8, to 14 1/2. I.B.M. rose 1 3/8, to 100 3/4, in heavy trading.
 
Tokyo Stocks Rise as Dollar Falls
TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 18 (Reuters) - Japanese stock prices rose today as the dollar continued to plunge against the yen.
The Nikkei index of 225 stocks gained 507.72 points, or 2.13 percent, to close at 24,367.08.
The dollar lost more than one yen today on active selling by banks. It was also lower against most other leading currencies.
At midday in Tokyo, the dollar was quoted at 124.25 yen, down from Wednesday's close of 125.43 yen in New York. Earlier Wednesday in Tokyo, the dollar fell more than two yen to close at 125.80 yen.
''Nobody expected the dollar to fall through 124.70 yen so fast in Tokyo today,'' one dealer said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Little Changed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as dealers wrestled with a number of conflicting developments.
A drop in oil prices, a stable dollar and the continued push in Washington to adopt a Federal budget were all seen as positives by market participants.
At the same time, however, economic data released yesterday, particularly an increase of two-tenths of a percent in industrial production in September, were somewhat stronger than anticipated. Most analysts had been expecting the factory output numbers to show a slight decline. 
''It's kind of a mixed bag,'' a government bond trader said. ''In the past few days there has been a bit of a pickup in demand for bonds, but for the most part everybody is sitting around waiting for something to happen in Washington or the Middle East.''
Investor uncertainty may be the least of the problems.
 
Toll on Economy Seen
In a luncheon meeting with clients yesterday, Anthony J. Vignola, chief economist at Kidder, Peabody & Company, suggested that the lengthy process of groping for solutions to the Kuwait and budget problems was probably taking a toll on the economy.
''Dithering over the budget is doing as much to undermine consumer confidence as the Middle East,'' he said. ''And the longer the status quo continues, the worse the economic outlook becomes.''
In a revised forecast, Mr. Vignola said the economy had slipped into a mild recession that will run through the middle of 1991. The risk, he added, is that the downturn ''will be longer and deeper'' than the firm expects.
On the assumption that a budget and an increase in the Federal debt ceiling will be passed in time, the Treasury said yesterday that it would auction a record $12 billion of new two-year notes on Oct. 24.
While that auction may take place on schedule, analysts said the prospects were dim that today's sale of one-year Treasury bills would be held.
Market participants today will probably get fresh evidence that inflationary pressures continued in September.
Most economists are projecting that the Consumer Price Index, which is expected to be released this morning, jumped seven-tenths to eight-tenths of a percent in September, pushed by last month's big increase in oil prices. The index rose by eight-tenths of a percent in August.
 
'Expecting Bad News'
Given the market's current state of paralysis, some analysts said that reaction to a bad inflation number could well be slight.
''I really wonder if the numbers will be that important, because everybody is expecting bad news,'' said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Ramirez Capital Consultants. ''I don't think the consumer price numbers will tell us anything we didn't already know about inflation.''
Traders did not make much of an effort yesterday to prepare for the consumer price statistics by selling bonds, the securities which are generally most sensitive to evidence of worsening inflation.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 98 5/8, up 3/32, to yield 8.88 percent. Late Tuesday the issue was offered at the same yield.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 2/32, unchanged from late Tuesday, to yield 8.73 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 13/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.89 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged to up slightly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.18 percent, up 3 basis points, or hundredths of a point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged at 7.19 percent. And one-year bill rates rose by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.10 percent.
 
Corporate Offering
In the corporate bond market, a unit of the First Chicago Corporation offered $800 million of securities backed by credit-card receivables through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 9 percent notes, which have an expected maturity date of April 15, 1993, were priced at $99.625 to yield 9.18 percent, 1.10 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent three-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of some bank debt issues, including Citibank, came under selling pressure yesterday. Aside from bank issues, prices of most other securities were little changed on the day, the traders said.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, participants said that prices of most actively quoted issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point in slow trading.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Plunges Against Yen; Gold Prices Move Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen yesterday and finished mixed against other leading currencies in busy trading.
Gold prices moved higher after tumbling more than $25 an ounce earlier this week. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery fetched $366.70 an ounce, up $4.70 from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid of $366.10 an ounce, up $2.10. 
But much attention focused on the Japanese yen, which rose significantly against the dollar. Traders said Japanese portfolio managers were bringing their money home to try to support a weakening stock market and banks that had experienced declines in their capital ratios.
''People expect the Ministry of Finance to keep yen interest rates fairly high,'' which attracts investors to Japan, said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York.
In addition, there is the belief that ''U.S. and Japanese officials have agreed to an orderly dollar decline, and they have been tolerating it,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.
The dollar fell sharply in Tokyo, settling at 125.80 yen, down from 128.05 yen on Tuesday. Later in London, it fell further, to 124.85 yen. In New York, the dollar closed off its lows at 125.43 yen but was still down from 126.79 yen on Tuesday.
Traders said a Government report showing a better-than-expected rise of two-tenths of 1 percent in United States industrial production in September helped halt the dollar's slide, even though a 7.5 percent spurt in automobile production masked overall weakness in manufacturing.
The report hinted that the Federal Reserve might have less room to ease interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to support the dollar by making dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.9650, from $1.9575 late on Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.9615 to buy a pound, less expensive than $1.9655 on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late Tuesday, included: 1.5125 German marks, up from 1.5115; 1.2720 Swiss francs, down from 1.2770; 5.0680 French francs, up from 5.0660; 1,132.50 Italian lire, down from 1,132.75, and 1.1683 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1564.
In London, gold rose to a late bid price of $366.50 an ounce, from $364.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $366.20, from $362. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 8.52 cents to close at a bid $367.81.
On the New York Comex, silver prices also rose, with the contract for current delivery settling at $4.198 an ounce.

HEADLINE: He Took The Journal in New Directions

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Slim, dapper and understated, Warren H. Phillips presided for 33 years over a sharp expansion of both The Wall Street Journal and its parent, Dow Jones & Company, while insisting that the company remain true to the principles with which the newspaper was founded 101 years ago.
He became managing editor of The Journal in 1957, executive editor of Dow Jones publications in 1965, and then chief executive of Dow Jones in 1975. In all these positions, he insisted that timeliness, reliability, independence and journalistic fairness should remain the hallmarks of a company started in 1882 by Charles H. Dow and Edward D. Jones as a hand-delivered financial-news-bulletin service. 
In an indication of his temperament, Mr. Phillips aggressively espoused new technology, like the use of satellites to send page images, and consistently pushed the company into new ventures, while at the same time preserving a vintage Royal manual typewriter at his desk - a reminder of the roots of The Journal's enterprise and his own days as a foreign correspondent from 1949 to 1951 in Germany, Britain and elsewhere.
When he became managing editor at the age of 30, The Journal's circulation was just over 500,000 and it was the ninth-largest paper in the United States. Today, it is the country's leading paper, with a circulation of just under two million. Dow Jones's annual revenue was $238 million when he became chief executive 15 years ago; last year it was $1.7 billion. Net income increased more than five fold in the 1980's, and Dow Jones was transformed into a global media company.
Mr. Phillips, who was often seen in the newsroom, was also able to step back from day-to-day events, taking the company in new directions. He seemed to take as a precept the words in The Journal's first issue of 1889: ''We appreciate the confidence reposed in our work. We mean to make it better.'' During the 1970's, Dow Jones acquired a chain of small-town dailies (Ottaway Newspapers Inc.), a book company (Richard D. Irwin), and established its first overseas edition, the Hong Kong-based Asian Wall Street Journal. During the 1980's, it started a European edition based in Brussels, and completed the $1.6 billion purchase of Telerate, a global purveyor of financial information.
 
Move Questioned
At a time of sharp economic downturn, during which Telerate's performance has suffered and its purchase price appears high, this acquisition is being questioned by some.
The Journal was consistently updated, evolving into a three-section newspaper that went well beyond its original mission of covering just business and finance.
Mr. Phillips, who was the son of a New York garment worker and left high school at 15 before later completing an economics degree, had a broad view of what could be useful or interesting to the business community. This was reflected in a wide range of pieces. A quirky unpredictability, combined with writing that was snappy while never vulgar, became a characteristic of The Journal.
The paper added coverage of personal finance, technology, marketing and law. It started a Leisure & Arts page. To save time for readers, it introduced indexes and graphics. And it vastly expanded international coverage.
Through all these changes, The Journal's message on the editorial page remained broadly unchanged. As summed up last year in a statement, by Mr. Phillips and the new chief executive, Peter R. Kann, this was: ''Less regulation, more entrepreneurship, lower taxes, freer trade, stronger military defense, more confidence again in America's ability to lead the free world.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
THE SENATE PASSES A BUDGET ACCORD BY 54-TO-46 VOTE

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct. 19

 BODY:
With bipartisan support, the Senate approved a comprehensive budget package early this morning that would raise the taxes or cut the benefits of nearly all Americans.
The bill, passed by a vote of 54 to 46 at about 1:30 this morning, was sent to a conference committee and a final confrontation between the White House and Congress over who will pay for deficit reduction.
Senior senators and representatives immediately started preliminary talks to work out the many differences between the Senate measure and the one Democrats rammed through the House of Representatives on party-line votes Tuesday.
 
Another Midnight Deadline
It is unlikely that the conference committee will finish its work by midnight tonight, when the Government's authority to spend money expires. But Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Bush would be willing to sign an extension of appropriations through the middle of next week if the conferees seemed to be making ''satisfactory progress.'' 
That reversed the position the President took in campaign stops this week. Then, he said he was prepared to close down the Government again if Congress did not meet the deadline. Two weekends ago, Mr. Bush suspended most Government services for three days to keep pressure on Congress.
The House approved stopgap legislation tonight that would continue the Government's spending authority through Oct. 24, and the Senate, which recessed soon after the vote on the budget measure, is expected to follow suit on the stopgap legislation later today.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, have no vote in the conference. But they will be central figures when the negotiations get tricky over the next few days, looking over the lawmakers' shoulders at every turn.
 
Tax Bite on the Wealthy
The House bill, which President Bush has insisted he would veto, would raise the income taxes of nearly all Americans, but place the brunt of the new tax bite on the wealthy.
The Senate bill, which the President said he would support Thursday, would not affect the income taxes for most people, but would hit the middle class by more than doubling the Federal gasoline tax and by cutting Medicare benefits.
Senate leaders of both parties managed over two days to beat back several amendments that would have made the moderate Senate bill more like the liberal House version.
Both versions are supposed to cut the Federal deficit, now about $300 billion, by $40 billion this year and $500 billion over five years through a range of tax increases and spending reductions.
Even before the first meeting of the conferees, lawmakers were angling for position Thursday and reaching for compromises.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee and a member in the conference, said at a meeting of about 50 Democratic leaders that they should be prepared for substantial compromises to reach an outcome that could pass the more conservative Senate and that could be signed by the President.
 
Most Favored Compromise
According to people who were at this meeting of the Democratic whip organization, some firebrands argued that the conferees should adopt a bill that would invite a Presidential veto and force Mr. Bush to defend it two weeks before the Congressional elections. But that was said to be the minority view, and most of the Democrats favored striving for a good compromise.
Speaking to a group of White House interns, Mr. Bush said that the ''soak the rich'' oratory of Democrats in the House and many in the Senate was a ''smoke screen to try to hide their effort to raise the income taxes of ordinary working Americans.''
Mr. Bush said he opposed the House bill, ''not because I want to help the rich, but because I want to help everyone.''
The House bill would suspend for one year the adjustment of tax brackets and personal exemptions for inflation in a step that would cost a few hundred dollars a year in extra taxes for middle-income taxpayers. But by raising the top tax rate, increasing the alternative minimum tax and levying a surtax on millionaires, the House bill would result in a cost to the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers - those with incomes of more than $200,000 - of about $11,000 a year in additional taxes.
A study by the nonpartisan staff of the Congressional Joint Tax Committee shows that the House bill would increase the taxes of those with incomes of more than $200,000 by 7.4 percent, compared with 3.7 percent under the Senate bill. The taxes of households with incomes between $20,000 and $40,000 would be raised 1 percent under the House bill and 2.7 percent under the Senate bill.
Just as Mr. Rostenkowski was preparing his troops for a compromise, so was Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader.
 
'The Best We Can'
Arguing on the Senate floor Thursday against several Democratic amendments that would have made the Senate bill more like the House version, Mr. Mitchell said he, too, favored higher tax rates and a larger burden on the wealthy and hoped that would be the outcome of the conference.
''We can't guarantee a result in conference, but we're going to do the best we can,'' Mr. Mitchell told the Senate.
But the majority leader went on to say, ''We must recognize what the realities are,'' specifically that the President vowed to veto a final measure that would raise the top tax rate to 33 percent from 28 percent.
''I don't agree with the President,'' Mr. Mitchell said. ''I think he's wrong. But that is the reality.'' The most prominent of the amendments rejected by the Senate Thursday was offered by Senator Al Gore, a Democrat from Tennessee. Defeated on a procedural vote of 55 to 45, it would have raised taxes on the rich and used the revenue to limit the increase in the gasoline tax and reduce cuts in Medicare benefits.
 
A Big Amendment's Fate
Thirty-seven Democrats and eight Republicans voted for Mr. Gore's amendment; 18 Democrats and 37 Republicans voted against it.
Senate leaders of both parties promised last week that they would work to defeat all amendments, and they did so. Had they not made such a pledge, the bill would have died in the Finance Committee.
The toughest challenges to their compact probably came late Wednesday night. One amendment then was similar to Mr. Gore's. Another would simply have scrapped the part of the bill that would raise the gasoline tax. Both were defeated handily. These are among the main elements of the Senate bill:
* An increase in the Federal gasoline tax to 18.5 cents in 1992 from 9 cents now.
* A doubling of the annual Medicare deductible, to $150 from $75. The monthly Medicare premiums the elderly pay for insurance against doctors' bills, now $28.60, would rise each year as medical costs increase.
* An increase to $89,000 from $51,300 in the amount of wages subject to the 1.45 percent payroll tax for Medicare.
* A 10 percent luxury tax on automobiles costing more than $30,000, boats costing more than $100,000, private planes costing more than $250,000, and furs and jewelry costing more than $5,000.
* Tax breaks totaling $3.5 billion over five years to encourage oil and gas production. They would not become effective unless the price of oil, now more than $40 a barrel, falls below $34.
* A limit on itemized deductions for affluent taxpayers. Those taxpayers' deductions would be reduced by 5 percent of the amount of their adjusted gross income above $100,000.
* Requirements that all state and local employees pay Medicare taxes and that those not in a public employee retirement system pay Social Security taxes.
* Higher taxes on alcoholic beverages and tobacco.
* A $15 billion cut in agriculture programs.
* An expansion of tax credits for poor workers.
The measure also would impose a variety of user fees for Government services, including a charge for commercial use of data from the National Weather Service.

LENGTH: 2372 words

HEADLINE: Viewing Chaos in the Capital, Americans Express Outrage

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 17

 BODY:
What will happen when Don Campbell, a 67-year-old farmer from Williamsville, Ill., enters the voting both in November?
''It's sad,'' he said, as he sat atop a roaring tractor waiting to dump a trailer load of soybeans at the farmers co-op, ''but I feel like going in there and just voting against every incumbent on the list.''
Though Williamsville is tiny, Mr. Campbell's is not a voice in the wilderness. In a 1,200-mile journey by automobile from Houston to Chicago, conversations with nearly 100 people from all walks of life found that the budget battle in Washington has awakened powerful anxieties and discontent.
The budget stalemate, many people said, is merely indicative of far greater problems. They expressed a foreboding about the economy, worries and impatience over the Middle East crisis and, most of all, a bitter disillusionment with political leadership at all levels. Still, news of the impasse in the nation's capital, like a magnifying glass that intensifies sunlight into one burning spot, is focusing people's emotions. 
 
Life Does Go On
''I don't try to keep up with what they're doing in Washington anymore,'' said Joseph Lewis Tucker, 69, as he tended the roadside stand where he sells produce near Henning, Tenn. ''There's not a thing I or anyone else can do about it.''
The anger is not so intense that it disrupts the rituals and joys of daily life. Last weekend there were celebrations for the birth of a calf to Daisy the cow in the petting zoo at the Piney Woods Fair in Lufkin, Tex. Convention-goers filled the lobby bar at the Peabody Hotel in Memphis with chatter and laughter. And the flag was saluted at hundreds of high school football games.
But the mere mention of the budget impasse can ignite uncommon rage. For instance, Jerry Barber greeted customers at her bookstore in Texarkana, Tex., with friendly grace, but when asked whether she was following the news on the budget, she responded sharply: ''I sure am paying attention, because I know they can damn well cut that budget. I'll be perfectly willing to listen to talk about raising taxes, but not until they cut back, and I'm watching them.''
Like many people, Ms. Barber, who is 53 years old, seemed almost entirely preoccupied with the tax proposals without paying much attention to the spending cuts under consideration. Except for the proposed gasoline tax, people generally do not mention any of the specific measures being debated, although there is a vague sense that the taxing of the rich is at issue. Nor did anyone offer specific suggestions of their own on how the budget deficit should be reduced.
No one person, event or institution was singled out to bear the blame. President Bush was criticized not so much for his role in the budget debate as for his failure to justify the reversal of his ''read my lips'' campaign pledge not to raise taxes.
''I am a solid Bush supporter,'' said Mark Wilcox, 54, a marketing executive from Kennebunk, Me., who was in St. Louis on Monday for a business meeting. ''But I think he's really hurt himself because he didn't come out at the beginning and deal with the people honestly and say: 'I made a mistake. There will have to be tax increases.' ''
Other people encountered during a five-day journey through a slice of America's midsection voiced similar feelings.
 
Houston
 
In Bush Country, Sense of Betrayal
In Houston's affluent Memorial neighborhood, which George Bush once represented in Congress, the wives of lawyers, oil-company executives and other professionals gather each morning in the parking lot of the Pines Presbyterian Pre-School to chat after they have dropped off their children.
Talking to two friends across the hood of a station wagon, Denise Kleypas, 32, said: ''I think what's going in Washington is so frustrating. On the one hand, you have these politicians saying that they are doing what the people want, but all that means is that each one of them is trying to get their piece of the pie, their own little programs so they can get re-elected. No one wants to make the really tough decisions.
''Increased taxes are going to be necessary, that's obvious. But Mr. Bush did say he was not going to raise taxes. He said that a lot. So now what does it mean to vote for him or anybody else? It makes you think we need a real shakeup in the whole system.''
A woman who would identify herself only as Laura P. because ''my husband is an attorney and he wouldn't like the publicity,'' said: ''We're barely making it with the taxes we have to pay now, and so it's real aggravating not to know when the tax increases are going to stop. What gives them the right anyway to raise taxes when we don't have any say in how it is spent?''
Another woman who declined to give her name, interjected: ''I saw a lady the other day buying beer and potato chips with food stamps, and then she drove away from the market in a $25,000 car. It wouldn't bother me so much what they were spending if I thought they were halfway careful about how they spent it.''
She added, ''I don't blame Bush or Congress more than the other. I think the blame is on everyone who let it get to this point, including we the people who have allowed the politicians to run our lives.''
 
Jefferson, Tex.
 
Yellow Ribbons, Fading Spirits
Train whistles hooted in the distance, and the sweetly fetid smell of Big Cypress Bayou blew in on the evening breeze as the Jefferson High School band gave a stumbling rendition of ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' The missed notes did nothing to diminish the cheers that marked the start of a Friday night football game in Jefferson, Tex.
For many youngsters like those at the game, joining the armed forces has traditionally been the fastest way out of East Texas poverty, and yellow ribbons adorn many homes and storefronts in remembrance of Jefferson people who are now in the Middle East.
Military service took on a new meaning this summer. ''All of a sudden, signing up doesn't just mean a paycheck and job training,'' said John Wright, a 42-year-old speech teacher who was collecting tickets at the gate of the football field.
He added: ''Everybody thought going to fight Iraq was going to be another quick-and-dirty, like Panama or Grenada. That was great. Now it's sinking in that they might go play in the sand dunes, and no one is really interested in signing up to fight a war.''
 
'Wish They'd Hurry Up'
Bo Byrd, an 18-year-old junior who has a cousin and four friends serving in the operation, has long planned to enlist. ''I think if we just go fight this war we went over there to fight, we wouldn't be having the problem we have now of those men sitting in the desert for no reason,'' he said.
Tugging on the brim of his camouflage hat, he said, ''I wish they'd hurry up and do something, because a couple of more months and there's going to be no sense to it.''
Kenneth R. Carver, 67, retired to Jefferson after 37 years in the Air Force. Wearing an old flight jacket and waiting for the game to begin, he too was worried: ''If it continues on as the status quo, you are going to see the support break up both here and around the world. It will become a political problem, and that's bad.''
The budget impasse, he said, ''is just making things worse because it's draining away people's faith in the Government just when we may need every bit of it for this crisis overseas.''
Asked if he had a solution for the budget problem, Mr. Carver thought for a moment and then said gravely, ''What I'd like to see, and I know it can't happen, is for every single member of Congress to get kicked out so we could start with a whole new group.''
 
Arkadelphia, Ark.
 
Sick of Hearing The Politicians
Arkadelphia, Ark., population 9,150, is a little more prosperous than many of the farming towns in the Southern Arkansas clay country because it is home to two universities and a little manufacturing.
Ruben Fendley's two-chair barbershop sits in a shaded neighborhood of old clapboard houses. It is a busy place on a Saturday afternoon. A small, neatly groomed man of 58, Mr. Fendley is dismayed.
''No one has bothered to explain what this budget thing is all about,'' he said. ''Basically, all you hear is the Republicans blaming the Democrats and the Democrats blaming the Republicans.''
Jimmy White, a 57-year-old machine tool operator who was getting his hair cut, broke in. ''Heck, all they want is more money to spend around so they can get themselves re-elected, and that's all it is.''
Asked if there were any politicians that any of those present admired, Mr. White replied, ''The last one I liked was Everett Dirksen,'' the Illinois Republican Senator who died in 1969. Mr. Fendley said, ''I can't think of any of them I've liked recently, because I've never admired a man who is not doing 100 percent of what he's supposed to be doing, and none of them are.''
Laws that would limit terms of office might help, the barber said, because then ''they'd know they were going back into the rat race, and that'd keep them in touch with real life.''
 
Memphis
 
Problems Persist, Gnawing at Hope
In Memphis, the Foote Homes, a public housing project built in the 1950's, is about a mile from where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in 1968. On a balmy Sunday morning, Fred Butler and some of his friends, all of them black, gathered on a sidewalk to talk about how a bad situation for black Americans was getting worse despite the opening of some major opportunities since the days of the civil rights struggle.
Mr. Butler, 50, who prefers to be known as Fast Freddie, complained that ''they're coming around saying the Government needs more money, but then they send all that money to fight a war over yonder when the main thing is, they should have solved all the problems around here first. It's just like Vietnam.'' Vernon Yancey, a 33-year-old truck driver, said: ''I don't see how they can be hurting for money when the rich are doing so good. Everyone else is just hanging on, especially the black people, and they are the ones who get hit when the Government says it's got money problems. Look at the gas. They raise the prices. They raise the taxes. Who gets hit? It's the poor folks. The rich don't even know what gas costs.''
Sitting in a metal folding chair, Mr. Butler acted as something of a moderator during a long conversation that others drifted in and out of. At one point he said, ''Let's admit it, black people are having more things than anytime else.''
''Yeah,'' agreed Ollie Boxley, who is 35 and works with Mr. Yancey, ''kids today have all kinds of opportunities we didn't have when we were coming up.''
''And they don't want it,'' Mr. Yancey said. ''They don't want to go to school. They're too happy on the street.''
After a moment, he spoke up again. ''You hear some people blaming the poor folks for getting too much Government money, and so they say, 'Cut the programs.' That's not right, because the seniors don't get too much; the women going crazy trying to raise kids without a man, they don't get too much; a lot of people who need a place to stay don't get anything. Who's to blame when they get cut?''
 
Cape Girardeau, Mo.
 
Insecure Feelings Transcend Taxes
Around Cape Girardeau, Mo., the major worry is a widely publicized prediction that in early December an earthquake will strike along the New Madrid fault, which runs through the area. Worries over the economy are far more diffuse, yet many in the Sunday afternoon crowd at the West Park Mall, a big suburban retail center, said they were looking more than buying.
''The last several years have been such a good time economically that people feel they'll have to ride out whatever's coming by tightening up a bit and making do,'' said Lou Ann Hopkins, 36.
Her husband, Mark, 35, who works in the management of a tobacco company, said, ''I guess we've cut down some purchases recently because you have to wonder how it will be if we get a recession with all these tax increases on top of it.''
Lil Reynolds, a 51-year-old bank teller, had stopped by her favorite dress shop to check out a sale. ''I've noticed people are opening savings accounts, putting away money, paying off consumer loans, those sorts of things, because they are starting to get scared that the economy's going sour,'' she said.
She added: ''I think everyone is blaming the Government right now because of the budget. They spend so much money they don't have to spend that I'm upset, too, and I'm upset about what it's doing to the country.''
Added Diane Huntze, a sales clerk, ''Yeah, but they won't give up their spending ways.''
 
Chicago
 
In the Middle, Feeling Left Out
The intersection of Cicero and Milwaukee Avenues on Chicago's Northwest Side is at the center of an old but seemingly vibrant working-class neighborhood. But inside one of the many new commercial establishments, the Seven Cousins sandwich shop, recently opened by two sisters, Marge Sergo and Karen LaPalermo, there is gloom.
''We both work other jobs,'' Mrs. LaPalermo said. ''We're doing this because it takes a family not two incomes anymore, but three or four to make ends meet.''
As the two put Halloween decorations on the walls of their little restaurant, Mrs. Sergo complained: ''As usual, Washington is not going to be much help. The Government doesn't do a thing for the middle man. The poor get welfare, and the rich get loopholes. Meanwhile, the middle man is going to disappear.''
Mrs. LaPalermo added: ''What I can't believe is that they were talking about cutting the benefits to the old people, They got to live on almost nothing as it is.''
Mrs. Sergo had a theory: ''I like some of what President Bush has done, but let's face it: he comes from money, and he lives with money, and the Republicans are always good at protecting the rich and cutting Social Security and other stuff that helps hard-working people.''
''To me,'' said Mrs. LaPalermo, ''neither side does anything for you, so it doesn't matter how you vote. We're worried about where the country's going, but we can't change anything, not anything. It's scary. It's not supposed to be this way.''

HEADLINE: ASSAILING BEIJING, HOUSE VOTES A RISE IN CHINA'S TARIFFS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Protesting the continued restrictions on political dissent in China, the House of Representatives voted today to raise tariffs on billions of dollars of Chinese apparel, toys and other exports to this country and to set tougher conditions for tariff breaks for China next year.
But the votes may have been largely symbolic, since it is not certain the Senate - in the midst of a pre-election session largely focused on budget matters -will have time to pass comparable measures.
Should the Senate also act, the President has promised a veto that many analysts believe could not be overturned. The Administration has argued that it would be unwise to punish China when it has cooperated with the United States at the United Nations Security Council on every resolution adopted since early August against Iraq. 
 
Resolution on Tariffs
The House approved a resolution rescinding a Presidential decision last May to continue most-favored-nation treatment for China, under which tariffs are cut to the lowest possible level. The vote was 247 to 174, well short of the two thirds majority needed to override a veto.
Citing a report that at least 1,000 pro-democracy Chinese students are still in prison 16 months after the Beijing Government's crackdown in Tiananmen Square, Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of upstate New York, chief sponsor of the resolution, said: ''We have just sent China a message that we haven't forgotten.''
Zhao Haiching, chairman of the National Committee on Chinese Student Affairs, one of the units in a federation representing 42,000 Chinese students in the United States, called the action a ''big victory,'' but cautioned that ''only if both Houses act can it really put pressure on the Chinese Government.''
 
A Presidential Certification
The House did approve a softer measure, chiefly sponsored by Representative Donald J. Pease, Democrat of Ohio, that approves the lower tariff status for this year but sets stiffened human rights conditions for maintaining the favored position next year. The vote was 384 to 30.
It also approved an amendment from Representative Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, stipulatingthat one condition of continued favored status would be Presidential certification that all prisoners detained after the Tiananmen Square incident had been released. The vote on the amendment was 347 to 74.
The Senate Majority Leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, has introduced a similar bill, ending the tariff breaks in three months if the President cannot certify that the prisoner release and other human rights conditions have been met.
 
Tax and Budget Issues
This legislation, however, has not been taken up by the Senate Finance Committee, which has jurisdiction. Its chairman, Lloyd Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, is immersed in the tax and budget imbroglio.
Although Congress took the lead in getting the United States to mete out economic punishment to China after the June 1989 crackdown, many analysts say there has been less interest in the issue since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last August.
Beijing's support of the American position in the gulf crisis has helped its case on Capitol Hill. It has supported all eight United Nations Security Council resolutions on the situation and acted to enforce the United Nations-approved trade embargo.
In other steps to improve ties with Washington, the Chinese authorities have released almost 900 political prisoners this year. And, after President Bush's action last June to renew China's favorable trade status, they have permitted the dissident Fang Lizhi and his family to leave the country.
 
Political Conduct a Factor
Many analysts noted that whatever happens to the trade legislation, this year's legislative debate has underscored the importance of China's political conduct as a critical factor in its trading relationship with the United States.
''I have told my Chinese friends that regardless of the legislation, the political reality here is such that the renewal of M.F.N. is conditional, and that if Beijing falls away from us, it will not get M.F.N. next year,'' said Roger W. Sullivan, director of the U.S.-China Business Council, representing 250 American companies doing business in China.
The United States became China's primary export market last year. Although China buys wheat, high technology products and machinery and other capital goods from the United States, its sales of textiles and other products are earning it huge surpluses in trade with this country.
For the first eight months of this year China's surplus was $6.3 billion, almost twice the $3.3 billion over the same period last year. Withdrawal of most-favored-nation status. would mean tariff hikes that could cut off its markets here and probably lead to retaliation.
 
Warning From White House
The White House and its supporters on Capitol Hill warned that the higher tariffs would hurt American business and consumers, damage the Hong Kong economy, which is heavily dependent on China trade, and reduce American influence with China on global issues.
''Instead of the open door policy, we would have the bolted door policy,'' said Representative Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, during the House debate.
Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's Trade Subcommittee added: ''I am not willing to sacrifice the interests of American farmers, businessmen and workers in a hollow show of outrage.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: EL SALVADOR (93%); SOUTH AFRICA (92%); UNITED STATES (92%); AFRICA (91%);

HEADLINE: TWO KOREAS AGREE TO FURTHER TALKS

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Senior negotiators from North and South Korea said today that they had again failed to reach agreement on any steps to reduce mutual tensions, but that there was reason to hope that an accord could be worked out in the future.
The two sides said they would try again to discuss ways to narrow their differences in another set of negotiations on Dec. 11-14 in Seoul. Reports from Seoul, moreover, indicated tonight that the session today was more civil and cordial than the one on Wednesday.
The second round of talks between delegations led by the Prime Ministers of the two countries ended at noon in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, followed by the first meeting between an official from Seoul and the 78-year-old North Korean leader, Kim Il Sung. 
Mr. Kim was quoted by Korean news agencies as telling Prime Minister Kang Young Hoon of South Korea that ''the fact that the high-level meeting was held marks a bright prospect for our nation's future.''
 
Called Significant Move
It was also taken as significant that he used the title Prime Minister for Mr. Kang, something North Korean delegates in the talks had not done, apparently as part of Pyongyang's general questioning of legitimacy of the South Korean Government.
South Korean officials said it was highly significant that Mr. Kim, one of the world's last remaining Communist dictators, lent his personal prestige. ''It was a sign of progress that Kim personally played a role in reinforcing our efforts,'' one official said.
On the other hand, Mr. Kim's response to South Korea's request for a future meeting with President Roh Tae Woo was seen as ambiguous. Mr. Kim said he accepted the idea in principle, but only at an appropriate time, presumably after South Korea accepts the North's conditions.
As officials discussed the talks, 11 young South Koreans armed with firebombs and other weapons were arrested early this morning as they tried to climb the rear wall of the American Embassy in Seoul. There were no injuries or physical damage.
 
A Delicate Atmosphere
The incident nonetheless scored the delicate atmosphere in South Korea, since dissident student radicals are still carrying out anti-American campaigns, adopting the North Korean line that the United States is the source of South Korea's problems.
The accounts of the meetings in Pyongyang that reached Seoul tonight were a little confused and fragmentary. North Korea allowed only about 40 South Korean journalists in to cover the talks, and only a handful of reporters from Western news organizations.
The agitation of student radicals is one of several political problems facing President Roh, who has made no secret of his desire to have a meeting with Mr. Kim of North Korea to help his own political standing. But such a meeting is still seen as unlikely.
As they had in the past, the two sides bogged down on South Korea's insistence that two countries reduce tensions first by cultural, social, family and economic exchanges and later tackle difficult matters like troop levels and pledges of nonaggression.
 
Wants U.S. Troops Expelled
North Korea, on the other hand, continues to insist that South Korea agree immediately to steps in the military and political sphere, particularly to expelling the 43,000 American troops in South Korea. As a first step, Pyongyang wants Seoul to cancel military exercises with American troops.
These priorities were aired in the first round of talks between Prime Minister Kang of South Korea and Prime Minister Yon Kyong Muk of North Korea, in Seoul in early September. This time, the two sides came with specific proposals on priorities.
News reports reaching here said there was talk at the meeting today about combining the two sets of proposals, in effect agreeing to discuss military actions and cultural and humanitarian exchanges simultaneously.
A South Korean official said tonight that to the extent that there was progress in the meeting today, it seemed to be that both sides agreed that they could discuss each other's approaches all together the next time they meet. But he said it was far from clear that such talks would yield a common point of view.
 
Some Adjustments Seen
''The North tried to show us they were trying to make some adjustments,'' said Lee Hong Koo, a special adviser to President Roh who is monitoring the talks here. ''At least from my viewpoint, they are making some efforts to adjust, although there is no fundamental change of position.''
Mr. Lee said the tone of the discussions today was more muted, by contrast to the atmosphere of contention and accusation that occurred on Wednesday. He said North Korea seemed not to want to press its own point of view too aggressively after doing so on Wednesday.
For example, Pyongyang continues to demand that South Korea drop its effort to enter the United Nations by itself, cancel the military exercises with the United States next spring and free two anti-Government dissidents.
These demands were not dropped, but they were also not advanced as aggressively as they were in the past. Mr. Lee said that some South Koreans thought that the reason that North Korea wanted to put off the next round of talks until December was to allow time to see if Seoul responds.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Bush Says He Will Press Lenders To Widen Aid to Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Pledging to help Eastern European countries cope with the rising energy costs resulting from the Persian Gulf crisis, President Bush said today that he would work to arrange an additional $5 billion in international loans to those financially strapped nations.
In a welcoming ceremony at the White House for Prime Minister Jozsef Antall of Hungary, Mr. Bush said he would urge the International Monetary Fund to change its lending regulations so it could provide the extra money. Administration officials said that the revisions could include raising the limits on lending to Hungary, Poland, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania.
Mr. Bush said he would also ask the World Bank to speed lending to those countries by drawing on a $9 billion fund collected after the invasion of Kuwait to help countries deal with the economic consequences of the gulf crisis. 
''Like all of us, Hungary and the other new democracies of Central Europe are paying a high price for resolutely supporting the United Nations sanctions against Iraq,'' Mr. Bush said.
 
Helping Budapest Buy Grain
Mr. Bush also announced that the United States was offering Hungary $47.5 million in credits and loan guarantees that are intended to help the country buy 500,000 tons of feed grain to make up for the effects of a severe drought this year.
In addressing Mr. Antall, the first democratically elected Prime Minister of Hungary to visit the White House in more than four decades, the President was full of praise for the country's reform programs.
''Hungary is no longer an emerging democracy,'' Mr. Bush said. ''Hungary is a democracy.''
Mr. Antall, in turn, credited the United States with helping to make the ouster of hard-line Eastern European Governments possible in 1989. ''You have contributed to the emergence of reform politicians such as Mr. Gorbachev, who, by transforming the Soviet Union, helped bring about new opportunities of freedom for the peoples of East-Central Europe,'' Mr. Antall said.
Administration officials said Mr. Bush's meeting with Mr. Antall focused primarily on economic issues, although the two leaders also discussed the Persian Gulf crisis and the evolving security arrangements in Europe.
 
Offers a Medical Unit
Mr. Antall said after his meeting with the President that his country was seeking to send a military medical unit to Saudi Arabia to join the international force arrayed there against Iraq. He said that Budapest was discussing arrangements with the Saudi Government.
Curtis W. Kamman, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, quoted Mr. Antall as telling Mr. Bush that his country was suffering from the loss of low-priced Soviet oil supplies, as well as from the rise in energy costs that have resulted from the worldwide trade embargo against Iraq.
In remarks greeting Mr. Antall, Mr. Bush said, ''We understand that the loss of export markets and rising energy costs complicate your historic effort to transform a centrally planned economic system to a free economy.''
He added, ''And so to help ease this burden, I am announcing today that the United States is asking the International Monetary Fund to increase its lending to the countries of the region by as much as $5 billion.''
Mr. Bush said that would require that the fund start ''modifying its lending policies as appropriate,'' but Administration officials provided few substantive details on how that might be accomplished.
 
Raising the Ceilings
One way would be for the fund to raise the ceiling on how much Hungary and other Eastern European countries can borrow, Mr. Kamman said. The fund expects that it will have loaned some $2 billion to Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia by next year.
The fund is currently negotiating with Bulgaria, Romania and Czechoslovakia on the terms of loan programs. Mr. Kamman said the United States would urge the organization to accelerate those discussions.
The fund could also help Eastern Europe meet rising energy costs by including the cost of oil and other fuels in a program that is designed to help countries cope with external events that harm their economies. Energy costs are not normally included in that category.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS: ARAB LEAGUE REBUFFS P.L.O.; WON'T CONDEMN U.S.;
Iraq Offers Cheaper Oil

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, Oct. 18

 BODY:
In efforts to gain political ground by economic means, Iraq sought to beat one embargo today and the Arab League moved to enforce another.
In Damascus, an Arab League agency announced a boycott of ships and planes taking Soviet Jews to Israel, while in Baghdad, Iraq offered cheap oil at $21 a barrel. Economic experts said the Arab League boycott could prove hard to enforce, while the Iraqi offer would be virtually impossible for anyone to accept. 
Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, its oil exports have been severed by an international trade embargo that has closed pipelines across Turkey and Saudi Arabia and halted exports through the Persian Gulf.
The embargo is costing Iraq at least $80 million a day in lost exports, and oil prices have rocketed at times to $40 a barrel since the invasion. The benchmark price recorded by oil traders today was $34 a barrel.
The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored here, said Oil Minister Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalabi announced a decision by President Saddam Hussein today that ''Iraq is fully prepared to sell its oil to states and companies that want to buy, including the United States, and the selling price will be on the basis of $21 a barrel.'' That is the price set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at its last meeting before the invasion.
 
Few Takers Are Seen
Shipping executives in the gulf region said by telephone that they believed no one would take up the Iraqi offer because of the blockade. ''Who's going to send a tanker through 100 warships and risk it being impounded?'' said one executive, speaking on condition of anonymity. The executive recalled that even when Iraq offered free oil earlier in the crisis, no one tried to collect it.
In Damascus, meanwhile, The Arab League's Special Bureau for Boycotting Israel said today that ''airlines and shipping companies which transfer Jewish immigrants to Palestine and occupied Arab territories will be put on the blacklist.''
Arab diplomats here said the boycott was the first tangible step Arab states have taken to try to halt the immigrant flow from the Soviet Union to Israel since it gathered momentum a year ago.
Over 100,000 Soviet Jews have moved to Israel since Moscow relaxed emigration restrictions last year. The exodus has brought widespread fear among Arabs, particularly in the occupied West Bank and in neighboring Jordan, that the influx of Jews to Israel will ultimately displace Palestinians.
Most Soviet Jews have traveled by Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, to Cyprus and Eastern European destinations for flights to Tel Aviv, where Aeroflot does not yet have landing rights. The same East European airlines also fly to many Arab cities.

HEADLINE: Texas Urges Quick Action to Halt Honeybees

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESLACO, Tex., Oct. 18

 BODY:
Efforts to quarantine, search and destroy the Africanized honeybee are in full swing as state and Federal officials scramble to halt the newly arrived intruders' spread into the United States.
Gathered with Federal experts at the United States Department of Agriculture headquarters here, Texas officials warned today that prompt action to slow the bees' northward spread was essential to avoid quarantines in agricultural states that stand to lose millions from the infestation.
The first identified swarm of Africanized bees in the United States was trapped on Monday near Hidalgo, just north of the Mexican border. The bees were destroyed. 
Africanized bees have been heading north since escaping in 1957 from a Brazilian breeding experiment.
Nicknamed killer bees because of their extreme irritability and tendency to sting repeatedly in defense of their hives, the bees have been responsible for 16 deaths in Mexico alone over the past three years, researchers say. Hundreds of other deaths, as well as livestock losses, have been reported across Central and South America since 1957.
 
'Be Aware'
Dr. Anita Collins, a researcher with the Department of Agriculture who has experienced killer bee stings herself, advised: ''Be aware. Know your facts. Know what a honeybee looks like. Our best advice if you stumble into a stinging incident is to run. You can get away from them.''
But scientists emphasize that the chances of a fatal encounter with the bees are ''quite small.'' And agriculture officials insist that the real threat from the bees is to the multimillion-dollar honey and pollination industries of American beekeepers. When Africanized bees invade other hives, their aggressive characteristics dominate. The bees also are inefficient pollinators.
The bee industry says infiltration by Africanized bees has cut honey production in Central and South America by 60 to 70 percent. The bees could also devastate farmers in the United States who depend on honeybees to pollinate $9 billion in fruit and vegetable crops.
 
More Money Sought for Fight
Texas officials say they will ask for an additional $710,000 from the Texas Legislature for regulation, research and public education.
Newly trained inspectors have begun searching in a two-mile radius around the Hidalgo site, with orders to destroy any Africanized or wild bees found. Eight counties in south Texas are under quarantine, and surveyors are intensifying their inspections of a trap line that runs from Laredo to near Corpus Christi.
''If we don't do this, the economic impact will come with a quarantine from other states who perceive that we're not doing our job to halt the progress of the Africanized bees,'' said Dr. Fowden Maxwell, head of the Department of Entomology at Texas A&M University.
He said such a quarantine would be ''devastating'' to Texas beekeepers.
Bee experts say the arrival of cooler temperatures in the lower Rio Grande Valley could mean Monday's swarm is the last for this year.

HEADLINE: High Hopes of Defeating Simon Are Being Deflated

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 18

 BODY:
At a meeting a year ago, two of the biggest names in the Republican Party's stable of consultants, Robert Teeter and Roger Ailes, told Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois that if she could raise the money, she could unseat Senator Paul Simon, the avuncular incumbent whose liberalism seemed to make him an inviting target.
''It takes $8 million to win in a campaign in Illinois if you're not an incumbent,'' Mr. Ailes said this week.
But in the end, Ms. Martin will raise and spend only about $5 million. ''That's fallen short,'' her press secretary, Kathy Lydon, conceded. And with this shortfall, the high hopes Republicans had for this race, one of their top targets for 1990, are falling, too. 
Money is clearly not Ms. Martin's only problem, and her other problems have made it all the more difficult to persuade contributors to support her.
 
Impact of Budget Debacle
She opened the campaign with several missteps, including a reference to downstate voters as ''rednecks.'' Moreover, the constantly changing national agenda, and particulary President Bush's reversal on taxes, an issue at the heart of her campaign, has made it harder for Ms. Martin to gain a foothold.Even Republicans who have mounted stronger campaigns than that of Ms. Martin find themselves in trouble in these final weeks because of the damage that Mr. Bush's handling of the budget debacle has done to the party.
There is also the all-important matter of personality. If you are going to be an incumbent in this turbulent year, it is best to be like Paul Simon, the unpolitician, with his bow tie and ears sticking out from slicked-down hair. Ms. Martin has also run up against a problem that some other women seeking office have faced, a resistance from voters who find her grating. ''The Joan Rivers syndrome,'' is what David Axelrod, a Democratic consultant who used to work for Mr. Simon, calls it.
''It definitely is a problem,'' said Ms. Lydon. ''The people of Illinois have never elected a woman to statewide office.''
But while money is not her only problem, it is the one that prevents her from even making a fight on the other fronts now, less than three weeks from Election Day on Nov. 6. ''We're off the air,'' Mr. Ailes said succinctly, using consultant talk for a campaign that cannot buy television time.
 
Running Out of Money
The Martin campaign has less than a million dollars left and is conserving it for a last wave of television in the final week or 10 days.
In the meantime Mr. Simon, who raised more than $7 million and had $1.7 million in the bank as of Sept. 30, continued to buy television time for advertisements, including one that depicted Ms. Martin as an enemy of the elderly. ''Lynn Martin voted to cut Medicare three times,'' the advertisement said. ''Simon fought to protect Social Security. Lynn Martin voted to cut Social Security.''
The advertisement is the sort of distortion now routine in politics, using the word ''cut'' to mean keeping benefits from growing as quickly as they otherwise might have. And, as is standard, it does not mention votes by Mr. Simon on budget bills that might be interpreted the same way. ''Justice apparently cannot be done to this complex issue in 30 seconds,'' The Chicago Sun Times concluded.
But these are subtleties that few voters in the news markets of Illinois will hear about. ''If you don't have the money to counter the message, you're stuck with it,'' Ms. Lydon said. ''No matter how much the press does to say he's not really right on this, unless you have the money to put that on the air, you're not going to be able to reach all those people.''
Mr. Simon has stressed his roots at home. His advertisements call him ''Paul Simon of Illinois'' and one mentions that he has held 400 town meetings. But recent events, including the Persian Gulf crisis and the hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of David H. Souter, have also given Mr. Simon an opportunity to gain some publicity by showing him at work on Capitol Hill.
 
Desperate for Attention
Ms. Martin's campaign is so desperate for attention that Mr. Ailes, a lightning rod who many other clients try to keep under wraps, was brought into the state to say things about Mr. Simon that the campaign did not have money to buy advertisements to say. But Mr. Ailes got carried away, calling Mr. Simon a bunch of names like ''weenie'' and ''slimy.'' Ms. Martin had to apologize.
The exchange did little to accomplish Ms. Martin's goal of pointing out genuine differences between the two candidates. Indeed, the voters could hardly complain about a lack of choice in this race, if they tuned in to it.
During a debate on Sunday, Ms. Martin said Mr. Simon favored increased spending for every Federal program that had been mentioned. Mr. Simon rushed to correct her. He favored cuts in spending in one category, the military. Ms. Martin thanked him for pointing that out, since she did not. Ms. Martin stressed her desire to hold down taxes, while Mr. Simon emphasized his willingness to spend money on desirable goals, most particularly education.
The debate had been Ms. Martin's big opportunity to generate interest in her flagging race, which was probably why Mr. Simon's campaign shifted the date from Thursday evening, when an earlier gubernatorial debate had been widely watched, to Sunday afternoon. Mr. Simon said he could not leave Washington on Thursday and risk missing votes in the Senate, a concern Ms. Martin said he had not shown when he was running for President in 1988, a time she brings up often to suggest that Mr. Simon might again run for President.
''The only person in America who is talking about Paul Simon running for President is Lynn Martin,'' Mr. Simon said after Sunday's debate.
 
Firing Up the Campaign
The audience at the debate was a tiny fraction of the Illinois electorate, and Mr. Simon's calm demeanor prevented any clashes that might have produced the sort of follow-up by reporters that Ms. Martin needed to fire up the campaign.
An opinion poll of 866 registered voters for WBBM TV and The Southtown Daily Economist found Mr. Simon leading Ms. Martin by a ratio of 60 percent to 30 percent. Half the survey was completed before the Sunday afternoon debate, and half afterward, but there was no appreciable difference in the outcome, said Kathy Frankovic of CBS News, which conducted the survey for WBBM, an affiliate. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Wendy DeMocker, a spokeswoman for the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, noted that Republican challengers in past campaigns had been 30 points behind three weeks from Election Day only to win in upsets. ''We're not throwing in the towel,'' she said of the Illinois race. But she acknowledged that Ms. Martin was short of the money she had hoped to have.
So there is little left now for her to do but to talk about the lessons of her campaign. ''I've come to a conclusion we have to radically address our campaign finance system,'' she said. Ms. Martin noted that she had raised more money than any other Republican challenger to an incumbent Senator, although most of the others are running in much less expensive states.
''I've out-raised my opponent in my home state, which should be enough,'' she added, asserting that half Mr. Simon's money came from out of state.
''I've got an opponent who has raised more money in L.A. than in 101 counties of Illinois,'' said Ms. Martin. ''Thats off balance.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
A Budget Status Report

 BODY:

Proposals Almost Certain to Emerge From Congress
 
Cigarette Tax: Increase of 8 cents (4 cents in 1991, 4 cents in 1993), to 24 cents.
Alcohol Tax: An increase of 16 cents a six-pack, to 32 cents.
10 Percent Luxury Tax: Applies to purchase price above the following thresholds: cars, $30,000; boats, $100,000; jewelry, $5,000.
Aviation Fees: Increase in passenger ticket tax to 10 percent from 8 percent, plus increases in other fees. 
Insurance: Reduced tax breaks for insurance industry.
Social Security: State and local workers not covered by a government-sponsored retirement plan to pay into Social Security.
 
Proposals in Dispute And headed For Conference
 
Income Tax Rates: House bill would extend the 33 percent marginal tax rate to all high-income taxpayers, who now generally pay a flat rate of 28 percent. New rate would apply to all taxable income above $78,400 for those filing jointly. House would also increase alternative minimum tax to 25 percent, from 21 percent. Senate bill has no such provisions.
Millionaires: House bill would impose 10 percent surtax on all taxable income above $1 million. Senate bill has no such provision.
Indexing: House bill would freeze indexing for inflation of tax brackets and personal exemptions for one year. Senate bill has no such provision.
Deductions: Senate bill would reduce itemized deductions by 5 percent of the amount of adjusted gross income above $100,000. House has no such provision.
Gasoline: Senate bill would add 9.5 cents a gallon to the gasoline tax by Jan. 1, 1992, to a total of 18.5 cents. House bill would not raise gasoline taxes.
Alcohol: House would increase tax on a gallon of 100-proof alcohol by $1, to a total of $13.50; Senate proposes $1.20 increase. House would add 22 cents in taxes for a bottle of wine, to a total of 25 cents; the Senate proposes an increase of only 18 cents.
10 Percent Luxury Tax: House would impose tax on purchase of furs for the amount above $10,000; Senate threshhold is $5,000. House would impose tax on airplane purchase above $100,000, the Senate $250,000.
Medicare: Major differences between House and Senate bills. House would impose 1.45 percent Medicare tax on wages up to $100,000, from a cap of $51,300 currently. Senate would extend cap to $89,000. Senate would extend Medicare tax to state and local employees. House would not. House would increase Medicare deductibles and premiums on the elderly, requiring them to pay $10.1 billion in new payments over five years, and would impose $33 billion in new costs on Medicare providers. The Senate would raise Medicare costs to the elderly by $14.2 billion over five years and would raise providers' costs over the same period by $32 billion.
Energy Companies: To encourage oil exploration and drilling, Senate would provide $3.4 billion in tax breaks over five years for small companies. House has no such provisions.
Capital Gains: House would exclude 50 percent of capital gains, other than securities, from taxes up to a $200,000 lifetime limit. On the sale of securities, the House would also permit $1,000 in tax-free capital gains a year for those with taxable income under $100,000. The Senate bill has neither provision.
The Poor: The Senate bill would give a new tax credit totaling $16.8 billion over five years to help low-income workers pay for child care and to help offset higher excise taxes. The House would provide at least $11 billion for the five-year period and perhaps as much as $22 billion.
 
Proposals Eliminated From Consideration
 
Heating Oil: The budget summit proposal for a 2-cent-a-gallon gallon tax on refiners for fuel such as heating oil, gasoline and diesel fuel.
Unemployment Insurance: The budget summit proposal to delay payment of unemployment income for two weeks.
I.R.S.: The budget summit proposal to raise $9.4 billion by improving auditing and collection efforts.
Small Businesses: Most of the $12.1 billion in tax breaks for small businesses proposed by the summit negotiators.
