HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Six Men Wrestling With the Budget

 BODY:

Senator Lloyd Bentsen...Chairman, Senate Finance Committee...Texas Democrat... his main effort will be to get a bill out of conference that can be supported by both Republican and Democratic members of the Senate...he personally has no objection to higher tax rates, but would like to maintain tax breaks for oil and gas producers.
Senator Bob Packwood...Ranking Member, Senate Finance Committee...Oregon Republican...he is opposed to an increase in tax rates...as one of the prime sponsors of the 1986 tax reform legislation he is supportive of limiting deductions and closing loopholes for the wealthy...is concerned that if you raise taxes, you create pressure to open the gates for new tax shelters, credits and loopholes...opposed to the provision in the House plan that would delay the adjustments in tax rates for inflation.
Senator Jim Sasser...Chairman, Senate Budget Committee...Tennessee Democrat...personally opposed to gasoline and excise taxes, but recognizes that some sacrifices may have to be made if you are going to achieve real deficit reduction...President Bush has made it clear what he will and will not accept, so that has to be taken into account if there is going to be an acceptable package...is very concerned about increasing Medicare premiums but is happier with what is being offered now than what was in the original budget summit package. 
Senator Pete V. Domenici...Ranking Member, Senate Finance Committee...New Mexico Republican...wants to insure that whatever taxes are raised, they indeed go to deficit reduction and are not spent on new and wasteful programs...wants strict enforcement provisions in the final package to prevent Congress from later exceeding spending targets as has been done in the past...believes that to achieve economic growth and protect the economy, the conference needs to adopt a package closer to the Senate version.
Senator Dan Rostenkowski...Chairman, House Ways and Means Committee...Illinois Democrat...principal architect of the House budget plan that would make the wealthy bear most of the cost of deficit reduction, would limit Medicare cuts, and would not raise gasoline taxes...likely to dominate the House conferees.
Senator Leon E. Panetta...Chairman, House Budget Committee...California Democrat ...has straight-forward goals...conclude the conference as quickly as possible to avoid another government shutdown...make sure full deficit reduction is achieved...make sure final package is fair and that all groups including the wealthy are required to bear their share of the burden.

LENGTH: 1042 words

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE: IS THIS AN ERA'S END?;
The Anti-Tax Offensive of the 1980's Is Over, or So the Democrats Believe

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
As Congress moved toward completion of a budget package today, the Democrats who control both the Senate and the House of Representatives cast their bets that the Reagan era was really over.
For six long years, from the defeat of Walter F. Mondale in the 1984 Presidential election until only a few months ago, Democratic politicians were on the defensive on taxes. ''There they go again,'' Ronald Reagan and his fellow Republicans would say, ''raising your taxes again,'' and the Democrats would scurry for cover.
Now Mr. Reagan is gone from the Washington scene, President Bush has abandoned his no-new-taxes pledge, oil prices are soaring, the economy is slumping, and the deficit threatens to race out of control under the impact of the savings-and-loan bailout and the Persian Gulf crisis. The Democrats feel free to utter the dread ''T'' word again, though they prefer to talk about ''fairness,'' and, like Franklin D. Roosevelt and Hubert H. Humphrey and Lyndon B. Johnson, to preach that old-time religion about soaking the rich. 
 
'No More to Give'
Are the Democrats right? Have times really changed? Or are they just deluding themselves? Are they walking into a trap that they don't see?
The Senate and House conferees who will labor to produce a bill to send to Mr. Bush will almost certainly agree, if they agree at all, on a measure that imposes new taxes of some kind on the wealthy. Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, pushed that sort of bill through the House earlier this week, and although the Senate as a whole preferred milder medicine, many Democratic senators actually favored Mr. Rostenkowski's approach of making the privileged pay more.
''The middle class has no more to give,'' said Senator Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland, who sponsored one of many amendments that the Senate defeated today, to her dismay and that of many of her Democratic colleagues.
''Ronald Reagan managed all through the 1980's to cast the tax debate in terms of economic policy,'' said Geoffrey Garin, a leading Democratic poll taker. ''He said low taxes meant greater growth, and people believed him. In that context, fairness didn't matter as much. Everyone was benefiting.
''Now many more people think the question is, Who pays? In that context, the old Democratic argument about fair shares is much stronger.'' Is Reaganism Alive? But a few Democrats on Capitol Hill, and many who ply their trade far from Washington, believe Mr. Reagan's anti-tax fervor is still alive.
Gov. James J. Florio of New Jersey, for example, is facing a fierce popular revolt against his policies, including a program of higher taxes. Representative Jill Long of Indiana, who won a special election on a no-new-taxes platform last year, is running far ahead this year by saying much the same thing. Two Democratic underdogs campaigning for governor in big Midwestern states, Neil Hartigan in Illinois and Anthony Celebrezze in Ohio, have gained a lot of ground in recent weeks by picturing their Republian foes as advocates of higher taxes.
''The landscape has changed,'' said Douglas Schoen, who helps plan campaigns for Democratic candidates, ''but the vast majority of people still think that waste, not inadedquate revenues, is the problem in Washington. So I tell my candidates that they have to establish their fiscal prudence first, then emphasize that they're taking the burden off working people. Otherwise, the Republicans can make us the tax-raising party again, and we lose.''
 
What Has Changed
One thing that is different about the political landscape is the replacement of Mr. Reagan by Mr. Bush, who has less of a core constituency behind him and lacks Mr. Reagan's almost magical ability to make any talk of tax increases a threat to working people, whatever the fiscal reality.
Another is the growing belief of large numbers of voters, reflected in many recent opinion surveys, that the 1980's were full of excesses that will have to be paid for sooner or later, by somebody or other. Relatively few people argue any longer that cutting taxes would balance the budget, as Mr. Reagan and the supply-siders argued with great success in the last decade.
''Politics does have some roots, however fragile, in reality,'' said Thomas Donilon, a Washington lawyer and Democratic strategist. ''Bush gave up the Republicans' strongest political hammer - the no-new-taxes pledge -because he couldn't postpone the day of reckoning anymore. The budget mess couldn't be alllowed to continue. That changes the political equation.''
For the moment, at least, the Democrats are defining the Republicans, for political purposes, as the protectors of the rich, rather than the Republicans' defining the Democrats as the tax-and-spend crowd. That, a very senior Republican senator said this week, ''will cost us some seats'' in the midterm elections next month, and could even imperil Mr. Bush in 1992.
Mr. Mondale, who is campaigning for his son, a candidate for the Minnesota Senate, sees international forces as the engine of change.
''Reagan was saved, it seems to me, by falling oil prices and cheap foreign credit,'' the former Vice President said in a telephone interview. ''They made big deficits tolerable, but now there's no alternative to footing the bill. No more open-field running, just straight through the line - and the Democrats have always been a bit better at that sort of politics.''
 
'Treacherous Ground'
Some even see Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who has made much of the Democrats' case on taxes during the last year, emerging from the budget crisis as such a hero that he will win the party's Presidential nomination two years from now.
Maybe. But as Mr. Donilon said, the Democrats are on ''treacherous ground,'' and a misstep could be very costly. Mr. Gephardt and many other Democrats thought they had a winner three years ago in Japan-bashing, and that faded away as Mr. Bush painted them again as the party of big government, at a time when most voters thought that government should get smaller.
It could happen again, especially at a time when public support for politicians of any stripe - indeed, for politics itself - is so slight.

HEADLINE: Lloyd H. Bailer, Economist and Arbitrator, 76

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18

 BODY:
Lloyd H. Bailer, an economist and arbitrator, died at his home in Brentwood on Tuesday after suffering a series of strokes. He was 76 years old. 
In the 1940's Mr. Bailer, who held a doctorate in economics from the University of Michigan, formed a labor arbitration practice and was appointed to the War Labor Board and the War Shipping Panel.
He was later appointed to the New York State Board of Higher Education and was director of industrial relations at the Urban League of Greater New York.
Mr. Bailer moved to Los Angeles in 1967. In 1968 he became the first chairman of the Los Angeles County Employee Relations Commission. He taught at Columbia, Howard, Rutgers and New York universities.
He is survived by his wife, Marvelyne, four daughters, two sons and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: To Fix the Budget Mess, Restore Pre-'86 Taxes;
Portent in the Rough

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is often the attitudes toward the economic environment that create major changes in an economy's vitality. These ''feelings'' lead individuals to act, precipitating the feared recession. I recently discovered a soft sign for predicting recession that I think may bear the scrutiny of economists and even the Federal Reserve Board. I call it the ''golf-ball sign'' - something I noticed at the local country club as well as during travel abroad. 
People fortunate enough to have enough disposable income to allow them to play golf and hold country club memberships are known for their wastefulness. Up to two years ago, while playing golf, I observed that brand-new golf balls could often be found in the rough just off the fairway, which might be explained this way:
The fat cat hits his brand-new ball, purchased for $8 or $9, into the rough. Subliminally aware of his net worth and of his ability to generate income, he feels it isn't worth pursuing a ball that costs so little.
While playing last spring I noticed that no golf balls were to be found. Why would these same golfers, who once left quantities of balls in the rough, suddenly go into the rough and retrieve those balls? How does this relate to an early recession?
Affluent individuals have now pulled back on minor expenditures. Those who have large disposable incomes really control little of how their money is spent. Most goes automatically to mortgage, interest, car, alimony or child support payments, and educational costs. Such expenditures occur without the individuals' direct intervention.
But small expenses like golf balls, for which they pay or sign, are controlled directly. So, feeling less secure about their financial future and indeed experiencing some crunches, such people will spend that extra moment to retrieve a lost ball, even though its cost is relatively insignificant. Thus, the disappearance of easily retrievable golf balls is a sign of early recession.
When I played recently at the Royal Golf Course in Spa, Belgium, my host said not to worry about retrieving balls because in the spring he and his children had found hundreds of them in the rough along the fairways. But after playing for several holes, my friend shook his head and said there just didn't seem to be any golf balls where he normally found them. For me this was proof that the golf-ball portent is spreading internationally.
 
STEVEN B. SIEPSER
 West Chester, Pa., Oct. 9, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: New York Lost 34,000 Jobs Over Summer

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
New York City lost 34,000 jobs this summer, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, and may be headed for its worst year since the dark days of the mid-1970's.
In June, July and August, the agency said, the city lost 4,300 jobs in finance, real estate and insurance; 5,200 jobs in manufacturing; 5,600 jobs in construction, and 6,500 jobs in trade, reflecting retailing's decline.
Employment in transportation and public utilities increased by 4,200, but the services sector, which expanded even after the stock market's collapse exactly three years ago brought an end to a decade of vigorous expansion, had a slight but worrisome drop. 
Almost 18,000 of the jobs lost during the three months were in private industry. The rest were in government, largely the result of the winding down of this year's census.
 
'A Double-Barreled Effect'
''We're seeing some progressive weakness that reflects the combined impact of the restructuring in a number of key industries, plus the impact of a national slowdown, which has become clearer in recent months,'' said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the regional commissioner of the labor statistics bureau. ''It's a double-barreled effect.''
The latest losses offset a gain earlier in the year from government employment and meant that the city has lost a total of 27,000 jobs so far this year. That already rivals 1982, when the city lost 31,000 jobs, the only year it lost jobs since the city's economy collapsed in the 1970's and about 100,000 jobs a year were lost.
There was uncertainty, however, over whether the recent losses represented an acceleration in an already ominous trend that could continue into the fall.
City and state officials, said they expect that some earlier Federal employment statistics for New York City will eventually be revised downward, lessening gains recorded earlier this year and making the trend seem less pronounced.
But in another gloomy assessment yesterday, the New York State Deputy Comptroller for New York City declared that the city economy is in a recession.
According to the report, the gross city product - the total output of goods and services produced by the city's economy - was 1.4 percent lower in the second quarter of 1990 than in the second quarter of 1989. It was the third straight quarterly drop.
The report also noted that New York City's unemployment rate, which had declined steadily from 1982 to 1988, had reversed direction and reached 7.9 percent last month and that retail sales, which fell in 1989, were sinking more rapidly in the second quarter.
The report by State Deputy Comptroller Elinor B. Bachrach also noted that the weakening national economy has hurt New York City. It has reduced the demand for city specialties like legal and accounting services, and has also reduced consumer spending.
Although there is no longer doubt that New York is well into a severe slump, economists are uncertain how bad it is and how long it will last.

HEADLINE: Raise in Dispute as New York City Negotiates 3d Day With 2 Unions

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
New York City's municipal labor talks ground through their third day yesterday as city and union officials shuttled in and out of the presidential suite on the 21st floor of the Sheraton Centre Hotel in Manhattan.
Both sides refused to comment on the negotiations, which entered an intensified phase on Tuesday. The negotiators hope to reach an agreement this week. 
The unions are the 140,000-member District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
 
Reduced Raise Indicated
Away from the bargaining table, conflicting versions emerged over a meeting that Mayor David N. Dinkins held on Friday at Gracie Mansion to discuss the labor contracts. The participants were several top mayoral aides and the administration's council of outside economic advisers.
One person who was present and who favors limiting raises said some mayoral aides had discussed the possibility of offering to settle the pending contracts for around 4.5 percent, or about 1 percent less than the raise given to the teachers' union. The teachers won an agreement providing for a 5.5 percent raise plus a $100-per-member contribution for health insurance that would effectively bring the raise to 5.8 percent.
The person, who asked not to be identified, said city officials appeared to have second thoughts about offering the other unions even 4.5 percent after the outside fiscal experts, led by Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, objected to it as still too high.
 
Report of Meeting Disputed
But two administration officials who were also at the meeting vehemently denied the account.
''It's absolutely not true,'' said the Labor Relations Commissioner, Eric J. Schmertz. ''No number was floated or discussed by anybody at that meeting.'' He said that in other settings, various city officials had discussed many possibilities but had not arrived at a single position.
The First Deputy Mayor, Norman Steisel, said, ''There was never a discussion at that meeting of a 4.5 percent proposal or of a specific strategy or what the offer might be.''
At a news conference marking the opening of the talks, the teamsters' president, Barry Feinstein, lashed out at Mr. Rohatyn, accusing him of interfering with negotiations by urging the cancellation of the teachers' contract and arguing against any raise for the other unions. Last night Mr. Feinstein said his criticsm was based on Mr. Rohatyn's public statements, not on anything that might have happened at the private meeting at Gracie Mansion.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Labor Commissioner Eric J. Schmertz said reports of an agreement on what to offer city unions were ''not true.'' (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: 7 Held in Mob Extortion of Clothiers

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Two years ago, prosecutors established a dummy garment-manufacturing company in a factory on the edge of Chinatown. Their aim: to investigate persistent reports that organized-crime figures had a stranglehold over the trucking business in Manhattan's garment industry.
Yesterday, the inquiry ended with the indictments of a reputed high-ranking Mafia captain and six other men on charges that they had imposed a ''mob tax'' on almost every garment manufactured in Manhattan since 1982. 
The investigation, prosecutors said, provided a glimpse into the harsh economics of the garment industry and the impact of the Mafia on it. The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said the Gambino crime family reaped ''tens of millions of dollars'' in illegal profits.
The indictments accused Thomas Gambino of heading an enterprise that virtually monopolized pickups and deliveries in showrooms and factories in midtown and Chinatown.
 
Owned 4 Trucking Companies
Mr. Gambino, who is 61 years old, has been identified by law-enforcement authorities as a captain in the Gambino crime family. He is the son of the late Carlo Gambino, who the authorities said founded the nation's largest and most powerful Mafia faction.
Also indicted was Thomas Gambino's brother, Joseph, 54. The Gambino brothers and their relatives own 4 of 10 companies said to have been used to control trucking routes.
The 10 companies handled about 90 percent of the garment-industry trucking routes in recent years, said Michael G. Cherkasky, the head of the District Attorney's investigations division. Mr. Cherkasky said they charged shipping rates about 40 percent higher than those asked by a handful of small, independent companies in Manhattan.
Each pleaded not guilty at arraignments in State Supreme Court. Both were released on personal recognizance bonds, $1 million for Thomas and $500,000 for Joseph.
 
'Low Profile, Well Buffered'
At the arraignments, their lawyer, Gerald L. Shargel, said, ''Charges like these are easy to make but proving them is quite different.''
Thomas Gambino, who lives at 6 East 68th Street, has been accused of a criminal charge only once before. He was acquitted of a Federal charge of obstruction of justice last year in Brooklyn.
A report issued last month by the New Jersey Commission of Investigation said Thomas Gambino was also influential in New Jersey's garment industry and that he ''epitomizes the low-profile, well buffered, successful businessman image common among second generation members of the Cosa Nostra.''
Prosecutors said in interviews that many companies in Manhattan that used independent truckers were later compelled by the Gambino group to reimburse it, even though it had provided no trucking services.
 
Solicited by Gambino 'Salesmen'
The dummy company, called Chrystie Street Fashions at 195 Chrystie Street, near Stanton Street, was run by New York State Police Division investigators from August 1988 to August 1989. The investigators, prosecutors said, were solicited for business by ''salesmen'' from the Gambino trucking group.
Mr. Morgenthau said that in conversations, which were recorded and video taped, the salesmen provided evidence about how the Gambino trucking group controlled routes and demanded payments.
Wiretaps and secret microphones were also installed in the offices used by the Gambino brothers at the Consolidated Carriers Corporation at 141 West 35th Street, near Broadway, Mr. Morgenthau said.

HEADLINE: Restaurants

BYLINE: By Bryan Miller

 BODY:

The Four Seasons
When the Four Seasons had its 25th birthday bash in 1985, it was more than just a restaurant jubilee. As New York's most glamorous (and among its most expensive) dining spots, the Four Seasons embodied a time of restaurant euphoria. Not too long afterward, the economy's bubble burst, and many thought that even the Four Seasons would have to adapt or sink. Bistro Four Seasons? Unimaginable.
Today, as it prepares to enter its fourth decade, the indomitable Four Seasons is showing its pedigree and prevailing in difficult times.
There have been some major changes in the kitchen in the last year. Seppi Renggli, the chef for 17 years, left and was replaced by his longtime sous chef, Christian Albin, and Stefano Battistini from the Sea Grill at Rockefeller Center. The cosseting management team, including the owners, Tom Margittai and Paul Kovi, insure that longtime customers feel that nothing else has changed. 
Dining at the Four Seasons is a dramatically different experience according to when you go and where you sit. The legendary Grill Room, with its soaring ceiling, leather banquettes and rosewood walls, is still the ultimate power-lunch destination. In contrast to the rarified Grill Room, where almost no one drinks or has dessert, the lavish Pool Room is more relaxed, with its graciously appointed tables, illuminated trees and gurgling marble pool. No one rushes here.
You surely do not want to race though excellent starters like crispy fried shrimp with sweet-spicy mustard fruits (especially at $18), silken smoked duck breast with mixed greens and pencil-thin white asparagus, Parma prosciutto with fresh figs, and lustrous carpaccio with coriander and ginger. Both soups sampled make one yearn for a snowy winter day. The tomato-tinted lobster chowder is full of big sweet chunks of meat, corn and potatoes; and mildly spicy lamb-and-barley soup has a deep rich lamb-stock flavor. A boring low-cal spa cuisine item, however, steamed shrimp surrounded by sliced cucumbers topped with tartar sauce, could persuade me to jettison my diet. And smoked sturgeon over mixed greens was inedibly acrid. The best pasta appetizer tried was thin tortelloni filled with ricotta cheese, spinach and shredded duck and served with a garnish of basil, tomato and duck.
The Four Seasons is renowned for its wine cellar, which is particularly strong in California, Italian and Bordeaux selections.
It is hard to tell that two chefs share the driver's seat here, for the menu has the same harmony it has always had. There seems to be more seafood than ever, perhaps the influence of Mr. Battistini. A thick disk of moist, peppered swordfish steak in a zippy curry sauce with small roasted potatoes and pineapple slices has an exotic appeal. Superbly fresh pompano is simply sauteed and garnished with crunchy chayote and sweet peppers. Crayfish stew on the side is the best part of a meaty but underseasoned roasted sea bass. Salmon for two, filleted at tableside, has wonderfully salty strips of skin for garnish and comes with an herb sauce aromatic of fresh tarragon. Crabs cakes are superbly meaty and golden.
One of my old favorites is still on the menu, roast duck with brittle skin and pepper sauce. It is especially good with a side dish of wild rice and pine nuts or spatzle with olives and Parmesan. Roasted sweetbreads marinated in port, a special, were deliciously crisp and were served with woodsy autumn morels and a Swiss chard sauce. One dish that oddly disappointed was veal shank for two with truffle sauce. Carved at tableside, it inevitably is cool by the time it reaches the diner, and no truffles could be detected. Moreover, I prefer veal shank on the bone with its marrow. When the dessert cart comes around the bend, you will spot two Four Seasons classics, the deadly chocolate velvet cake, which resembles a torpedo head in solid chocolate, and the fancy cake, a dome of genoise and custard gift-wrapped in a layer of chocolate. The former is much more interesting than the latter. Fruit tarts and fruit layer cakes excel, as do the hazelnut cheesecake and the Hudson Valley apple custard pie.
As the staff at the Four Seasons dons its pumpkin-colored outfits this fall, one has to give the restaurant credit for spanning three decades of dining in New York without missing a step.
 
Sam's
Three years after its completion, the restaurant complex at the Equitable Life Assurance Tower on West 51st Street has proved to be not only a dynamic dining hub, but also a catalyst for other entrepreneurs in the neighborhood. Just as impressive as the success of Le Bernardin and Palio, two luxury establishments in the tower, is moderately priced Sam's, which has brought in a younger repeat clientele. Moreover, recent visits found that the food, under the energetic chef, Gregory Anne Cox, has improved a notch since it was last reviewed late in 1987.
The setting is staggering in its dimensions: a 28-foot-high cathedral ceiling with Wild West accents; brass-and-clay-colored chandeliers, and a bronze bison grazing on top of the circular bar.
As is often the case at this time of year, my reviewing spanned two seasonal menus, so some dishes mentioned here may not be available except as daily specials. Crab cakes have always been winners, generous and dusted with corn flour. A gastronomic hybrid called Tex-Mex ravioli worked splendidly. A single ravioli was filled with toasted corn, green peppers and garlic and garnished with moist smoked chicken.
Soups change frequently. What the kitchen calls gumbo-laya had good spicy chicken sausage and shrimp going for it, and the stock was hearty, but too much clove ruined the blend. Roasted tomato soup with potato and cabbage puree, on the other hand, was excellent.
Sam's has a limited but well selected wine list that complements the food. The young service staff, wearing Western shirts and bolo ties, is nothing if not fast on the draw, particularly at lunch.
The all-American entrees here range from steaks and pastas to exotic salads. Among the pastas, our favorite was the clean and saline spaghettini with lobster and shrimp and cucumber ribbons in a fresh tomato sauce. But some pastas needed a boost, like a special with asparagus, red peppers, salmon and cream.
Other main courses were almost uniformly good: juicy lamb chops with a sweet three-onion tart, paillard of Black Angus with new potato salad and tomato salad, grilled rosemary-seasoned chicken with deep-fried laces of potatoes, and a top-notch hamburger. The Black Angus steak is well cooked, too, and richly beefy. The salmon now comes glazed with a balsamic vinegar reduction scented with honey and lavender, accompanied by a winter vegetable ragout on the side; and scallops are enhanced with smoked salmon creme fraiche, new potatoes and onion cakes. Swordfish is particularly well turned out, moist, golden and with peppery potato pancakes laced with onions.
Boston cream pie is about as high on my list of sweets as it is on the American Heart Association's, but the version here is unconventionally light. Chunky apple pie is a fine fall treat, as is the blueberry nectarine pie.
Sam's has clearly found its niche among the budget-watching corporate minions of midtown. And if you take a closer look, I'm sure you'll see a lot of their bosses there, too.

HEADLINE: Pop/Jazz;
Very Private Jill O'Hara Once Again Goes Public

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN

 BODY:
When Jill O'Hara strides to the tiny stage of Dannys' Skylight Lounge, the back-room cabaret at the Grand Sea Palace restaurant, it's hard to imagine that this vivid, confident performer in a bright red gown used to be so shy that she could barely bring herself to do an interview.
In her act, Ms. O'Hara sings material that runs from Joni Mitchell to Leonard Bernstein to David Frishberg in a big, pungent voice that is part Broadway and part folk, with a tinge of jazz. Interspersed with the songs are amusing personal anecdotes. Introducing her powerful rendition of ''Ten Cents a Dance,'' the singer tells the story of her aunt, who worked as a dance-hall girl during the Depression. Ms. O'Hara's uncle was so upset, she said, that he paid her father, who was then a hotel dishwasher, to buy up all her dance tickets. 
Commenting on Randy Newman, several of whose songs she performs, Ms. O'Hara observes that though he is thought of as cynical by many, she sees him as ''a hopeless idealist,'' obsessed with comparing the dream of America with the realities.
Such observations hardly suggest diffidence. Yet there was a time two decades ago, Ms. O'Hara said recently, when her reticence was a career hindrance. At the time, she happened to be among the toasts of Broadway. In 1967 and 1968, she portrayed in rapid succession the female lead in the original Public Theater production of ''Hair,'' co-starred with Joel Grey in the hit musical ''George M!'' and played opposite Jerry Orbach in the Burt Bacharach, Hal David and Neil Simon musical ''Promises, Promises.'' Barely 21 years old, she was a big star.
 
'I Was Very Young'
But then Ms. O'Hara pretty much faded from sight in New York. It has been only in the last year and a half that she has re-emerged as an accomplished cabaret performer, singing songs by Mr. Newman, Ms. Mitchell and Mr. Frishberg, in addition to theater and folk songs, and even a little country.
''I never capitalized on the opportunities I had back then,'' Ms. O'Hara recalled, looking back 20 years. ''I was very young and so incredibly shy that I couldn't do talk shows and things like that. The whole thing was overwhelming.''
Ms. O'Hara, who grew up in Warren, Pa., had gone to Manhattan in 1963 right after high school, singing in Greenwich Village coffeehouses. Her first professional theater work was ''Hang Down Your Head and Die,'' a satirical Off Broadway revue about capital punishment, produced by Marion Javits. The show lasted only one night, but it had the distinction of being the vehicle that brought together Jerome Ragni and James Rado, the creators of ''Hair.''
After her Broadway successes, Ms. O'Hara chose not to go to Hollywood, establishing a career in regional theater. What Is Serious? ''I couldn't bring myself to go to California, and do all the things you have to do to survive as an actor,'' she said. ''For me to live in a place where your entire life revolves around getting a prime-time sitcom seemed insane. There wasn't enough money in the world.''
A serious actress who studied for 12 years with Uta Hagen, she played leading roles in regional productions of ''The Hot L Baltimore,'' ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf'' and ''The Importance of Being Earnest,'' among many other plays. Among her last interesting projects, she said, was a production of Michel Tremblay's play ''Albertine, in Five Times,'' in Hartford.
Six years ago, she married Philip Jones, an architect and painter, who encouraged her to start performing in clubs.
''I'd be singing in the backyard, and he said, 'You ought to be doing this in public,' '' she recalled.
 
And the Benefits of Cabaret
Only once before had she dipped her toes into cabaret: in the 1970's, at the Grand Finale, an Upper West Side club that has since closed. Ms. O'Hara set about putting together an act, which she tried out for two nights at Eleonora's, a small restaurant cabaret on West 58th Street. In October 1988, she took that act to Dannys' Skylight Room for four nights. With her husband as the producer, she also recorded a limited-edition album.
In July, she opened an expanded version of her act: a two-hour one-woman show, ''Jill and Her Jacks,'' in London at the King's Head Theater, to warm critical reception.
If cabaret, far more than theater, is an economically marginal profession, Ms. O'Hara said she still prefers nightclubs.
''The price of working in the theater is enormous,'' she said. ''I got so tired of having so little say over my material and having my life controlled by somebody deciding whether to give me a job or not.
''Cabaret may be difficult, but artistically it's much more satisfying.''
Ms. O'Hara is to perform at Dannys' Skylight Room, 346 West 46th Street, at 9 tonight and tomorrow night. Admission is $12, with a $10 food and drink minimum. Reservations: 265-8133.

The Economy
With bipartisan support, the Senate approved a comprehensive budget package early this morning that would raise the taxes or cut the benefits of nearly all Americans. [Page A1.]
The bailout of the savings industry may be forced to slow down for lack of new financing as elections near. [A1.] 
A judge reduced Charles H. Keating Jr.'s bail to $300,000 from $5 million, and hours later Keating was freed, having spent a month in a county jail. [A23.] The Senate Ethics Committee weighed its next move in an inquiry of Senators who helped Keating. [A23.]

At the Milken hearing, Government witnesses described unethical and possibly illegal relationships between Drexel employees clients, but none of it by Milken. [D2.]

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New Bond Request By Trump

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Donald J. Trump is offering bondholders of his Taj Mahal casino new high-yield ''junk bonds'' in lieu of a coming interest payment and is trying to keep more than 80 percent of the equity in the casino while reducing the interest rate on $675 million of its bonds, the Trump Organization disclosed yesterday.
The disclosure, which came in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, drew fire from the bondholders, which have been negotiating with the New York financier for several weeks about the payment on the Taj Mahal bonds.
''What he is asking the bondholders to do is to make him a couple of hundred million dollars as a present,'' said Wilbur Ross, senior managing director of Rothschild Inc., which has been retained by the bondholders' steering committee. ''We think it's a little too early for Christmas.'' 
 
Prices Depressed
The offer further depressed the casino's bond prices in the open market, where Mr. Trump is free to purchase them. The Trump Organization said it reserved the right to purchase the bonds, but its chief financial officer denied that any purchases had been made in recent months.
''The economic reality of what he's proposing is that instead of cash, we get paper,'' Mr. Ross said. ''And in that case, we would greatly prefer to have the keys to the casino.''
The Taj Mahal bondholders have a first mortgage on the casino and would almost certainly be given the property in a bankruptcy.
 
Changing the Terms
Mr. Trump's proposal would, among other things, reduce the interest rate on the bonds to 9 percent from 14 percent, permit future payments to be made in newly issued bonds, and extend the maturity of the original bonds from Nov. 15, 1998, to 2000.
Holders of the original 14 percent first-mortgage bonds on the Taj would also receive 100 percent of the common stock of a newly formed company that would have as its assets a 19.9 percent interest in the Trump Taj Mahal Associates Limited Partnership. Mr. Trump pledged the entire assets of that partnership to banks that rescued him from bankruptcy earlier in the year.
The Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, Mr. Trump's largest casino, faces a $47.3 million interest payment Nov. 15 on high-yield junk bonds that were issued to build it. But the casino has not generated enough cash to pay it out of earnings.
In yesterday's filings, the Trump Organization warned bondholders that unless the offer was accepted, Trump Taj Mahal Funding Inc., the company that financed the casino, and the partnership that owns the Taj might be forced to file for bankruptcy protection.
''This is far worse treatment than the bondholders would receive if we were to be in Chapter 11, so there is no point to it,'' Mr. Ross said. He also pointed out that by allowing him to keep more than 80 percent of the Taj, Mr. Trump's plan would leave the developer with all the tax benefits of owning a property that generates losses.
 
Stake of Banks
All of Mr. Trump's equity interest in the Taj has already been pledged to the commercial banks that rescued his tottering empire several months ago, and some analysts have noted that this means the banks have more to lose than the developer if the casino is forced into bankruptcy.
Mr. Trump has sought financing to buy back the Taj bonds in the open market, but it is not known whether he has been successful.
The Taj Mahal bonds lost about four points in slim trading to end yesterday at about $24 per $100 of face value, said Ray Neidl of Dillon, Read & Company.
Mr. Trump's real estate and gambling holdings are about $3 billion in debt. Last spring and summer, dozens of banks helped to cobble together a package of new loans and deferral of payments on about $1 billion out of $2 billion in bank debt.

HEADLINE: New Jump in Gasoline Price Feared

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Even as crude oil prices descend from the $40 range, gasoline prices seem poised for another significant increase, industry experts say.
But they disagree on how long oil prices will have to stay at their current elevated levels to prompt such a new surge. Some say that with gasoline inventories relatively high and an economy teetering on recession cutting into demand, prices might be stable until the spring.
If the price of gasoline already seems high, it has actually risen less in recent weeks than that of crude oil, and, taxes not included, remains far lower than in Western Europe and Japan, which compete with the United States for supplies. 
 
Oil Company Restraint Seen
For motorists, prices are already up by about 26 cents a gallon since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, to about $1.34 a gallon for regular unleaded self-serve, according to the Department of Energy. But for refiners, the price of crude oil has gone up as much as 50 cents a gallon, and even after the modest declines of the last few days the price is still up by about 35 cents. (Oil closed yesterday at $36.80 a barrel, or nearly 88 cents a gallon, in trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange.) And the mix of oil has shifted, creating a surplus of heavy oil products, like asphalt and fuel for boilers, and a shortage of light ones, like gasoline.
Oil executives say these numbers make it clear that at least some companies are exercising the restraint in pricing called for by President Bush after the Iraqi attack.
But as a result, refineries that are paying more for oil have not raised gasoline prices enough to compensate.''Refinery profits are dismal,'' said James Bailey, a spokesman for the Coastal Corporation, a refiner and marketer. Therefore, domestic refiners are producing less gasoline, and foreign refiners that can get more for their gasoline in other nations are sending less to this country. In a free market, lower gasoline supplies eventually mean higher prices.
If crude oil prices, which are determined largely by events and the threat of events in the Persian Gulf, do not soon fall substantially more -to, say, $30 or so - then the likely outcome is that gasoline prices will catch up with them, industry analysts say. Stockpiles are substantial at the moment and the driving season is over, which would slow any major shift, but supply is down, too.
''It can't go on,'' said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, adding that some refiners were losing money. ''Unless crude prices drop in the very near future, which isn't likely, we will have to see product prices go up.''
The president of Conoco Inc., Constantine S. Nicandros, said yesterday that when Mr. Bush made his request for restraint, ''I said, this is a temporary thing and I don't mind taking a hit for a little while.'' But eventually, he said, ''you've got to recover your raw materials.''
So far, the major oil companies, whose pricing effectively sets a ceiling on what others can demand at the pump, have sacrificed profits in their ''downstream'' operations, refining and marketing, even as profits increase in their ''upstream'' drilling operations.
Refinery margins are commonly measured by the ''crack spread,'' a formula that compares the price of three barrels of oil with that of two barrels of gasoline and one barrel of distillate oil, like diesel or home heating oil. The Oil Daily Group, based in London, reported last Friday that the spread had declined from $10 per barrel of crude in August to under $1.50 a barrel now. In some refineries, that $1.50 does not cover operating costs.
 
Windfall-Profits Tax Feared
The big oil companies appear to have sacrificed downstream profits largely because they fear that if they appear too profitable Congress will reimpose windfall-profits taxes on their oil-pumping operations.
But if the major oil companies can achieve balance that way, the artificially low prices at the pump will still have an effect, by cutting gasoline supplies. And if supplies decline even slightly more than demand, the result will be price increases, experts say.
Another reason for reduced supply is that refineries abroad are increasingly shipping to nations with higher prices. That means just about anywhere else in the industrial world, according to the Department of Energy. Since the end of July the retail price of gasoline, excluding taxes, is up by more than 50 cents in France, Germany, Italy and Britain, and 64 cents in Japan, compared with the 26-cent rise here.
A wild card in predicting gasoline prices is the speed at which demand for gasoline will shrink. It was down about 6.1 percent in September, according to the Oil and Gas Journal, and will go lower as the price rises and if a general recession takes hold. No one is sure just what amount is being consumed, and part of the September drop may be a decision by nervous buyers who stocked up in August to let their inventories decline in September.

HEADLINE: Consumer Prices Rise 0.8% Again

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
With sharply climbing oil prices accounting for more than half the increase, the Consumer Price Index rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September for the second straight month. That raised the inflation rate so far this year to 6.6 percent.
Despite the price surge, today's Labor Department report met a generally favorable reception among economists, most of whom had accurately anticipated the continuing price impact of the confrontation in Persian Gulf. They noted, for example, that the rise in the so-called core inflation - the index excluding energy and food - was three-tenths of 1 percent, less than in August and only half as much as in July. 
The report was also consistent with a slumping economy, and analysts anticipated that the oil-driven inflation, which may prove temporary, would not dissuade the Federal Reserve from cutting short-term interest rates once a satisfactory deficit-reduction plan is in place.
The higher cost of imported oil also had an big impact in the trade deficit report released by the Government today. The deficit for August rose 2.4 percent, to $9.3 billion, chiefly because of the big oil price jump caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. [Page D6.] Increases to Be 5.4% An immediate result of the report today was a calculation by the Social Security Administration that cost-of-living increases for retirees and other beneficiaries would be 5.4 percent in 1991. The average monthly benefit for retired workers rises to $602, from $571; the average for a couple, both of whom receive benefits, rises to $1,022, from $970.
Today's report, which appeared to contribute to a rally in the stock and bond markets, tended to reassure economists that inflation remained largely under control and that even the shocks resulting from the explosion in oil prices were smaller than many had feared.
Prices of plastics and other goods derived from petroleum seem checked by weak demand and strong competition, said Gilbert Benz, an economist for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. ''It's much more difficult to pass on price increases'' to others, he said, allaying recent fears that the oil shock would be quickly transmitted throughout the economy.
Mr. Benz also noted that inflation in services was four-tenths of 1 percent last month, markedly below the increases of six-tenths or seven-tenths posted in June, July and August. Services are an ever-growing share of the economy and are seen as harder to contain than goods prices.
The price of energy of all kinds jumped 5.6 percent in September after a 4.3 percent August advance, with gasoline soaring 9.5 percent to bring its two-month rise since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait to 17.9 percent.
Among the seven main categories in the price index, the biggest impact was in transportation, where motor fuels accounted for more than 80 percent of a 2.3 percent advance. Public transportation costs rose 1.5 percent, the biggest advance since March, reflecting 1.9 percent increases in both airline fares and other intercity travel. Prices of new cars, however, edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent and used cars eased two-tenths.
 
Housing Component Up
The housing component, which represents 42 percent of the index, rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September, well below the seven-tenths of 1 percent rise for August and the lowest since May. Sharp increases for household fuels - with heating oil up 15.9 percent and natural gas up 1.5 percent - were partly offset by a decline for hotel rooms. And renters' costs rose only negligibly after two months of sharp increases.
Food and beverage prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, the same as in August, as an upturn in fruits and vegetables was more than offset by smaller increases in dairy products and each of the other major grocery-store groups. Egg prices tumbled 5.9 percent.
Apparel prices climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent, mostly because of the continued introduction of higher-priced fall and winter merchandise. Although women's and girls' apparel rose 1.5 percent, the C.P.I. branch chief, Patrick C. Jackman, said this was a smaller increase than he had expected and seemed to reflect the weak economy and intense competition for the consumer's dollar.
Inflation even slowed a bit in medical care, where prices rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September after two months of nine-tenths of 1 percent increases.
 
Higher Admission Prices
The lightly weighted entertainment category - 4.4 percent of the index -jumped to an eight-tenths of 1 percent increase from two-tenths in August, mainly reflecting higher admission prices for movies, theaters, concerts, sports events and fees for participant sports.
The other-goods-and-services category fell two-tenths of 1 percent as school supplies and tuitions rose less than the seasonal adjustment factor. Before adjustment, college tuitions climbed 3.4 percent, bringing the 12-month increase to 8.3 percent.
The September price surge lifted the inflation rate for the third quarter to 7.9 percent, up from 3.5 percent in the second quarter but below the 8.5 percent first-quarter rate when energy prices were also soaring.
The consumer inflation rate was 4.6 percent in 1989.
 
Annual Rate 9.5%
Before its upward rounding, the Consumer Price Index covering all urban consumers rose 0.7604563, or 9.5 percent if maintained and compounded for 12 months.
The index covering urban wage earners and clerical workers also rose eight-tenths of 1 percent last month. It is this index that is used to adjust Federal benefit programs, including Social Security. The 5.4 percent increase for 1991 represents the amount by which prices in the third quarter of 1990 exceeded those in the comparable 1989 period.

HEADLINE: Dow Soars 64.85 Points, To 2,452.72

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stable oil prices carried the stock market sharply higher yesterday, with transportation stocks a big beneficiary.
The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue chips soared 64.85 points, or 2.7 percent, to 2,452.72.
The rise also ran through most of the big stocks, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 issues rising 6.98, or 2.3 percent, to 305.74.
Trading volume surged to 204.1 million shares, from 161.3 million the day before. It was the first time volume had passed the 200-million-share mark since early this month. 144 Stocks at New Lows While 1,116 stocks rose and 12 touched new 52-week highs, 436 declined and 144 fell to new lows. 
Among the new highs, Ralston Purina jumped 6, to a high of 107 3/8. John M. McMillin, food analyst for Prudential-Bache, said Ralston was expected to report strong earnings on Nov. 1.
Among the new lows, Freddie Mac, a quasi-government agency that buys and sells mortgages, fell 1 7/8, to 37 7/8, after hitting a new low of 37 3/4. The agency said it would charge off $124 million from its loan loss reserves, but that earnings for the quarter would not be affected.
Traders called the big market upturn just another rally in a bear market. Birinyi Associates said that despite three waves of program buying and an equal number of selling programs, the activity trimmed the Dow a little more than a point.
 
Small Stocks Show Gains
Some of the small stocks, particularly the high-tech issues, also showed strong gains.
The Nasdaq composite index jumped 7.25, or 2.2 percent, to 334.03. The small stocks on the American Stock Exchange lagged a bit. The Amex's market value index rose only 2.71 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 291.84.
''The stock market is still marching to the tune of the price of oil,'' said Hugh Johnson, chief strategist for the First Albany Corporation.
Crude oil fell early in the day to a low of $34.40 a barrel, and the Dow jumped 18 points. By 11:15 A.M., oil moved only slightly higher, and the Dow moved ahead 43 points. By 1:15 P.M. oil retreated a bit, but the Dow was ahead more than 50 points. From then on and for most of the session both moved ahead together, but by the end of the day the oil was up only 8 cents a barrel, to $36.80.
''Stocks look cheap, and there's a lot of cash and itchy investors around,'' Mr. Johnson said.
Figures released last month by the Investment Company Institute, trade group for the mutual fund industry, show that mutual funds currently have close to 12 percent of their assets in cash - the second highest in 20 years.
''That's enough for a spirited rally,'' he said.
''The only thing missing is a catalyst to move confidence just a notch, and the decline in oil prices was the catalyst.''
 
Reaction to Economic Data
Less significant to traders were yesterday's economic figures. The rise in the Consumer Price Index was lower than expected, Mr. Johnson said, and consequently was ''helpful'' in lifting the market. He added that the market largely ignored the merchandise trade deficit, which he described as being in line with expectations.
''It's hard to make the case that this will be anything but a rally in a bear market unless we get a resolution to the main problems. The Middle East crisis continues to mean that risks in the stock and bond market are very high.'' The budget talks are, of course, the other big problem.
Moving up on the drop in oil prices, Delta Air Lines rose 3 1/8, to 60 1/2; AMR 2 1/2, to 48 1/4; Southwest Airlines 1 1/8, to 15 7/8; USAir 1 3/8, to 16 3/8; Federal Express 2, to 39 1/4; Burlington Northern 1 1/4, to 26 5/8; CSX 1 1/8, to 27 5/8, and Union Pacific 1 1/4, to 64.
While AMR's earnings fell 52 percent, they were stronger than expected and helped lift airline stocks. Michael R. Armellino, the Goldman, Sachs analyst, added it to his list of recommendations.
He said he thought oil prices would drop ''substantially'' and that airline stocks would soon outperform the market.
UAL rose 5, to 94 3/8. After the market closed, the company said Keith Gollust and Paul Tierney of Coniston Partners, which owns 11.8 percent, would become UAL directors and had agreed not to change their holdings. UAL said it might repurchase up to two million shares.
Among the high-tech stocks, Digital Equipment rose 4 1/4, to 48, on 2.1 million shares despite a sharp drop in profits; it said it wanted to cut its work force by 5,000. Hewlett-Packard rose 1 1/2, to 29 1/4; NCR 1 3/8, to 46 1/2; Compaq Computer 3 1/4, to 42, and I.B.M. 4 5/8, to 105 3/8, on 1.9 million shares.
Citicorp, which sold for as much as 29 5/8 in the last year, headed the Big Board active list for the third day in a row, rising 3/8, to 13 1/8, on 7.7 million shares. After a sharp drop in profits, It is expected to lay off as many as 5,000 at a cost of $100 million.
Commenting on the group, Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/ Twenty-First Advisers, said, ''I've never seen a new bull market begin without leadership from financial services stocks - insurance, banks, S.& L.'s - and these are so wounded I can't see anything more than brief, sharp rallies.''

HEADLINE: For Dow Chemical, The Good Times Stall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDLAND, Mich.

 BODY:
In the last few years, the Dow Chemical Company has ridden a wave of expansion, driven by a strong market for chemicals. But now the wave may have crested for the nation's second-largest chemical company. A number of analysts contend that the company took on too much and will be paying too dearly.
The company's aggressive expansion helped earnings to a record $9.20 a share last year from 20 cents in 1985. [But profits have started to slide - 52 percent in the third quarter, announced Thursday, and 50 percent in the second - and many analysts think Dow's earnings will tumble at least 25 percent for the year.] Dow, second in size only to E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company as a chemical producer, has in the last three years allied itself with makers of pharmaceuticals, most notably Marion Laboratories; raised its production of high-performance plastics; solidified its dominance in chemicals, and bought specialty-chemical concerns. 
 
The Market Is Sliding
But today the market for commodity chemicals, the building-block products that go into everything from tires to plastics, is sliding after three booming years as the economy slows.
''This will affect them to a larger degree than many of the other companies in the chemical industry,'' said Anantha Raman, president of Anantha Raman & Company, an investment firm based in Parsippany, N.J., that specializes in the chemical industry. Despite some significant diversification by Dow, commodity chemicals still represent nearly a third of the company's sales, more than at competitors like Monsanto and Du Pont, he said.
Analysts are also troubled by Dow's acquisition of a 67 percent stake in Marion Laboratories last year. The acquisition built the company's interest in the lucrative pharmaceutical business, but saddled it with much higher debt - $6.14 billion currently, up from $3.95 billion in 1987.
Furthermore, Dow is now in the midst of a sweeping capital spending program that will cost nearly $2 billion this year alone and that analysts fear could lead to a cash squeeze. ''I see one of the classic mistakes that a company in a capital-intensive business can make,'' said Paul T. Leming, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''They committed to an aggressive capital spending program at the peak of a cycle. Then, you have to borrow to keep funding the capital spending program.''
Adding to the uncertainty about the company's outlook is the Mideast crisis. Higher oil prices translate directly into higher chemical costs, and Dow is a leading producer of ethylene, which is derived from oil, as well as of oil-based plastics and advanced materials, which account for 40 percent of Dow's sales. It is unclear whether the company will be able to pass higher raw-materials costs along to customers in a period of weakened demand and overcapacity. [Dow reported Thursday that its net income had dropped to $282 million, or $1.04 a share, in the third quarter, from $589 million, or $2.19 a share, for the third quarter of 1989. Sales rose 16 percent, to $4.92 billion from $4.25 billion.] A Sense of Unease These developments have created some sense of unease at Dow's campus-like headquarters here, where 8,000 executives and workers have become accustomed to strong growth. Frank P. Popoff, the company's president and chief executive, acknowledges that conditions at Dow are now far from robust, but he maintains that after five years of spectacular earnings growth, it would not be reasonable to expect the pace to be sustained. ''We don't measure ourselves in short cycles,'' Mr. Popoff said. ''We are committed to industries - automotive, construction and appliance -that move in cycles with the economy.''
Mr. Popoff said the company had scaled back its budget for new plants, equipment and properties. He declined to give specific figures, saying only that Dow's capital spending budget this year would be ''less than $2 billion, instead of more than $2 billion.'' Over the next three years the company will spend $500 million less than called for in earlier plans, he said.
 
'A Very Strong Position'
As for Dow's debt level, Mr. Popoff said, ''We are not any more leveraged than we have been in the past.'' He also said that the company's plants were operating at a high level.
Mr. Popoff is not accustomed to being on the defensive against Wall Street analysts. Under his leadership, the last few years have been wildly prosperous for Dow.
In addition to strong growth in chemicals, Dow has established itself as a leader in consumer products, with such labels as Handi-Wrap and Saran Wrap plastic films and Spray'n Wash and Fantastic cleaners. The company has also solidified its position as the leading maker of chlorine and caustic soda on the chemical side, and polyethylene and polystyrene on the plastics side.
In addition, the company's advanced polymers business is considered a source of potential growth. Dow last year began a joint venture with the United Technologies Corporation to develop advanced plastics for the automotive and aerospace industries. And the outlook for that business is bright, analysts say, because of renewed interest in reducing the weight of cars.
Now, with the industry on the downturn, Mr. Popoff said, Dow's return on equity will not continue at last year's level of 35 percent, but will more likely be in the 20 percent range over the next few years. [Dow's stock, which traded at around $75 at the beginning of the year, closed Thursday at $41.625.] Several analysts, including Mr. Leming and Leonard Bogner of Prudential-Bacche, have downgraded Dow's stock from ''buy'' to ''hold.''
A key reason for the analysts' disaffection is Dow's acquisition of the 67 percent stake in Marion Labs. Under the complicated transaction, Dow agreed to pay Marion shareholders a total of $1.5 billion by September 1991, or a larger amount the following year if Marion's stock price did not reach $45.77 a share. The company's payment would decrease if Marion's shares rose above $30. [Marion's shares closed Thursday at $31.125.] Even if Marion's shares increase to $35, Dow Chemical would still have to pay $1 billion.
Still, Mr. Popoff maintains that the company's strategy is sound, and he said detractors fail to look at the long-term picture. The Marion acquisition, he said, ''is the right thing to do strategically'' in an age in which the chemical industry is global and the company must compete against such international giants as ICI Industries of Britain and, BASF, Bayer and Hoechst of Germany. He added that ''we have confidence in the stock.''

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If a Recession, How Serious?

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IT is probable, but not yet certain, that the United States is in a recession.
The highly regarded Research Seminar in Quantitative Economics of the University of Michigan, in a report issued last Friday, estimated that real gross national product declined at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent in the July-September quarter. But this week the Federal Reserve Board reported that helped by a jump in auto sales, industrial production rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, and it revised its figures upward for July and August, showing a slightly rising trend for the third quarter.
The basic trend in the overall economy right now can be described as wiggling around zero. The consensus forecast of the 50 economists surveyed by Blue Chip Economic Indicators calls for real G.N.P. to decline six-tenths of 1 percent in the current quarter and one-tenth of 1 percent in the first quarter of 1991, which would technically make it a recession. But the consensus calls for recovery to start in the second quarter of 1991 and pick up gradually as the year wears on. 
There is still some chance, however, that we can pull ourselves out of the current morass. Most important, the Fed is likely to bring down interest rates once a budget agreement between the Administration and Congress is set.
The Fed is worried about a credit crunch that could dump the economy into recession and crack its financial structure. In his Congressional testimony last July, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said: ''We have been closely watching various interest rate spreads and other indicators to determine if the pulling back of commercial banks to less lax lending standards is moving over the line, so to speak, and in effect creating a tightening in credit markets independent of actions by the Federal Reserve.'' His conclusion: a tightening ''of modest dimensions may be occurring.''
Since then, the danger to borrowers and banks alike has increased. As James J. O'Leary, economic consultant to the United States Trust Company of New York, puts it, ''Many commercial banks and life insurance companies, including many large ones, are seriously undercapitalized, raising the risk of insolvencies as large loan losses continue.'' Hard pressed for reserves, and nervous about nonperforming loans, many banks are turning down borrowers who once would have been considered creditworthy.
A tightening of private credit has the same impact on the economy as a tightening by the Fed, as Mr. Greenspan has made clear. To prevent the system from seizing up, and falling, many businesses say, the Fed should make more reserves available and bring down interest rates.
After the lending binge of the 1980's, the restoration of stricter lending standards is necessary and healthy. But the Fed is now worrying about signs that the banking system is contracting more than it should and endangering the economy.
However, the Fed still believes that the money-supply indicator it watches most closely - M-2, which includes currency in circulation and demand deposits plus time and savings deposits - is growing adequately, within its 1990 target range of 3 to 7 percent. But M-2 is in the lower half of that range, and has been slowing. A more decisive move toward easing by the Fed may be needed to prevent a worsening credit crunch that would chop into the nation's money supply.
The gulf crisis and the surge in oil prices have stirred both recessionary and inflationary fears. But higher oil prices have also spurred spending in the United States for oil drilling and production. And, assuming no further acceleration in oil prices or, preferably, a continuation of the decline that set in this week, the prospects of recovery in 1991 will be strengthened.
The biggest risk to this forecast of sluggish growth or moderate recession through the rest of this year and early next year, followed by a gradual recovery, is the threat of a financial crisis that would result if several major banks were to go under. But it is unlikely that the Federal Reserve, Congress and the Administration would permit that to happen. A more likely outcome involves rescues and mergers of threatened major institutions.
Another big risk is that of an outflow of foreign capital. Yutaka Yamaguchi, the chief representative in the Americas of the Bank of Japan, that country's central bank, said in an interview in New York that he was not greatly concerned whether the United States was in a slight recession or still growing slightly - it came to much the same thing. What he was worried about, he said, were ''external shocks that could have a negative impact'' on America's highly leveraged corporations and financial institutions. He expressed strong agreement with the Federal Reserve's policy, which he called ''very cautious.'' Too sharp a fall in United States interest rates, while foreign rates are rising, could increase capital outflow.
This must be the best-advertised, most carefully watched financial contraction ever. That in itself may help to keep it from becoming an economic catastrophe like the one in the early 1930's.

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. and 3 Regional Bells Post Slightly Higher Profits

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A.T.& T. reported a 1.9 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday despite a much higher tax liability. Three Bell regionals also posted slightly higher earnings.
''We consider it over all a very solid quarter, particularly in view of what is happening to the economy at large,'' said Morris Tanenbaum, chief financial officer at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Higher interest expenses and the loss of investment tax credits prevented an 11 percent increase in A.T.& T.'s operating income from reaching the bottom line, Mr. Tanenbaum said. Overseas sales of telephone network equipment climbed sharply for the quarter. 
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, A.T.& T.'s share price gained $1.125, to $32.
Nynex, Bell Atlantic and U S West all reported quarterly profit gains of a few pennies a share. ''They were in line with expectations, non-eventful,'' said Marion M. Boucher, a telephone industry bond analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
A.T.& T.
A.T.& T. announced profits of $712 million, or 65 cents a share, up from $699 million. Earnings a share a year earlier were also 65 cents, reflecting the fact the company had fewer outstanding shares then. Sales rose 5.2 percent, to $9.36 billion from $8.89 billion.
A.T.& T., the nation's largest long-distance carrier, posted a 7 percent increase in traffic from a year earlier. MCI and US Sprint are growing faster, but the difference is narrowing, said Jack B. Grubman, an analyst at Paine Webber.
Revenues from long-distance traffic, minus payments to local telephone companies for completing calls, rose only 1.5 percent as rates fell and more customers switched to new and less expensive services.
If the American economy goes into a recession, the long-distance industry will probably continue to grow, but at a slower pace, said Robert E. Allen, the chairman and chief executive of A.T.& T. The effects of a recession on A.T.& T.'s long-distance business are unclear, he added. ''It's really hard to tell because this would be the first recession in which we've had such active competition -there's really no baseline experience,'' he said, in a brief interview on Saturday at a conference in Hot Springs, Va.
Because of rising sales overseas, A.T.& T.'s telephone network equipment revenues rose 12.2 percent. The gain came despite a dip in sales to the seven regional Bells, which normally account for three-quarters of such sales.
 
Bell Atlantic
Third-quarter profits at the Bell Atlantic Corporation rose 4.2 percent, to $358.4 million, or 91 cents a share, from $344.1 million a year earlier, or 86 cents a share. Sales climbed to $3.1 billion from $2.91 billion.
Based in Philadelphia with local telephone service in six Eastern states and the District of Columbia, Bell Atlantic posted steady growth of 3.2 percent in telephone lines despite a weak regional economy. The company's results were ''right on the button, as usual,'' said Daniel P. Reingold, an analyst at Morgan Stanley.
Bell Atlantic's share price rose $1.25 yesterday, to $50.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Nynex
The Nynex Corporation, which serves New York and five New England states, reported third-quarter profits of $296.7 million, or $1.50 a share, on sales of $3.4 billion. For the comparable period a year earlier, the White Plains-based company earned $288.7 million, or $1.47 a share, on sales of $3.3 billion.
''The downturn in the Northeast economy is reflected in this quarter's flat revenues in the telecommunications sector,'' William C. Ferguson, the chairman of Nynex, said in a statement.
Nynex's third-quarter results included a $1.4 million payment to the Government and a onetime reduction of $35.5 million in the rates charged to long-distance companies for completing calls.
Both moves were the result of a consent decree with the Federal Communications Commission, under which the F.C.C. dropped its proceeding against the company concerning Nynex's alleged siphoning of profits to an unregulated subsidiary from the New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company. Nynex did not admit any wrongdoing.
The share price of Nynex fell 37.5 cents yesterday, to $70.75, on the Big Board.
 
U S West
Headquartered in Englewood, Colo., and serving 14 Western states, U S West Inc. posted third-quarter profits of $302.6 million, or 77 cents a share, up from $258.1 million, or 69 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales increased to $2.48 billion, from $2.32 billion.
The sharp increase in profits reflected the company's low growth in expenses. U S West's cost of services and products rose nine-tenths of a percent from a year earlier, while its selling, general and administrative expenses dropped six-tenths of 1 percent.
U S West's share priced rose $1.50 yesterday, to $37.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Japanese Banker to Head A Morgan Stanley Unit

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
The Morgan Stanley Group said yesterday that it had hired a Japanese banker, Takeo Kani, to be chairman of Morgan Stanley Japan Ltd. and general manger of the firm's Tokyo securities branch.
Mr. Kani, 58, is joining Morgan Stanley from the Industrial Bank of Japan, where he has spent 36 years. He came to the United States five years ago to be vice chairman of the IBJ/Schroder Bank and Trust Company in New York after the Schroder bank was purchased by the Japanese bank. 
Mr. Kani will join Morgan Stanley in New York next month and will take over in Tokyo Jan. 1.
There, he will succeed David S. Phillips, 57, who is retiriing at the end of the year to become an advisory director of the Morgan Stanley Group and senior adviser to the firm in Japan, his home country.
When Mr. Phillips came to the United States to study at the University of California at Berkeley, he took the name of a professor of economics with whose family he lived and who was a close friend of his father's in Tokyo, a Morgan Stanley spokeswoman said.
In Tokyo, Mr. Kani will also become co-head of the firm's investment banking business, working with John S. Wadsworth Jr., the current head of investment banking. After a transition, Morgan Stanley said, Mr. Kani will assume responsibility for investment banking. Mr. Wadsworth will continue as president of Morgan Stanley Japan and deputy general manager, as well as head of the firm's investment banking business in Asia.
Mr. Kani said yesterday that Morgan Stanley was expanding rapidly in Japan and would continue to grow. The company currently employs 700 people there. Of 10 Morgan Stanley managing directors in Tokyo, six are Japanese.
Mr. Kani declined to make any comments on the direction of the Japanese stock market, saying he had been in commercial banking and felt unqualified to speak on the market at this point.
Mr. Kani graduated from the University of Tokyo in 1954 and joined the Industrial Bank that year. He founded IBJ International in London in 1975 and was named a managing director of the Industrial Bank in 1984.
''We are delighted to have a seasoned banker of the stature of Mr. Kani succeed to this leadership role,'' said S. Parker Gilbert, chairman of the Morgan Stanley Group.

HEADLINE: Reflecting Oil Cost, Trade Deficit Hits $9.3 Billion

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit continued to worsen in August, rising 2.4 percent, to $9.3 billion, the largest imbalance since January, the Commerce Department reported today. The increase chiefly reflected the higher cost of imported oil resulting from the crisis in the Persian Gulf.
The first Government report on the trade gap covering the period after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait showed that the average price of oil imported into the United States rose by $5.04 a barrel, to $19.54.
Over all, imports rose 1.8 percent, to $41.97 billion, a high, while exports were up 1.6 percent, to $32.63 billion, the third-highest monthly level. Although the trade gap widened in August from a revised July deficit of $9.12 billion, it improved over the first eight months, showing a seasonally adjusted rate of $96.8 billion, down from the $110.7 billion shortfall in 1989. 
But the further rise of oil prices since August could spell more bad news later this year.
The Commerce Department figures showed a $4.8 billion oil bill for August - 20 percent higher than in July - which would have been even greater had there not been a decline in the volume of oil imported - from 274 million barrels to 245 million.
''We're not out of the woods yet in factoring in the oil shock,'' said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley.
Excluding oil, the deficit in August, at $5 billion, showed a modest decline from the $5.4 billion in July. Non-oil imports fell during the month by three-tenths of 1 percent, against the 1.6 percent rise in exports.
The deficit has been narrowing since 1987, when it hit a record $152 billion. In 1988 the overall gap between exports and imports fell to $118.53 and in 1989 to $109.40 billion.
Over the first eight months, the non-petroleum deficit, which some Government economists consider a good measure of international competitiveness, was down 28.5 percent from the period a year earlier.
J. Antonio Villamil, chief economist at the Commerce Department, said the improvement reflected an 8.3 percent year-to-date gain in exports compared with a 2.5 percent rise in non-petroleum imports over the same period.
''We expect this trend to continue, reflecting the growing ability of U.S. industry to to compete in expanding overseas markets,'' Mr. Villamil said.
Exports, the strongest part of a weakening American economy, have been made more competitive by the recent decline in the dollar's international value compared with the German mark and the Japanese yen, and by still robust economic activity in Europe, Japan and other major markets. A declining dollar makes American goods cheaper overseas.
Exports of food, beverages, consumer goods and industrial supplies were particularly strong in August. But aircraft sales, another big item on the balance sheet, fell.
Altogether, exports of manufactured goods, at $23.9 billion, were $400 million greater than in July, they were $900 million less than the average of the first seven months of this year. Imports of manufactured goods, at $33.3 billion, were $400 million less than July and $1.5 billion more than the $31.8 billion seven-month average.
Michael P. Niemira, economist for the Mitsubishi Bank, said that exports might have gone higher during the month had it not been for the requisitioning of civilian aircraft to transport more than 200,000 American troops to Saudi Arabia.
 
Less Capacity for Merchandise
This meant less capacity to fly out merchandise for foreign customers. Although the large bulk of exports moves aboard ships, Mr. Niemira said that in terms of value, commercial aircraft take about a third of the total.
An official at the Federal Express Corporation confirmed that air freight capacity had been withdrawn in both the trans-Pacific and trans-Atlantic markets as a result of Government use of the Civilian Reserve Air Fleet for the flights to Saudi Arabia.
He said it was likely, however, that shipments delayed in August for national security reasons may help swell the September totals.
A country-by-country breakdown showed that the deficit with Japan, which had been moving down earlier this year, jumped $800 million in August to $3.8 billion. One of the factors was an increase in imports of Japanese cars.
For the first eight months, the deficit with Japan stood at $26.3 billion, compared with $32.4 billion over the corresponding period last year.
In August, the United States also recorded large deficits with Taiwan, $1.2 billion; China, $1.1 billion; Germany, $1.1 billion; Canada, $509 million; South Korea, $518 million; Venezuela, $466 million; Saudi Arabia, $456 million; Hong Kong, $397 million, and Brazil, $178 million.
