HEADLINE: A Saudi Oil Windfall? If Prices Remain High and Fields Intact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
Whether Saudi Arabia reaps a windfall from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait depends on two big ifs - if its oilfields are undamaged by war and if oil prices stay high.
If those conditions are met, the profit is likely to exceed even the substantial new commitments Saudi Arabia undertook after the invasion: subsidies of $1 billion a month to the United States and the Saudis' neighbors in the Persian Gulf that are supporting the United Nations embargo of Iraq; about $1 billion a month in extra operating expenses for the Saudi military, and the purchase of $7.3 billion in American weapons. Much of that equipment has already been sent to Saudi Arabia, although it is not clear exactly when payment will be made.
Last week, with crude oil selling at $40 a barrel, the Saudis were thought to be able to earn as much as an additional $16 billion in the fourth quarter, which would more than cover those expenses. Oil has fallen in recent days to below $37 a barrel, and should it stay at that level the extra Saudi profits for the quarter might be closer to $14 billion. 
The real windfall could begin in 1991, if Persian Gulf tensions and oil prices remain high and the Saudi Government does not incur additional costs, said Edgard H. Habib, the senior director of the Middle East and Africa service at the WEFA Group, a large consulting firm in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ''What is critical in this situation is how long it lasts,'' he added. $65 Billion Extra Based on the rough-and-ready arithmetic of multiplying expanded Saudi oil production next year by nearly $37 a barrel - which is what Saudi Arabia actually receives when the world price is $40 - analysts estimate that the extra revenues could total as much as $65 billion over the next 12 months. Balanced against that would be continued monthly subsidies and military expenses, the proposed purchase of another $14 billion of American weapons for delivery over the next several years - which has drawn hostility in Congress -and a range of other expenses that are hard to estimate, like the accelerated development of oilfields.
The estimates of additional annual oil revenues are highly conditional. They assume that Saudi oilfields will not be damaged by military action or sabotage, while tensions nonetheless keep oil prices high. Yet oil traders and analysts say the surge in crude oil prices after the Iraqi invasion reflected, in part, concerns that a Persian Gulf war would destroy some Saudi oilfields, which would limit the Saudi Government's ability to benefit from higher prices.
If Saudi oilfields continue to produce at full capacity, oil prices may fall, said Fareed Mohamedi, an oil industry analyst at the Petroleum Finance Company. Contracts for delivery of oil next spring are trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange for $29 to $31 a barrel, meaning that the consensus of the market is that there will then be nearly adequate supplies and lower prices, he said.
Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's former oil minister, said recently that crude oil should drop to $15 to $18 a barrel when the Persian Gulf crisis was settled. Reimposing production quotas may be difficult then for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
 
Long-Term Commitments
Higher oil prices also represent a two-edged sword for Saudi rulers, producing extra revenues now but increasing the risk that Western nations will look harder for new sources of energy. ''They've got 120 years of reserves - it's not in their long-term interest to have oil-shale production, geothermal energy and other alternatives become economical,'' said Ronald J. Rizzuto, a finance professor at the University of Denver who specializes in the economics of the industry.
Saudi Arabia has acquired several long-term commitments since the Iraqi invasion, the cost of which may dwarf any oil windfall that lasts only a few months, experts say.
Countries that have sided with Saudi Arabia are likely to expect economic assistance, said David T. Mizrahi, the editor and publisher of the Mideast Report, a New York newsletter. Saudi officials hinted at such aid when the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia established diplomatic relations on Sept. 17, he said.
 
Some Aid Is Halted
At the same time, Saudi Arabia has cut off its aid to Jordan and the Palestinian Liberation Organization in response to their support of Iraq. Jordan has lost $350 million a year, plus subsidized oil, while the P.L.O. has lost $80 million to $100 million a year.
The biggest expense to the Saudis may be a permanently larger and better-equipped army. Prince Bandar bin Sultan, the Saudi Ambassador to the United States, said recently that his country had begun a review of the size of its armed forces. Iraq has a little more than twice the population of Saudi Arabia, but its regular army is nearly 10 times as big.
Prince Bandar and the Saudi Embassy in Washington declined to comment on how extra oil revenues would affect Saudi Arabia.
The country has relied more on diplomacy and lavish foreign aid and less on the size of its armed forces to maintain its independence for the last several decades. Since World War II, Saudi diplomacy has emphasized the kingdom's devotion to Islam and its defense of two of the religion's holiest cities, Mecca and Medina, in contrast to the secular Pan-Arab nationalism espoused by President Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt in the 1950's and 1960's and Saddam Hussein now.
 
The Social Costs
The average Saudi is unlikely to perceive any dramatic benefit from higher oil prices, said Sharif Ghalib, the director of the Africa and Middle East department at the Institute of International Finance, a Washington-based research organization supported by international banks. That is because the Saudi Government had planned to cover a projected deficit this year of $6.7 billion by selling bonds, but may instead keep the additional oil revenues.
Estimates of Saudi Arabia's financial gains and losses as a result of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait also ignore the social costs to the kingdom of being unable to defend itself and forced to accept more than 100,000 foreign troops.
The clearest beneficiaries of Iraq's invasion, although not in total dollars received, may be the oil exporters that do not border Kuwait or Iraq and are receiving higher prices for their oil. These countries include Algeria, Egypt, Indonesia, Mexico, Nigeria and Yemen.
''For the countries that have high populations and low incomes, this is a fortune'' because they spent their previous oil revenues and ran up large foreign debts, said Marvin Zonis, a professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business who studies Middle Eastern politics and business. ''The other countries are living and dying on these barrels,'' he said. Algeria has already said it will devote most of its extra oil revenues to the payment of overdue foreign debts.
''When the creditors see these windfall gains, they will not say, 'Sow it in your economy and pay us later,' '' Mr. Habib said.

HEADLINE: Macy Will Report Deeper Losses for the Fourth Quarter and the Year

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
R. H. Macy & Company's fourth-quarter loss deepened to $80 million, from $57.3 million a year earlier, and its losses for the full fiscal year ended July 28 more than tripled, to $215.3 million, from $63 million the year before, according to statements relayed to credit agencies and confirmed yesterday by sources close to Macy.
Macy, New York's biggest retailer and the operator of about 100 department stores in the East, South and West, had a sales gain of 2.5 percent in the quarter, to $1.63 billion, from $1.59 billion the year before. For the full year, Macy's sales rose 4.3 percent, to $7.27 billion from $6.97 billion. 
The preliminary figures for the year were published in The Wall Street Journal and Women's Wear Daily yesterday. The fourth-quarter results were extrapolated from the full-year results and those for the nine months ended April 28. Macy expects to furnish final results in a financial statement to the Securities and Exchange Commission late next week, One Measure of the Decline Earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation fell 22.1 percent, to $721 million, from $926.1 million the year before. The tax aspect does not apply to a company losing money. In the fourth quarter, earnings before inventory accounting adjustment rose 7.2 percent, to $179 million from $167 million. ''The drop in those earnings was due to higher inventory accounting charges, which reduced the income by $35 million,'' said one executive close to Macy.
Macy is one of the nation's most highly leveraged retailers, following its 1986 leveraged buyout and its 1988 acquisition of the Bullock's and I. Magnin stores in California. In its regular, informal report to credit agencies, Macy said that its inventories were $560 million less than a year ago, which could be seen as an indication that Macy, along with most other retailers, does not expect a robust Christmas selling season.
''I think Macy's primary markets in the Northeast and California suffered from very sluggish consumer buying,'' said Janet Mangano, research director for Jesup, Josephthal & Company, New York. ''That produced the kind of top line or sales that would affect any retailer leveraged or not. But then the high leverage makes weak results seem even weaker.''
 
'Macroeconomic Factors' Cited
Ms. Mangano said that Macy had had a relatively good third quarter ended April 28 after two ''very weak'' quarters. But the improved trend waned in the fourth quarter ''probably due to the macro-economic factors,'' Ms. Mangano continued. ''But the fourth quarter may have implications for arranging future lines of credit,'' she added.
Frank Basile, chairman of the CIT Group/Factoring, New York, which has been closely monitoring Macy, said yesterday: ''You can't help but be concerned when dealing with such highly leveraged companies as Macy. But it is actually doing better than most of the others. The company has sufficient resources and support to make it through the holiday, and they have a number of options they could take afterward.''
He said that the recent sale by Macy of its credit unit to the General Electric Capital Corporation ''will benefit Macy's earnings and allow it to cut its debt.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose and interest rates fell yesterday, as a better-than-expected report on inflation and an early drop in oil prices inspired buying.
The eight-tenths of a percentage point increase in September's Consumer Price Index was as high as most analysts had feared. But excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, the so-called core inflation rate rose by a much more modest three-tenths of a percentage point.
''I hate to put too much emphasis on one figure, but the core inflation number was a positive one,'' said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. 
The consumer price figures helped to generate a rash of buy orders.
''A lot of money was spent today,'' one Government bond trader said. ''That's fine for right now, but it makes you wonder if there will be any money around when the refunding takes place.''
 
Quarterly Refunding Auctions
The Treasury, which is expected to hold its quarterly refunding auctions in early November, was forced to cancel a planned auction of one-year Treasury bills yesterday because the Federal Government is still without a budget.
In place of the one-year bills, the Treasury said, it will sell $12.5 billion of 69-day cash management bills today. Analysts said the decision, which allows the Government to raise new cash before the temporary increase in the Federal debt ceiling expires at midnight tonight, effectively gives Congress more time to come up with a new budget.
''The cash management bills, which settle on the day they are sold, will give the Government enough cash to operate until the end of October in the absence of any increase in the debt ceiling,'' said Louis v.B. Crandall, chief economist at R.H. Wrightson & Associates, an economic consulting firm.
The move, Mr. Crandall said, ''stretches out the time Congress has to work on the budget by another week. The Bush Administration has rolled the budget deadline back one more time.''
The Treasury Department's announcement helped to push up interest rates on some short-term bills, but had little impact elsewhere in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
Treasury prices, which early in the session rose by as much as a full point, retreated later in the day when oil prices reversed course. But the gains, particulary by bonds, continued a rally that began on Monday.
By late in the day, the 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 10/32, up 22/32, to yield 8.81 percent, down from 8.88 percent late Wednesday. At the end of trading last Friday the bellwether issue was offered at a price to yield 8.95 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes rose by 14/32, to a late price of 100 1/2, to yield 8.67 percent. And the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 100 3/4, up 1/4 point, to yield 8.30 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury bills, rates on three-month bills moved higher in the wake of the Treasury's announcement to sell cash management bills.
 
Three-Month Bill Rates
In late trading, three-month bill rates were offered at a discount rate of 7.24 percent, up seven basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Meanwhile, six-month bill rates fell by one basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.18 percent.
In other developments, late Wednesday the Resolution Trust Corporation said it had selected Salomon Asset Management, a unit of Salomon Inc., as adviser on the liquidation of the agency's $3.3 billion face-value portfolio of high-yield ''junk bonds.''
Salomon, which was one of 23 firms that were vying for the business, was selected on the basis of ''technical competence and cost to the tax-payer,'' the R.T.C. said.
But market participants said they were somewhat surprised by the selection.
''Salomon doesn't really have a lot of expertise in the market, which from the Government's perspective is good, because it means they don't have any conflicts of interest,'' said one high-yield bond trader, who asked not to be identified. ''At the same time, the selection is kind of curious, because they picked guys who are largely unproven.''
The big rise in the stock market yesterday helped to reverse what had been a sharp drop in the price of a number of actively traded high-yield issues. Traders said that for the day prices of most issues were down only modestly from Wednesday's close.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, prices of most actively quoted issues rose by 1/8 point to 1/4 point, participants said.
Elsewhere, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Oct. 8. The narrowest measure, M-1, fell by $6.9 billion.
The money report had no real impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Tumbling Dollar Hits A Low Against the Mark

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled yesterday, breaking though the 1.50 level against the German mark and ending at its lowest level since the mark was created 42 years ago.
The dollar also fell against other major currencies, including the Japanese yen, where it is no longer far from its low of 120.90 reached in November 1988.
Traders said there was no particular event yesterday that pushed down the dollar, which has been falling steadily since the summer. Instead, it appeared that this was the day that the dollar, weighted down by a bevy of negative factors, just finally stumbled under its burden and fell below an important level against the mark. 
 
Decline to 124.40 Yen
In late trading in New York, the dollar ended at 1.4980 marks, down from 1.5124 Wednesday and 11 percent below where the dollar was on June 1. Against the yen, the dollar was at 124.40, down from 125.43 Wednesday and 13 percent below where it was Aug. 29, the day before the Bank of Japan increased its official discount rate to 6 percent.
''There is a temerity in the marketplace,'' said Jeffrey M. Mondschein, manager of foreign exchange at the Continental Bank in Chicago. ''There is little reason to hold on to the dollar.''
Liliana Nealon, vice president for foreign exchange at the Union Bank of Switzerland, said she thought the dollar would continue to fall unless there were some official action by the United States and its allies to stop it. But she said that she did not expect any action and that the economic changes that would support the dollar, like a turnaround in the economy, would not come for some time.
 
Expectation of Recession
Among the factors pushing the dollar down are the expectation of lower interest rates, the expectation of a recession in the United States, a weak stock market and the appearance of Government paralysis, as the White House and the Congress struggle to compromise on a budget and avoid a shutdown of the Federal Government this weekend.
Adding to the negative sentiment is this factor: If there is a budget -which would avoid a Government shutdown and perhaps restore some confidence in the Bush Administration and Congress - traders say they are still likely to sell dollars because such an agreement would heighten the expectation of declining interest rates. The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, has promised such an easing of interest rates if there is what he calls a credible budget agreement to reduce the Federal deficit.
But if there is no budget agreement, then traders say they will sell dollars because of the Government's fiscal mess and a growing lack of confidence in the ability of the President and Congress to deal with the country's severe economic problems.
Traders said that it was likely that the dollar would soon fall to its all-time low against the yen.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New York Times Co. Posts 43.9% Drop in Operating Net

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that income from current operations fell 43.9 percent in the third quarter, to $9.2 million, or 12 cents a share. That compared with operating income of $16.4 million, or 21 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.
Revenue rose 1.3 percent, to $420.7 million, compared with $415.3 million in the 1989 third quarter. 
The company attributed the decline to a drop in advertising linage at the company's main publication, The New York Times, and an increase in expenses for two new printing plants.
The Times also owns 35 regional newspapers, 17 magazines, 5 television and 2 radio stations, information services businesses and has interests in paper mills.
Lisa Donneson, a newspaper analyst at County NatWest, said the earnings were in line with expectations. ''The New York Times linage is off considerably and the regional papers are doing O.K.,'' she said.
 
Lower Ad Linage
The company said advertising linage at The New York Times for the third quarter fell 10.7 percent from last year's third quarter, to 21.1 million lines, reflecting continued weakness in the New York region's economy. Last year's third quarter had one less Sunday than this year's. Many public newspaper companies have reported significant decreases in linage for the quarter.
Circulation for The Times reached record highs for the six months ended Sept. 30, with 1,108,400 copies sold on weekdays, up 40,400 copies from the same 1989 period, and 1,687,000 copies sold on Sundays, up 58,900.
The company also said operating income fell because of increased depreciation and interest expense from the completion of a new production plant for The New York Times in Edison, N.J., and a new plant at The Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News. The depreciation and interest expense reduced earnings by 9 cents a share in the third quarter.
The company said that excluding increased depreciation and interest, 1990 third-quarter earnings from continuing operations would have equaled the same 21 cents a share as in the 1989 quarter.
 
Special Gain Last Year
In the third quarter, the company's net income fell more sharply than profits from current operations. Net income, at $9.2 million, fell 95.6 percent from $210.8 million, or $2.68 cents a share, in the quarter last year, which contained a special gain of $194.4 million from the sale of the NYT Cable TV unit in August 1989.
The newspaper group had operating income of $19.6 million in the third quarter, down 43.7 percent from $34.9 million a year earlier. Revenues increased to $320.6 million, from $316.2 million last year.
The company's magazine group had an operating loss of $2.3 million on revenues of $81.1 million, compared with a loss of $4.5 million on revenues of $81.4 million in the 1989 third quarter. The most recent losses, which were anticipated, were from the costs of acquiring McCall's magazine in July 1989.
The broadcasting and information services group had third-quarter operating income of $3.3 million on revenue of $19.1 million, compared with operating income of $2.6 million on $17.8 million in revenue in the quarter last year.
The company's share in the earnings of the forest products group declined to $2.4 million, compared with $2.6 million in the 1989 third quarter.
The Times Company's stock closed yesterday at $18.625 a share on the American Stock Exchange, down 12.5 cents.

HEADLINE: First Fidelity Profit Up 29%

 BODY:
The First Fidelity Bancorporation, the largest banking company in New Jersey, yesterday announced profits of $70.1 million in the third quarter, its most profitable quarter in two years.
Third-quarter profits, which equaled $1.14 a share, were up nearly 29 percent from $54.4 million, or 87 cents a share, a year ago. 
Although problems with bad loans continue, particularly as a weakening economy causes more problems for borrowers, First Fidelity is benefiting from a cost-cutting program started early this year when it announced plans to reduce its work force by 10 percent, or 1,400 jobs.
In the third quarter, the company set aside $70 million to cover possible losses on bad loans, up from $50.9 million a year ago but well below the $300 million set aside in the second quarter. Operating expenses, for items like salaries, rent and computers, declined $30.2 million, or 12.7 percent, from a year ago.

HEADLINE: Tickets;
Madison Sq. Garden Planning $70 Seats To Pay for Face Lift

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
The owners of Madison Square Garden, which is in the process of an unexpectedly costly overhaul, are preparing a plan for luxury courtside and rinkside seats that could cost as much as $70 apiece for Knicks and Rangers games in the 1991-92 season, according to former executives at the Garden.
The plan, referred to as the ''club'' or ''premium'' seat package, is to be announced to current season ticket-holders after Jan. 1. It would represent a sharp increase in costs for the spectator and perhaps a radical change in the atmosphere at the events as well. The highest ticket price this season is $45, up $10 from last season. Renovation Debt Cited One executive familiar with the plan said the price increases were necessary to help pay off the huge debt incurred by the renovation, which is projected to cost $200 million, twice the original estimate. 
''Obviously they believe there is a segment of the population capable of and prepared to pay that kind of money,'' said one former executive familiar with the plan. ''Whatever, it's still a lot of dough for a ticket,'' he said. And it stands to affect a large number of fans. According to the former officials, the plan as currently devised will involve the upgrading of close to 2,200 courtside or rinkside seats in the building, which holds more than 19,000 fans for basketball games and more than 17,000 for hockey games.
Waitress service, access to the two private clubs under construction, drink trays and larger, reupholstered seats are some of the amenities that would come with the ticket package.
The increased price of the deal, which will likely require the purchase of season tickets for both the Rangers and the Knicks, could force longtime holders of those season tickets to either relocate or abandon them altogether. The former officials said the potential for a backlash from season ticket-holders or corporations was one of the Garden's enduring fears. But, they added, if sales of the ''premium'' seats were good, the Garden plans to consider expanding the luxury section up into a portion of the arena's first promenade.
 
Celebrity Seats, Too
Additonally, according to the former officials, the Garden, which is expected to raise the price of all other seats next season, has plans to expand its allotment of celebrity and promotional courtside seats at Knick games and to sell a portion of them for $300 apiece. These ''v.i.p.'' seats are now distributed free by invitation.
One high-level Garden executive, however, insisted yesterday that the specifics of both plans were still not definite.
''We're not finalized on the plans, and for a lot of reasons,'' said Mike Walker, the Garden's executive vice president for marketing. ''The pricing, for instance, has not been determined. It's not our intent to do anything that would be perceived as taking advantage of any loyal, traditional fans.''
The premium plan, though, follows the recent national trend toward the commercial cultivation of sports events as elite entertainment, a path the Garden, a subsidiary of Paramount Communications, committed itself to when it announced in February 1989 that any plans for relocation had been scotched and that a $100 million renovation would be undertaken of the arena, which was opened in 1968.
''Our objective over all,'' said Mr. Walker, ''was to put the Garden at the top of the list as a major events center.''
 
Atop the Price List
With the proposed increase, the Garden would find itself at the top of the price list for entertainment in the city. At $65 or $70, the ''premium'' seats would outstrip the $26 best seats for a Giants football game. The top price for a Broadway show ticket is $60, although $100 has been announced for a limited number of seats to the musical ''Miss Saigon,'' which is scheduled to open in March.
The Garden's elite seat plan will be outdone only perhaps by the arrangement for Los Angeles Lakers and Kings games at the Great Western Forum in Inglewood, Calif., where 128 prime courtside celebrity-type seats go for $450 each per game. At the Forum, there are also 1,704 designated ''Senate'' seats that cost $90 each and where spectators receive similar v.i.p. treatment.
A handful of arenas across the country offer extremely expensive seats, but these are usually limited in number. In Philadelphia, for example, 118 courtside seats sell for $125. The price for 75 exclusive courtside seats for Nets games at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., is $75.
The ''club'' or ''premium'' seats, as well as the celebrity section at Knicks games, are only a part of extensive designs the Garden has and that it will unveil next fall with the completion of the renovations.
 
A $36 Top in Boston
Corporations are often willing to absorb high ticket prices to sports events for entertainment purposes, but prices in other cities vary. The top prices at the Boston Garden for hockey (Bruins) and basketball (Celtics) are $36 and $34, respectively. In the Detroit area, home of the National Basketball Association champion Pistons at the Palace in suburban Auburn Hills, Mich., the most expensive regular-season seat is $45.
The top ticket in Chicago is $45 for hockey and $25 for pro basketball. In Los Angeles, although the more established Lakers and Kings can command high prices, the top courtside seat for the rival Clippers is $25. The Los Angeles Rams and Raiders of the National Football League each charge $30 In the New York City area, top hockey prices are $28 for the Devils in the Meadowlands and $22.50 for the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum.
At the Garden, the plan includes revamped concession stands, food courts, redone and enlarged restrooms and construction of 88 luxury boxes that encircle the top of the arena and carry a price tag of from $125,000 to $190,000 annually, to be taken for a minimum of three years. 56 Boxes Opened The Garden, which absorbed a net loss of nearly 1,000 arena seats because of the box suites, opened 56 of the boxes this fall. The remaining 32 will be completed by the 1991 season.
There is, though, ample confusion about how briskly the sale of the suites has gone.
''I understand that there are a substantial number of them unsold,'' said one of the former executives.
Mr. Walker, though, maintained that 60 of the 86 available to the public were under contract. ''We're excited by how it's gone so far,'' he said. Asked whether the deteriorating economic climate, with its resulting corporate layoffs and cutbacks, had left the Garden worried about the eventual marketability of luxury seats and expensive skyboxes, Mr. Walker said:
''I don't know if apprehensive is the right word. We're aware of it and sensitive to it. We're reacting to it as any good business would.''

HEADLINE: For an Expert on Tax Code, Bradley Is Strangely Silent

BYLINE: By PETER KERR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
At a time when Washington's politicians and New Jersey's voters are gagging over taxes, Senator Bill Bradley, the architect of the Tax Reform Act of 1986, is barely uttering a word here on the very issue that gained him national attention four years ago.
As Mr. Bradley seeks re-election to a third term, his campaign commercials do not mention his role in his major achievement in office, the Tax Reform Act. Nor has he given a speech in New Jersey or issued a position paper offering solutions to Federal or state fiscal problems.
Despite continued questioning from his Republican opponent, Mr. Bradley refuses to say whether he supports or opposes the $2.8 billion in new taxes pushed through the New Jersey Legislature by his longtime Democratic colleague, Gov. Jim Florio. Where's Bradley? In Washington, meanwhile, some fellow Democrats have questioned why Mr. Bradley, who is often mentioned as a possible Presidential candidate, and who played such a commanding role during the debate over tax reform four years ago, has taken a markedly low profile on taxes this year. 
Just when the nation is desperate for leadership on fiscal policy, they ask, where is Bill Bradley the tax expert?
''For somebody who has cut out a very impressive turf for himself on the tax code,'' said Geoffrey Garin, a leading Democratic poll taker in Washington, ''it is a little surprising that he has not had a front-and-center role on determining what would be a fair tax code in 1990.''
Mr. Bradley points out that this year, unlike 1986, he was not invited into the meetings of Congressional leaders and White House officials in which most budget initiatives were hammered out. In the last week he has made two statements on the Senate floor, attacking new tax concessions for the oil and gas industry and proposals that he said would unfairly increase tax burdens on the middle class.
Nonetheless, his muted voice on taxes this month reflects how Mr. Bradley has been caught in the strange crosscurrents of politics in 1990: the very leadership on fiscal issues in Washington that brought him national attention four years ago is the kind of association with the nation's fiscal mess that risks wrath from irate voters at home.
''It is a delicate position for Bill Bradley,'' said Michael McCurry, a former director of communications for the Democratic National Committee. ''Emotionally and intellectually, he has invested himself in tax reform and tax simplification. But most people are saying: 'My taxes didn't get reformed. My taxes didn't get simpler.' '' Mr. Bradley's bid for a third term is widely assumed to be easily assured for the state's senior Senator, who has raised $12 million to the $1 million of his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman. Polls show him with huge leads.
New Jerseyans, living in a state conscious of its national image, have often expressed a pride in having a Senator who has achieved stature in foreign affairs and the settlement of international debt issues, and who has been described as a possible Democratic Presidential candidate.
 
Concepts Embraced by Reagan
A good deal of the Senator's prominence grew out of his role as a proponent of tax simplification, the idea of broadening the tax base by removing most exemptions and loopholes, and lowering the rate for most taxpayers. He proposed those ideas in his 1984 book, ''The Fair Tax.''
The idea, which was endorsed with some differences by other elected officials, including Representative Jack F. Kemp, was later embraced in concept by the Reagan Administration.
This year, Mr. Bradley's well-financed campaign has stressed the Senator's commitment to children and the environment, and has dismissed attacks by Ms. Whitman, a former president of the State Board of Public Utilities, that he has shied away from leadership on fiscal issues.
Ms. Whitman has charged that Mr. Bradley was late taking a position on the President's tax proposal, and has an obligation to take a stand on the unpopular Florio tax increases, enacted by the Democratic Governor to eliminate a budget deficit and increase school aid to the state's poor cities.
''He hasn't been a leader in the Federal budget process, just as he refused to be a leader in responding to the Florio tax program,'' said Pat Morrisey, a spokesman for the Whitman campaign. ''At the very least you want him to take a firm stand, one way or another.''
In a telephone interview, Mr. Bradley described the Whitman campaign's allegations as unfair, and said he has shown no shyness in discussing his record.
The root of the current Federal budget crisis, he said, was the Reagan tax cuts of 1981, which Mr. Bradley voted against. The 1986 Tax Reform Act made for a more rational process of investments in the American economy and greater economic efficiency.
''I believe the Tax Reform Act of 1986 is a reason why we did not have a recession,'' Mr. Bradley said.
 
Refused to Comment on Kean
He said he had chosen not to include tax reform in his television commercials because the topic was too complex to explain quickly. As for the Florio tax plan, he maintains it is inappropriate for him to comment on state tax issues because he is running for Federal office.
In 1982, Mr. Bradley said, he also refused to comment on the tax increases of Gov. Thomas H. Kean, a Republican.
Mr. Bradley was also the subject of some grumbling among Democrats on Capitol Hill who said he was less than enthusiastic in suppport of recent Democratic initiatives to raise taxes substantially for affluent taxpayers.
But aides to Mr. Bradley said that many Democrats had misunderstood his position on taxing the affluent, after a vote in the Senate Finance Committee on Oct. 12. Mr. Bradley voted against that measure, they said, because it was tied to a cut in the capital gains tax and ''new loopholes for the oil and gas industry,'' not because he opposed higher taxes on the rich.
''On the one hand, you say the way you want to increase taxes is raise the rates, which I would support,'' Mr. Bradley said. ''But don't get into a bogus increase, through special interest loopholes.''
In a vote on Thursday, Mr. Bradley supported an amendment to a bipartisan budget package by Senator Albert Gore that would have raised taxes on the wealthy and used the revenue to limit the increase in the gasoline tax and reduce cuts in Medicare benefits.
Mr. Bradley then voted against the budget package, saying it would spend too much on defense and place too much of a burden on families earning $20,000 to $40,000 a year.

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
TAX RISE FOR RICH IS SEEN AS A PART OF A BUDGET DEAL

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
President Bush went to Capitol Hill today to rally Republicans around a plan that would cut the Federal budget deficit without raising income tax rates. But House and Senate negotiators predicted that a final budget deal would likely include some increase in income taxes on the wealthy, as well as a rise in gasoline taxes.
After speaking privately with Congressional leaders, the President met with the 23 Republicans who helped push a White House-backed bipartisan budget proposal to passage in the Senate early this morning.
But senators who attended the session said Mr. Bush had not explicitly discussed what he could and could not accept from a conference committee that is trying to reconcile the Senate plan with a rival version that the House passed on party-line votes Tuesday. 
 
Stopgap Measure Signed
Hours after his Capitol Hill visit, the President tonight, as expected, bowed to pressure from both Democrats and members of his own party and signed a stopgap spending bill to keep the Government running through midnight next Wednesday, 24 days after the beginning of a fiscal year that still has no budget law.
An earlier stopgap measure was due to expire at midnight tonight, and Republican leaders had warned the President that forcing another Government shutdown like the one two weeks ago would be politically damaging to their party and only sour the atmosphere for reaching a final budget compromise.
 
Differences in Approach
The House and Senate versions of the budget vary in a number of significant ways, among them a proposal for increases in the income tax rate for the well-to-do, a provision that is included in the House's plan but not in the Senate's. The House version would increase the tax for those with the highest income from its current flat rate of 28 percent to a marginal rate of 33 percent, a level that Mr. Bush has said he cannot accept. The White House has been less explicit as to whether a smaller increase would be acceptable, and a number of Republican lawmakers have said they would be willing to accept a rate of 31 percent if Mr. Bush would go along.
Meanwhile, the Senate's plan, unlike the House's, provides for an increase in the Federal gasoline tax, by 9.5 cents a gallon, to a total of 18.5 cents. Opponents of this provision declare that it would hit far too hard at the middle class.
While the two houses have adopted very different approaches to raising new revenue, negotiators of both parties said today that the compromise would almost certainly include some increase in the gasoline tax, a surtax on incomes of over $1 million and some limits on deductions for high-income taxpayers.
But the most contentious issue is whether to raise the 28 percent income tax rate and, if so, by how much. The White House and many Congressional Republicans argue that an increase in the rate on the wealthy - for families in which the parents file jointly, the increase would affect those earning about $200,000 or more - would inevitably lead in time to further rate increases and to pressure for Congress to reopen loopholes it closed four years ago when it adopted the Tax Reform Act.
''I think the Administration position is much tougher on rates than it is on the surtax,'' said Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the House Budget Committee. ''Since we are going to have to pass this with Democratic votes in the House, everyone knows that the compromise has got to be closer to the House position. The question is, How close?''
 
'Have to Persuade the House'
But the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, who is a senior member of the Finance Committee, warned that negotiators had little room to deviate from the plan passed in the Senate if they hoped to win enough votes in that chamber for the final compromise.
''If we go much from this in either direction, the bill might not pass the Senate,'' he said. ''We have to persuade the House to accept the Senate bill.''
Mr. Dole, who hoped to strengthen the Senate's bargaining position in conference, worked feverishly on Thursday night and into this morning to get a majority of the Senate's 45 Republicans to vote for the bipartisan plan worked out by Senate leaders. He succeeded, but with only a one-vote margin and only after help from Mr. Bush in persuading Utah's two Senators -Jake Garn and Orrin G. Hatch, both Republicans - to switch their votes at the last minute from ''no'' to ''yes.''
 
President Noncommittal
After the President's visit to Capitol Hill today, Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee and a member of the conference team, said, ''He was neither optimistic nor pessimistic, but realistic, about what he hoped we could accomplish.''
Mr. Bush was no more explicit in brief comments to reporters as he made his rounds at the Capitol, insisting that the visit was not intended to signal anything more than a desire to move the budget process forward.
''I think people recognize that more important than any individual getting it exactly his way, including the President, is to get the nation's business completed, and that means getting a deal,'' Mr. Bush said. ''I'd like to move, and I hope we can convince some who have not understood that broad picture that that's what we have to do.''
Nearly two-thirds of the tax increases and spending cuts that make up the five-year deficit reduction of $500 billion sought by both houses falls within the jurisdiction of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. Negotiators from those panels are hoping that their work can be completed by Sunday night and that a final budget package can be presented to the House and the Senate for votes next week.
In addition to the increase in the tax rate for those of highest income, the plan that the House adopted earlier this week with only minimal Republican support would impose a 10 percent surtax on those earning more than $1 million a year and would avoid cuts in the Medicare program that are as deep as those called for in the Senate plan, slashes that are unpopular in both parties. But to avoid any increase in the current 9-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax, the House plan would impose a one-year freeze on inflation adjustments in tax brackets and tax exemptions.
Congressional Republicans and the White House have said this freeze would be a direct hit on all working families, but many Democrats have argued that it would be less of a burden than increasing the gasoline tax.
''We're certainly expecting something where the flavor of the House bill will come through,'' said Representative Jim Moody, a liberal Democrat from Wisconsin and a member of the Ways and Means Committee. ''It certainly should be, since we are going to have to carry it.''

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1990, Saturday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A front-page headline in some copies on Saturday about Federal budget negotiations misstated President Bush's position on taxes. Mr. Bush was taking a position against increases in income tax rates, not against all tax increases.

HEADLINE: Sisters Have Special Duty to Reflect Catholic Abortion Position

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Anna Quindlen, in ''The Nuns' Story'' (column, Sept. 16), cites the case of two former religious sisters asked to resign from their congregation because they signed an advertisement in The New York Times supporting the possibility of abortion.
As Ms. Quindlen and the two former sisters would say, ''Tell me about it.'' As members of religious congregations of the Roman Catholic Church, religious sisters have a special obligation to reflect the example and teaching of Jesus. Jesus certainly repeated the commandment in the Law of Moses, ''Thou shalt not kill,'' and both Scripture and early Christian leaders were consistent in including abortion - the direct taking of innocent human life in the womb - as falling under that commandment. 
Other sisters, such as Mother Teresa, have chosen to show the love of Jesus both for mothers and for the children to whom they have given birth under difficult circumstances. The decision to take innocent human life, no matter how well intentioned, cannot be a sign of compassion; caring for both mother and child is.
We would hope that all people would recognize the right to life of unborn children, which was reflected in the oath of Hippocrates followed by doctors for more than 2,500 years. We would hope that religious sisters, in particular, would accept not only this wisdom of the ages but also the teaching of Jesus, to whom they have pledged their lives.
It is in the service of the poor, of the sick and of the little ones so loved by Jesus that thousands of religious women in the United States have distinguished themselves for centuries, exercising full responsibility for networks of hospitals, schools, orphanages and homes for the aged long before women in other segments of American society could hold similar positions of fiscal and administrative responsibility.
Is the Catholic Church un-American? It has members of every race, ethnic group, social background and economic standing in the country. Its schools are open to members not only of all races but also of all creeds in American inner cities, where they offer that unique opportunity for success in a democracy, a quality education. Its hospitals, orphanages and homes are open to all regardless of creed. Historically, its members have served in the armed forces in numbers beyond the percentage of their presence in American society.
The Catholic Church believes what almost all Americans once believed - that the right to life, endowed by the Creator, is inalienable and that there is an authority beyond that of the majority, as expressed in our pledge of allegiance to the flag, ''one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justics for all.''(Most Rev.)
 
JOHN P. FOLEY
Archbishop-President, Pontifical
Council for Social Communications
 Vatican City, Oct. 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Don't Let Redwoods Fall to Corporate Greed;
A Global Resource

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The attempt to ''save the rain forests'' is largely a futile campaign owing to a confused idea of property rights. Having collected medicinal plants in some tropical regions since 1969, I write with the knowledge that independent countries do not want outsiders like United States environmental organizations telling them how best to utilize their resources.
Various forestry and resource administrators argue that they owe their people the best possible standard of living and that hardwood is their commodity to sell on world markets. Aside from the fact that too many of these officials are often the principal recipients of most of the revenue from the sale of these desirable woods, as in Sarawak, this argument is flawed on another level. 
The Malaysian Government, for example, has told the indigenous nomads of Sarawak that they have no claim to the land, that it is owned by the Government. The nomads cannot understand how they can be forced to leave forests they and their ancestors have inhabited since the beginning of their oral histories.
Herein lies the solution. We can argue that just as governments claim that nomads have no authentic territorial claim to the rain forests, neither do they! Mere possession of land does not necessarily make an adequate claim to ownership.
In the case of the world's remaining rain forests, where a good percentage of the earth's oxygen is generated, we might claim them as a global, not a national, resource. The shortsighted exploitation of a rain forest like that of Sarawak - a 160-million-year-old ecosystem that has been decimated by 50 percent in only a few decades and will be gone forever in another 10 years - is not the right of any country. By destroying this ecosystem, the Malaysian Government is destroying one of the planet's primary survival pumps. We the outsiders whose existence is affected by the destructive actions of a few greedy individuals or countries have every right to insist that such decimation be halted.
Oxygen belongs to the plant, not to countries. If we send our troops to defend the world's oil supply, arguing that global economic health is at stake, surely we can do the same to protect global survival on a health level.
 
MICHAEL WEINER
Exec. Dir., Fund for Ethnic Medicine
 Larkspur, Calif., Oct. 8, 1990

TYPE: Letter

LENGTH: 350 words

HEADLINE: High School Buildings, and Structure

 BODY:
A task force appointed by New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, concludes that a slowdown in construction and poor management of space has caused overcrowding in many high schools. The panel recommends a number of short-term and long-term solutions. Fine, but while Mr. Fernandez is at it, the whole structure of high school education needs thorough review. 
The task force found that the average city high school is used at 111 percent of capacity, chiefly because of a 10-year hiatus in school construction and cutbacks in funding in the last fiscal crisis. While overcrowding exists throughout the system, the panel focused on high schools because the Chancellor controls them directly.
Most students attend neighborhood high schools that offer comprehensive or academic programs. A handful offer enriched or magnet programs in specialized areas. But many schools are trying to serve such large, diverse populations that they lose students to anonymity and apathy.
For immediate relief at the most severely crowded schools, the task force recommends capping enrollments and moving administrators out of classrooms. For the long term, however, the panel suggests that Mr. Fernandez think about how high school education ought to be structured.
To that end, he might consider a new Rand Corporation study called ''High Schools with Character.'' The study included an intensive examination of eight New York City high schools, public and parochial, that largely serve disadvantaged youths.
Students at six Catholic and special purpose schools, called ''focus'' schools, were more successful than students in two zoned high schools. Why? Mainly because the focus schools had a central sense of mission and strong organizational structures. The zoned schools, by contrast, had diffuse missions that were defined largely by outsiders.
Mr. Fernandez's major initiative, school-based management, ought to help more schools achieve the coherence lauded in the Rand study. But the challenge is to see how reorganizing the space in high schools can create an environment for success.

HEADLINE: Soviet Capitalism? First, Stability

 BODY:
The biggest news in Mikhail Gorbachev's newest economic reform plan may not be economic at all but political. What started out as a 500-day plan to overturn Communism and install capitalism is now an 000-day plan, without deadlines or even a timetable. And his program makes clear that he's ready to rule by decree, if necessary, to restore order and compel change. 
The title of his plan, which the Soviet Parliament has just endorsed, puts first things first: ''The Main Directions for the Stabilization of the People's Economy and the Transition to a Market Economy.''
As the apparatus of command breaks down and the Soviet economy teeters on the edge of collapse, he understandably wants to put goods on store shelves. But decrees aren't likely to do that. This could become a tough winter indeed for the Soviet Union, and Americans may wind up not only as concerned observers but also as participants. Everywhere in the Soviet Union, people talk about the pace of reform. Some republics, like Russia and the Baltics, want to move fast; others, like Kirghizia and Turkmenia in Central Asia, oppose haste. But the real struggle is over control. Mr. Gorbachev would keep authority over banking, transportation, communication and foreign trade, all critical to economic change. Boris Yeltsin and others would devolve it to the republics.
As they grapple, the ramshackle Soviet economy is buckling. Individuals and enterprises, lacking incentives to produce, stop working. Hoarding, hijacking, strikes and blockades keep goods from getting to market. And governments at all levels try to hold onto goods. This winter, cities may run short of food and fuel.
That's why Mr. Gorbachev got the Soviet Parliament to strengthen his power of decree. His proposal to Parliament says, ''Transition to market relations and their effective functioning are possible only under conditions of a strong and clearly organized state power.''
He also declared that, ''In the first instance, it is necessary to use to the maximum the special powers granted recently to the President by the Supreme Soviet.'' In Moscow, there's serious talk of martial law. He may try to use troops to open blocked roads and railways, break up strikes and compel goods to come to market.
But it's a contradiction for Mr. Gorbachev to take command of markets. The same apparatchiks who have tried to strangle economic reform may use his special powers to perpetuate theirs. And he'd do well not to invoke martial law against rebellious republics. From Lithuania to Azerbaijan, wherever troops have been called out, they've only inflamed nationalism.
Americans understand the need for Federal intervention in an economic emergency. U.S. Presidents intervened when coal, steel or rail strikes threatened to shut down factories and chill homes. But force can't hold the Soviet Union together; only functioning markets can.
The bitter question remains: Can Mr. Gorbachev force goods to market before privation drives Soviet citizens to fury? That's where America might come in. Timely aid from abroad in the form of food and fuel could ease his predicament. That's something for Western governments to plan for now, before the Soviet winter.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Congress Sets Tentative Pact on Immigration Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Congressional negotiators said tonight that they had reached a tentative agreement on a bill that would allow a substantial increase in legal immigration to the United States.
The bill would allow 700,000 immigrants a year in 1992, 1993 and 1994 and would set an annual limit of 675,000 for subsequent years. The United States has been admitting about 500,000 immigrants a year, not counting refugees. 
Representative Bruce A. Morrison, a Connecticut Democrat who is chairman of the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, said: ''We have reached an agreement over all on the bill. There are details still to be worked out. But the basic outline of the bill is agreed to.''''
 
Labor Shortages Expected
Under the compromise bill, the United States would admit more skilled immigrants, including scientists, engineers and medical technicians, to compensate for expected shortages in the 1990's. Congress, the Labor Department and many economists see legal immigration as a way to correct the imbalance in labor supply and demand.
The tentative agreement was unexpected. The Senate passed a version of the legislation last year, and the House passed a major bill on Oct. 3. But disagreements among some lawmakers were so profound that the Senate refused to send members into formal negotiations with the House.
After four hours of informal talks today, senators and representatives agreed on the outline of a compromise bill. They plan to convene a formal conference committee over the weekend or early next week.
The bill sets the total number of immigrants between the numbers specifed in the Senate bill, 630,000 a year, and the House bill, 775,000.
 
Relatives and Skilled Workers
Under the compromise, the 700,000 immigrants permitted in each of the first three years would be chosen as follows: 465,000 would be relatives of United States citizens and permanent resident aliens; 140,000 would be selected because of their job skills, and 40,000 would come from countries that have sent relatively few immigrants here in recent years.
Mr. Morrison also said that in each of the first three years there would be 55,000 visas for spouses and children of illegal aliens who gained legal status under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986.
In 1995 and later years, the 675,000 visas would be distributed as follows: 480,000 to relatives of citizens and permanent resident aliens; 140,000 to workers with special skills and their relatives, and 55,000 to citizens of countries that have sent relatively few immigrants here in recent years.
Mr. Morrison said he believed the conference ''will be smooth sailing.''
But Rick Swartz, an immigration lawyer in Washington, said: ''It is possible that major ethnic and religious constituencies will find the direction of negotiations and the apparent agreement on family issues unacceptable.''

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
Reading Lips of the Rich: Spending, Not Taxes, Is the Problem

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS

 BODY:
As the halls of Congress reverberated with partisan slogans about ''soaking the rich'' and ''making the rich pay a fair share of taxes,'' some of America's millionaires were shaking their heads and saying that Washington politicians were all wet.
A dozen millionaires, chosen at random from among the nation's executives who had time to answer the telephone over the past few days, said that Washington was hopelessly out of touch with them and many of their high-income friends.
Nine of the 12 businessmen said it would be fair to raise their taxes, although at the same time they said the Government should be more serious about holding down spending. Only three opposed a greater contribution from the rich, saying the Government could cure the deficit by shrinking its operations.
 
Investment Banker's View
''If they are going to raise taxes on the wealthy, which I am absolutely not opposed to at all, they should also be drastically cutting spending on things like defense and increasing funding for things like education and the environment,'' said Leonard I. Green, an investment banker in Los Angeles who said his annual income exceeds $1 million. 
The comments of Mr. Green and his 11 peers do not represent a scientific sampling of high-income people, but their views erode the stereotypes of the rich being greedy tax-dodgers or captains of industry whose only motivation for expansion is that it fills their pockets and not Uncle Sam's.
Who are the rich? Do they pay their fair share of Federal taxes?
The questions are hard to answer, in part, because fairness is a subjective concept and, in part, because richness is too. An income that puts a family squarely in the middle class in New York or San Francisco, for example, might put them near the top of the heap in a small town in the Midwest.
 
Proposals Being Considered
The House and Senate budget proposals cut different slices off the pile: One House proposal would impose a 10 percent surtax on all taxable income above $1 million, which would have affected about 65,000 taxpayers in 1988. The House would also extend the 33 percent marginal tax rate to all high-income taxpayers and increase the minimum tax paid to 25 percent from 21 percent. The Senate has no such provisions, but it would limit itemized deductions.
Exactly how these proposals would affect the rich is not known, but it is clear there are a lot more people that can reasonably be defined as rich than there were 10 years ago.
Wealth has come so suddenly to so many people that they themselves cannot believe it, said John J. DeMarco, senior vice president of PSI, a Tampa, Fla., research organization that monitors the habits and attitudes of affluent consumers in frequent surveys.
 
Surge in Millionaires
''Most rich people don't think they're rich; they say: 'Me? Rich? That's somebody else. Not me,' '' Mr. DeMarco said. In the last four years, he said the number of millionaires doubled to 1.8 million from 900,000. PSI's definition of a millionaire is an individual or family whose assets, excluding a primary home, exceed debts by more than $1 million. Forbes magazine published its list of America's 400 richest people this month, noting that since 1982 their fortunes have tripled, to an average of $682 million from an average of $230 million; all told, the 400 now have $272.5 billion in assets.
The national growth in wealth was stimulated in part, experts say, by President Ronald Reagan's tax revisions, including the 1986 law that significantly lowered tax rates in exchange for eliminating most deductions.
''The Affluence Explosion,'' a marketing report put out last year by Alert Publishing in New York, summarizes surveys and marketing research on the wealthy, and paints this statistical portrait of the typical millionaire:
He (the majority are men) is a 57-year-old white business owner - a college graduate who has been married for 32 years, has two grown children, works 10 to 14 hours a day, six days a week and earns $120,000 a year. Only one in five inherited their money.
 
Spectrum of Viewpoints
As the middle class surged into the brackets of wealth in the 1980's, they brought their middle-class values and opinions with them. Apart from listing to starboard - a plurality of 47 percent of the wealthy are Republicans - affluent people hold political views that are representative of America as a whole, according to 500 interviews with wealthy people around the nation by Louis Harris and Associates in 1987. Forty percent identified themselves as conservatives, 40 percent called themselves middle-of-the-road and 20 percent said they were liberals.
''Politically they are becoming less party-affiliated, less doctrinaire, and are looking for what works,'' concludes the Alert report. ''They are less 'big government' but want the homeless housed and the environment improved, and they want the Federal Government to do it.''
Those sentiments were repeatedly echoed in interviews with the wealthy executives.
''If we could trade significantly higher taxes for a more optimistic outlook on where this country is going, we would be happy to pay,'' said Eugene M. Lang, who made his first million by inventing a screwlike device in 1948 that holds airplanes and automobiles together. He has since given $25 million to colleges and started a widely copied program that pays college tuition for inner-city children. ''I am more concerned about how the money is going to be spent,'' said Mr. Lang.
 
'You Can Afford to Pay More'
Noel D. Ginsberg, a millionaire who owns a plastics company in Denver, said any tax rise should be considerably higher for high-income people than for middle-income people - not because the higher rate would bring in so much money, but because it would restore confidence in the nation's tax system. ''I am not a tax accountant, so I don't know if the rich are paying their fair share, but if you're making over $150,000 or $200,000 as I am, you can afford to pay more,'' he said.
Nonetheless, when it comes to the topic of fairness and taxes, people's attitudes are warped by emotion and self-interest, said Howard J. Kogan, a Manhattan psychotherapist. ''The psychology is always the same: 'My money is more precious and needed by me than your money is to you,' '' he said.
Some other experts, like Dr. Thomas J. Stanley, a marketing consultant and author of ''Marketing to the Affluent'' (Dow Jones Irwin, 1988), say that most high-income people are paying their fair share of taxes, but argue that high-income people with extraordinary wealth are not paying anything close to a fair tax bill.
''It's absurd that Congress is talking about raising taxes for somebody who might make $100,000 or $200,000 in a good year, when they aren't talking about taxing the 100,000 households with net worths exceeding $15 million,'' said Dr. Stanley, noting that the really wealthy can find ways to minimize their taxable income, while those simply have a good year must report their income and pay their taxes.
A close observer of multimillionaires, Robin D. Leach, host of the television program ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,'' confirmed that the people on his program would not notice the taxes being discussed in Washington. ''They won't bat an eyelid,'' he said. ''It is nonsense. It's a cosmetic tax that only looks as though it's penalizing the rich.'' However, he opposes any tax that would cause them to bat eyelids, saying that would be a move towards socialism.
 
Wealth, Taxes and the Rich
The Internal Revenue Service's latest statistics show that in 1987 1 percent of the nation's population held 36 percent of the nation's wealth, up from 27 percent of the wealth in 1973, according to marketers' estimates based on the Census Bureau's reports. The Bush Administration says the tax burden on that the wealthiest 1 percent has sharply increased to about 27 percent of the total income tax in 1988, up from 18 percent in 1981.
But Kevin P. Phillips, author of ''The Politics of Rich and Poor,'' (Random House, 1990), said in an interview that the rich are paying more taxes because their share of national income almost doubled to 15 percent from 8 percent in the same period. ''It is not that the rich are burdened unduly,'' he said, ''it is just that they have more of the money.''
Robert David Lion Gardiner, speaking from his home in Palm Beach, captured the sorry state of the economy in an anecdote about the Ritz-Carlton in Paris charging $24 for a martini. He attributed the dollar's decline against other currencies to the failure of Congress and President Bush to rein in Federal spending. Mr. Gardiner, whose family owns Gardiners Island in Long Island Sound, said his family's money was ''old when George Washington stayed with us.''
Although he is worried that higher taxes could spark a severe recession, he conceded that it was a ''legitimate criticism'' to say the wealthy are not paying enough taxes. He said he would go along with higher taxes, adding, jovially, ''I'm for the fairness thing.''
 
Opposition to Tax Increase
George F. Kettle, who owns the Century 21 franchise for several Mid-Atlantic states, was among the minority of millionaires interviewed who opposed tax increases on the wealthy. While he would not say how much he made in 1989, he added: ''I paid $1.2 million in taxes last year and I think that is a fair share to pay. If you increase taxes and redistribute the money to the poor, that will take the work incentive away from the poor and take away the incentives for the rich to build motels and businesses that provide jobs and health benefits.''
Another opponent of higher income taxes, Peter M. Flanigan, said: ''Anybody who says that the rich are paying a lesser share of taxes doesn't know what he's talking about.'' Mr. Flanigan, a wealthy investment banker in New York, was an economics adviser to President Richard M. Nixon. ''If there have to be tax increases, the least distorting taxes are consumption taxes,'' Mr. Flanigan said, referring to proposed excise taxes on things like gasoline and cigarettes.
Ralph E. Ablon earned $2.2 million last year as chairman of the board of directors of the Ogden Corporation, a New York-based conglomerate in the food service and waste disposal industries.
He said he supported a tax increase for high-income people if it were part of a serious effort to reduce the Federal deficit and not simply part of the current ''comic opera performance'' in Washington.
None of the millionaires interviewed had anything nice to say about Congress or President Bush, but Mr. Ablon offered this on the bright side: ''The really marvelous thing about our form of government is that it is designed to survive mediocre leadership.''

LENGTH: 1746 words

HEADLINE: Drive to Organize Virginia Food Stores Is a Pivotal Test of Labor's Future

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va.

 BODY:
A young woman in a cashier's smock walks out of a Farm Fresh supermarket and ambles by Juanita Fridley and Chad Young, union organizers, who are sitting on a bench against the wall of the store. The woman buys a Pepsi from a machine and, warily, she walks back toward the organizers. She lets them catch her eye.
''Are you on your break?'' Mr. Young asks.
''Yes,'' the woman says. ''You the union?'' 
They say they are. They invite her to join them on the bench, but she declines. ''Apprehensive about talking to us here?'' Ms. Fridley asks. The woman nods. But she writes down her name and phone number and invites them to visit her at home.
''If you're just a worker and management wants to get rid of you, they scheme something up,'' Ms. Fridley said. ''The workers are frightened of management. They're frightened of us. They're afraid of losing their jobs.'' If workers are anxious, said Michael E. Julian, president of Farm Fresh Inc., it is the union that is stirring the pot. ''Our employees, the ones I talk to, repeatedly ask, 'When are these people going to go away and quit bothering us?' '' he said.
The fear, whatever its cause, runs through much of this membership drive, one of organized labor's biggest in years, now in its seventh month. The United Food and Commercial Workers Union, the nation's second largest after the Teamsters, is trying to enroll supermarket workers throughout the Tidewater region of eastern Virginia.
 
Test of Labor's Future
The campaign puts the eternal conflict between labor and management in uncommonly stark relief. The long-withering labor movement sees the drive as an important, high-visibility, test of its future in the American economy. The supermarket chains face pressures that have already driven several competitors to the grave. Neither side has much room to give.
Ms. Fridley, Mr. Young and 50-some other organizers of Local 400 of the 1.3-million-member union are courting 7,000 employees of the region's 52 Farm Fresh supermarkets and 43 stores of two smaller chains in the region, Bonnie Be-Lo Markets and Marketplace Foods. The organizers want to add them to the 16 unionized Super Fresh stores, similar in name to Farm Fresh but owned by the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company. Super Fresh's slightly higher wages and better benefits put it at a disadvantage in competing with nonunion stores.
In the Tidewater area, most supermarket employees are among the working poor - the nearly three million people who last year worked full time and still earned too little to stay out of poverty, according to the Census Bureau. The Federal poverty level for a family of four is an income below $12,000 a year.
A Farm Fresh computer printout that a union organizer obtained lists 184 people hired or rehired during three weeks in July and August. It shows that 51 started work for wages from the $3.80-an-hour Federal minimum wage to $3.99, and that 93 started at $4 to $4.49. Just three people, who had special skills and years of experience, started at $6 or more.
 
Two-Thirds Are Women
About two-thirds of the supermarket workers here are women, many of them single mothers or their families' sole source of support. Three-quarters of the Farm Fresh workers are permanent part-timers because the chain says it needs most workers only in prime shopping time, 4 to 9 P.M. Most part-timers earn $4 to $5 an hour and none receive health or pension benefits.
Full-timers, who tend to keep their jobs longer than part-timers and therefore earn a dollar or two more each hour on average, are offered health insurance and pension benefits. But many reject it because they have to pay part of the cost.
In the parking lots outside the stores, some workers steer wide circles around the union organizers. The organizers say Farm Fresh has called in the police to arrest them for violating its rule against approaching workers within 50 feet of a store. Four organizers were jailed but the courts dismissed the charges.
Few workers would agree to interviews with a reporter; fewer still would give their names. An exception was Paula Hayes, a 25-year-old single mother of two children.
A full-time employee, Ms. Hayes said she was paid $5.50 an hour and got a little support from her children's fathers but still struggles. She said she could not afford a home of her own, so she shared an apartment with another single mother. Each pays $221 a month rent.
One of Ms. Hayes' weekly pay stubs shows take-home pay of $176.71. Until a few weeks ago, Ms. Hayes said she was having around $50 a week deducted to provide health insurance for herself and her children. But she said she had to drop the children's coverage to make ends meet and now paid $13.10 to cover herself. She deducts $1 for charity.
Ms. Hayes said she liked her work. ''I'm an office supervisor,'' she said. ''I work in the back. I count all the money in the store. The cashiers come back with their tills. I tell them to count the money first, and then I count it.''
But she said she wanted a union, partly for the higher pay and better benefits that the it might negotiate from management. Even though she is an office supervisor, she said, ''most of the cashiers make what I make.''
She and a colleague said their supervisors trid to give them two consecutive days off some weeks but they never know whether that would happen, or which two days they would be, until their schedules were posted the Friday before the following week, making it hard to plan for their children's care.
Other workers see unions differently. ''I've been in a union,'' said Betty Ruiz, a consumer service representative at a Farm Fresh store in Norfolk. ''They never did show me anything. This time I'm not interested.''
At the unionized store where she worked previously, she said, ''they took money out of my paycheck'' - union dues that here would come to about $5 a week. She said management raised wages after negotiations with the union, then dismissed some workers.
''I made more money,'' she said, ''but I also worked harder.''
No one here attributes workers' poverty solely to management's frugality. The performance of the nation's economy in the 1980's required more families to put two people to work. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that nationally, average hourly wages have fallen 12.6 percent from a peak of $8.63 in 1973 to $7.54 currently, after taking inflation into account.
The corporate takeover wars took a toll, too. Farm Fresh is making payments on the $285 million it borrowed to thwart a hostile takeover in 1987, so it is losing money and would be hard pressed to raise wages even if it were willing. And Safeway Stores Inc. closed or sold its Tidewater stores, all unionized, to raise money to reduce the debt it amassed in averting a takeover.
In part because of the ground it lost with Safeway's withdrawal, the labor establishment has a big stake in this drive. Membership in unions has shrunk from a quarter of the work force in the early 1950's to 16.4 percent.
Unions have lost members with the erosion of industrial jobs, although they have been capturing new members in Government and in services, like retailing. Last year, the National Labor Relations Board said, unions won 50 percent of their organizing campaigns, the highest level of the 1980's.
Here, the Food and Commercial Workers Union, one of the more successful organizers, has an opportunity to establish a base from which to mount campaigns deeper into the largely nonunion, low-wage South.
If the union fails, on the other hand, it could endanger A&P's Super Fresh, because it alone would continue to pay higher labor costs to its unionized staff.
 
Potential Large Competitor
Further, both Local 400 and the three chains are looking over their shoulders at Food Lion Inc., a 675-store, nonunion Southeastern chain based in Salisbury, N.C., that is thought to be planning a northward expansion into the Tidewater region and beyond. A multibillion-dollar business that dwarfs the Tidewater chains, Food Lion could have the muscle to drive down wages and prices, pushing out both the union and competitors.
But if the union succeeds, the prevailing wage in the Tidewater market rise and Food Lion would find it harder to find people to work at its rates.
''No question, it's high-stakes poker,'' said Thomas R. McNutt, president of Local 400. ''This is our last potential beachhead for a highly organized South.''
The union's first objective here is signatures on beige, three-by-five cards authorizing the union to represent the workers in negotiations. Federal labor rules require cards signed by 30 percent of an employer's workers to let them vote on whether to make a union their bargaining agent.
Mr. McNutt said the local has already spent more than $1 million on the campaign since it started in April and that he is prepared for the long haul. He said he had just signed a contract on about 30 motel rooms to house the organizers until 1992.
Management seems just as determined. ''My responsibility as chief executive of this company is to find a way to satisfy the needs of our customers and at the same time satisfy the needs of our employees,'' Mr. Julian said. He said he could cut prices to draw hordes of shoppers but would have to chop wages and drive away workers. Or he could double prices and wages and drive away shoppers.
He said he does not need a union to help him find the balance. ''I'm never going to sign a contractual agreement that makes us unable to compete,'' Mr. Julian said.
He said he will be raising wages regularly without significant price increases by raising the stores' productivity - getting employees to work better or harder, or investing in machinery to help them do more work.
In this campaign, neither side has deployed the gun-wielding goons of old organizing drives. They pit lawyers against lawyers, slogan against slogan. Management plays on the workers' fears of losing jobs to strikes; the union plays on fears of management's power over wages, hiring and firing.
The union is concentrating on the fearful. ''They fear if they sign, something will happen to them,'' said the campaign's newest organizer, Karen Gompers, 27.
Presumably, Ms. Gompers lends the union a genetic edge. She is the the great-great grandniece of Samuel Gompers, father of the 20th century American labor movement. The union discovered her last summer waiting on tables in Virginia Beach.

She joined Chad Young, a fellow United Food and Commercial Workers Union organizer, in an effort to recruit members outside a Farm Fresh supermarket in Norfolk, Va. (Tim Wright for The New York Times)
