HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Bush Describes Himself as 'Determined' on Kuwait

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he was as determined as ever to force President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait.
Speaking to Italian-American leaders at the White House this morning, Mr. Bush rejected talk of concessions to Mr. Hussein.
''I'm determined as I was the day that the first troop left that Saddam Hussein's aggression not be rewarded by some compromise,'' he said. ''Not be rewarded by our failing to get him totally out of Kuwait or restore the legitimate rulers.'' 
The President reiterated this stance later in a private talk with Yevgeny M. Primakov, a member of the Soviet Presidential Council who was recently sent to Iraq by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis with President Hussein.
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said the President had told Mr. Primakov that ''there is no interest, either on the part of the United States or the international community, for any partial solution to the blatant aggression that Iraq has perpetrated against Kuwait.'' The two men talked for an hour and 20 minutes, an hour longer than scheduled.
 
Fate of Hostages Discussed
Mr. Bush stressed to the top Soviet official that ''the international community was prepared to consider alternative options'' if the United Nations economic sanctions and diplomacy fail to persuade Mr. Hussein to end his occupation of Kuwait.
''The President's resolve was firm and firmly expressed,'' Mr. Fitzwater said.
A top Administration official said that contrary to rumors about a Soviet compromise to settle the standoff, Mr. Primakov had come ''with no plans whatsoever.'' The two men reviewed the status of the crisis, the official said, and Mr. Primakov expressed his concern about the fate of thousands of Soviet citizens in Iraq, noting that the Soviets have won permission from President Hussein to get 1,500 of them released.
Mr. Bush urged the Soviets to hold fast on sanctions, telling Mr. Primakov that American-Soviet cooperation has been a key factor in isolating the Iraqi leader.
Speaking to reporters through an interpreter after the White House meeting, Mr. Primakov said he had not brought the President a message from Mr. Hussein.
 
'I Am Not a Messenger'
''No message from Saddam Hussein, because I am not a messenger, you know,'' he said in Russian.
He added, ''I believe we should not rule out the possibilities of a peaceful solution until we have exhausted all options.''
Administration officials said that the meeting was important less for its substance than its signals. They said the meeting sent a signal to President Hussein that the Soviets and the United States continue to maintain a united front based on the United Nations Security Council resolutions.
Officials said they hoped that the meeting would dispel rumors emanating from the Middle East that the Soviets wanted to promote a settlement that would reward Iraq for withdrawing from Kuwait.
At the State Department today, the spokesman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, was asked if there were any signs that Iraq was willing to compromise. ''Not that I'm aware of,'' she said.
 
Baker Urges Support
In a speech today to the American Committee on U.S.-Soviet Relations, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d also praised the Soviets, urging the West to support them in their time of economic hardship.
''The danger is that the breakdown of the old Stalinist system will outstrip the development of the new system -one built on universal democratic values and the rule of law,'' he said.
''Their choices will be less hard if we in the West stand by their side,'' he said, even though ''our influence may only be marginal.''
Saying that the two superpowers both regard arms proliferation ''as perhaps the greatest security challenge of the 1990's,'' Mr. Baker proposed joint talks with the Soviets on oil extraction, energy efficiency and the initiation of an international center for ecological research in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Baker also said that the President has decided to include the Soviets in the Citizens Democracy Corps program, a privately financed program intended to train leaders in emerging democracies in the ways of democratic rule and market economics.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Tunisians, Seeking Roots, Turn Toward Iraq

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUNIS, Oct. 18

 BODY:
The contrasting Western and Muslim faces of this former French protectorate mix comfortably in the bustling streets of downtown Tunis as car horns honk over the sound of midday prayers and girls in tight jeans move past women draped in traditional Arab gowns.
But while the dream of many young men is to emigrate to Europe and both French and Italian television programs are rebroadcast locally, the growing Arab identity of this North African nation has come to light in the strong sympathy that many ordinary Tunisians feel for Iraq in the current crisis.
''We like Saddam Hussein,'' a policeman in his 40's said without hesitation, echoing a widely held opinion. ''He is courageous. He wants all Arabs to be equal. He wants to give the money of the rich Arabs to the poor Arabs. The emirs gave us nothing.'' 
A 62-year-old Tunisian, who boasted that he had traveled the world, felt little differently when the subject came up. ''Kuwait is not important,'' he announced in fluent French. ''It is part of Iraq. It is not worth a war. The United States has no right to intervene.''
 
A Muslim Opposition
For President Zine al-Abidine Ben Ali, though, the gulf crisis has proved less straightforward. Tunisia has long benefited from being a friend of the United States and its economy is enormously dependent on trade with Western Europe and the remittances of 250,000 Tunisians living in France.
The strongest opposition to his three-year-old Government comes from the Islamic Renaissance Movement, known as Nahda, which gained ground in the 1980's in reaction to the Westernization of Tunisia that was tasking place under his predecessor, Habib Bourguiba.
And since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, it is the Arab voice of Tunisia that has been raised on the streets. ''What you hear is the fruit of the accumulated frustration of the Arab world,'' a Government official said. ''The Western response has turned Saddam into a political and religious hero.''
In preparing his own response, Mr. Ben Ali has therefore measured the risks of a domestic Islamic backlash against the dangers of Western reprisals. And he has chosen a policy that balances strict adherence to United Nations resolutions on a trade embargo with public disapproval of the Western military buildup.
 
Keeping the Peace at Home
In his only major speech on the subject to date, he criticized American troop deployments more than the Iraqi invasion. He boycotted an Arab League summit meeting, creating the impression that he was trying to avoid condemning Baghdad. He has also promoted a so-called Arab solution to the crisis, urging Saudi and Kuwait leaders to be patient and reminding Western visitors of the need to appease Arab public opinion.
But his main priority has been to maintain peace at home. And in this, he has been successful. Tunisian officials say experience shows that any American attack on Iraq would result in angry protests here, but to date there have been only demonstrations against the American presence in the gulf, organized by the Government party as part of what officials call their ''management'' of the crisis.
Diplomats looking to explain Tunisian grass-roots support for Iraq recognize the impact of President Hussein's televised messages. With a strong appeal to Arab nationalism, their exploitation of envy of rich Saudis and Kuwaitis and their defiance of the United States and Israel, they have been well received throughout the Arab world.
But in Tunisia, many political experts go further, noting that pro-Iraqi sentiments also reflect the population's strong desire to reassert its Arab identity and Muslim traditions after 30 years in which both were suppressed as part of the Bourguiba Government's drive to modernize Tunisia.
 
Reversal of Policies
Under Mr. Bourguiba, not only was French preferred over Arabic as the language of Government, but he also banned prayers on television, ordered Tunisians to work all of Friday, denied the mullahs the right to decide holy days and had his police persecute leading members of the Islamic movement.
After Mr. Ben Ali seized power in November 1987, however, these policies were reversed, with the new President displaying his Muslim colors by visiting holy places in Saudi Arabia on his first trip abroad.
When he visited France on his next trip, he then surprised his hosts by speaking publicly in Arabic.
While stressing that he is the Muslim leader of a Muslim country, though, his own version of Islam is far from fundamentalist. He continues to encourage emancipation of women, he is building a Western-style market economy and to this day this country remains one of the most cosmopolitan in the Arab world, visited by two million foreign tourists a year.
When he met leaders of the Islamic Renaissance Party to encourage them to take part in a more open political system, however, he refused them the right to identify themselves as a Muslim party. ''My party is also Muslim,'' he reportedly told them. ''We are all Muslims.''

HEADLINE: Congressional Attempt to Impose Higher Tariffs on China Collapses

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19

 BODY:
A Congressional move to impose higher tariffs on China involving billions of dollars of exports collapsed today when the Senate missed a voting deadline, thereby enabling China to continue getting low duties at least through the end of next June.
To protest the repression of pro-democracy student demonstrators, the House of Representatives voted 247 to 174 on Thursday to rescind President Bush's decision last May renewing for China the favorable tariff status known as most-favored-nation treatment.
Under a measure enacted in August, both chambers faced a deadline of midnight Thursday for action to reverse the Administration move. 
In a statement early today, the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, officially pronounced the effort dead, but he said he continued to believe that given the current condition of human rights in China, Mr. Bush was wrong.
 
Bush Promised Veto
The Congressional move was largely symbolic, since Mr. Bush, a former Ambassador to Beijing, had promised to veto any resolution of disapproval, and most estimates said the two houses lacked the two-thirds voting strength to override a veto.
Mr. Bush said the higher tariffs would hurt American business and consumers, reduce American influence with China on global issues and damage the Hong Kong economy, which is heavily dependent on China trade.
Eliminating the favored status would mean up to a 10-fold rise in tariffs on the apparel, electronics, toys and other products that China sells here.
The two countries do about $18 billion in two-way business. Although China buys wheat, high-technology products and machinery and other capital goods from the United States, it has a large trade surplus with this country.
Signaling the importance of the Chinese market for American farmers, the Agriculture Department announced today that China has bought an additional 449,370 metric tons of wheat, its second purchase this week. At current prices the wheat would have a farm value of around $40 million.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Cellular Phone Deals for Alert Buyers

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
Purchases of cellular telephones continue to climb rapidly, and their prices are falling with almost equal speed. As what was once a luxury becomes affordable for many Americans, competition among manufacturers and among providers of service is becoming more intense.
Prices for the phones themselves have been slashed to as little as $50 in some cases. These lower prices are tempting more and more people to buy cellular phones. But there is more to think about than just the base price of the phone. It's not like making other electronic purchases, like a television set or a stereo. 
In the first place there are three kinds of cellular phones to choose from: one for use only inside a car, a mobile phone; one for inside and outside a car, a transportable phone; and one for use only outside, a portable phone. And as many as seven plans for buying cellular service may be offered by a single provider in a metropolitan area. There is also the question of insurance, which varies with the kind of phone. 74% Growth Last Year Growth in sales of cellular phones has been astonishing. In 1989, the number of such phones in use soared by almost 74 percent, according to Dataquest Inc., a research concern based in San Jose, Calif. The increase in 1990 is expected to be another 48 percent, bringing the total number of phones to almost five million.
Steve Sazegari, a Dataquest analyst, says he expects this cellular phone base to rise by another 34 percent next year. ''Prices could come down 20 to 30 percent over the next 4 to 5 years,'' he said.
Prices have already dropped since the advent of the phones in 1983. Consumers can still spend as much as $3,000 for a unit, but many models sell for $50 to $99. Most phone sales are in the mobile category, says to the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association, the largest and most mature segment of the market.
 
'Gimmicks in the Marketplace'
But the lowest prices offered by dealers often carry various conditions, like a commitment to use a particular cellular telephone company for a minimum period. Thus the buyer could be locked in with one service provider and cannot change to another to get better service or a lower price until the period ends.
Because cellular phone owners pay for both incoming and outgoing calls, providers are offering a slew of service plans encompassing the monthly charge and the per-minute use charge to attract customers. One plan combines a $35-a-month service charge with a use charge of 60 cents a minute in peak periods and 40 cents in off-peak periods. Another offers a $55-a-month charge and a use charge of 45 cents a minute at all times.
''Beware of come-ons,'' said Robert B. Miller, vice president of merchandising for Radio Shack. ''There are a lot of gimmicks in the marketplace. You want to be sure of not entering into a five-year agreement with a carrier'' that limits switching to a more attractive deal. The Federal Communications Commission licenses two providers in each area.
Find out whether a package of extras is included. They are often bargains. For example, the Nynex Mobile Communications Company, a service provider, is currently offering a $400 package encompassing a mobile phone, antenna, installation and a microphone. Purchased separately, an antenna could cost $60 or more and installation could cost about $100.
Cellular phones also have warranties, similar to those on other electronic equipment. Most manufacturers offer a one-year warranty on parts and labor, plus another 2 to 4 years for parts alone.
Questions have been raised about exposure to the radiation that is emitted by cellular phones. Prof. Theodore S. Rappaport of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute in Blacksburg, said that in general the low power and relatively low UHF transmission frequency is not viewed as a health hazard. But he said it is an issue that requires further study, even though cellular phone emissions are a small part of the total radiation the average person encounters each day. Professor Blacksburg is the director of the institute's mobile and portable radio research group.
As for insurance, coverage for mobile phones attached to a car and drawing power from it is not usually a part of standard auto policies. But you can buy a special electronic equipment endorsement to an automobile or homeowner policy, or a separate policy, called a floater.
Transportable phones that can be operated through either a car's electrical system or an independent rechargeable battery pack are also not generally covered under automobile policies. While the phone might be protected under a standard homeowner policy when the owner is out of the car, it is not covered inside without an endorsement to an automobile or homeowner policy, or a separate policy.
Finally, self-contained hand-held portable phones are automatically covered under a homeowner policy as personal property. They normally have a deductible amount, typically $100 to $250, that applies to the phones, and certain perils, like mysterious disappearance and breakage, are not covered. ''The safest thing with any cellular phone is to add an endorsement to a homeowner policy or get a floater,'' said Barry J. McCall, senior personal property underwriting specialist at the Kemper Group insurance company. ''Then there are no deductibles and most risks are covered.''

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Debate Over Federal Tire Ratings Just Keeps Rolling Along

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Fall is tire-buying time, and as shoppers search for quality and long wear, Federal officals, tire-industry executives and consumer advocates are still arguing over what buyers should be told.
As things now stand, Federal law requires that a tread-wear index and A, B or C ratings for traction and temperature resistance appear on a paper sticker attached to the tire and be imprinted on its sidewall.
Manufacturers are not required to give a tire's expected life in miles, and Federal officials do not endorse any system that does. That is largely the focus of the dispute. 
The argument flared again most recently in August, when the Center for Auto Safety, a Washington advocacy group, released its annual list of top-rated tires and included their expected life in miles. The list is based on data manufacturers are required to submit to the National Highway Traffic Safety Adminstration, which makes the data public but does not say which tires are best.
 
Interpreting the Data
The Tire Industry Safety Council, the manufacturers' public-relations arm, said the center's rankings showing expected life in miles, based on travel on average roads, were misleading because road conditions vary widely. Officials at the traffic safety agency agreed. But the center said that without a conversion to miles, the data are not useful. Consumer advocates also say the Government should rank tires instead of simply releasing a list of 1,800 tires and their grades every six months.
''All we are trying to do is embarrass the Government into doing what it's supposed to be doing,'' said Clarence M. Ditlow, the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety.
Present Federal regulations require manufacturers to provide dealers with lists of tire ratings so they can be easily reviewed by consumers. But compliance appears to be spotty.
At the Jersey City auto center for the one of the nation's largest tire retailers, Sears, tire-rating lists were not available earlier this week. Jackie Bitowt, a Sears spokeswoman, said the company provided such lists but its outlets had to order them.
Some insight into the troubled history of tire ratings sheds some light on the debate over what and how much the consumer should be told.
In 1966, Congress, concerned about deceptive tire marketing, ordered Federal regulators to develop a tire-rating system to help consumers. The results are the present Uniform Tire Quality Grading System, which rates tires on two safety factors, traction and temperature resistance, and one economy factor, tread wear.
For traction, measured by a tire's ability to stop on a wet surface, the grades are A, B and C. An A-graded tire stops the most quickly. Temperature resistance is also graded A, B and C and indicates a tire's ability to withstand heat. A tire graded A is the most heat-resistant and the least likely to suffer a blowout under the same conditions as a tire graded B or C. Tread wear is the most controversial factor. To measure a tire's life, cars are driven 6,400 miles over public roads near San Angelo, Tex. To minimize variables in tread wear because of different driving styles, the cars travel in convoys of four at constant speeds, and drivers regularly change between cars.
Tires are graded on an index, which indicates relative tread wear. A tire graded 150 should provide 50 percent more mileage than one graded 100. Under average conditions each 50 points represent a life expectancy of about 10,000 miles.
The tire industry took issue with the index and went to court in 1975 to block it. Producers argued it was of little value because a tire's life varied sharply, depending on factors like road conditions and the type of driving. ''It is a meaningless system,'' said Thomas Cole, the president of the Rubber Manufacturers Association, a trade group in Washington.
A Federal court in Washington rejected that argument, and the rating system took effect in 1979. But in 1983, the tread-wear index was dropped again, this time by the traffic safety agency, which echoed the industry's earlier argument that grading was a tricky business. The Center for Auto Safety filed suit against the agency, and in 1984 a Federal appeals court in Washington ordered the agency to reinstate the index.
The traffic safety agency, which used to publish a guide to help consumers convert the index to expected mileage, no longer does so. Barry Felrice, the assistant administrator for rule making, said the agency now believes that differences in road conditions vary too much to make mileage figures meaningful. And he insisted that ranking tires was impossible because buyers must balance a tire's tread wear against the safety factors of traction and temperature ratings.
 
What's Important May Vary
''We try to tell consumers what these ratings mean and assume they are smart enough to know what is important to them,'' Mr. Felrice said. ''Someone who does a lot of high-speed highway driving might be more interested in temperature than tread wear.''
Mr. Ditlow of the Center for Auto Safety said he would continue to press Federal officials to make the tire-rating system more intelligible and accessible. He pointed out that such a system is already used by the Environmental Protection Agency, which widely publicizes its gas-mileage ratings for cars.
''Everybody knows that gas ratings vary according to driving habits, but that does not stop E.P.A. from publicizing them or ranking the best performers,'' he said.
 
BEFORE YOU DRIVE OFF TO THE DEALER
Car owners buy an estimated 175 million replacement tires annually. Most of them are steel-belted radials, the most popular tires in the country. Here are some shopping tips.
Always buy the same size as the tire you are replacing unless the car or tire maker approves the use of another size.
If you are mixing radial and nonradial tires - ask your car maker if you should - put the radial tires on the rear wheels.
So-called ''high performance'' tires will have a lower tread-wear rating than a regular tire. This is because they emphasize traction and are made from softer compounds intended to hold the road better.
Make sure the dealer registers your name and address with the tire's producer to make notification easier in case of a recall.
For a list of long-lasting tires compiled by the Center for Auto Safety, send a stamped, self-addressed envelope to the center at 2001 S Street NW, Washington, D.C. 20009. For a list of the 1,800 tires rated by National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, call agency's Auto Safety Hotline at (800) 424-9393, except in the District of Columbia, where callers should use (202) 366-0123.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
As head of the Office of Financial Services and the chairwoman of both the Financial Services Corporation and New York City Industrial Development Agency, LERESSA R. CROCKETT has not been one of Mayor DAVID N. DINKINS's high-profile commissioners.
But in supervising a $1.6 billion portfolio of economic development loans, Ms. Crockett, 39 years old, is an increasingly significant figure in the city's troubled financial future and ''a person emerging in power and influence and likely to be a future leader in the financial community,'' according to the Women's Bond Club of New York. The 69-year-old club, whose members are female executives in investment banking, brokerage and insurance, honored Ms. Crockett on Thursday.
Ms. Crockett, a former vice president at Salomon Brothers now making $110,000 a year, less than her former salary, said, ''There's a much broader perspective in working for the city.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Strengthens in U.S. After Weakening in Europe

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly stronger in domestic trading yesterday after weakening in Europe, but foreign exchange brokers said it remained wobbly because of American economic uncertainty.
It rebounded yesterday to 1.5025 marks, after having fallen through the psychological barrier of 1.50 German marks on Thursday to 1.4970 in New York.
''This is volatile stuff,'' said Lloyd G. Atkinson, chief economist for the Bank of Montreal, ''and all indications are that this is going to continue for some time.'' 
 
Markets Still Pessimistic
Traders said the foreign exchange markets continued to display pessimism about the dollar, especially in light of the prolonged political stalemate in Washington over the budget deficit.
''We've had comments all week from Japanese, U.S. and German officials that they're either happy with the dollar right now or they welcome further gains in the yen or the mark at the expense of the dollar,'' said Michael Faust, a currency analyst with Money Market Services in Chicago.
In New York, traders said, the dollar's behavior was largely influenced by the oil market. Oil fell by about $3 a barrel, easing inflation fears and thereby helping the dollar rally a bit. Inflation erodes the value of dollars. Rises Against Yen The dollar also rose against the Japanese yen yesterday, ending a long slide. In Tokyo, the dollar finished trading at 125.25 yen, up 0.85 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 125.90. In New York, the dollar closed at 125.95 yen, up from 124.40 late Thursday.
In London, the cost for one British pound rose to $1.9590, from $1.9540 late Thursday. At closing in New York, one pound cost $1.9585, less expensive than Thursday's $1.9710.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.2680 Swiss francs, up from 1.2590; 5.0295 French francs, up from 5.0165; 1,124.25 Italian lire, up from 1,122.00, and 1.1731 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1698.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday, included: 1.5040 German marks, down from 1.5115; 1.2700 Swiss francs, down from 1.2735; 5.0380 French francs, down from 5.0630; 1.6940 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7035; 1,127.00 Italian lire, down from 1,132.75, and 1.1675 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1750.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Up Again; Copper Increases Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of precious metal futures rose for the third straight day yesterday, partly offsetting recent steep losses as a sharp drop in oil prices stirred speculation that interest rates might fall.
On other commodity markets, copper futures rose sharply and livestock and meat futures were mixed, as were grains and soybeans.
Gold futures settled $2.70 to $2.80 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the spot price, represented by the contract for October delivery, at $372.80 a troy ounce; silver was 5.8 cents to 6.1 cents higher, with October at $4.258 a troy ounce. 
Platinum outpaced the other precious metals. Platinum futures ended $10.50 to $11.50 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with October at $407.70 a troy ounce.
The metals virtually ignored a number of traditionally bearish signals including sharply higher stock prices and a stronger dollar.
Instead, metal traders focused on oil prices, which fell $2 to $3.01 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with November light, sweet crude at $33.79 a barrel. The drop was attributed to perceptions that the Iraqi-American standoff in the Middle East was moving toward a peaceful settlement. That led to a letup in inflationary worries and prompted speculation that the Federal Reserve might act to lower bank lending rates.
''The last time the Fed indicated it was easing credit policy back in July, that's when gold accelerated to the up side,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst for Paine Webber Inc.
John Jonat, who trades precious metals for Deak International Inc., also said gold's rise was a spillover from the platinum market, which rose on strong Japanese demand.
Strength in the stock market contributed to a strong rally in copper futures on the Commodity Exchange. Copper has many applications in the manufacturing and construction industries, so its price responds strongly to economic signals.
Copper futures ended 1.5 cents to 3.8 cents higher, with October at $1.267 a pound.
Cattle futures rose moderately on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in line with stronger cash-market fundamentals. Traders also evened their positions ahead of the Government's quarterly cattle-on-feed report, which will be released Monday afternoon.
Hog futures fell slightly while pork bellies advanced.
Live cattle were unchanged to 0.50 cent higher, with October at 79.30 cents a pound; feeder cattle were 0.07 cent lower to 0.60 cent higher, with October at 86.85 cents a pound; live hogs were 0.20 cent lower to 0.13 cent higher, with October at 57.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.17 cents to 1.8 cents higher, with February at 67.17 cents a pound.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Loss Posted By Texas Instruments

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Texas Instruments Inc., one of the nation's largest makers of computer memory chips, said today that it lost $7 million in the third quarter, compared with a profit of $65 million, or 67 cents a share, in the period a year ago. Revenue rose 7 percent, to $1.68 billion from $1.57 billion.
Falling memory chip prices, rising spending on new technology and chip plants as well as a temporary shutdown of its Philippine chip-making plant after an earthquake in July contributed to the loss, said Jerry R. Junkins, chairman and chief executive. The Philippine plant is now running at full capacity, but production was limited for four weeks. 
The third-quarter loss was anticipated on Wall Street, in part because two other large makers of memory chips, Advanced Micro Devices and National Semiconductor, had reported losses. Also, Mr. Junkins said last summer before the earthquake that a third-quarter loss was likely.
Texas Instruments shares fell 37.5 cents, to $25.125, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange. Fourth-Quarter Losses Seen Mr. Junkins also indicated that the company's losses would extend through the fourth quarter. He said high levels of capital spending would continue in a period with falling prices for memory chips and a weakening economy in the United States.
Prices for dynamic random access memory chips that store a million characters of memory fell from more than $6 to below $5 in the quarter.
Some Japanese chip makers have begun shipping memory chips that store four million characters. A spokesman, Stan Victor, said Texas Instruments would start shipping these new chips later this year. Prices for the four-megabyte chips are above $25.
Mr. Junkins said the company's orders for military supplies, which include missiles and computer chips, fell by 51 percent. The overall backlog declined by $640 million, to $4.07 billion, in the quarter, with most of the decline recorded in the military-electronics unit. The company has cut 950 jobs from its military-related payroll in the last four months.
Royalty payments rose to $41 million in the quarter from $32 million in the period last year.
Negotiations with Japanese and Korean chip makers on new licensing agreements are continuing, and the company declined to estimate their potential for future royalty income. Some analysts have put the figure as high as $2 billion.

HEADLINE: Zenith Reports $11.6 Million Deficit

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The Zenith Electronics Corporation yesterday reported a third-quarter loss of $11.6 million on sales of $342.3 million. The consumer electronics maker, based in Glenview, Ill., said the slowdown in the economy had resulted in reduced sales of picture tubes for television manufactuers and videocassette recorders. Lower prices for color television sets also hurt the company's performance. 
Results for the quarter included a $2.4 million gain resulting from the termination of a defined-benefit pension plan. For the period last year, the company lost $24.1 million on sales of $376.8 million. In that period for the businesses that Zenith still owns, the loss was $9.1 million. The company sold its computer business to Groupe Bull of France last year for $511 million.
Demand also fell for the company's monochrome computer screens.
''The businesses that they operate in are intensely competitive and that shows up in their operating performance,'' said Russell L. Leavitt, an analyst with Salomon Brothers.
The company's stock rose 12.5 cents, to $4.25 on the Big Board.
Zenith has largely staked its future on the development of a market for high-definition systems for television sets and computers.
Zenith is developing two aspects of its high-definition system and plans to spend $10 million on research this year. The company is developing a high-resolution color cathode ray tube, known as a flat tension mask. Zenith plans to sell the screens, which provide a brilliantly clear picture even in sunlight, to computer makers, as well as use them on the company's high-definition television sets.
Zenith's chairman and president, Jerry K. Pearlman, has lobbied intensely for Government financing for Zenith, framing the discussion in terms of the United States' global competiveness. He has said producing such high-resolution displays would be the next high-technology battleground between the United States and other countries. With developments like Zenith's flat tension mask, ''It is not too late for the U.S. to win,'' Zenith said in a typical statement in a recent company report.
In August, the United States Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency said it would provide slightly more than $1 million in financing for Zenith to develop the screen for a military work station.
The company is also developing a broadcast transmission system for high-definition television. Rival high-definition television systems are under development by companies in Japan and in Europe.
If the market does not develop according to Zenith's plans, analysts said the company's future was uncertain.

HEADLINE: Bad Loans Up in New England Bank Loss

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Bank of New England Corporation, one of the nation's weakest large banking companies, yesterday announced a loss of $123.2 million in the third quarter as bad real estate loans in the sour New England economy continued to grow.
The loss, which raised the company's total loss to $1.44 billion over the last four quarters, further reduced the already thin capital cushion the company has to absorb future losses. The company has shareholder capital equal to about 1.1 percent of assets, well below a target of 3 percent of assets it set earlier this year. 
The third-quarter loss resulted from the company's decision to set aside $100 million for possible losses on bad loans, even though its measurements of risk in its loans showed that just $30 million needed to be set aside.
''Given the current environment, the weak real estate market, and the uncertain oil situation and how it might affect the regional economy, we decided it would be prudent to be conservative and strengthen our reserves,'' said Lawrence K. Fish, chairman of the Boston-based bank.
Mr. Fish added that real estate loans accounted for 80 percent of the company's bad loans. Although the general economy is weakening, he said defaults on other kinds of business loans were not rising.
''We see businesses behaving very conservatively, and reducing their level of debt,'' the chairman said. ''We are also seeing the same thing in the consumer loan portfolio.''
Besides its loan losses, another big challenge at the bank has been to cut costs. After selling about $5 billion of assets earlier this year, including the credit card and leasing businesses, the income of the company has fallen more rapidly than expenses. Thus, it lost $48 million in the third quarter from its regular operations, not counting the loss caused by increasing the reserve for bad loans.
Mr. Fish noted that the company had cut 5,000 jobs this year and expected to cut 1,000 more by early next year. Even after cutting expenses, analysts said that profitability might be weak because of the burden of bad loans and real estate acquired from bad loans, which rose $65 million, to $2.84 billion in the third quarter. While no interest is paid on those loans, the company must still pay interest on the deposits and other money it borrowed to finance them.
In a move to rebuild capital, the company met yesterday with holders of $706 million of its bonds and presented them a proposal for converting the bonds into capital. The bank said that acceptance of its proposal would raise its equity capital to more than 3 percent of assets, but would greatly reduce the share of the company owned by holders of the existing 69.5 million shares.
With equity capital of only $255 million at Sept. 30, the bank would need more than $441 million of new capital to exceed 3 percent of its assets. Its existing shares have a total market value of only about $104 million.
Earlier this year, some bondholders proposed an exchange of each $1,000 bond for $250 of cash and new stock in the company of about $250. the bank officials declined to comment on the earlier offer from bondholders or the terms of the new offer made yesterday.

HEADLINE: Oil Lowest In a Month, Down $3.01

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil prices fell to their lowest level in a month yesterday, as oil traders' fear of war was overtaken by a belief that shooting is less likely and by prospects that supplies have just about recovered from the effect of the United Nations embargo of Iraq and Kuwait.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, oil for November delivery closed at $33.79, the lowest price since Sept. 20. The drop, $3.01, was the third largest in the 13-week crisis and brought the decline for the week to $5.90 a barrel.
Several traders cited a statement by Taha Yasin Ramadan, the First Deputy Prime Minister of Iraq, that the crisis had entered ''a phase of reassessment and reconsideration of positions.'' Various rumors circulated to the effect that Iraq was looking for a way out of the crisis. 
 
A Change in Psychology
The psychology has turned around, said one trader, Christian D. Gohler of Merrill Lynch Futures. Earlier this month, he said, ''people were in there buying with their eyes closed, people who felt there's going to be a war and you'd better be covered.''
But the dealers who were once afraid to leave for the weekend ''short'' on oil, or holding contracts that obligate them to deliver oil at a fixed price on some distant day, are now afraid to go ''long,'' he said -promising to buy a fixed quantity at a fixed price on a specified day.
An oil refiner or speculator who went long and agreed to buy in December at $40 a barrel could lose big if peace were assured and the spot price on the appointed day in December fell to $30 or less. Indeed, anyone who bought a contract obligating a purchase at $40 has lost unless prices go back up; anyone who promised to deliver at $40 has made money. For every dollar one trader loses, another gains the same amount.
 
Last Trading on Contract
Today was the last full day of trading for the November crude contract, which may also have helped to push the price down, because many contract holders did not want to take actual delivery. But the price of oil for delivery in later months also went down sharply.
''It's war and peace,'' said Theodore Eck, chief economist of the Amoco Corporation in Chicago. ''This is a Tolstoy market.''
John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York, agreed, saying the balance of supply and demand did not justify a price much higher than $30 a barrel. ''Everything above that is psychology,'' he said.
Some analysts think even $30 is too high. At Pegasus Econometric Group, in Hoboken, N.J., Peter C. Beutel said production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries appeared to be 22.5 million to 23 million barrels a day, about equal to, or slightly higher than, the level before the crisis. Since the embargo, Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and others have sharply raised production to make up for lost supplies from Iraq and Kuwait.
The Department of Energy, which had been predicting for weeks that the shortfall in November would be less than a million barrels a day, now says it will be less than half a million barrels a day. Mr. Beutel said that along with high production, the price was down because demand for oil products was ''dreadful, absolutely miserable.''
Heating oil inventories held by oil companies are 15 million barrels ahead of what they were a year ago, according to the American Petroleum Institute, and the weather in New York, the main market, has been warm. In addition, Ed Rothschild of Citizen Action, a consumer group in Washington, said many consumers and dealers who were caught by price increases last December decided to fill their tanks early this year.
As a result, he said, demand is weak, and among the refiners ''no one is willing to pay $40'' anymore.
Refiners had been paying for expensive oil and selling products at a price that did not reflect the increase, reducing their demand. Mr. Lichtblau pointed out that last week refinery runs averaged 13.1 million barrels a day, down from 14.3 million for the week ended Sept. 21.
On the New York Merc, heating oil for delivery next month closed at 88.40 cents a gallon, down 8.11 cents -an especially sharp decline. Unleaded gasoline closed at 87.91 cents, down 5.05 cents.
Mr. Lichtblau referred to a ''snowballing effect'' in the market. ''Once it starts going down, everybody wants to sell before it goes down further,'' he said.
Mr. Beutel predicted that there would be strong psychological support for oil at $30 a barrel. But the only certainty is volatility, he added.

HEADLINE: Midway Air Leaving Philadelphia

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Less than a year after it began an ambitious plan to make Philadelphia a hub, Midway Airlines Inc. said today that it was abandoning the effort and selling the operations to USAir Inc. In doing so, Midway, already troubled by high jet fuel costs, will lay off more employees, end 60 flights by April 30 and retreat to its home base of Chicago to ride out what could be a long and difficult period for the entire airline industry.
Midway's problems are symptomatic of the industry. Faced with sluggish traffic, continued harsh competition and the possibility of even more fuel price increases, many airlines fear deep losses in coming months.
Midway said that with fewer people traveling and with the cost of airline fuel nearly doubling since July, it simply could not afford to cover its day-to-day operating costs and continue the investment needed to make a strong hub at the Philadelphia International Airport. 
Midway said it would sell its entire Philadelphia operation - landing slots, international routes, 11 gates and other equipment - to USAir for $67.5 million. Midway established its Philadelphia hub last November by buying the assets, along with about $100 million worth of planes, from Eastern Airlines for more than $200 million. Midway will keep the aircraft: 16 DC-9 jets.
Midway said it would lay off an unspecified number of its 800 employees in Philadelphia. The carrier recently announced an 8 percent cut in its work force of 6,300. Dismantling the Philadelphia operation is a major setback that will force Midway to post a loss of more than $30 million in the fourth quarter on top of the $34 million it lost in the first half of the year. Company executives said the airline's declining resources left them no choice.
''The risk would have been continuing to drive down the same road and driving off a cliff,'' David R. Hinson, Midway's chairman and chief executive, said today in a telephone interview.
Midway had come very close to the edge. Thomas Longman, the airline analyst at Bear, Stearns Inc., said Midway had about $15.5 million in cash on June 30 out of total assets of $440 million. Although Midway has not yet reported its third-quarter results, Mr. Longman said he expected a $17 million loss, which would have nearly depleted the company's bank account. The airline pays about $3.5 million a quarter for interest alone.
''They were running low on cash, and that is why they needed to make this move,'' Mr. Longman said.
The company's share price rose 87 1/2 cents today, to $6.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Midway suffers more than many other carriers from the higher fuel costs. Its fleet is less fuel efficient and it pays a special fuel tax in Chicago that many airlines elsewhere do not pay.
Philadelphia would have helped, but the results there turned out to be a big disappointment. No sooner had Midway begun service out of Philadelphia than competitors responded with a vengeance. USAir beefed up its service from that city to points throughout the Northeast, other airlines started Philadelphia-to-Miami service, and Eastern cut fares on Northeast-to-Florida runs to $79 one way.
The competition kept Midway from charging the fares it needed to make a profit and it began to lose money substantially. Companywide losses were $50 million in the first six months of operation at the Philadelphia hub.
Mr. Hinson said Midway would now try to ride out the weak economy and high fuel costs, then make another attempt to establish a second hub. Cash Improvement Expected He said that Midway's cash position would improve greatly because of the sale to USAir and that ''there is no prospect for a bankruptcy.'' He noted that Midway took on most of its debt to finance revenue-generating aircraft rather than to cover operating losses.
But analysts say that Midway has only bought some breathing room, that it still could get into deep trouble, and that its fate may be out of its hands.
''A lot of the prognosis for Midway depends on what fuel prices and the economy do,'' said Mark Daugherty, the airline analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''A lot of airlines are anticipating a real tough period with heavy losses over the coming months.''

At the airport, left, a Midway ground crew worker threw down wheel chocks around aircraft at the Midway gates. (Associated Press)

The Economy
 President Bush pressed Republicans for a budget cut to reduce the deficit without raising income tax rates. But House and Senate negotiators predicted that a final budget deal would include higher income taxes on the rich and a rise in gasoline taxes. [Page 1.] Legislation to regulate cable television is dead for this session of Congress, Senate sponsors declared, despite a flurry of last-minute deal-making. Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, acknowledging that he could not muster enough support to get the bill to the floor in this session, blamed the White House. [29.] The Senate passed far-reaching aviation legislation that couples new local fees on passengers to a new national policy on airport noise. The compromise measure faces uncertain prospects. [9.] A Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts executive testified that he was not informed for years that investment partnerships affiliated with Michael R. Milken had obtained a multimillion-dollar stake in a 1985 buyout by the firm. He said disclosure should have been made. [30.] 
 
 
 
Markets
 Oil for November delivery fell $3.01, to $33.79, its lowest level since Sept. 20, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The decline for the week was $5.90 a barrel, as oil traders' fear of war was overtaken by their belief that shooting is less likely, and by prospects that oil supplies have just about recovered from the effect of the United Nations embargo of Iraq and Kuwait. [29.] The Dow Jones industrial average surged 68.07, to 2,520.79, bringing its rise for the week to 122.77 points, or 5.1 percent. The drop in oil prices, new Iraqi peace feelers and strong signs of an imminent budget agreement combined to buoy stocks. [29.] Prices of Treasury bonds continued to climb, largely as a result of plunging oil prices. Reports that Congress was making progress on a budget package also lifted the debt market. It cited falling prices for computer memory chips and rising spending on new technology and chip plants. [31.] B. HEADLINE: First Gubernatorial Debate Focuses on Budget Trouble

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Oct. 19

 BODY:
Meeting tonight for the first debate of the gubernatorial campaign, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his three opponents scoffingly questioned one another's competence to handle what they all agreed were the daunting fiscal problems facing New York State.
The hourlong debate, which was not broadcast live anywhere in the state, quickly lost its veneer of political politeness and took on the tone of a schoolyard brawl.
''If Mario ever came in an economics class of mine - and I taught economics for seven years - I'd give him a double F,'' the Republican candidate, Pierre A. Rinfret, said early in the debate.
Governor Cuomo responded: ''If ever I come to your economics class, I shouldn't be flunked. I should be committed.'' 
 
At the Time of the World Series
Mr. Cuomo had refused to debate Mr. Rinfret one on one, saying that the other candidates, Herbert London, the Conservative, and Louis P. Wein, the Right to Life candidate, deserved to be included.
The timing of tonight's debate - on a Friday night in the middle of the World Series - appeared designed to minimize coverage, and Mr. Cuomo's opponents accused him of deliberately scheduling the encounter to reduce its audience. Aides to the Governor, however, denied this, saying that other dates that had been offered had conflicted with the Governor's schedule.
Almost the entire debate was devoted to fiscal issues, and even when questions on other topics were posed to the candidates, they dragged the discussion back to economics, repeatedly disputing one another not only on questions of competence, but also on questions of fact, including what New York's tax rate is and how many workers the state employs for each 10,000 residents.
''You're dead wrong on your numbers, because you always are,'' Mr. Rinfret said to Mr. Cuomo at one point. At the start of the debate, Mr. Cuomo acknowledged for the first time that the state would probably run a deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends in March.
 
'He Did Nothing About It'
Earlier in the week, when the State Comptroller reported that state tax collections were lagging seriously behind projections, Mr. Cuomo said it was too early to tell whether the state would end the year in debt.
But tonight he said, ''I project that we will have a deficit in the current year.''
His opponents quickly jumped on this opening, arguing that the Governor should have recognized the deficit months ago and started to close it.
''It fascinates me that Governor Cuomo, Mario, discovered what I knew 110 days ago,'' Mr. Rinfret said. ''He heard me say it. He did nothing about it.''
Mr. London charged that the Governor should have cut the budget earlier to avert a deficit.
''Why are we now talking about cutting the budget when we should have been doing so eight years ago?'' he asked.
 
Specifics on Trimming the Budget
Mr. London was the only candidate in the debate to offer specific suggestions about how he would cut the state's $50 billion budget. They included cuts in the staff at the Governor's mansion, a $400 million reduction in Medicaid expenses and the establishment of a means test and a sliding tuition scale for students in the state university system.
Mr. Wein, in contrast, spoke in generalities, calling for ''a total restructuring of state government.''
''We have to return to the idea that people take care of people, not government,'' he said.
There was no clear winner in tonight's debate, which started at 7:45 P.M. Four reporters posed questions to the candidates, who were given two and a half minutes to answer and one minute for rebuttal.
 
By Bus, for $39.55
Even before the debate started, Mr. Rinfret had made the most of the free publicity the event afforded. Saying that his campaign did not have enough money for him to fly to Syracuse, he traveled here from New York City by Greyhound bus, at a cost of $39.55.
Mr. Rinfret, whose campaign tactics have raised quite a few political eyebrows, scheduled several news conferences today at bus stations along the route.
''Is this a publicity stunt?'' he asked before boarding the bus this morning. ''Yeah, in part. But we're out of money.'' As of last month, Mr. Rinfret's campaign was $90,000 in debt.
The debate was scheduled to be shown in a delayed broadcast in Albany tonight at 10 P.M. In New York City, the debate will not be seen until Monday night at 7 P.M. on WNET. In Buffalo it will be broadcast at midnight Monday. #2d Debate Nov. 4 Representatives for the three challengers charged Governor Cuomo with purposefully arranging the debate for a time slot when it would receive little news coverage.
''The bottom line,'' said Michael R. Long, the state's Conservative Party chairman, ''is that it's a very calculated move on the part of the Cuomo campaign to get as little exposure as possible. At the same time, no one can criticize him for not debating. He can say, 'What are you talking about? We had two debates.' ''
A second debate is scheduled for Nov. 4.
The Governor's aides insisted today, however, that he had no ulterior motive in agreeing to debate tonight.
 
'What's Herb London Doing?'
''The Governor is a guy who's widely in demand and who has other obligations, like running the state,'' said Gary G. Fryer, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo. In contrast, he said, ''What's Herb London doing on any particular night, and who cares?''
Mr. Cuomo, the overwhelming favorite in this year's race, is widely perceived to have nothing to gain through the debate. But his under-financed opponents see it as a critical opportunity for free media coverage.
During the last gubernatorial campaign, in 1986, Mr. Cuomo spent several months trying to avoid debating his heavily outspent opponent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive. During the current campaign, Mr. Cuomo has often insisted, in mock serious tones, that he is not a good debater.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Where Farmers Would Take a Hit In the Cause of Cutting the Deficit

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When debate began in January on a farm policy law to replace legislation that expired this year, few members of the House and Senate Agriculture committees thought the Government's 57-year-old program to subsidize basic farm commodities needed to be changed much.
Grain prices were strong, exports were high, and the net incomes of farmers had reached the highest levels in history. The cost of the subsidy programs, moreover, had fallen from $25.8 billion in 1986 to less than $8 billion in the 1990 fiscal year.
But looming at the edge of the debate was the matter of the Federal budget deficit, which made farm policy vulnerable to change overnight. Last week, the deficit finally cornered the Congressional conference committee that was writing a new farm policy law, and the results have potentially momentous consequences for farmers and consumers. 
The committee, responding to demands from the White House and Congressional leaders that they cut farm program spending by 25 percent, or $13.6 billion, over five years, approved the most important changes in the commodity price support programs since 1973.
First, the conference decided to levy a tax, requiring producers of milk, sugar, tobacco, peanuts, honey and wool to pay when they market their products. They favored the fees because it is hard to predict the results of lowering price supports.
Second, the conferees agreed to slash to $450 million from $1 billion the amount the Agriculture Department can lend directly to the most debt-burdened farmers.
Most important, the conferees reduced by 15 percent the amount of land on which crops eligible for Government price supports can be grown. Under the new rules, a farmer who signs up for Government subsidies must first set aside 5 percent to 15 percent of his land to lay fallow. He then has to take another 15 percent to grow anything he likes, but can only receive market prices, which in recent months have been much lower than the prices paid by the Government.
The change would reduce Government payments for a wheat farmer in Kansas who cultivates 1,000 acres by roughly $13,000, according to an analysis by an economist at Oklahoma State University. This alters the formula that each farmer uses to decide whether to stay in the Government program or get out. Currently, about 80 percent of corn and wheat growers participate.
The Bush Administration celebrated the new policy. ''Farmers have more flexibility to grow crops to meet market needs,'' said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter. ''It should be beneficial for consumers because farmers can respond more quickly to their demands.''
In Iowa, where the nation's largest corn crop is being harvested, many predicted that the changes would drive farmers away from the programs and introduce a new level of uncertainty in grain supplies and prices. ''All the farmers across the country are going to make the same hard decision this winter,'' said Jack Kintzle, a 46-year-old corn farmer from Coggon, Iowa, and president of the National Corn Growers Association. ''The way I figure it now, if I stay in the program I'll lose money.''
Since 1933, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the first farm subsidy law, the foundation of farm policy has been an ever more complex contract between the Department of Agriculture and producers of corn, sorghum, wheat, rice and cotton. In exchange for setting aside land, typically 5 to 15 percent of his tillable acres, a farmer receives direct payment.
The payment is the difference between the market price and a higher target price set by the Government. This year, corn farmers are likely to receive 50 cents to 60 cents a bushel from the Government, the difference between the market price of $2.10 to $2.20 and the Government's $2.75 target price. Wheat farmers will receive more than $1 a bushel.
Through most of their history, the farm programs were a light burden for the Government. But in the last five years, farmers flocked to the programs, payments mounted and criticism from economists was fierce.
Environmentalists also urged changes in the programs, contending that they locked farmers into destructive cultivation patterns, such as planting the same crop year after year, that hurt the fertility of the soil, caused erosion and led growers to use increasing amounts of fertilizers and pesticides.
The new rule reducing the amount of acreage eligible for Government payments is a response to environmentalists and economists, even if it wasn't meant to be. Farmers could use freed-up land for new crops. They might also drop out of the programs in record numbers and plant from fence row to fence row as they did in the 1970's, causing the reappearance of costly surpluses.
Farm programs, in effect, have become an immense experiment with enormous implications for the Treasury, the food supply, farmers and the environment. ''It is entirely possible,'' said Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska and a member of the conference committee, ''that after all the criticism, these changes could generate new enthusiasm for farm programs.''

HEADLINE: Headliners;
Unheeded Advice

 BODY:
In recent months Felix G. Rohatyn has been complaining that one of the biggest problems facing New York City is that no one - including the Mayor and the unions - will heed his warnings of an impending financial crisis worse than the one he helped to resolve in 1975. Last week he said he would resign at year's end as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the state agency that helped untangle the mess 15 years ago. But he left open the possibility that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo could persuade him to stay. ''He could lock me in a room,'' Mr. Rohatyn said, ''but all things being equal, my intention is to get out.''

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: October 21, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1590 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/October 14-19

BYLINE: By Sallie Hofmeister

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
An Accounting Change That Raises Health Care Costs
 
Unions may have an even tougher time holding the line on health care benefits, for corporations now have a greater incentive then ever to skimp on coverage. The board that makes the nation's accounting rules voted last week to require employers to set up reserves to cover the cost of providing health care to future retirees - an expense that would reduce corporate earnings. Most companies now account for benefits as they pay for them, but the Financial Accounting Standards Board claims this does not give investors an accurate picture of a company's future liabilities. The new rule, which will take effect in 1993, is expected to cost the largest 1,000 companies a total of $227 billion. When General Mills adopted the method in 1989, its health care expenses doubled that year to more than $10.5 million. Many companies may experience as much as a 10-fold increase in their medical costs, says Pat McConnell, a managing director at Bear Stearns & Company. To narrow their liabilities and the hits on their profits, companies may be prompted to pare benefits. 
 
A Breather on the Hill
 
Congress passed another stop-gap measure to extend Government spending power five days beyond Friday night, when automatic, across-the-board budget cuts were to go into effect. The measure, which the President was expected to sign, gives Congress time to patch together a compromise budget. While a House bill passed on Tuesday would raise income taxes and make the wealthy bear most of the brunt, a Senate version, passed Thursday and preferred by the President, calls for no new income taxes, but would raise Federal gasoline tax and cut Medicare benefits.
 
Inflation Holding Steady?
 
Despite the spike in wholesale prices in September, which suggested that soaring energy prices were spreading through the economy, manufacturers do not seem to be passing their added costs on to consumers yet. The Consumer Price Index rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in September for the second straight month. But economists noted that without energy and food prices, the monthly rise in inflation was less than in August and only half as much as in July - an indication that ebbing demand for some products is keeping manufacturers from raising their prices and that inflation is largely under control.
 
A Deepening Deficit
 
The dollar hit an all-time low last week against the German mark - a decline that should continue to discourage investments in the United States. But the weak dollar has one redeeming value: it makes American goods attractive abroad. Export growth has been one of the few bright spots in the economy all year, and in August prevented the United States trade deficit from widening any more dramatically. The higher cost of imported oil deepened the deficit in August by 2.4 percent, to $9.3 billion, the largest imbalance since January. But the gap would have been worse, except for an 8.3 percent gain in exports this year, up from a 2.5 percent rise in the 1989 period. That helped narrow the nonpetroleum deficit this year by 28.5 percent.
 
Congress Defers the Damage
 
 November elections are making legislators weak-kneed. Lawmakers rejected the President's budget package two weeks ago for fear of offending constituents. Now, they are trying to distance themselves from the savings and loan crisis by delaying the authorization of $40 billion needed by the agency handling the bailout to keep the program going. Lawmakers don't want to appear eager to add to a bailout bill that is already expected to cost taxpayers $500 billion. But Congress may be just deferring the pain: The bailout agency is about out of cash, and the lack of a new allowance could stymie the process and further increase taxpayer costs.
 
Crude's Downward Drift
 
Prices of oil fell to their lowest level in two weeks, to $33.79 a barrel, down $6. The prospect of a diplomatic settlement in the Gulf and ample oil stockpiles drove the trend. Traders also saw as a desperate move Iraq's offer to sell oil at the pre-invasion price of $21 a barrel.
 
Skittishness on the Economy
 
Americans are more nervous about the economy than they have been in a decade, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. Of 960 adults polled early this month, 69 percent said the economy is getting worse and more than half said it is in a recession. Only 18 percent blame President Bush.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
 A Prize and a Plan
 
He may have won the Nobel Peace Prize last week for easing global tensions, but President Mikhail S. Gorbachev introduced a plan to switch the Soviet Union to a free-market economy that is bound to stir up trouble at home for months to come. Approved by the Soviet Parliament on Friday, the plan would sell state property to private investors, lift Government price controls and hand over many economic decisions, including determining a timetable for the shift, to the country's 15 republics. But critics, including Mr. Gorbachev's archrival, Boris Yeltsin, the President of Russia, prefer a more radical remedy. And some republics may secede in protest of the plan - a path pocked with peril given the interdependency of the Soviet republics, each with an economic specialty.
 
 A Break for Matsushita
 
If the yen continues to strengthen against the dollar, the Matsushita Electrical Company, Japan's largest consumer electronics company, could get an unexpected bargain on its purchase of MCA Inc., the giant entertainment company. Since news of the deal first surfaced on Sept. 24, the yen has risen 9.1 percent against the dollar, to 125.85 yen. At the current exchange and the rumored $85-a-share purchase price, the deal would cost Matsushita about $6.8 billion rather than the expected $7.5 billion.
 
COMPANIES
 
Higher Airfares on the Horizon
 
The runaway cost of jet fuel may create a $1 billion loss for airlines in the fourth quarter - more than any yearly loss ever for the industry, says the Air Transport Association. Since the Iraqi invasion, jet fuel, which represents more than 15 percent of an airline's operating costs, has increased in price by more than 120 percent. The jump is behind the 52.1 percent decline in the third-quarter earnings of the successful parent of American Airlines. Fares have already drifted upward, but some analysts estimate that airlines would need a 21 percent price hike to compensate for its costs. That is within sight: Last week, Continental Airlines and Northwest Airlines announced increases that could cause a rise in industry fares of at least 15 percent in two months, one of the steepest and quickest ever.
 
 A Big, Bold Aircraft Order
 
United Airlines is not as overwrought by rising costs as some carriers, which have put off buying new planes. Boldly, the airline on Monday placed the largest aircraft order ever: for $22 billion worth of long-range, wide-body planes, including 777's, from the Boeing Company. It is good news for Boeing, hurt by a downturn in military spending, and a show of strength by Stephen M. Wolf, the head of the UAL Corporation, who seems to have won a harrowing takeover skirmish with the unions. Another hint of his victory: a peace pact with Coniston Partners, a big shareholder, which agreed to stop supporting a takeover in exchange for two board seats.
 
A Surprise From Citicorp
 
Many of the nation's top banking companies reported weaker earnings for the third quarter, mainly because of losses on commercial real estate loans. The biggest surprise came from the biggest bank: Citicorp's earnings not only dropped 38 percent for the quarter, but its troubled commercial loans rose by roughly 17 percent, to $4.6 billion, prompting it to set aside an additional $283 million in reserves. Most large banks set aside reserves for at least 50 percent of their nonperforming assets, but Citicorp's provision for commercial loan losses amounts to a mere 14.7 percent. ''We expect them to add up to $2 billion to reserves next quarter,'' said Thomas H. Hanley of Salomon Brothers. ''That would bring their reserves on their bad commercial loans to the level of other big banks.'' Will Citicorp be forced to join the band of bank dividend cutters? Mr. Hanley says no.
 
With a cold shoulder from Wall Street making it difficult to raise capital, many banks are shearing their work forces, dividends and lines of business to cover loan losses. They are also becoming reluctant lenders. This year, bank loans to businesses have fallen by $5.2 billion, to $315.6 billion, the biggest drop since 1987, according to the Federal Reserve.
 
In Brief
 
Donald J. Trump is asking bondholders of his Taj Mahal to accept new ''junk bonds'' in lieu of a coming $47.3 million interest rate payment and is trying to keep control of 80 percent of the casino while reducing the interest rate on $675 million of its bonds. Why oblige? Mr. Trump says the Taj might otherwise go bust.
 
I.B.M.'s third-quarter earnings rose 27 percent, to $1.11 billion, in part because of cost controls put in place last year.
 
Dow Jones & Company, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, will get another newspaper man as its head when Peter R. Kann, president, newly named chief executive, and a Pulitzer prize-winning reporter, takes over as chairman, as expected, when Warren H. Phillips retires on July 1. Mr. Phillips inspired a 15-year growth streak at Dow Jones.
