HEADLINE: A Soldier's Tale From the Middle Market

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
Clouds scudded across the early afternoon sky as Richard Donatuti sped down the Bronx streets, whistling past piteous apartment houses, weed-choked lots, sidewalks dominated by idle people, on his way to see someone wanting a million dollars. His driving stood hair on end. He regards anyplace as fit for a U-turn and does not feel a one-way sign always must be obeyed. Office colleagues constantly rib him: ''The crash helmets are in the trunk;'' ''You're going out with Richie? Make sure you drive. Tie him up if necessary.'' 
Rarely silent, he filled the Chevy Caprice with his chatter. ''You're going to get a good feel for what I do,'' he said, narrowly missing a bus, ''which is go crazy most of the time. I'm like the old-fashioned general practitioner. I've got all kinds of customers. Boiler makers. Toy importers. The Botanical Garden. People make fun of the Bronx. Listen, I'm loaning money all over this place. Chemical Bank is making good money here. I love the Bronx.'' As the head of one of two lending units in the Bronx commercial office of Chemical Bank, Rich Donatuti lends money to small and medium-sized businesses. He is part missionary, part capitalist. It is tricky work in the best of times, but it gets done now at a dark moment for the banking industry. Banks are in dreadful shape, reeling from the lash of ill-advised loans and intensified competition, their portfolios thick with deadbeat borrowers, and many lenders have tightened their credit. Chemical itself just posted a $43.7 million loss in the third quarter, overwhelmed by problem real-estate loans.
But one market that remains attractive, although it too is slowing down, is the middle market, the loans to companies boasting sales of between $1 million and $250 million. Chemical Bank is the king of New York's middle market, biggest in the country. It estimates it does business with 36 percent of middle-market companies in the region; it has loans to them totaling $5 billion, and another $5 billion in deposits. The work pays well, producing about 15 percent of Chemical's profits, since small companies accept rates that blue-chip companies don't have to and they keep plump deposits in branch accounts, many of which don't pay interest.
One curious landscape in which to see the pursuit of the middle market is the Bronx, speckled with droves of light manufacturers, meat wholesalers and retailers, small companies with large dreams. It is here, mere miles from the slick world of gleaming Manhattan offices, that Rich Donatuti and nine other Chemical account officers ply Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse, rapping on padlocked steel doors. It is not a big growth market, nothing like Manhattan, but it is dense with solid, loyal businesses. As economic clouds darken, many companies are smarting, and some banks are retreating. Chemical, too, has grown wary, but, with other corners of banking drying up, it has been plowing the Bronx harder than ever.
The middle market is one where personal relationships matter more than points above prime, where you need to show up with a smile at customer weddings and where it doesn't hurt to play golf. It is a market where loan officers are habitually on the road. Several days of feverish trips in Rich Donatuti's Chevy offered a glimpse of a life lending money in the wilds of the Bronx, and a window into the world of small business during a harrowing time.
 
'The Tough Ones'
 A security guard was scolding a loiterer outside the Daughter of Jacob Nursing Home, where Mr. Donatuti, accompanied by Robert Pearson, a Chemical account officer, parked, on his way to meet its director. ''They talk about how parking is impossible in New York,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''Not in the Bronx. Of course, the engine's gone when you come back.''
Mr. Donatuti is 39, with short, sandy hair and lively features. He often wears a wistful expression, and he has such ardor for giving out money that it infects those who are with him. He has a contagious rollicking laugh that gets an airing a few hundred times a day. He joined Chemical after acquiring a management science degree in college, and has been there 15 years, the last 14 in the Bronx. ''I don't know what I did wrong in Manhattan,'' he quipped. ''But they won't let me back.'' An endowment fund affiliated with the nursing home needed $1 million to build a new parking garage. Militating against the loan was the fact that the home was losing quite a bit of money. ''These are the tough ones,'' Mr. Donatuti said. He confessed that if this were a brand-new customer rather than a longstanding one he would reject the loan.
 
The Board Member
Joining Mike Brucella, the director, for the session was one of the board members. She snippily said she disliked a previous proposal by Chemical that the loan be secured by Treasury bills it had on deposit. ''We can go to an S.& L.,'' she said. ''They're going out of business anyway.''
She went on, ''We've done so much for so long with Chemical. Now we feel that Chemical should be doing something for us, certainly more than what you've put down here, because we are nonprofit.''
Mr. Pearson said more information was needed on the formal tie between the endowment fund and the nursing home and about the losses experienced by the home.
''Well, we're not going to continue with those losses,'' the woman said. ''So we don't even need to start with that.''
The director interrupted and asked to speak to the woman in private. Once they were out of earshot, Mr. Donatuti said: ''She's off the wall. But I can't tell her that. When you have a situation like this, all you can do is keep things from getting volatile.''
When they returned, Mr. Donatuti said Chemical would try to generate some fresh suggestions. ''O.K., do that,'' the woman said.
Mr. Donatuti dropped in on Diane Rubin, the executive director of the Riverdale Y.M.-Y.W.H.A., which was not having a merry time. The ravages of the economy had sapped it of donations and it was finding it troublesome paying the loan from Chemical, due next July, that financed its new quarters.
''I will recommend an extension,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''But they're on our watch list of risky loans. Yet what choice is there? I could foreclose on the center and kick out thousands of people who use it and become real popular up here or extend it.''
 
'That's Reality'
 Mr. Donatuti had come to take the pulse of recent fund-raising efforts. ''We've been back to the substantial families three and four times,'' Ms. Rubin said. ''We're hearing left and right how bad the market is and how bad the businesses are. It's been a grim story.''
''I think what we need to do is get a schedule and start apprising people at Chemical of what the thoughts are,'' Mr. Donatuti said.
''It's scary,'' Ms. Rubin said. ''For the first time, we don't see the light at the end of the tunnel.'' ''Oh, look, that's reality,'' Mr. Donatuti said. Ambling back to the car, Mr. Donatuti said he would push for a five-year extension. ''I don't want to deal with this stress every year,'' he said.
En route to the next appointment, Mr. Donatuti gave a baleful look out the window and remarked, ''I think the Bronx has really improved from when I started here. When I drove down the Grand Concourse then, I always saw a building burning.''
Mr. Donatuti had come to a restaurant across the street from Chemical's Bronx office, in a hushed and clean building on Riverdale Avenue. As he picked at his lunch, he pointed out that the Bronx office has loans out of about $200 million and similarly sized deposits from those customers, making the loans self-funding.
''Our bread and butter deal is a loan of $450,000 to $1.25 million,'' he said. ''I call these our singles. We hit a lot of singles and we play good defense. I've got one $8 million deal. That's a home run. But it's rare for us to clear the fences. We hit singles.''
The lending is an effective way to attract checking and savings accounts for Chemical branches. ''We only make 1 or 2 percent on loans,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''We make most of our money on balances.''
With the loss of corporate Fortune 500 business to the commercial money markets, banks have chased middle-market business with fervor. In the Bronx, Chemical frequently runs across Citibank, Manufacturers Hanover and Chase. But the sputtering economy has wrought changes. ''We're in a tough credit situation,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''I've seen it for the last six to nine months. So we're trained to look a little harder at something and wonder about the risk. Our credit is not really tightening. But we are talking to our customers more.''
 
Bar Mitzvahs and Golf
 The middle market is a business of relationships, where clients will spurn better terms from another bank because they enjoy the personality of their longtime account officer. Small courtesies add up. Just the other week Mr. Donatuti went to the bar mitzvah of a customer's son. He is a frequent golf partner of customers. It is unnecessary for him to be polite and allow a client to just barely outscore him. He has yet to find anyone needing money he can beat. ''I normally shoot 105, 107, 110,'' he said. ''Let's face it, I'm not good.''
A squirrel scrabbled across the sidewalk as Mr. Donatuti parked his Chevy in front of Dayton Industries, its outside mottled with rust stains, and hustled in to see Fred Collins, the owner. Dayton is a metal fabricator, and when Mr. Donatuti asked for his assessment of his industry, Mr. Collins gave a sad-dog look and said: ''It's been a bloodbath.'' ''How're you doing?'' Mr. Donatuti asked. ''Off 30 percent for the first six months,'' Mr. Collins replied. He said he just laid off his general manager, earning $75,000 a year. ''That was rough.'' Mr. Collins asked about refinancing some outstanding loans - totaling roughly $680,000 - to afford him more working capital.
Mr. Donatuti rattled through some numbers, appraisals and inspections that would be required. It turned out that to do the deal, Mr. Collins might have to cough up fees of more than $25,000. ''Ouch,'' he said.
''It's a lot,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''But look, I didn't ask for your first born.''
''You didn't ask,'' Mr. Collins said. ''But you can have him. He's making good money.''
Mr. Collins said he would ponder the numbers. As the banker left, Mr. Collins said, ''Hey, who'd you have watching your car?'' Mr. Donatuti gave a laugh, even though he gets that line all the time.
The wind blew small bits of rubbish across the lot outside the F. W. Honerkamp Company, a wholesaler of wood products. The company has been leasing its building and the landlord wants to sell. Mr. Donatuti needed to discuss financing possibilities. ''We want him to stay in the Bronx,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''He could easily go to Jersey or to Westchester.''
Two of the Honerkamps gathered in a conference room with Mr. Donatuti.
''O.K.,'' Mr. Donatuti said, ''so you want to know what do I need to finance this sucker?'' ''A gun,'' Frank Honerkamp said. ''Not really,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''But a lot of money.''
They sped through numbers, options, concluded that the best bet would be if the landlord cut his price and did some of the financing.
Mr. Donatuti had some simple calls. He checked on a renewal of credit with Mario Sardo, owner of Fordham Marble, a prospering marble wholesaler, who teased Mr. Donatuti that a Japanese bank had come calling and maybe he was interested. He acknowledged another credit line renewal to C. C. Controlled Combustion, a successful oil burner company. Because C. C. Control was a loyal customer, Mr. Donatuti had even agreed to assume a mortgage on an Atlantic City condominium that the president had acquired. ''You do that stuff for a good guy,'' he said.
 
Going South?
 Buckets of rain came down as Mr. Donatuti popped in on the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, an outfit that promotes Bronx development. Chemical has some mortgages through it and it regularly refers clients, so Mr. Donatuti makes a point of keeping in touch. ''How's it going?'' asked John Patterson, the group's president. ''We've had a good year and we're positioned for another good year,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''But everyone's worried about the economy.''
''You know, I heard from two banks recently that the Bronx is their best market,'' Mr. Patterson said.
''This is a very strong market,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''Of course, I do worry about what the economy will mean for our customers. Yet I look at our portfolios every single day and I don't see anyone who I think will go south on us.'' ''Is anyone expanding?'' Mr. Patterson wondered. ''A minority are,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''The majority of companies are trying to walk very, very slowly.''
On the way back to the office, Mr. Donatuti zipped past a strip of auto-glass purveyors. ''There're lots of them up here,'' he said. ''We do nothing with them. They're all cash businesses. We call them cash and carry. Get the cash and carry it to the mattress.''
On a Wednesday morning, Mr. Donatuti had a credit analysis meeting in his office. He perused an application by a company that sold repair supplies to owners of apartment buildings. It wished to borrow more money and have a mortgage assumed.
''We need to do more homework,'' Mr. Donatuti said. ''We've got to do a vendor check and a receivables check.'' ''What's his personal statement look like?'' someone asked. ''Not strong,'' the credit analyst said. ''He's got a 60-foot boat with a $400,000 mortgage. He's got an $800,000 house. He's got a Rolls-Royce. All mortgaged.''
''Maybe the bank needs a boat,'' Mr. Donatuti said.
 
Blitz Day
 Shortly after dawn, six Chemical teams of two bent over their bagels and coffee in the Bronx conference room. Today was a ''blitz'' day. A blitz is a roughly every-other-month phenomenon for Chemical's Bronx office (it's commonplace at other banks as well) during which loan officers are dispatched to competitor clients to try to persuade them to borrow from Chemical.
Mr. Donatuti was paired with Susan Rogan. Against her best instincts, she allowed Mr. Donatuti the wheel. Screaming down the Henry Hudson Parkway, he remarked, ''Over a year of blitzing, if we pick up a half a dozen to 10 solid relationships, that would be good. To get them, you need to make several hundred calls. It's a lot of work, but it's necessary.''
At the first call, an oil company, the owner was out and not expected back for the day. Ms. Rogan did note that the office was one of the nicer ones she had encountered; she saw no bugs.
At the next call, an elevator service firm, the executive vice president said business was great and he was dashing to a meeting, leave your card.
At Selby Furniture, which makes hinges for the furniture industry, the owner gave the team a warm greeting but no definite interest.
Time was now running short, because everyone was to be back at the office by 12:15 for a blitz wrap-up.
Reassembled in the conference room, the teams recounted their experiences and then classified each prospect as ''hot,'' ''warm'' or ''cold.'' The final tally was three hot, seven warm and 10 cold.
All in all, Mr. Donatuti considered the blitz disappointing. But he had no time to brood, for he had to hop into the car for another round of adventures. ''You going to drive, Richie?'' someone asked. ''Yeah,'' he said.
''Well, let's all pray.''
 
KEEPING COMPETITORS AT BAY
Though king of the middle market seemingly forever, and with a wide lead over its rivals, Chemical Bank is not without feisty competitors looking to broaden their penetration if the risk is not too great.
Citibank, which ranks as the No. 2 player in New York's middle market, finds middle-market companies suffering from less liquidity and scrambling to conserve cash.
''Yet the opportunities to do business are greater because more banks are pulling out of this market,'' said Alan Weiss, the managing director of Citibank's business and professional banking for the New York area. ''We see this as a prime time to stay committed to this market.''
Manufacturers Hanover Trust is also applying some heat. ''I think this is still a very attractive business for the bank,'' said Carol Parry, who heads the business banking group that embraces companies with sales of $3 million to $40 million. ''The problem is the economy. Businesses aren't growing the way they were so there are fewer lending opportunities, and businesses are keeping smaller deposits.''
Nonetheless, Ms. Parry, who oversaw the middle-market business at Chemical until she left in 1989, said Manufacturers is ''very aggressively looking for new business.'' Among other things, she said, the bank plans to increase marketing efforts and introduce more attractive pricing.
 
LOANS THAT GO SOUR
Though Chemical Bank feels most of its middle-market customers are loyal and solid, it has had its share of loans explode on it.
 The Bronx office writes off about $100,000 a year in bad loans, according to Richard Donatuti, who heads one of Chemical's commercial lending units there. Mr. Donatuti said he personally has written off just $2,000, lent to a silk-screening business that was ripped apart by squabbling.
Among current time bombs are the roughly $500,000 lent to a window manufacturer that branched into installation and, as Mr. Donatuti put it, ''got burnt big-time.'' The company sought protection from its creditors, including Chemical, under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code, but Mr. Donatuti is hopeful that much of the money will be retrieved.
Another borrower, a medical supplier, is in Chapter 11 and Mr. Donatuti believes that $25,000 to $50,000 of loans will have to be eaten there.
The office loses some customers in other ways. It recently refused a loan to a supermarket chain because it felt the chain was overextended. Chase gave the money. And when Chemical closed a branch on 125th Street in Manhattan, a plumbing and lighting wholesaler located across the street switched to Citibank, which was more convenient.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Restrained Corporate Political Speech

BYLINE: By S. PRAKASH SETHI; S. Prakash Sethi teaches at Baruch College and the Rochester Institute of Technology. He is author of ''Advocacy Advertising and Large Corporations,'' and ''Handbook of Advocacy Advertising.''

 BODY:
In one of last summer's Supreme Court decision - Austin v. Michigan Chamber of Commerce - the Court upheld a Michigan law prohibiting corporations from using their treasury funds for independent expenditures to advance or oppose political candidates. The case involved an attempt by the Michigan Chamber of Commerce to place a local newspaper advertisement in support of a candidate for state office. The Court held that corporations can engage in political speech only if they use segregated funds, voluntarily collected through such mechanisms as political action committees that accurately reflect the contributors' support for the corporation's political views.
Critics of the decision - including the author of the minority opinion - have been quick to raise the specter of an unwarranted encroachment on free speech. These critics contend that the decision, if left unchallenged, would lead to a further and more pernicious restraint of political debate by other groups, including businesses. 
I believe these concerns to be unfounded. If anything, the Court's decision is a step in the right direction and is in line with its previous decisions regarding free speech.
In 1986, in Federal Election Commission vs. Massachusetts Citizens For Life Inc., the Court gave a bona fide political organization the right to endorse candidates with its own treasury funds. But in this case, it was clear that the members shared the organization's political views. Additionally, in the same decision in 1986, the Court denied such rights to corporations. This set out the doctrine adhered to later in Austin vs. Michigan Chamber of Commerce.
The Michigan decision, in my opinion, adds to free speech rights. In it, the Court affirmed the right of the management to engage in political speech on behalf of the corporation. However, it also wanted to insure that what it called the ''speech attributable'' individuals, the stock holders, for example, do not have their free speech rights taken by others who abrogate those rights by claiming to speak on their behalf.
The primary issue here is the right of the management of a company to engage in political speech as if it were the corporation. The issue also focuses on the extent to which stockholders or members of a particular group have the right to influence political speech made on their behalf by the organization and its leaders.
In the corporate world, real power is controlled by a small group of top managers. These managers most often also exercise effective control over the company's board of directors. The power of shareholders is currently severely limited in influencing management decisions often even in economic areas affecting the shareholder's vital interests. By giving managers the unrestrained right to use corporate resources to express particular viewpoints, the court would be rendering a large group of legitimate owners powerless.
How would the advocates of management's right to speak on behalf of the corporation react if the management were to use corporate funds to advocate the passage of laws that strengthened management's rights against those of the stockholders in the event of unfriendly takeovers? And what if a majority of large corporations were to use their tremendous resources - such as the stockholders' money - to advocate the election of political candidates and the passage of laws that would severely restrict the rights of stockholders in voting out current management?
Morally and legally, would it really matter very much whether these shareholders were ''greedy corporate raiders,'' and that the managers were ''corporate statesmen'' acting to protect the interests of all of a corporation's constituencies? I don't think so.
Institutional investors have demonstrated greater activism in protecting shareholder rights. They should now build upon these successes by exerting more pressure on behalf of First Amendment rights. It would be a tragedy indeed if society were to endow further rights to the management without instituting realistic safeguards.
Corporate free speech under these circumstances would not only abridge the rights of the shareholders, but would also most likely misrepresent the views of the majority of workers, supervisors, and even middle managers, because no efforts would have been made to ascertain their opinions or to act upon them.
I believe that corporations should go beyond the Court-mandated provisions before engaging in political speech. Corporations should create mechanisms for building effective consensus on controversial issues of social policy. They should become more responsive to diverse views of stockholders, other corporate constituencies and public sentiment.
If corporations were to do this, it would give management the legitimacy that is a prerequisite for effective corporate governance. It would also minimize the potential for the enactment of statutes that would lead to greater encroachment on management's discretion. After all, in the real world, there exist high entry barriers into the marketplace of ideas for those without a large cache of money. It is the powerless who need the most protection to exercise their free speech rights. The Court is on the right track.

GRAPHIC: Photo: S. Prakash Sethi (Baruch College); drawing

HEADLINE: Looking for Growth in the Domestic Market

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
At Mr. Micro, a three-store personal computer chain in Dallas, sales of the International Business Machine Corporation's sharp new PS/1 home computer have been brisk. The Texas retailer has sold 200 of the machines since August and its president, Marty Ackerman, says he's looking forward to Christmas.
His optimism may be ill-founded. Both market researchers and computer makers have predicted a new bloom for the home market, and a host of computer makers, including I.B.M., Philips, Tandy and most recently, Apple Computer, have piled into the market looking for new growth. Commodore, which still has 19 percent of the American home computer market, plans to enter the fray later (box). But the ebbing economy may give consumers second thoughts about spending up to $2,000 on a single purchase.
Home computer makers are used to such turns of fate. Fickle consumers bought millions of PC's in the early 1980's, only to mothball them when the fad fizzled. 
But believing the 90's are different, computer companies are plying the market anew, with approaches all aimed at making the machines simpler to use. Analysts say the home market is ripe for growth because people are more familiar with computers than they were in the early 80's and are more eager to use them at home. ''More people are familiar with using PC's at work, and are not uncomfortable with using them at home,'' said Ray Boggs of Biz Cap International, a market research firm in Boston.
According to Donna K. Bonyun, a researcher at Dataquest Inc. in San Jose, Calif., 18 percent of all households in the United States now have computers, up from 15 percent for the last three years. Dataquest expects the home computer market to expand by an annual 16.3 percent for the next five years, ahead of the business market, which it expects to grow by 12.6 percent annually.
Adds Ms. Bonyun: ''The home market is very much driven by business applications. Most people who buy a home computer are buying it for some business application.''
Indeed, at Mr. Micro, the largest group of customers for I.B.M.'s PS/1 has been white-collar workers who have been laid off by Fortune 500 companies and need a home computer to prepare resumes or start a business.
But economic uncertainties could put a chill over the consumer electronics market. Creative Strategies Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif., conducted two nationwide surveys of 5,000 potential first-time home computer buyers.
The first, taken in June, showed that 1,500 of those called were considering buying a computer. Three weeks ago, almost 60 percent of those 1,500 respondents said they had postponed their plans.
''Sales of the PS/1 are basically stalled,'' said Tim Bajarin of Creative Strategies. ''More worrisome, it's going to be stalled going in to the fourth quarter.''
Vowing it has done its homework and learned its lessons, I.B.M. has returned to the home market hoping to avoid a failure of PCjr. proportions.
 
The Lessons at I.B.M.
Once Burned, Twice Cautious
In 1985, the Armonk, N.Y.-based computer maker withdrew from that market because of the poor response to its PCjr., which was viewed as technically weak and too expensive to be treated as a toy, as I.B.M. had positioned it.
After a cautious three-city introduction in August in carefully chosen department stores, I.B.M. has declared its new PS/1 formula, based on months of market research, a success and has expanded its sales nationwide.
In the PS/1, I.B.M. has tried to create a sophisticated machine that is easy to handle. It has reduced the various choices that come with buying a home computer by putting together a ready-made package: a full-featured machine for the whole family. It has the processing power to handle spreadsheet programs and the graphics capability - I.B.M.'s top-of-the-line high-resolution graphics display is a standard for the PS/1 - to run programs like the I.B.M.-Sears Prodigy on-line service, which allows electronic home shopping and banking.
As much thought seems to have gone into packaging and marketing as into the product design. I.B.M. executives take pride in the fact that the computer comes in a single box. And it is designed to be up and running right after it is unpacked: All models come with a mouse and a modem and, rather than being barren of software, these come with a range of programs, from Microsoft's Works to special communications software which provides a plug into Prodigy.
To take the aggravation out of repairs, I.B.M. technicians can diagnose a system failure over the telephone. If something is wrong, a new computer will be shipped express within 48 hours.
But skeptics argue that by using Intel's 80286 microprocessor instead of a more powerful chip, I.B.M. has limited the scope of its potential market and repeated one mistake that undermined the PCjr. This flaw has led John C. Dvorak, a computer columnist, to call the PS/1 a ''weeny'' computer.
I.B.M. chose the less powerful chip in part because it is after first-time buyers. But critics contend that most current demand is from seasoned users. ''The PS/1 is miscast,'' said Seymour Merrin, an analyst at Merrin Research Inc. ''There are virtually no first-time users buying computers today.''
He warns that the company's statements that the PS/1 is ahead of expectations must be measured with care. The company's reports are based on shipments rather than retail sales. ''They're trying desperately to stuff the channel,'' he said. ''But there is no ground swell waiting for this product.''
 
The First-Time Tandy
Holding Down Cost And Complexity
In these recessionary times, first-time buyers are probably more apt to spend in the $500-to-$700 range on a starter computer than to splurge on a PS/1, which starts at $999 for a bare-bones model.
Of the machines to come to market in the last six months, only the Tandy Corporation's RL series, introduced in July, comes close to this price range. These machines are designed to function more as a home appliance than as a computer - no harder to use than a Cuisinart and just as practical. The company has included dozens of small programs that do useful tasks like calculate interest payments on loans and store information, but require minimal learning.
Priced between $749 and $1298, Tandy's new line has apparently been selling well against the PS/1, its closest competitor in price. Notably, Ed Juge, Tandy's director of market planning, said that the company has seen its best sales in the three cities where I.B.M. has focused its PS/1 marketing: Chicago, Minneapolis and Dallas.
The Texas-based Tandy, one of the first personal computer makers, says that in recent months, its personal computer sales have been up 10 percent, largely because of the success of the RL line.
 
The Aging Apple
Replacing An Old Standard
Perhaps no company has more to lose in this new home computer contest than Apple Computer. For more than a decade, the venerable Apple II has been a standard in both schools and the home. But the II has increasingly shown its age - its graphics capabilities pale by today's standards and the computer lacks new software. Apple's share of the low end of the computer market has eroded as a result: Recently, I.B.M. has made impressive gains in sales to schools, which influence home-buying decisions.
Apple's new series of low-cost Macintoshes, introduced last week, is intended to prop up its market presence and be more competitively priced with I.B.M. computers and compatibles. They enjoy greater ease-of-use than either the new I.B.M. or Tandy home machines. Apple's new version of its Mac II, the Macintosh LC, which comes with an inexpensive color monitor, is priced to compete with I.B.M.'s $2,000 PS/1. And Apple's lowest-price machine, the $999 Classic, goes head-to-head with the entry-level PS/1.
Apple projects rapid growth for the home market. It recently told one of its mouse suppliers that the supplier's capacity to produce 250,000 mice per month might not be enough. That would more than double Apple's current sales volume of Macintoshes.
 
OFF IN THE DISTANCE: THE MULTIMEDIA MACHINE
Despite the new wave of home computers, many analysts believe that buyers won't make any purchases until a reasonably priced ''multimedia personal computer'' is developed. Such machines represent the next generation in home computer technology, combining the audio, video and animation qualities of television with the interactivity of a computer.
Most analysts acknowledge that it will be several years before prices for such machines, now $3,000 or more, fall to below $1,000, qualifying them as true consumer products. The holdup? Multimedia machines need expanded storage capacity like that offered by CD-ROM disks, which are still costly.
Yet there are several early attempts to bring together multimedia features in desktop packages. Earlier this year, Philips introduced a top-of-the-line computer based on Intel's 386 processor with a built-in CD-ROM drive that range in price from $1,999 to $2,799.
At the Consumer Electronics Show last summer, Commodore International demonstrated a system known as Commodore Dynamic Total Visionthat may be on the market later this year. The system, which is supposed to retail for less than $1,000, will look like a video cassette recorder and will hook into a television. Instead of a keyboard, the machine will be operated with an infrared remote control device.
The remaining question is whether the most popular systems will connect with the television or the computer. Japanese and European television makers are designing systems that plug directly into televisions. But American computer makers are trying to ward off the trend. Early next year, Tandy and the Microsoft Corporation are expected to unveil a multimedia home computer that will run with computers using moderately powered 286 chips. And I.B.M. is expected to enter the market in 1992.

HEADLINE: Tech Notes;
Electricity From Wind

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
With oil prices rising and concern about the environment growing, alternative ways to generate electricity are becoming even more attractive. Now a company in Livermore, Calif., U.S. Windpower Inc., is developing a wind-powered turbine for generating electricity that according to the California Energy Commission will cost 5.3 cents a kilowatt. This would make the turbine competitive in cost with natural gas, oil, coal and nuclear power, but without the environmental impact. The new turbine has three blades, each 54 feet long, with a rotor diameter of 106 feet, nearly twice that of previous models. The generator has a rating of 300 kilowatts. Unlike previous models, which can be damaged if operated in winds that are too high, U.S. Windpower said, the turbine has an electronically controlled gearbox enabling it to operate safely in high or variable winds. The turbine is designed to produce either AC or DC electricity.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
The Lure of Single-State Munis

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
As budget talks intensify in Washington, investors are diving for cover. But they don't have to stray far from home. The prospect of higher taxes has given new luster to single-state municipal bond funds, which invest in debt issued by a state, its municipalities or agencies.
''Taxes will rise and that fuels the desire for tax-exempt income,'' said A. Michael Lipper, president of Lipper Analytical Services, in Summit, N.J.
In fact, single-state municipal bond funds are the fastest-growing segment of the mutual fund industry. The number of home-grown funds, available in 30 states, has more than tripled since 1985 while assets have increased fourfold to $46.4 billion in June, Lipper said. And experts expect that growth to continue, even in the face of deteriorating municipal finances in various places and the risk that introduces. 
There are good reasons for the popularity of single-state funds: Yields are high, the stock market looks dicey and state taxes are spiraling heavenward. But erosion in some states' economies is beginning to concern investors, so be forewarned: New York and Massachusetts investors, in particular, should keep no more than 40 or 50 percent of their total tax-free portfolio in state bonds, said Christine Carter Lynch, a Santa Fe, N.M.-based money manager and editor of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory, an investment newsletter. Even in better-managed states, she recommends tying up no more than 75 percent of tax-free assets in-state.
Any tax increases translate into better yields for single-state municipal bonds because income earned by most of the funds is exempt from Federal, state and local taxes. In many states, the state-and-local tax tab can run 10 percent or more.
But there are some exceptions. Interest on some or all bonds issued by Illinois, Iowa, Mississippi, New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Kansas, Oklahoma and Wisconsin is taxable to state residents, said David J. Mangefreda, assistant general counsel for the Investment Company Institute. And some states, like Florida and Texas, have no income tax. Despite the fact that there is no tax advantage, investors buy funds from such states because ''people like to invest in bonds that they feel comfortable with,'' Ms. Lynch said. Connecticut, too, has no state income tax, but it levies a stiff tax on interest and dividends. As a result, single-state funds, whose income is tax-free, are extremely popular there.
By contrast, Indiana, New Mexico, North Dakota, Utah and the District of Columbia do not tax the interest from any municipal bonds. That means that if you live in those places you get the same tax break from single-state funds as you would from any of the national municipal bond funds, which buy issues of many states.
In New Jersey and New York, interest on municipal bonds issued by those states is tax-free to state residents, but interest on municipal bonds issued elsewhere is not.
When does a single-state fund make sense? To figure the rough taxable-equivalent yield, divide the fund's yield by one minus your combined Federal and state tax rates. Then compare that with yields from another investment. For instance, a New York fund yields 7 percent and an investor in the 33 percent Federal and 7 percent state tax bracket is thinking about buying into it. When that investor uses the formula for approximating yields - 7 divided by 1 minus .40 - the investor sees that the fund's 7 percent yield is roughly equal to a taxable investment yielding 11.6 percent. (The actual yields are slightly less because state taxes are deductible on Federal tax returns.) Because of differences in the quality and maturity of bonds held by the funds, yields vary. So it pays to shop around. For example, the average 12-month yield of the 49 New York funds tracked by Lipper is 6.8 percent as of Sept. 30. But Paine Webber Municipal Classic-New York yields 7.6 percent, while the laggard, the Landmark New York Tax-Free Income, yields only 5.9 percent. The 58 California funds yield an average of 6.7 percent, but Franklin California Tax-Free Income yields 7.5 percent and the three bottom-ranked funds yield only 6.1 percent.
Other considerations: When you choose a single-state municipal bond fund, check its average maturity. The longer the maturity, the more volatile the performance because the price of the bonds in the fund's portfolio can move sharply up or down. The average maturity of the New York funds is 21.7 years, but ranges as high as 28 years for Alliance Municipal Income-New York.
In addition, tightly strained state budgets make it worthwhile to look at the credit quality of the bonds in the fund. In New York, the average fund keeps 27.4 percent of its portfolio in AAA bonds, the highest-rated, but some funds have much more.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
An Economist Kicks the Clouds Away

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
Most economists, looking at the future, are gloomy right now. Not so Mark A. Miles, executive vice president and senior economist at H. C. Wainwright Economics, a consulting firm in Boston. In a conversation with Joel Kurtzman of The New York Times, Mr. Miles, who has a doctorate in economics from the University of Chicago, outlined his forecast for strong growth in 1991.
Q. What is your forecast for the coming year? 
Mr. Miles: Contrary to most people, we at Wainwright are very, very bullish. People keep asking me, is this another 1973, when we had a recession and oil-price rise? No. I think it is more like 1987, when the stock market plunged but the economy did very well. We see the economy turning around by the end of the year and accelerating into 1992. We could have 3 percent growth next year and perhaps even 4 percent in 1992.
Q. Why are you so bullish?
Mr. Miles: Let's just say it's a minority point of view. But our track record is very good. In the spring of 1981, when we made our official forecast for 1982, we called for a downturn in the economy of 2 percent. We were right. There was a deep recession in 1982. In middle of the 1982 recession, we said 1983 and 1984 would be the best two years since the Korean War. That turned out to be true. When the stock market plunged in 1987, we had already made our forecast for 1988. We said in 1988 growth would be at 4.7 percent, and it was something between 4 and 4.5 percent - pretty close. Everyone else was cutting their estimates because of the stock market collapse. But we said no recession in 1988, and we kept to it. Then, in the spring of 1989, we said there would be a recession - a mild one - in 1990, and here we are. We see 1991 as a typical first year following a recession. It will be led by consumer durables, housing, autos, appliances and retail sales.
Q. What role does higher-priced oil play in your forecast?
Mr. Miles: Ah, oil, that three-letter word. A lot of attention is going to it. That's why people ask if this is like 1973. It's true oil prices are up. But in 1973 other things were up as well. Gold was up, short-term interest rates were up and commodities were up.
But today gold prices are below where they were at the end of last year. Short-term interest rates are below where they were in July. Commodity prices are falling. The question is: Which are the more reliable signals of the economy? History and the data tell us that oil does not tell us whether the economy will grow slowly or more rapidly.
Q. You mentioned gold. What is the price of gold telling us?
Mr. Miles: The fact that gold has not risen like oil, and that other commodities have not risen, means we won't see accelerating inflation.
Q. What kind of a job is the Federal Reserve Board doing right now?
Mr. Miles: The Fed is paralyzed by two of its paradigms. One says raise interest rates because of the threat of inflation, and unless interest rates go up inflation will take off. That assumes higher interest rates are followed by lower inflation, and lower interest rates are followed by higher inflation. That's incorrect. We have found that higher Fed rates are associated with higher inflation rates. The Fed's first paradigm does not square with the facts.
The Fed's second paradigm is that the way to control a weak economy is to allow rates to fall. Our empirical work shows that changes in interest rates are destabilizing to the economy and that they cause the growth rate to flucuate.
Q. What facts do you base your reasoning on?
Mr. Miles: We have been looking at the relationship between interest rates and the economy over the last 40 years. We have been making our own forecasts for the last 10 years. We've been able to pick turning points by abandoning the two paradigms. We simply let the data tell the story.
Ideally, what we would like to have is price stability and a stable economy. We are not likely to achieve a stable economy by shifting interest rates up and down.
That means the best Federal Reserve policy is to focus on stabilizing interest rates, the dollar and prices directly. The traditional way is to hold reserves of gold or other commodities and when the dollar price of gold rises, step in and sell gold and buy dollars. When the price of gold falls, you buy back gold and sell dollars.
Q. Are you advocating a return to a fixed-exchange-rate system?
Mr. Miles: Just go back and look at the post-World War II Bretton Woods economic system. Until the mid- to late-1960's, the dollar was pegged to gold. Other countries pegged their currencies to the dollar, and they were all tied to the American inflation rate. Between 1947 and 1964, America's inflation rate averaged about 1.5 percent a year. Treasury bills averaged less than a 2 percent yield. Price stability was a major componenent in the postwar growth.
What can we in United States do by ourselves? We can stabilize inflation and interest rates in this country and get ourselves back on track. If we then were also to go to an international system where other countries tied themselves into our stability by pegging their rates and currencies to ours, they too could get their economies on track.

LENGTH: 1980 words

HEADLINE: The Baldrige Badge of Courage - and Quality

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The envelope, please. This year's winners are the Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation, the Rochester division of the International Business Machines Corporation, the Federal Express Corporation and the Wallace Company, a Houston-based distributor of industrial plumbing supplies.
All four are recipients of the most recent crop of Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Awards, Presidential citations given to companies that have made the greatest strides in improving quality and consumer satisfaction with their products and services.
Initiated in obscurity three years ago, the award has rapidly become a glittering prize for many top executives who see it as an official recognition of their behind-the-scenes efforts to improve quality. ''The Baldrige award has helped rally business around a common objective,'' said John F. Akers, the chairman of I.B.M.
Some quality experts say the requirements to win the award are having an impact on American business that goes well beyond the companies that have actually applied. ''We have sent out 175,000 copies of the guidelines for application this year alone,'' said Curt W. Reimann, an official at the National Institute of Standards and Technology, who directs the program. ''We are defining what quality is for the nation. Companies are using these criteria as a self-assessment tool.'' 
The application forces companies to go through a detailed self-examination in seven categories: leadership, information and analysis, strategic quality planning, human resource utilization, quality assurance of products and services, quality results and customer satisfaction. The number of requests for the guidelines booklet has soared from 12,000 in 1988.
The Baldrige award, named for the former Secretary of Commerce who was killed in a rodeo accident in 1987, is loosely modeled after Japan's Deming Award, which has been presented in Japan since 1951 to recognize achievements in improving quality. The enormous economic success of Japanese companies, based in recent years more on a reputation for quality than on low price, has deeply impressed American managers, many of whom have lost markets to the Japanese.
Ironically, the Japanese award is named after W. Edwards Deming, an American quality specialist whose ideas were eagerly adopted by the Japanese in the 1950's after being largely disregarded at home.
The Baldrige award is now bringing attention back to those ideas. ''I feel good for what it is doing for the United States,'' said Norman E. Rickard, vice president for quality at the Xerox Corporation, a 1989 Baldrige winner. ''When we started in 1982 there were not many places in the United States where you could get information on total quality control.''
Baldrige award winners are required to share their knowledge. For example, Motorola Inc., Westinghouse's nuclear fuel division and Milliken & Company have given dozens of seminars and sent hundreds of speakers to other companies.
Part of the message is the argument that better quality does not necessarily mean higher costs. In fact, it can actually lower production costs, when flaws are eliminated and hence no longer require time and labor to correct. Armand V. Feigenbaum, a quality consultant who heads the General Systems Company, said his studies have indicated that 10 to 40 percent of the total productive capacity of a typical company exists solely to fix or replace poor-quality work.
''The widespread application of Baldrige standards could add 7 percent to the gross national product,'' Mr. Feigenbaum said. He said the figure was based on an economic model of the economy and estimates of the gains from quality improvements.
The Baldrige award program was established by Congress in 1987 when improving quality was moving to the forefront of many corporate agendas. The competition was intended for profit-making corporations in three categories: manufacturing, service industries and small business, defined as companies with not more than 500 full-time employees.
Applicants have to fill out a detailed questionnaire with 33 categories, each weighted with a certain number of points out of a total of 1,000. An example: ''Employee involvement. Describe the means available for all employees to contribute effectively to the company's quality objectives; summarize trends in involvement.'' That is worth 40 points.
The applications are reviewed by a board of examiners chosen largely from industry, but with a sprinkling of academics and consultants. Companies that pass muster on paper are visited by a group of examiners to make sure that what has been described is accurate. A nine-member panel of judges makes the final decision. The awards are limited to two companies in each category.
Although the award is public, most of the proceedings are conducted in secret. The applications are treated as confidential and an outside contractor is used to administer the program; as a result, the records are not subject to Freedom of Information requests. The names of unsuccessful applicants are also concealed.
Organizers defend the secrecy as necessary to persuade companies to reveal information that could be helpful to competitors if made public. ''If you really describe what you are doing, it is going to involve proprietary information,'' said A. Blanton Godfrey, chairman of the Juran Institute, a quality consulting firm, and a member of the Baldrige panel of judges. ''We felt confidentiality was necessary to get people to play the game.''
The organizers also go to great pains to avoid conflicts of interest among the judges. For example, an examiner from the Digital Equipment Company would not be assigned to read an application from I.B.M.
The names of the companies are deleted in the early stages of judging and examiners do not know who else is working on a case until after the first round of ratings. The result, Baldrige officials say, is to insulate the process from commercial or political influence.
''We have devised a process we like to think of as impenetrable,'' Mr. Reimann said. ''Sixteen different people have to render judgment in the average case,'' and the candidates do not know who they are. ''We do not think there is any possible path for company or political influence.''
Cadillac and I.B.M.'s Rochester division are the 1990 winners in the manufacturing category, after failing to make the cut last year. Federal Express is the first to have won in the service category (nobody was deemed worthy last year or the year before), and Wallace is only the second in small business. (The first was Globe Metallurgical, a foundry based in Cleveland that won in 1988.) To John Grettenberger, the general manager of Cadillac, the award is a vindication of the progress Detroit has made recently in catching up with imports in quality. ''For the last four years we have been the top domestic manufacturer in consumer satisfaction surveys,'' he said. ''Now we have a Presidential citation.'' The award noted that Cadillac's warranty had been increased to four years or 50,000 miles from one year or 12,000 miles in 1988, but its warranty related costs dropped 29 percent in the last four years. ''In tests of 1990 and 1991 cars, nearly all models met or exceeded world-class levels for reliability and durability,'' the award citation said.
At I.B.M. Rochester, the Baldrige examiners noted that improvements in quality had translated directly into productivity gains. Revenues per employee increased 30 percent from 1986 to 1989, and the time to develop a new mid-range computer has been cut in half.
Larry L. Osterwise, the manager of the division, said the feedback from the failed 1989 application motivated the company to push harder to improve quality. ''We learned a lot about ourselves through the application and the self-examination it involves,'' he said. One change, he said, was to formalize the procedure for forming problem-solving teams. Another was to focus training programs more sharply.
''Education around here used to be like a college catalogue - you could pick and choose. After 1989 we decided there were things everybody needed to learn in terms of customer needs, defects and benchmarking. Everybody got educated about that in nine months.''
Baldrige winners say the principal benefit of the application process is the internal changes required, not the reward itself. ''The point is not to win a trophy and go back to the old ways of doing things,'' said Jack Roberts, vice president for quality at Federal Express. ''The objective is to change and improve the quality of the service we provide.''
Mr. Roberts said because of his company's rapid growth, older measures of performance, like the percentage of packages delivered on time, have become obselete. ''We are delivering 1,250,000 packages a day. If we have a 99 percent success rate that means we have thousands of customers a day that are unhappy with us. That is unacceptable. Our objective is to drive down the absolute number of failures.''
The award cited Federal Express's use of computers and tracking systems to follow packages and its Service Quality Indicator performance index, which is transmitted to each employee every day. ''Executive bonuses rest on the performance of the whole organization in meeting performance goals,'' the citation noted, adding that bonuses are suspended if employees do not rate management leadership at least as high as the previous year in an annual survey.
Although most Baldrige winners prefer to emphasize the internal benefits, it is clear that winning is good for business as well. ''If you talk to district sales people, you hear stories of them getting their foot in the door to talk about quality and that later led to sales,'' said Sam Malone Jr., a spokesman for Xerox's Rochester quality office.
Indeed, Mr. Grettenberger thinks the award will brighten the outlook of General Motors employees who have been ground down by a decade of market share loss to the Japanese - as well as helping move a few more Cadillacs out of the showroom. ''The great benefit is to the corporation itself,'' he said. ''When you go around the offices and plants you see people smiling again.''
 
A WINNER'S ROAD MAP
The Wallace Company, which is based in Houston, supplies pipes, valves and fittings to the huge chemical and petroleum refining plants that dot the Gulf Coast. Delays in delivering parts can result in the shutdown of major facilities with losses to the refineries counted in thousands of dollars an hour.
So to the $100 million-a-year company - this year's Baldrige winner in the small-business category - fast action is important. The company decided that the quality of its service was a matter of knowing precisely what customers needed and moving on it as quickly as possible.
''We found that the Baldrige criteria were a good road map to where we wanted to go,'' said Michael E. Spiess, a vice president of the family-owned company. ''It was easy to understand, but tough to do.''
The award noted that the company has improved its rate of on-time deliveries from 75 percent in 1987 to 92 percent this year, as a result of programs that emphasized teamwork and training.
Customers are surveyed regularly on the company's performance. And there is a rule that all customer inquiries and complaints must be addressed within 60 minutes.
To insure that parts meet customer expectations, Wallace insists that its own suppliers guarantee products for at least a year. It has cut the number of suppliers to 325 from more than 2,000 in 1987 to weed out those unable to perform.
''We decided to use quality,'' Mr. Spies said, ''to differentiate our business from others in the same field.''
The effort has paid off. According to the citation, sales have grown 69 percent since 1987 and profits have grown more than sevenfold.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
The Market in Moscow's Future

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
John J. Phelan Jr., the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, made a promise to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the President of the Soviet Union, on a visit to Moscow just over a week ago.
Mr. Phelan, a 35-year veteran of free markets, told the Soviet leader that the New York Stock Exchange would take special note of the opening of a stock exchange in Moscow. A plaque would appear near the urn in the exchange boardroom that commemorates the first trading of Czarist bonds in New York in 1905. And the Soviet flag would fly next to the American flag on Broad Street. 
But Mr. Phelan, on his return from a three-day conference on stock markets, also said that the day of celebration is some time off. Even if limited trading begins in a year and a half, which he thinks is likely, a vibrant and useful stock market in the Soviet Union is a hope for much further in the future.
''They still have only a vague notion of what a market is,'' he said in an interview.
This is important for investors to remember - as well as for officials in the Soviet Union and elsewhere who want to stimulate their economies by selling state-owned companies to the public.
Indeed, proposals for investing in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union are multiplying and many will ultimately require an efficient and liquid stock market as the avenue for taking profit. This is true already in Hungary, which recently opened its first stock market. And it will be true for the Soviet Companies Fund, a venture announced last week by Batterymarch Financial Management of Boston and Soviet officials. The fund will invest from $400 million to $1 billion in Soviet companies.
Mr. Phelan said that the first trading in the Soviet Union is likely to begin with notes and bonds. Already, some banks in Leningrad are selling notes at an 11 percent interest rate that could become tradeable. But he also said the Government probably would decide to sell some state-owned companies soon and have that stock traded in the new market.
This will provide important experience. But it is a long way from a small start like that to an efficient exchange in a country where trades that produce a profit are still illegal. Despite all the talk of free markets during the recent conference, Mr. Phelan said, the Soviet officials kept asking, ''When does the state come in to set the price?''
''I am worried that the expectations are greater than what can be produced in the short term,'' Mr. Phelan said. ''Three years to a big, broad liquid stock market is more a hope than a reality. But in the intermediate to long term, I think they can get a market up and do a lot of privatizing.''
The Tokyo market stock rallied last week with the Nikkei 225 index rising 2,090.88 points, or 8.5 percent, to close at 24,481.49. Friday was the most active day of the year: 1.1 billion shares traded hands as investors scrambled to get back into the market. The index is now 24 percent above its low point for the year, which was reached after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the official discount rate was increased by the Bank of Japan.
The reason for the rally is a new confidence riding on the back of the strengthening yen. There is also a hope that as the yen gets even stronger, the Bank of Japan will lower interest rates, which have already fallen slightly. And there are some recent signs that the economy may be slowing a bit, a goal that the bank has pressed in its fight against emerging inflation.
''It is really a turning point for the economy and for the stock market,'' said Akira Suzuki, chief strategist for Morgan Stanley & Company in Tokyo. ''As interest rates start declining, the stock market will clearly start recovering.''
But Mr. Suzuki is even a little bolder in his predictions. ''For the coming three to six months,'' he added, ''Japan's equity and bond markets seem the most attractive of the world's major markets in terms of possible currency and price appreciation.''
Given the history of the Tokyo market this year, some investors may be forgiven if they are skeptical. The Nikkei 225, which ended 1989 at 38,915.87, fell 28 percent during the first quarter of 1990 and had recovered only slightly before it began a second slide that accelerated with news of the Iraqi invasion. The market fell a total of 49 percent before hitting its low of 19,781.7 on Oct. 1.
Mr. Suzuki thinks that institutions and individuals who were hurt so badly by the declines will begin to buy again when the Nikkei gets to 25,000, which is only a good day's rally away. And this means, he said, that ''28,000 is an easy target.''
Buyers are already starting to flock to companies that are the natural beneficiaries of a stronger yen and lower interest rates: those with a domestic focus, including the housing and construction sectors, retailing, trading companies and even some banks.
And with a decline in long-term interest rates from their high of 8.7 percent toward 7 percent, Mr. Suzuki sees the market moving to 30,000 and beyond. This would be a rally of 50 percent from the low for the year. But put another way, it would be a recovery of just half of what the market lost this year, which does not seem unreasonable.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
And Now a Blast From the Past: Stagflation!

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Pornography, like beauty, may be in the eye of the beholder. If so, what is happening to the Federal deficit is patently obscene, says Mark L. Melcher, the director of Washington research for Prudential-Bache Securities.
''The deficit-reduction package now working its tortuous way through Congress doesn't even begin to address the fiscal problems facing this nation,'' Mr. Melcher said, as House and Senate conferees grappled with their latest legislative contraption on Friday. 
Moreover, the rosy and unreliable economic predictions from the Office of Management and Budget offer little but comic relief, in Mr. Melcher's view. Tomorrow, the Government will disclose the Federal budget figures for September, the final month of fiscal 1990. Even with the monthly surplus of $19.7 billion that Mr. Melcher expects, the resulting 1990 deficit would approach $222 billion, about what it was in 1986. In other words, all of the deficit shrinkage achieved in the prosperous times since then has vanished. And the threatened recession isn't even here yet, fumes Mr. Melcher.
Nevertheless, the market took heart from weaker oil prices and marked the third anniversary of the crash of 1987 by closing at 2,520.79, 122.77 points, or about 5 percent, higher than the previous week's close and, for the record, about 45 percent above its level on Black Monday.
The rally didn't reassure Edward McKelvey, senior economist with Goldman Sachs. Mr. McKelvey, too, sees a sordid ugliness enveloping the nation in the coming year. He gives it a name: stagflation.
You remember - stagnant economic growth coupled with chronic inflation. That's what Mr. McKelvey and Robert Giordano, his boss and the director of economic research at Goldman, are forecasting for 1991.
Now, an economy with anemic consumer demand and declining prices for real estate and many non-oil commodities would not seem to be an obvious candidate for an attack of stagflation . But Mr. McKelvey notes that the nation's factories are near full capacity and unemployment is still relatively low - factors he sees as putting upward pressure on production costs without easing demand.
And Washington isn't helping either with its budget proposals, he adds. ''The tilt toward excise taxes and user fees, without meaningful cuts in fiscal spending, does create an inflationary bias to this particular package,'' Mr. McKelvey said.
To be fair, the Goldman team is not absolutely certain that the economy is due for a siege of stagflation. It might not be that lucky. ''All the routes that avoid stagflation lead to recession,'' Mr. McKelvey said. ''There's no significant upside here.''
He added, a bit wistfully: ''What you'd really like to do is to live in the O.M.B.'s post-1991 world, where inflation is low and growth is strong and you just melt the budget out of existence.''
Unfortunately, in his view, you just can't get there from here.

HEADLINE: TV VIEW;
Jesse Jackson Courts the Viewer/Voter

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman

 BODY:
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the once and probably future Presidential aspirant who has lately taken up journalism, has quickly climbed the heights of the profession. Since the last Sunday in September, he has presided over a syndicated hour program called, yes, ''Jesse Jackson.'' The title is accurate. Mr. Jackson narrates the documentary passages, leads the panel discussions, puts questions to members of the studio audience and occasionally addresses the television camera, for instance, when announcing a pause for a commercial. He does not personally deliver the commercials for products, but causes are another matter. In New York, at 9 P.M. on Channel 11, the program finds itself up against Fox's popular ''Married . . . With Children'' and has not been doing nearly as well as Mr. Jackson did in the 1988 primaries. 
The journalist-advocate holds a respectable place in the history of American press and television, from the muckrakers to Edward R. Murrow, and like those estimable predecessors, Mr. Jackson stands with the little guys against the big shots. Retired politicians have also been known to transform themselves into journalists of a sort, Edward I. Koch, lately Mayor of New York, being a conspicuous recent example. But Mr. Jackson may be the first active seeker for the Presidency to devote himself to journalism more or less full time between elections, which raises questions about his intentions. Is he simply putting the image won in politics to the service of his new career, or is he using the new career to advance the old one?
For example, was his journey a few weeks ago to Baghdad, where he was granted an interview with Saddam Hussein and allowed to return to the United States with a planeful of released Americans, an example of journalistic enterprise, a humanitarian act or a political ploy? Given the significant place that Mr. Jackson has attained in American public affairs, such questions become inescapable, and in his current television endeavor, he shows little disposition to avoid them.
The panels on ''Jesse Jackson'' have more than the customary complement of minority participants, and the subjects come straight from the agenda of his Rainbow Coalition: the plight of American Indians, expressions of prejudice against blacks by Japanese officials, the threat of a cut in Federal student loans, with particular attention to the effects on blacks. This week, it's ''environmental racism.'' Compared with what often passes as subject matter on ''Oprah'' and ''Donahue,'' these are serious concerns, deserving of a public hearing. What the public gets to hear on ''Jesse Jackson,'' however, is mostly on one side of the case, and everybody knows which side.
Mr. Jackson promised that his opening program, on the clashes between groups of Indians and soldiers and police in North America, would expose ''the shameful conditions of native Americans in the United States.'' Newsreel footage shows Canadian soldiers being confronted by Indian women and men whom Mr. Jackson calls ''Mohawk warriors.'' Mr. Jackson, who says that he visited the scene of the Canadian confrontation with ''other journalists,'' is seen holding a press conference in which he calls, in his imitable way, for moving past ''face-saving to life-saving.'' An instance of a journalist covering his own performance. Indian spokesmen review the history of betrayal by American officials and of continuing designs by mineral and energy companies on their ''sacred burial grounds'' and on other land that they say is like a mother to their people. Words like ''genocide'' and ''holocaust'' are applied.
Much of this was effective. The Indian leader Russell Means in particular got across the point about the casually dismissive national attitude toward Indians by offering a possible sports-page headline, ''Washington Redskins Scalp the Chiefs.'' Why not, he asked, have the Cleveland Jews playing the Washington Negroes?
So the case was made, but Mr. Jackson, the journalist, evidently could not come up with any hard questions for his Indian guests, for example, about the quality of leadership on some of the relatively well-to-do reservations. He knew whose side he was on, so why complicate matters?
Perhaps if the United States Bureau of Indian Affairs had accepted the invitation to send a representative, the discussion would have picked up, but to judge by the second program, that is doubtful. It began with an apologetic appearance by the Japanese ambassador to the United States, Ryohei Murata, who was repeatedly pressed by Mr. Jackson and his other guests to compensate American blacks for the discriminatory words and actions. Mr. Jackson called for ''a summit meeting'' between Japanese ministers and black businessmen to discuss ''economic reciprocity.'' It was like sitting in on a lobbying session.
Similarly, the discussion about a threatened cut in college loans was weighted with opponents of the cuts. Representative Carl D. Pursell, a Michigan Republican, who served as straw man on the four-person panel, said that he would rather cut defense spending and assured the panelists that nothing approaching the $2 billion reduction in college loans referred to by Mr. Jackson was going to be made. But nobody seemed to be listening. The Congressman's main point was only that the budget crisis required reductions in all areas. ''Do you mean students should bear the burden?'' asked the moderator but did not pause for a response. So much for discussion.
Mr. Jackson did better in last Sunday's program about the commercialization of college athletics, particularly in a prison interview with Charles Thomson, the former University of Oklahoma quarterback who has been convicted of selling cocaine. But most of Mr. Thomson's account of a star athlete's life (whisky, women and other perks) had already been publicized, and Mr. Jackson had his customary difficulty in getting his panel (two coaches, a football player and a sportswriter) to carry on a conversation that went much beyond the obvious. The segment was filled with sloppy runs and wild passes. Mr. Jackson's own contributions sometimes fumbled: ''The students who in fact are generating the resources are scandalized for asking for money.''
The premise in every case is that the host knows where justice resides and conversation is orchestrated accordingly. His efforts at getting straight answers on the matter of defaults on student loans were largely ineffectual, but his questions to high school students in the studio showed where his interests really lay. ''If student aid is cut,'' he asked a black girl, ''can you go to college?'' That would be difficult, she replied. The same point was made in a report on another black student who needs aid to attend college. The attractive youngsters were being set against faceless political forces, a common television device.
So ''Jesse Jackson'' is more advocacy of a standard sort than journalism. But there are other reasons, mainly having to do with Mr. Jackson's style, why it does not make for exhilarating television. The speaker who can be so rousing on a political platform turns out to be stiff in the studio; his dully written narration of the hour's documentary segments tends to be muddy, diction not being his strong point.
The set, a bare-looking table and some bleachers, seems to have been put together on the cheap, and his encounters with his studio audience, which he conducts like a schoolteacher, have little spontaneity. Most disappointing, he is proving himself a weakish interviewer, willing to settle for canned statements when they suit his predilections.
Perhaps ''Jesse Jackson'' the program will help to keep Jesse Jackson the politician in the public eye. But so far, like a star athlete who does not perform all that well in the classroom, he has not demonstrated much affinity for the journalist's calling.

LENGTH: 714 words

HEADLINE: SOUND;
Some Loudspeakers Reward the Bargain Hunter

BYLINE: By Hans Fantel

 BODY:
In the present economic climate, budget crunching has become a favorite exercise wherever you look. Audio is no exception. These days, even formerly profligate audiophiles wonder how to shave costs without cutting quality - or, as one of them puts it, to be frugal without being stingy.
This leads to a search for components offering exceptional dollar value. Not always the cheapest - for cheap goods are just that and no bargain at any price. Rather, the quest is for those rare items that manage to match - or at least approach - performance levels normally found only in costlier models. The next several columns will conduct a bargain hunt for just such products. 
Starting with loudspeakers seems a good idea, for it is among speakers that one encounters the greatest diversity of design, the widest range of prices and, on occasion, the least correspondence between quality and price. The latter is what we are looking for: models that sound a lot better than their price would indicate.
There are plenty of overpriced loudspeakers, some of them good. But to find a good underpriced speaker takes persistence and lots of listening. Even so, it can be done, and here are a few examples, including some less-known brands that deserve to be more widely heard.
For example, a Canadian company called PSB, based in Pickering, Ontario, has lately gained broader distribution in this country precisely because its speakers offer outstanding sound at prices below par. Even the least expensive model in the company's line - the PSB20MKII, listing at $225 a pair - has the natural, spacious sound that marks all PSB designs, and even its bass response is highly creditable for its compact dimensions of 13.5 by 8.5 by 6.3 inches.
But perhaps the best bargain offered by PSB is its Model 50-MKII. This is a floor-standing speaker priced at $550 a pair that hints at no compromise. Its sonic depth, warmth and detail are rarely matched in this price range, and even massively orchestrated music sounds natural and convincing. In their overall sonic character, PSB speakers resemble the better British brands. They achieve clarity without overdue brightness. There is no aggressive edge to the sound. The music is all there, but it doesn't shout about itself.
Another winning combination of tonal merit and dollar value is to be found in B.I.C.-Venturi speakers, made in Stow, Ohio. Its Model V62 is certainly one of the best speakers to be had for under $100 ($199 a pair), and the elegance of the cabinet, with its beveled corners, belies the low price. Its sonic balance suits all kinds of music, classical as well as popular.
Listeners favoring a somewhat more pronounced treble to bring out the percussive detail in popular music should also audition the Mordaunt-Short MS3.10 ($229 a pair). It is notable for being able to project extremely clear sound at comparatively high volume levels - something rare among small speakers in this price class.
Boston Acoustics of Peabody, Mass., has long been a standby for audio bargain hunters in search of speakers with a natural tonal balance. These designs are happily free of the acoustical tricks frequently used to dramatize the sound. At $260 a pair, the Boston Acoustics A60 Series II has become something of a classic among budget models, while the Model T830 - at $500 a pair - sets a fine standard of performance in the midprice range.
Getting ample bass from low-cost speakers has always been a problem. In this respect, Pinnacle Loudspeakers of Hauppauge, N.Y., has achieved wonders with its patented version of a bass reflex enclosure. It features interior ducts, angled within the enclosure in a way that extends the lower range. As a result, a small speaker like the Pinnacle PN-5+ ($179 a pair) yields far deeper bass than is normally heard from a small, inexpensive speaker. By the same design principle, the company's larger PN-8+ (19 by 12 by 12 inches, $399 a pair) manages to reach to the very bottom of the musical range, with audible output down to the lower depths at 30 Hz.
Even though these speakers' main strength lies in the lower part of the tonal spectrum, their upper range is more then adequate and agreeably smooth. For listeners wanting lots of low sounds at low prices, the Pinnacle may be tops.
