HEADLINE: Suriname, in Army's Ever-Tighter Grip, Skids From Tranquillity to Turmoil

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARAMARIBO, Suriname, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Ten years after he overthrew the elected Government in this once-peaceful land, the former sergeant who is now commander of this country's small army is using violence to keep control of the country, Surinamese civic and human rights leaders and foreign diplomats say.
Under Comdr. Desire D. Bouterse's orders, the human rights leaders and diplomats say, Suriname's army has been responsible for scores of murders of perceived opponents and has razed villages. At the same time, he is fighting a guerrilla insurrection that has hastened the flight of Surinamese from this former Dutch colony to the Netherlands, the United States and neighboring French Guyana. In the last year alone, diplomats estimate that 10 percent of the population of 400,000 fled.
Commander Bouterse's military control continues despite elections held nearly three years ago in which a coalition of civilian politicians won 95 percent of the vote in defeating a party allied with the army. The result was seen as an overwhelming rejection of Commander Bouterse's nationalistic railings against the Netherlands by a people who have long been South America's most prosperous but who, under military rule, had grown accustomed to mysterious disappearances, widespread shortages and skyrocketing inflation. 
With its small population, abundant production of bauxite and alumina, and a massive aid program from the Netherlands, Suriname was the economic envy of South America throughout most of the 1960's and 70's.
 
President Declines Interview
But when the Dutch interrupted their aid in 1982 after the army executed 15 critics, and bauxite markets collapsed, this country fell on a period of hard times from which it has never recovered.
The President, Ramsewak Shankar, and Vice President, Henck Aaron, declined to be interviewed or comment on the political situation, an attitude that some say reflects their insecurity.
Dr. Artie Jesserun, a member of the National Assembly and rising star of the Mr. Aaron's National Party of Suriname, advocates gradually increasing political and civilian pressure on the military.
''It appears on paper that we have a powerful President, but he has no power,'' he said in an interview. ''The legislature also has no power. The power is with the army. They have the guns and they have shown their readiness to use them.
''We are slowly moving to the point where we will have an eruption,'' he added. ''In the coming months or maybe years, there is going to be a stronger movement to force democratic change and nobody will be able to stop it, even if it takes time to build.''
Since losing the 1987 elections, diplomats say, Commander Bouterse, a voluble 45-year-old former sergeant major and physical education instructor, has replaced his fatigues with linen suits, fine leather boots and designer sunglasses, while steadily working to block government initiatives in areas as diverse as peace talks with guerrilla forces and plans for economic restructuring. At the same time, Commander Bouterse's men have set out to silence critics.
In the last year in particular, observers say, the intimidation has grown steadily bolder, as the 3,000-member army sparked a spree of brazenly violent incidents. They included attacking the police in drive-by shootings and assassinations and using telephone threats against ordinary citizens.
 
Army Role Denied
Commander Bouterse declined to be interviewed, but Army Chief of Staff Badresseein Sital denied any army role in the violence and intimidation. He said the military was forced to become more assertive because the Government had become ''a helping hand to neo-colonialism.
''International notions of democracy and the codes and rules - that doesn't apply here in Suriname,'' Commandant Sital said in explaining why the army has repeatedly overruled the civilian authorities. ''Whether in bringing peace or development, the Government has not respected its commitment to the Surinamese people. It is the responsibility of the army to correct that.''
Last fall Commander Bouterse, irritated by criticisms of his refusal to abide by a Government peace plan to stop a four-year jungle insurgency by Maroons - descendants of slaves who escaped Dutch plantations in the 17th century - warned in a speech that his men would soon begin ''raising pitbulls'' to quell his opponents.
 
Human Rights Leader Attacked
The threats materialized in December when a hit squad launched a 3:30 A.M. attack on the home of the country's leading human rights advocate, E. Stanley Rensch.
Mr. Rensch, a soft-spoken 50-year-old, said he fled out the back door as his house was being sprayed with gunfire and eventually escaped to the Netherlands. Explaining his return to the country last week, which quickly prompted renewed threats, he said, ''Everyone interested in justice here must take risks.''
Also in December, on the anniversary of the 1982 torture and execution in military custody of the 15 civilian critics, the national courthouse was burned down, destroying almost all of the country's legal records including, many critics say, documents that might one day have been used against Commander Bouterse in matters ranging from those killings to persistent reports of army involvement in cocaine trafficking.
Officials in the Netherlands, quoted in press reports, have estimated that more than 60 percent of the cocaine that reaches their country is smuggled by Colombian cartels via Suriname.
In March, Ronny Brunswijk, the leader of the Jungle Commando, the Maroon insurgency fighting to topple Commander Bouterse, visited the capital for government-sponsored peace talks. During discussions at Commander Bouterse's office in army headquarters, according to police accounts that the army does not deny, two of Mr. Brunswijk's bodyguards were shot dead at point-blank range. Mr. Brunswijk himself was held for several days before a threat by his rebels to blow up a huge hydroelectric dam forced his release.
The killing of the bodyguards, seen by many here as an act of uncommon treachery, generated sympathy for Mr. Brunswijk in this ethnically diverse capital, which had previously regarded the guerrilla leader as a Maroon fighting solely for Maroon interests.
 
Police Inspector Murdered
In an interview, Army Chief of Staff Sital called the killing of the bodyguards ''a normal act,'' saying that the Jungle Commando were terrorists.
Perhaps the most traumatizing of all recent events, however, was the murder in August of the country's chief police inspector, Herman Gooding, a crusading lawman who was investigating charges of involvement by senior officers in cocaine trafficking.
In response to the murder, most businesses closed for a day and a handful of protest groups formed and were quickly able to mass 10,000 people in the streets to denounce military abuses and call for government action.
The police have remained on strike ever since, holed up at their union headquarters where they have barricaded surrounding streets. Most streets are without policemen, though the military police have begun to undertake some of their tasks.
But with the Jungle Commando on the defensive and the police marginalized, many residents here have begun to despair that the army can be brought under control with outside assistance. They speak of many possibilities ranging from a full-blown invasion to disarming the army to providing increased training and support for the police.
Because of their strong emotional ties to the Netherlands, many Suriname residents look to that country to save them. The recollection of an incident in 1969, when Dutch marines landed in the Netherlands Antilles island of Curacao to put down a political uprising and looting, offers hope to those wishing some sort of intervention.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSION;
And Now the Hard Part: Making Hussein Give In

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Eleven weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, Administration officials still appear determined to confront President Saddam Hussein, but they are discovering just how difficult their policy is to sustain and showing some signs of anxiety about how the crisis will be resolved.
''It was a lot easier to see how to get into this thing than it is to see how to get out of it,'' a senior Administration official said.
While the officials acknowledge that recent diversions - from the budget debate to the Palestinian-Israeli conflict in Jerusalem - have sapped some of the momentum of their anti-Baghdad policy, it does not appear to have drained their resolve. Interviews with senior policy makers indicate that they still do not want a face-saving way out for President Hussein and are steadily building up military power in the Persian Gulf to convince the Iraqi leader that he has only two choices: stay in Kuwait and risk the destruction of his army, as well as his Government in Baghdad, or leave and survive. 
While officials have never expressed it in public, convincing the Iraqi leader that those are indeed his only two choices is the key to their strategy. Officials believe that while economic sanctions might be a necessary condition for persuading the Iraqi President to pull out unconditionally, they probably are not sufficient. There is no modern historical precedent for economic sanctions inducing one country in a conflict to engage in unconditional surrender. The sufficient ingredient, officials say, is the credible threat of the Iraqi Government's destruction.
 
Bush Sees Soviet Expert
Washington's rejection of any partial solutions, and the stark choices it is offering Baghdad, were conveyed personally by President Bush on Friday to a Soviet Middle East specialist, Yevgeny M. Primakov. Mr. Primakov came to brief Mr. Bush on his visit to Baghdad two weeks ago and his lengthy discussion with President Hussein. American officials are hoping that Mr. Primakov, who has known Saddam Hussein for 20 years, will, one way or another, relay that message back to Baghdad.
But officials concede that while their objectives remain the same, the events of the last two weeks have underscored for them how difficult they will be to achieve. Diversions from the Israeli-Palestinian dispute have preoccupied the State Department, and shifted the focus of world attention. Behind-the-scenes tussles with the French over how harshly to condemn Israel at the United Nations has sown doubts among policy makers as to as to how much Paris can be counted on in the pinch.
More and more anxiety is being expressed by Congress about the potential for thousands of bodies coming home from a gulf war, and more and more lawmakers are saying aloud what they only whispered two months ago. As the Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, put it during last week's budget debate: America is in the gulf for one reason and one reason only: ''O-I-L'' - and that is not something parents are anxious for their sons and daughters to die for. Finally, the distraction of the budget problem has diverted President Bush's attention and made it impossible for him to devote as much attention to the gulf crisis as he did a month or two ago.
''Oh, the good times are over,'' remarked Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, a member of the Foreign Relations Committee. ''It was exciting to land all that equipment over there and watch the buildup, but now that they are there and nothing is happening and we didn't scare Saddam and we may now might have to fight him, and then the Israelis got into the middle - well, we are all starting to become a little anxious. It means we may soon face the hideous choice of pull out or go in, and George Bush has not really prepared the American public for this choice.''
 
A Different Phase Now
Adminstration officials acknowledge these sentiments, but insist that many of them were the natural product of the gulf policy moving into its second phase, which they always said would require patience. The first phase of the policy involved moving troops to Saudi Arabia, raising billions of dollars in support from allies, building an international coaltion against Iraq and imposing United Nations sanctions. One dramatic headline followed another, and the American public barely stopped to calculate the costs.
Now that the policy has shifted into its second phase - seeing whether the sanctions and the military buildup are working to change Iraqi conduct - it is understandable that people would get bored and nervous.
For now, Administration officials do not appear perturbed enough by these diversions and strains to feel that their policy has been derailed. In fact, they point out that the Iraqis have just announced gasoline rationing, citing this as a sign that the sanctions are really beginning to hurt.
Rather, a senior official said, they view the events of the last two weeks as ''a warning signal'' about the dangers of a policy built largely around coercing Iraq through diplomatic and economic sanctions, which could require months or years to have an effect.
The lesson that they appear to be drawing is that they must take a variety of steps in the United Nations to refocus attention on Iraq, and its destruction of Kuwait. But they also must start thinking more seriously about what sorts of military measures, short of war, they might be able to take to persuade President Hussein that the alternative to his unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait is destruction of his leadership.
American officials acknowledge that despite the large-scale troop buildup in the gulf, their intelligence assessments, which Mr. Primakov confirmed, indicate that the Iraqi leader is still not convinced that Mr. Bush is ready to sacrifice American boys to drive him out of Kuwait.
Getting that point across is not easy. Administration officials identify with a point that the strategist Thomas C. Schelling, in his classic work, ''Strategy of Conflict'' makes: In a crisis, if one side looks too controlled, too disciplined and too sensitive to arguments and counterarguments, then it lacks credibility with its adversary.
Mr. Schelling wrote that if a man is in an car and playing a game of chicken with another driver coming at him, the best way for him to convince the other driver that he must move aside first is if he starts the race by throwing out the steering wheel of his car. This apparently irrational act will have the rational effect of convincing the other driver that he has no choice but to change course.
Administration officials concede that one of Mr. Bush's main problems today is that he appears too moderate and controlled, too much part of an international coalition, to be able to convince Mr. Hussein that his only options are to stay and die or leave and survive.
As an important policy maker put it: ''Unless the sanctions have a greater impact on Saddam then they have up to now, we will have to make the military threat more credible in order to convince him to settle now through diplomatic means.''

LENGTH: 1457 words

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSION;
Amid Preparations, No One Can Say When War Might Break Out or End

BYLINE: By JAMES LeMOYNE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Two and a half months after American forces were sent to Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf states, military commanders and political officials are finding it difficult to assure achievable goals in an ambiguous conflict whose outcome they cannot easily control.
In interviews over the last three weeks, American, Saudi and European military and political officials have pointed to the growing realization that if war comes, its human, economic and political costs are likely to be high.
They say there is little prospect of winning a neat ''victory'' in such a conflict and that its consequences for the region and for the United States could prove severe.
''We can retake Kuwait and hit the Iraqi Army hard,'' said an American official. ''But what happens after that is hard to say.'' 
At present, American and other forces are engaged in a steady military buildup designed to accompany growing diplomatic pressure on Iraq.
 
Testing Iraqi Defenses
Barring unexpected developments, American officials say they do not forsee a war beginning for at least two months. They add that the United States and other countries are likely to seek further United Nations backing before initiating any military attack.
American forces are not yet fully deployed in the desert here and a British armored brigade is just arriving. In the air, American jet fighters are testing Iraqi defenses by flying at the border and recording the signals of Iraqi radar - but pilots say the Iraqis often foil the exercise by refusing to turn on their electronic equipment.
In the midst of such martial preparations, no official can say with assurance when war may begin, nor how and when it might end.
American military planners and political analysts here run countless scenarios - all of them possible, none of them certain. Officials say prediction is difficult because of shifting alliances and sudden developments in a Middle Eastern region that is inherently unstable. American planners say they have yet to decide if their goal is simply to liberate Kuwait, or to destroy the Iraqi military, Iraqi weapons factories and the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, as well, perhaps by sending a multinational force to occupy Iraq.
There is little doubt that the forces here can retake Kuwait and destroy much of the Iraqi army and air force. But there are grave doubts about the costs of occupying Iraq and the future of a defeated Iraq.
 
The Ideal Scenario
Saudi and American officials say war with Iraq may deepen the identity crisis Arab societies have been suffering for decades as they confront a period of threatening change that many see as spurred by Western societies they both admire and fear.
''The way we win will be as important as winning itself,'' said an American diplomat here. ''We have to think about Iraqi and Arab reaction to a humiliating defeat at the hands of the United States.''
American planners admit they cannot predict the reaction of the Iraqi people to an outside attack, especially the reaction of the country's Shiite Muslim majority.
Several diplomats said the ideal scenario would be to force an Iraqi withdrawal that brings the downfall of Saddam Hussein. But they admit there is no assurance of this and no certainty that a more mainstream leader would replace him.
Uncertainty is heightened by the possibility that Iran or Syria might invade Iraq to seize disputed territories, or that Iraq's long-abused Kurdish people will rise up and demand a state of their own.
 
New Terrorism Expected
There also is a realization that American and civilian casualties may well be high in a war of rockets, heavy armor, poison gas and possibly biological weapons. The Western hostages held in Iraq may die. Leaking poison from bombed Iraqi chemical plants may kill civilians.
American officials have sought as much Arab participation as possible in the military force that may attack Iraq. But so far Arab states have sent minimal troops, increasing the political exposure of American, British and French forces sent here.
There appears to be a possibility that American forces could find themselves used by Arab states in a regional feud that, but for the importance of oil, appears distant from traditional American concerns. This is a region dominated by rigid military dictatorships and Arab monarchies.
In the event of war, American planners expect a new wave of terrorist strikes against American and European targets. They say they fear American embassies could also be attacked in several Arab countries, especially Jordan.
''The American Embassy in Amman will probably burn,'' one American official said.
Several diplomats said they feared further polarization between Israel and the occupied Palestinian population it controls. If Iraq were to attack Israel, American officials say, the conflict could easily widen to include other Arab countries, threatening the present alliance against Iraq.
It is a scenario that causes planners here particular concern. Faced with Arab demands and the need to assure future oil supplies, American and international pressure may grow on the Israeli Government to negotiate autonomy for the Palestinians.
Saudi, Kuwaiti and American officials say war with Iraq will redefine attitudes toward the defense of oil reserves and the Persian Gulf states that hold most of them.
It appears likely that a multinational force will remain, backed by a security pact aimed at imposing a degree of stability in a long-volatile region where Iraq, Iran and Saudi Arabia will continue to vie for influence.
For the United States, the crisis has the makings of a defining experience for a troubled and economically weakened superpower finding its way in a post-cold-war world that it will strongly influence, but not dominate.
American officials and troops express bitterness that of all the nations arrayed against Iraq, it is the United States that will likely bear the greatest burden - in blood, in dollars and perhaps in ideals.
Despite much talk of Arab allies and international censure of Iraqi aggression and loss of oil supplies, Arab, European, Asian, African and Latin American participation in the alliance against Iraq is minimal.
Many nations of these other regions are more dependent on Gulf oil supplies than the United States. But most of their armies have remained safely at home. Even Saudi Arabia, by far the most threatened state, has reacted to the crisis in part by trying to pretend that life is normal.
While divisions of Americans are here to defend this kingdom, most Saudis appear to assume that their affluent lifestyle will go on much as before, secured by booming oil profits and millions of imported foreign workers.
Frank and opinionated in the way of young Americans, the more than 200,000 American troops deployed in this region are outspoken in interviews about their concern that their lives not be spent in a war whose goals are not clearly defined and not fully supported by the American people.
In more than 200 interviews and conversations in distant desert bases, on sun-baked tank turrets, at jet fighter take-off lines and inside maintenance hangars, the American men and women sent here by their President constantly ask what it is they are expected to do and whether their countrymen support their mission.
Citizens of a strongly ideological nation, they are imbued with an ethos of democratic liberalism, intensified by the Manichean American sensibility of a world divided into good and evil.
 
Prospect of Broken Illusions
American troops become visibly uncomfortable when discussing the thought that they are here to defend low oil prices and the near-absolute monarchies that dominate Saudi Arabia and most other gulf states.
Discussions with soldiers stationed in the desert here makes it apparent that the political cost of broken illusions or large American casualties in a treacherous war is likely to be high, both for President Bush and for the American people.
Faced with such daunting and unpredictable futures, it is not surprising that many American and Saudi officials say they hope Iraq withdraws from Kuwait, avoiding a wider war.
Saudi officials say that if Iraq were to withdraw, Saudi Arabia would back American, British and French demands that Iraq pay large war reparations, or face indefinite sanctions and a naval blockade.
But if Iraq does not begin a complete retreat sometime in the next two to six months, every official interviewed said, there will be no alternative but to fight.
''President Bush and the United Nations have said Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait,'' said a senior American official here. ''If Saddam Hussein does not comply, then yes - there is going to be a war.''

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSION;
Poor Nations Worried by U.S. Payout in Gulf

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 19

 BODY:
A plan by the United States to use about half of the roughly $22 billion it hopes to raise toward the costs of the Persian Gulf crisis to pay for American military operations there is causing increasing concern among developing countries and aid experts, diplomats and United Nations officials say.
The American proposal would leave enough money to meet the needs of the three ''front line'' developing countries bearing the biggest share of the cost of United Nations sanctions against Iraq and occupied Kuwait - Turkey, Egypt and Jordan.
But other developing countries, which are also seriously affected by sanctions, complain that there will be no money for them if the United States takes so much. As a result, some want the oil-exporting countries to distribute more of the roughly $150 billion a year they will receive in windfall profits from the gulf crisis if oil prices remain at present levels, these officials say. 
Developing countries with oil of their own, like Mexico, Algeria and Nigeria, have so far prevented third-world countries from formally asking the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries for a bigger share of this windfall. But Egypt and Kuwait's government-in-exile are considering asking this year's United Nations General Assembly to urge rich countries to give more aid to poorer nations affected by the sanctions.
 
Treasury Declines Comment
The United States Treasury now hopes to raise about $22 billion from the world's richest countries to help pay the costs of the gulf crisis this year and next, United Nations and other officials say. The Treasury this week declined to comment on the estimate.
The aid is being sent directly from the donor countries to the recipients. But the flow is monitored by the Gulf Crisis Coordination Group, which comprises representatives of the major aid-giving nations.
Saudi Arabia is expected to provide $8 billion, Kuwait $4 billion, Japan $4 billion, the European Community $2 billion and Germany $2 billion. The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund will lend affected countries $2 billion more.
United Nations officials say the Treasury now plans to use about $1 billion a month over the next 10 months to pay for American military operations in the gulf, or about half the total contributed by donor countries. Japan and Kuwait have already earmarked half their contributions for the American military effort.
This will leave about $12 billion for the three front-line countries, which are expected to suffer $12 billion to $14 billion of economic damage in 1990-1991 as a result of lost exports and remittances from workers in the gulf as well as from higher oil prices.
The cost of the crisis for Turkey is estimated at $5 billion over this period. The figures for Jordan and Egypt are $4 billion and $3 billion respectively.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSION;
Jordanian Economy Devastated by Effects of the Gulf Crisis

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The port of Aqaba is still. Tourism, which brought in more than half a billion dollars last year, has evaporated. Fruit and vegetables intended for export are rotting at the border.
As punishment for its criticism of the presence of American troops, Saudi Arabia has cut off oil. Of the more than $2 billion pledged by Europe and Japan to countries affected by the Persian Gulf crisis, only $4 million has been received here. 
Jordan is facing an economic catastrophe of such enormity, said Crown Prince Hassan, that the political stability of the country may be in jeopardy.
 
Country in a Double Bind
''If there is a war we are lost, but if there is no peace and this crisis continues we are also lost,'' the Crown Prince said in an interview. ''Even the United States says we are scrupulously implementing the United Nations sanctions, but we are still being penalized by Saudi Arabia and the West. Jordan is being pushed into the Iraqi camp, into an extremist frame of mind.''
There are no discernible shortages in Amman, and the shops and restaurants are crowded. But the confrontation in the gulf is having a devastating impact on the economic underpinnings of this country of 3.5 million people.
Jordan's traditional markets - Iraq and Kuwait, which accounted for 30 percent of its exports - have been lost because of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and the United Nations embargo on trade with Baghdad. Saudi Arabia, its other major market and the country that could have compensated Jordan for the loss of Iraqi oil and trade, has shunned Amman.
Jordan has tried to adopt what it sees as a neutral stance: condemning Iraq's invasion and carrying out economic sanctions against Baghdad while criticizing the presence of foreign troops and trying to avert a military clash. But in Riyadh's view King Hussein of Jordan has been acting like a lawyer for President Saddam Hussein of Iraq - making the best case for his actions and giving his brutal Government a human face.
 
A Billion-Dollar Loss
According to the latest Government figures, by the end of the year Jordan is likely to lose more than a billion dollars in revenue - at least 30 and possibly as much as 50 percent of its anticipated gross national product.
Remittances from Jordanians and Palestinians working in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, expected before the crisis to total some $730 million, will decline by $320 million. By Oct. 11, official statistics show, 133,149 Jordanians had returned from the gulf. Because many fled Kuwait without money or possessions, they will cost the Government an extra $300 million in social services this year, the Government said.
The drain of returning Jordanians on the country's scarce resources would have been far greater, Crown Prince Hassan said, had Israel not agreed to waive its regulations and permit some 40,000 Jordanians who lived on the West Bank before working in the gulf to return to their homes in Israeli-occupied territory.
Finding jobs for returning Jordanians here is extremely difficult, given the rate of unemployment, officially 20 percent but by some estimates closer to 40 percent.
''We are really the second victims of the gulf crisis,'' said Ziad Fariz, the Minister of Industry and Trade. ''All of our economic sectors have been hit.''
 
Trucks Carry Furniture Home
Mr. Fariz said Jordan's truckers, who once formed a major industry, have been reduced to transporting the furniture of Jordanians fleeing Kuwait to Jordan.
Early in the crisis, Jordan was accused of violating the United Nations trade embargo against Iraq. This week the United States was permitted to station monitors at the Jordanian-Iraqi border to inspect truck cargo to see whether Jordan was enforcing the embargo.
''So they opened the trucks and found furniture,'' Crown Prince Hassan said. Then, he said, the British also wanted to inspect cargo.
''We told them that the day of high commissioners and viceroys are over,'' he said. ''The degree of humiliation is clear.''
Foreign aid has also been affected. Some $300 million of assistance to Jordan provided by Iraq and Kuwait has vanished. Jordan currently receives only one major form of assistance from Iraq: oil. Amman is not paying Baghdad for it, but is crediting it against Iraq's $310 million debt to Jordan at a rate of $16 a barrel. While that is far below the current market price, the United States and other countries in the alliance have not objected, aware that without that oil, Jordan's economy would collapse.
 
Restrictions on Cargo
Tawfiq Kawar, president of the Jordanian Shipping Agents Association, said in an interview that Saudi Arabia was attempting to restrict all shipping through Aqaba, not just cargoes bound for Iraq. Some 200 containers destined for Jordan were waiting in Jidda, unable to find ships to transport them, he said. In the past few days, he said, Riyadh had begun delaying ships bound for Aqaba to pick up cargoes of Jordanian phosphates, the country's major export. Along with potash, shipments of phosphates are expected to suffer a 50 percent decline, roughly $250 million.
Mr. Kawar said that exorbitant war-risk insurance rates coupled with arbitrary inspections that delayed shipments to Aqaba between one and 12 hours had resulted in a 75 percent decline in cargo unloaded at Aqaba.
To service its $8.4 billion debt, Jordan will need roughly $500 million dollars by the end of the year, said Hans Heino Kopietz, a London-based Middle East analyst who recently visited Amman. He estimated Jordan's cash reserves at about $170 million.
A senior official said, ''We have absolutely no idea where the rest of the money will come from.''
Jean Ripert, a former United Nations official, recently completed a report after a four-day mission to Jordan for Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General. Mr. Ripert concluded that Jordan's economy might collapse next year if greater amounts of foreign aid were not immediately forthcoming.
''Something has to happen,'' Mr. Ripert was quoted as saying in Friday's Jordan Times. ''Such a country will not survive unless something happens in the region.''

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSION;
Thousands March in 16 Cities to Protest U.S. Intervention in Gulf

BYLINE: By EVELYN NIEVES

 BODY:
Thousands of people rallied in New York and 15 other American cities yesterday to protest the United States' military buildup in the Persian Gulf. It was the largest demonstration against the American presence in the gulf since President Bush first sent troops after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.
Similar rallies were held in other nations, including Australia, Canada, England, Italy and Panama, said rally organizers from the Manhattan-based Coalition Against the U.S. Intervention in the Middle East. 
 
'Won't Fight for Texaco'
In Manhattan, a parade of marchers six blocks long wound its way through midtown before rallying at Times Square in the late afternoon. Many chanted, ''Hell no, we won't go; we won't fight for Texaco'' or ''Money for peace, not for war.''
The police estimated the crowd at about 5,000; marchers said there were more than 25,000. The march was peaceful, with three arrests on minor charges reported.
The march included contingents representing students' groups, Vietnam veterans, senior citizens, Palestine Liberation Organization supporters, labor groups and homeless people from Manhattan's Lower East Side. There were 10 military reservists, including two who have been called for active duty and have refused to go.
Former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark, who formed the coalition, was joined at the head of the march by Michael Moore, a documentary film maker. There were speeches before and after the march, including two by the military reservists now considered absent without leave.
Stephanie Atkinson, 23 years old, of Murphysboro, Ill,, joined the Army Reserves six years ago to pay for college, she said, and was called to active duty in Saudi Arabia last week. ''I believe in the economic sanctions and in honest negotiations, not war,'' she said. ''If I have to go to jail, I'll go.''
Organizers said they began planning for the march after a speech by Mr. Clark on Sept. 13 at Cooper Union drew 2,500 to an auditorium that seats 1,000.
Leo Brody, a retired typographer who came from Long Island with about 20 other retired men and women, said: ''Isn't this proof that the people are not 100 percent behind Bush?''
Mumtaz Hussein, a Pakistani whose mother now lives in Kuwait, said many Kuwaitis supported Iraq's invasion. ''They are happy that the oppressive regime is removed,'' he said. ''My mother's family has been there 20 years and they've had no rights there. We would be happy if the same thing happened to Saudi Arabia.''
Mr. Clark told the marchers that the turnout was ''terrific.'' ''I hope they're listening in the White House,'' he said.
In Washington, 125 people rallied at the White House to demonstrate against the deployment. The White House declined to comment on the demonstration.
The Manhattan rally was the largest. Organizers said about 1,000 marchers gathered in San Fancisco, 200 in Cleveland, 200 in Boston and 100 in Atlanta.

HEADLINE: MALAWI CRITICIZED BY A RIGHTS GROUP

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 20

 BODY:
The Government of Malawi, one of the larger recipients of United States economic and military aid in sub-Saharan Africa, has been harshly criticized in a report by a human rights organization for the killings of political opponents, intolerable conditions in overcrowded jails and ethnic discrimination.
''Although many states in sub-Saharan Africa suffer from greater political violence than Malawi, there are fewer African countries with such a combination of totalitarianism and personal despotism,'' concluded the assessment on Malawi issued this month by Africa Watch, a group based in London.
Much of the 116-page report, which reviews the 26-year rule of President H. Kamuzu Banda, concurs with last year's State Department report on human rights in Malawi, a sliver of land in southern Africa that is miserably poor and, because of an almost total ban on foreign reporters, largely forgotten.
Like Africa Watch, the State Department pointed to the murder of a leading political dissident; the death in prison, apparently from torture, of a Government official suspected of leaking information, and the use of arbitrary detention to suppress any sign of dissent. 
 
U.S. Criticizes but Gives Aid
But Africa Watch points to what it calls the inconsistency between the declared interest of the United States in human rights and its policy of increasing economic and military assistance. Unlike other black-ruled nations in the region, Malawi has maintained formal relations with South Africa and thus has been praised by the Bush Administration for being a ''reliable partner'' in Southern Africa. The Government has also been lauded by the United States for admitting nearly 800,000 Mozambican refugees, the largest concentration in refugee-laden Africa.
This year, Malawi was rewarded with $21.5 million in United States economic aid, up from $18 million in 1987, and was one of the handful of African countries to receive military aid. American officials said the military help of $2.2 million, nearly double the 1989 assistance, was to be spent on M-16 rifles, grenade launchers and training.
In detailing human rights abuses in Malawi, Africa Watch said those arrested in the 1980's without charge and still in jail included the country's only neurosurgeon, Dr. George Mtafu and its best-known poet, Jack Mapanje.
The organization said Fred Sikwese, the principal protocol administrator in the Ministery of External Affairs, was arrested in February 1989, apparently because he was suspected of leaking information about Malawi's relationship with South Africa.
When his family visited him at Lilongwe Prison a month after his arrest, he was weak from lack of food and possibly from torture, the report said. He died in prison shortly after the visit. The authorities refused to give his body to his family for burial, the report said.
 
Exiled Journalist Slain
A Malawian journalist living in exile in Zambia, Mkwapatira Mhango, died after a firebomb attack on his home in Lusaka last October. The circumstances of the attack point to Malawian security guards in Lusaka having carried out the attack, the report said. The Malawian Government has said the deaths had been the result of internal feuding within the Malawian opposition.
Describing a police shooting in March this year, the Africa Watch report said 20 protesters were shot dead in Lilongwe after city residents threw stones at a convoy of armed police. The report said that the shootings were not mentioned in the heavily censored Malawian press but that two senior police officials were dismissed after the incident.
The Africa Watch report said it did not agree with suggestions by the State Department that there was little ethnic discrimination in Malawi. The organization said President Banda, a member of the Chewa ethnic group from the central region of the country, had practiced a policy of ''systematic exclusion of people from the northern region, as well as Yaos from the southern region, from political power.''
A system of limiting educational opportunities for northerners, who have traditionally excelled at school and at the national university, was introduced three years ago, the report said.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Recent Crises May Help Cause of European Unity

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Caught off guard successively by the collapse of Communism, the unification of Germany and the Persian Gulf crisis, the 12-nation European Community is now using all three surprises to give new momentum to its search for greater economic and political unity.
The eventual shape of this unity is still the subject of intense debate, with Britain among the countries determined that it should not lead to anything resembling a United States of Europe or even a loose federation of nations with its capital in Brussels.
Yet the events of recent months appear to have convinced most community governments that they must accelerate their step-by-step approach to integration if the region is to emerge as a major economic bloc that can play a major political role in the world.
German unification has provided new impetus for what is known as economic and monetary union, a daring concept that includes establishment of a single European currency and central bank as a follow-up to the existing plan to create a single regional market by the end of 1992.
But in political terms, the gulf crisis has proved even more of a watershed. ''The gulf crisis has become a test of how the community responds to world events,'' one community official said. ''It has been a great definer of where it can work together and where it cannot.'' 
Prompted by embarrassment at having to rely on the United States to defend its vital interests and criticism of its disorderly military response in the weeks after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the community now seems ready to start coordinating its foreign and defense policies.
''We thought for a long time that a common foreign and security policy would be more difficult than economic and monetary union,'' France's Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, noted recently, ''but it seems that we now have better prospects for political and security union.''
At a summit meeting in Rome next weekend, community leaders hope to set the stage for the complex negotiations necessary to turn these two objectives into reality. And while it is still unclear where they will lead, fears that the community had lost its way now seem to have evaporated.
 
Threats Become Opportunities
''What at one point looked like threats to the community have now turned into opportunities,'' one French Government official said.
The formal negotiations will take place at two parallel conferences on economic and monetary union and on political union that will open in Rome in December and aim to complete their work before the single European market begins operating in 1993.
But already next month, when a 34-nation summit of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe is held in Paris, the community hopes to demonstrate to the United States, the Soviet Union and other countries that it is well equipped to serve as the principal pillar of the new Europe.
Earlier this year, it decided it could best do this by not immediately inviting in the new democracies of Eastern Europe. Rather, while Britain favored ''widening'' the community, the majority preferred ''deepening'' it in the sense of speeding the integration of the existing 12 members.
A primary objective in this was to anchor a powerful united Germany to the West, something that was considered more likely if Germany was required to make immediate commitments to further European integration than if it emerged as the dominant force in a looser regional arrangement.
 
Germany's Role in Europe
As it happened, eager to appease European anxieties about Germany's new strength, Chancellor Helmut Kohl enthusiastically embraced this approach, repeatedly insisting that he wanted to see ''a European Germany and not a German Europe.''
The single voice of dissension remains that of Britain's Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, who has warned that she will not accept a single European currency and, after Bonn and Paris proposed new steps towards political unity in April, that Britain will cede no further sovereignty.
Preparations for the Rome conferences have nonetheless continued. And while disagreements over the timing of economic and monetary union have emerged, with Germany and Spain cautioning that it should not be rushed, only Britain still disapproves of the final objective.
Earlier this month, though, Britain took a major step toward its community partners when it brought the pound into the exchange rate mechanism of the European Monetary System, thus tying it to other regional currencies and, in effect, fulfilling one of the prerequisites of monetary union.
Since then, Mrs. Thatcher has insisted that Britain's economic policies will never be decided by the European Commission, the community's executive branch, which is based in Brussels. But more than ever, other community governments seem determined to move ahead with or without Britain.
The only important change in the plan presented last year by Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, seems likely to be that the clock for economic and monetary union will now start on Jan. 1, 1994, rather than one year earlier.
 
Effect of the Gulf Crisis
Until the Gulf crisis, in contrast, the French-German initiative on political union had lost momentum. In June, European leaders approved the idea of a conference on this subject to make amendments to the 1957 Treaty of Rome, which created the original six-nation Common Market.
But while Italian, French and even German leaders spoke poetically of an eventual federation, it soon became apparent that the conference itself would probably limit itself to strengthening such institutions as the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament and the European Commission, without moving toward what might ordinarily be understood by political union.
With the gulf crisis, though, the focus changed drastically, exposing the community as an economic giant with a weak political voice and no military power and challenging the 12 members to look afresh at their role in the world.
Specifically, while the community quickly denounced the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and imposed a trade embargo on Baghdad, it was prevented by its own charter from coordinating the region's military response or even from discussing military matters.
The immediate result was that although Britain joined the United States in a multinational force protecting Saudi Arabia, and France independently sent troops to the gulf, it took three weeks before a nine-nation group called the Western European Union, which had long been moribund, provided a regional umbrella.
 
The Debate Intensifies
But since then, the debate about political union has intensified, with Italy, which currently holds the rotating presidency of the community, proposing that the Western European Union be absorbed by the community. A former British Prime Minister, Edward Heath, has even argued that a coordinated defense policy could lead to creation of a European Army.
On the other hand, Britain and France, Western Europe's two nuclear powers, favor less drastic changes. Yet it was Mrs. Thatcher who first criticized Europe's slow reaction to the gulf crisis, while President Francois Mitterrand of France has long favored a European security role as an alternative to full dependence on the United States.
Community experts said that with different approaches to a coordinated foreign and defense policy still being discussed, no major decisions were expected next weekend. For example, several governments are eager not to be seen weakening the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. There is also the unresolved question of how Ireland's neutrality should be handled.
Yet, in an area that was out of bounds only a few months ago, there is already a consensus that where common political and security interests are at stake, community members should be ready to work in unison.

HEADLINE: Ecologists' Foe to Become Amazon Governor

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Hoisting the banner of an Amazonian backlash against ecologists, Gilberto Mestrinho likes to boast, ''I wasn't elected by the trees.''
Instead, it was the voters of Amazonas state, the heart of Brazil's Amazon, who elected Mr. Mestrinho Governor on Oct. 3.
Most of Brazil's governorship races face runoff votes Nov. 25, but Mr. Mestrinho won handily on the first round. His landslide was partly because of his 35-year experience in state politics and his popular opposition to ''foreign ecologists.'' 
''The center of ecology should be man,'' the Governor-elect said in an interview in his penthouse apartment by a beach here. ''Ten million people can't be condemned to die of hunger so the animals and trees can grow.''
As he views the world, foreign ecologists are working in league with foreign business interests to bottle up the Amazon's tremendous wealth in timber, furs, minerals and oil.
''As soon as the satellites showed that Amazonia is the richest mineral province in the world, immediately the movement started that the Amazon is untouchable,'' said the 62-year-old Governor-elect, whose fans have nicknamed him ''Boto'' after the Amazon River porpoise.
''Behind the environmental movement, there are economic interests who fear that economic development of the Amazon would risk investments made in other parts of the world,'' said the man who will govern Brazil's largest state, an expanse almost three times the size of France.
''Most trees in the Amazon are rotten with termites and fungus,'' Mr. Mestrinho continued. ''We should cut and replant with better species.''
One logging restriction adopted this year requires registration of all chain saws with the Brazilian Institute of Environment and Natural Renewable Resources, known as Ibama.
On the campaign trail, Mr. Mestrinho won whoops and hollers with bellowed promises to ''throw abusive Ibama agents in the clink.''
''In Canada, Finland and the United States, people use chainsaws,'' he in Rio de Janeiro. ''Why do our people have to go back to axes?''
He also proposed that Brazil legalize a long-established practice in the Amazon, hunting for meat and for pelts.
''The world consumes 7 million alligator skins a year - that's $7 billion,'' he said. ''If the industrialized world is against it, why don't they prohibit the use of skins?''
In a rare point of common ground with ecologists, Mr. Mestrinho said he would promote ''green tourism'' -ecological safaris for foreigners. In one boost for Amazonian tourism, President Bush is to start a Latin American tour with a visit on Dec. 2 to Manaus, capital of Amazonas state.
''It's very positive that Mr. Bush is coming,'' said the Governor-elect, who takes office in Manaus on March 15. ''It's very important that outsiders get to know the reality of the Amazon.''
 
President Backs Ecologists
Pushing a traditional, aggressively pro-development stance for the Amazon, Mr. Mestrinho may find that attitudes have changed since he last left the state governor's offices, in 1987. Brazil has a growing ecological movement in the nation's industrialized south and a new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, who is committed to limiting environmental damage. ''Weird proposals'' the Rio daily, Jornal do Brasil, recently said of Mr. Mestrinho's views. ''Old conceptions about the forest and ecology - a grab bag that not only goes against good sense, but even sounds like a joke.''
In Brazil state governments need to get along with Brasilia to receive federal funds, and it is doubtful that Mr. Mestrinho will get far with his ''forest improvement'' schemes.
Indeed, within four days of Mr. Mestrinho's election, the president of Ibama, Tania Munhoz, slapped a mining company with a $1 million fine, a record environmental fine for a mining operation in Brazil. She then fined a lumber company $1.9 million, a record for a lumber operation in Brazil.
Asked for his reaction to the raids in his state, Mr. Mestrinho snapped, ''Absurd exhibitionism.''

HEADLINE: BEIJING AND SEOUL SIGN TRADE ACCORD

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 20

 BODY:
China and South Korea agreed today to exchange trade offices, a move that the Seoul Government hopes will eventually lead to the establishment of diplomatic ties.
China has close relations with its hard-line Communist ally, North Korea, and Chinese maps still depict an undivided Korean peninsula with its capital in the north. But over the last few years, South Korea's stunning economic development has captured the interest of a growing number of Chinese scholars and officials, both because they would like to duplicate the growth and because they would like to attract South Korean investment. 
The signing of the agreement today, at a ceremony in Beijing, will lead to the formal opening of representative offices before the end of this year in each capital. Formally, the offices will represent the China Council for the Promotion of International Trade and the Korea Trade Promotion Corporation, but they are also empowered to issue visas and handle consular affairs.
 
Embassies Not Mentioned
Officially, Beijing's position is that while the offices are necessary to facilitate growing trade, they will not lead to an exchange of embassies. To reassure North Korean officials, the agreement today was disclosed in a four-sentence dispatch by the New China News Agency, and no senior Chinese officials attended the ceremony.
''It is believed that this will promote nongovernmental trade and economic and technological cooperation between China and South Korea,'' the press agency reported.
China and South Korea originally considered exchanging trade offices in 1988, but hard-liners in Beijing objected that any Seoul representative office should be allowed only in coastal Shandong province rather than in the capital. The exchange was further delayed after the military crackdown in June 1989, when one of the architects of improved relations with Seoul - Bao Tong, secretary to the Politburo - was dismissed and arrested.
The rise of the hard-liners led to closer ties with North Korea, whose orthodox Communist President, Kim Il Sung, sought commitments from Chinese leaders that they would not go too far in building relations with Seoul. Mr. Kim is believed to have made a secret visit recently to China to ask Chinese leaders to delay any exchange in trade offices, but his appeal was apparently rejected.
 
Indirect Trade
In addition to a small amount of direct shipping between South Korea and Chinese ports such as Lianyungang, indirect trade through third countries exceeded $3.2 billion last year. That compares to trade with North Korea of less than $600 million each year.
South Korean companies in recent years have poured into China to look for investment opportunities, and some South Korean-financed joint ventures have begun manufacturing refrigerators, drugs and other products. Conglomerates from South Korea also donated millions of dollars to Beijing for the Asian Games several weeks ago, and a few South Korean companies have opened offices in Beijing - normally using the names of subsidiaries registered in the United States.
Yet many South Korean executives complain that despite their investments, they still have been treated as second-class citizens and since the crackdown, there appears to have been a cooling of their enthusiasm to do business with China.

HEADLINE: Here at Last, Killer Bees Are Met With a Yawn and a Snigger

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WESLACO, Tex., Oct. 19

 BODY:
There is no talk of killer bees at Andy's Cafe 2 here, no panicked calls to the City Hall in nearby Alamo, not even a mention of the bee invasion in The Beeville Bee-Picayune.
But over the next few years, the Africanized honeybees will have a dramatic impact on beekeepers and agriculture as they cause a reduction in both honey production and pollination. And their long-awaited arrival here in the Lower Rio Grande Valley this week set off speculation about possible effects on everything from lawsuits to wearers of beeswax-based hair replacement systems.
Still, after years of films like ''The Swarm'' and ''Saturday Night Live'' skits of John Belushi in killer bee regalia snarling, ''Your pollen or your wife,'' the bees' arrival has been something of a welcome anticlimax.
''Here in the valley, people have been anticipating this for so long, people are just sick of hearing about it,'' said Dave Mayes, with the department of agricultural communications at Texas A&M University. ''People know more about the bee, and their anxiety level has decreased.'' 
 
A 3,000-Bee Swarm
The relaxed response is likely to change as the bees become more prevalent and as stings are reported. Beekeepers view them as a serious threat to the $150 million in honey produced in the United States annually and to American agricultural products, worth nearly $10 billion, that bees help pollinate.
Still, when the first swarm of aggressive bees finally buzzed into Texas, their debut played out here much as their spread across the country probably will - an epochal event for beekeepers and a real, but minor, risk for the general public.
Officials from the United States Department of Agriculture confirmed Thursday that a 3,000-bee swarm of Africanized honeybees was found and then destroyed Monday in one of the department's pulp-paper traps about a mile north of the Rio Grande.
The discovery means that 33 years after African bees were inadvertently let loose in Brazil, the aggressive strain has entered the United States.
Although the Africanized bees' sting is no worse than that of other bees, the bees are extremely aggressive in defending their hives and have the potential to attack and sting in angry swarms.
There are no precise figures on fatalities. The Government of Mexico says at least 16 people have been killed by the bees there in the past three years, and some experts estimate that 700 to 1,000 people have been killed by stings since 1957, when the bees escaped from a Brazilian breeding experiment and started heading north at about 200 miles a year.
 
'I Just Read Past It'
For the most part, the bees' arrival in South Texas was met with yawns.
''I saw it in the paper, but I just read past it,'' said Jesse Delgado, manager of Andy's Cafe 2, a popular Mexican restaurant. ''No one has even mentioned it.''
A hotline set up to give out information on the bees received only about 15 calls, most from nervous residents who wondered if hives near their homes could contain the Africanized bees.
But John Thomas, a Texas A&M entomologist, said some people are so panicked by the thought of the bees they are in a constant state of anxiety about their arrival.
''I still get calls, primarily from elderly widows, wanting to know when it's going to get to Corpus Christi, or when it's going to get to Houston, and how far north it will go,'' Mr. Thomas said. ''They want to sell their home and move to St. Louis or Kansas City or Chicago before the real estate market crashes because of the bee panic in San Antonio.''
In Houston, Tom Magliaro of Tom Magliaro's Hair Additions, says he worries that Africanized bees might attack the 60 to 80 clients of his who have used beeswax to attach new hairs to thicken existing ones in thinning areas. He raised the specter of a terrified client driving along in a convertible with a three-pound swarm of Africanized bees chasing his hair. The New Pet Rock? In Beeville, where President Bush goes for his annual South Texas hunting trip, Jeff Latcham, general manager of the Bee-Picayune, said his paper found the state of the oil industry and the town's imperiled Naval Air Station more newsworthy than the bees' arrival 200 miles to the south.
When the subject was raised, Mr. Latcham joked that the bees might provide an economic opportunity for the town, which, it turns out, was named not for the insects, but for Col. Bernard E. Bee, President Sam Houston's Secretary of War for the Republic of Texas.
''Maybe we should figure out a way to make some money off the bees, like the pet rock,'' he said. ''Maybe we should have a commemorative stamp and mail it from Beeville.''
Experts say a more telling test of the public's reaction will come in a year or two when, inevitably, there is a stinging incident.
The incident this week ''was totally controlled,'' said Anita Collins, Research Leader with the United States Department of Agriculture's honey bee research laboratory here. ''Eventually, there will be one where someone is stung severely or dies, and that will be more difficult.''
Still, experts say that even when the bees arrive in greater numbers the risk of a fatal sting will be less than that of being struck by lightning. In 1987, the last year for which figures are available, 99 Americans died after being hit by lightning and 53 died from stings by bees, wasps and hornets, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.
 
An Industry at Risk
For the bee industry, the risks are far more immediate and real.
''The arrival of Africanized bees in the U.S. is probably one of the biggest things that has ever happened to U.S. beekeeping,'' said James Tew, an entomologist at Ohio State University who puts out a beekeeping newsletter called Apiculture Awareness.
The Africanized bees are harder to work with, produce less honey, and are of less use in pollination, experts say. In Mexico, beekeepers reported a 20 percent reduction in honey production in areas infested with Africanized bees. Officials say the United States beekeeping industry could face annual losses of $26 million to $58 million after the arrival of the bees, if no effective steps are taken to limit their spread.
And some say the bees bring an added hazard: the potential of dangerous swarms of aggressive lawyers.
''Handling the bees wouldn't be the big problem,'' said Orley Taylor, an entomologist at the University of Kansas. ''Handling the interaction with your neighbors would be the problem. We're a very litigious society, and the biggest problem associated with Africanized bees as far as I'm concerned is the potential for litigation.''
 
Accepting the Inevitable
Beekeepers hope that the bees will lose some of their ferocity as they move north and breed with other bees, though there is little evidence that this has happened in the past. Instead, their main hope is that by carefully managing their hives, being sure, for example, that they are stocked with European queens, bee keepers will limit the impact of the Africanized bees.
''In Texas, the beekeepers have accepted that it's coming, and we have to deal with it,'' said Glenn C. Mace, president of the Texas Beekeepers Association. ''We're going to do our best to maintain European stock in our hives. It'll take a little more time and labor, which translates to money, but I think we can do it.''
For the entomologists who flocked to the hackberry tree near Hidalgo where the bees were found this week, the discovery was as much a source of excitement as a threat.
''Bees are far more interesting than most of the people we know,'' said Mr. Thomas of Texas A&M. ''They sting, they die, and they laugh all the way to the grave.''

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTION: Political Memo;
In '90 Races, Abortion Is Not the 'Silver Bullet'

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
A year ago, the abortion issue roared across the political landscape like a rough midsummer storm.
After the Supreme Court gave states new latitude last summer to restrict abortion, candidates reeled and panicked over the issue, elections seemed to turn on it, and both parties scrambled to adjust to the suddenly awakening power of the abortion rights movement.
Today, in the midterm elections of 1990, the politics of abortion looks more complicated, more subtle and, at a time of crisis in the Persian Gulf and economic turmoil at home, less dominant than it did in the fall of 1989.
This is not to diminish the political impact of Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, the Court's decision in July 1989 that galvanized the abortion rights movement. Abortion is a central issue in many elections this fall, from the race for governor in Florida to the race for Senate in Iowa. Support for abortion rights is now widely considered a net advantage for a candidate, while it was often considered a liability in the pre-Webster era. 
 
No Longer the Magic Issue
''Am I more prone to talking about being pro-choice this year than I was six years ago?'' asked Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa, who was dogged by abortion protesters in his 1984 campaign. ''Absolutely.'' Mr. Harkin, a Democrat in one of the most competitive Senate races this year, is running many commercials on radio stations across Iowa that compare his support for abortion rights with the anti-abortion stance of his opponent, Representative Tom Tauke.
In North Carolina, Harvey Gantt, a Democrat, has been highlighting his support for abortion rights in his challenge to Senator Jesse Helms. And in Florida, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Lawton Chiles, has recently begun to contrast his stance with that of Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican and staunch abortion opponent. Some Democratic strategists argue that support for abortion rights could make the margin of difference in several of these close races this year.
Still, a variety of analysts and politicians agree that the abortion issue is not the magical ''silver bullet'' it seemed to some in 1989, when L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia built his successful campaign for Governor around it. Even Kate Michelman, the executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, said: ''Right after Webster, it was the issue that was moving politics. Now it's become part of a global political framework.''
 
Distracted by Thoughts of War
Part of this, perhaps, reflects a diminished sense of threat among people who support legal abortion. The wholesale changes in state abortion laws that were widely predicted after the Webster decision have yet to materialize. ''The focus has shifted, the world hasn't changed overnight and women aren't being imprisoned for talking about this,'' said Linda DiVall, a Republican poll taker working for candidates on both sides of the issue.
And this year, unlike last year, the abortion issue is competing with the issues of war and the threat of recession. Shelly Bain, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League in Iowa, said, ''There's a lot going on in our economy and in our world to take people's minds off abortion.''
The politics of abortion is also becoming more complex, more nuanced. In 1990, the issue seems much less partisan than it did in 1989, when Democrats who supported abortion rights squared off in Virginia and New Jersey against Republicans who opposed abortion. This year, to the relief of many Republicans, a combination of serendipity and strategy has blurred party lines.
First, the serendipity: Some of the highest-profile races this fall involve Republicans who support abortion rights, including Senator Pete Wilson in the California governor's race and Jim Edgar in the Illinois governor's race, as well as the Senate campaigns of Representatives Claudine Schneider in Rhode Island, Lynn Martin in Illinois and Pat Saiki in Hawaii.
 
Keeping the 'Big Tent' Up
The governor's race in Kansas pits Joan Finney, a Democrat who opposes abortion, against Gov. Mike Hayden, a Republican who supports abortion rights. Similarly, in Pennsylvania, Gov. Bob Casey, a Democrat who opposes abortion, is being challenged by Barbara Hafer, a Republican who supports abortion rights.
Republicans have tried to highlight this diversity since the '89 elections, with Lee Atwater, the national Republican chairman, depicting the party as ''a big tent'' with room for differing views on abortion. This is a very different message from the party's 1988 platform, which is firmly anti-abortion and committed to overturning Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized it.
The ''big tent'' doctrine has filtered down to the states, with varying degrees of grumbling on both sides. In Iowa, for example, incumbent Gov. Terry Branstad is a staunch opponent of abortion who spent two hours at the Iowa Right to Life convention in Waterloo last week, participants said. But he has picked as his running mate a Republican woman, State Senator Joy Corning, who supports abortion rights.
 
No Waffling
Democrats say the Republicans have only managed to postpone the moment when they must decide where the party truly stands. Republicans might have finessed the 1990 midterm elections and the appointment of a Supreme Court justice, David H. Souter, who won confirmation without stating his views on Roe, but they cannot finesse the 1992 platform, Democrats say.
''I think probably the best political fight in America will be how the Republicans deal with their platform on this issue in 1992,'' said Harrison Hickman, a Democratic poll taker who works for the National Abortion Rights Action League.
Still, politicians in both parties are becoming increasingly adept at managing the abortion issue. ''We did do a lot of study on this, and tried to do a lot of training,'' said Mary Matalin, chief of staff of the Republican National Committee. ''But the main contribution I think we made was the big picture one, which is to make candidates understand that this is a character issue, and if they treat it as such, they'll be O.K.
''If you waffle on a character issue, then that defines your character, and you just draw attention to a fatal flaw that people loathe in their politicians,'' the Republican official added.
 
Exaggerated Importance
Abortion opponents, who say news organizations exaggerated the power of the abortion rights cause in the 1989 elections, say they are confident they will more than hold their own this year. ''I think we're going to do very well in some of the races that the pro-abortionists had picked that they thought they were going to win, like the Texas governor's race, the Ohio governor's race,'' said David O'Steen, executive director of the National Right to Life Committee.
In the meantime, the politics of abortion continues to play out. In Iowa, for example, Don Avenson, the Speaker of the Iowa House, won the Democratic nomination for governor in large part because of his support for abortion rights. But his stand has not been enough to overcome Mr. Branstad, according to an Iowa Poll in The Des Moines Register last week, which showed the Governor, a strong abortion opponent, with a considerable lead.

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTION;
Usual Flurry of Election Ads on Television Becomes a Blizzard This Year

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Feeling overwhelmed by political advertising this year? There's a reason: Candidates and their consultants say they are bombarding the electorate with more political advertisements than ever before.
Spending for televised political commercials in the first half of 1990 was almost 34 percent higher than in the first six months of 1988, a Presidential election year, according to the Television Bureau of Advertising. While much of that can be attributed to the inflation of advertising rates, some consultants say they have been producing and broadcasting 20 percent more commercials than in past campaign cycles.
Candidates, consultants and media-buying specialists say there are several reasons for the proliferation of political advertising, including these:
* A ruling by the Federal Communications Commission in September forced broadcasters to stop charging premiums for political advertising on television, lowering costs below the projections made at the beginning of the year and giving campaigns an unexpected boost to their treasuries, which many are using to increase their advertising volume. 
 
* Voters are tuning out political advertising more than ever because of competition for their viewing time from cable television, videocassette recorders and advertising clutter, forcing campaigns to double the number of times that people must see an advertisement before its message sinks in.
* An increase in press scrutiny of political advertising has, paradoxically, given campaigns more source material for negative commercials.
* Candidates are fearful that if they do not react immediately to negative charges made in their opponents' spots, they will go the way Gov. Michael S. Dukakis did in the 1988 Presidential campaign, when he failed to combat George Bush's attacks.
 
'You've Got to React'
''Mike Dukakis taught everybody a lesson,'' said Hank Morris, who is creating commercials for Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic nominee for governor in California. ''You can't let anything go. You've got to react.''
Because of what one Republican consultant, Adam Goodman, called ''Dukakis-induced paranoia,'' candidates are parrying each other's advertisements much more quickly and much earlier in their campaigns. Their ability to take an advertisement from idea to air within 24 hours - in the past, a practice that was used only in the final weeks of a campaign - is now being used months before Election Day.
Quick responses have become such an apparent need that some consultants say they have created and broadcast advertisements in six hours, hastening the process by beaming them off satellites and sending them to television stations on the campaign trail.
An advertisement by the campaign of Senator Carl Levin, Democrat of Michigan, featured articles clipped from newspapers charging Mr. Schuette with ''attack ads'' and ''distortions.'' The commercial underscored one of the paradoxes of this year's campaign: increased scrutiny of political advertising appears to have fueled more negative ads by providing material for campaign messages that attack an opponent's commercials.
This year more than a dozen major newspapers are trying to assess the truth or falsity of political commercials, some in boxes that quote the text of the advertisement and try to judge its veracity.
In the last month alone, newspaper articles critical of an opponent's advertising have been featured in commercials for Senator Levin; Bruce Morrison, the Democratic candidate for governor in Connecticut, and Harvey Gantt, a Democrat who is challenging Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina. Windfall From the F.C.C. A candidate's ability to react has been abetted by a cash windfall, courtesy of the F.C.C.
By law, television stations are required to charge political candidates no more than the lowest rate they charge their best commercial customers, who receive discounts for buying time in bulk. But commercial advertisers generally buy ''pre-emptible'' time, knowing that if an advertisement is bumped it can run at other times.
Stations have interpreted the lowest-rate rule as requiring them to charge politicians low rates only for such pre-emptible time. But the candidates' spots must run before Election Day, so they are forced to buy fixed time, whose rates the stations are free to set.
In July the F.C.C. raided television and radio stations in five cities, seizing the records they are required to keep on political advertising sales. In September the commission issued a report saying that at almost all the television stations, political candidates paid far more than commercial advertisers for advertising. At one station, which the F.C.C. did not name, mainstream advertisers paid an average of $2,713 for a 30-second spot; candidates, on average, paid $6,000.
The commission affirmed that stations must charge politicial advertisers no more than they charge commercial advertisers for the same time slots, and threatened to fine stations who violated the rule or to hold the violations against them when their licenses come up for renewal.
 
Ad Prices Cut 20% to 30%
People who specialize in buying time for political advertising say television stations around the country reacted immediately, dropping their prices for political advertisements by 20 percent to 30 percent. This enabled candidates to buy more advertising now or stockpile the savings for televised volleys late in the campaign.
It appears they will need them. Political media buyers say that, in an effort to pierce the electorate's torpor, they have had to double the amount of time they buy for their advertisements.
Larry McCarthy, a Republican consultant who is creating spots for several House candidates and for Pete Wilson, the Republican nominee for governor in California, attributed the difficulty of reaching people to the same demons troubling mainstream advertisers: ''increased video choices because of VCR's and cable, and more advertising clutter because of 15-second spots and 10-second spots.''
Tony Fabrizio, a Republican media buyer, said that to reach at least 96 percent of the voters on television campaigns used to buy enough time to assure that each voter would see an ad five times. Now, he said, campaigns are hitting each viewer 8.2 to 8.6 times.
''It's scary,'' Mr. Fabrizio said. ''The sponge isn't absorbing as well.''
