HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTION;
NO CLEAR LEADER IN CALIFORNIA RACE

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20

 BODY:
They have dueled over limits on how long elected state officials may serve, crime and punishment, growth and environment, as well as taxation and spending. But the race between Pete Wilson and Dianne Feinstein for governor of California stands just about where it started more than four months ago: deadlocked.
''It is very much up in the air,'' said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe of the Center for Politics and Policy at the Claremont Graduate School. ''This campaign is so close anything could make a difference.''
Barring the unexpected or a major gaffe, the campaign has come down to what political professionals call the numbers. Both candidates appear to have solidified their bedrock support: Ms. Feinstein, the Democratic candidate, who is a former Mayor of San Francisco, in the San Francisco Bay area and Mr. Wilson, the Republican, who is a former Mayor of San Diego, in the more conservative Southern California counties of San Diego and Orange. #4 Counties Seen as Critical So both sides are concentrating on getting out the vote in their strongholds and on advertising in the vote-rich Los Angeles area, where half of California lives. ''It all depends on the margins in the four perimeter counties of Los Angeles,'' said Bill Carrick, Ms. Feinstein's campaign manager - Ventura, San Bernardino, Riverside and northern Orange counties. 
Tacticians for both national parties have called this race a top priority. With its population at 29.3 million in the 1990 census, California is expected to gain up to seven new seats in Congress in 1992 and the Republicans are hoping to have a Republican Governor to veto any reapportionment plan drawn up by the Legislature, which is under overwhelming Democratic control and is expected to stay that way.
The latest public opinion polls gave both camps something to cheer about. The independent California Poll, released Oct. 12, gave Mr. Wilson the edge, 47 to 42 percent, with 11 percent undecided. With a sample size of 1,021, the margin of sampling error was three percentage points either way.
On Oct. 18, a statewide survey taken by The Los Angeles Times found the race virtually dead even: 42 percent for Mr. Wilson and 41 percent for Ms. Feinstein. The sample size was 2,154 and the margin of sampling error was also three percentage points either way. The poll found Mr. Wilson leading by 2 to 1 in Orange and San Diego Counties and by 5 to 4 in the agricultural Central Valley. Ms. Feinstein led by almost 2 to 1 in the San Francisco Bay area and by a slight margin in Los Angeles County.
 
'Gender Gap Has Evened Out'
While much has been made of Ms. Feinstein's appeal to women, both surveys seem to show that Mr. Wilson has offset any advantage his opponent might have had in this area. In the California Poll, Mr. Wilson led Ms. Feinstein 49 percent to 41 percent among men and 46 percent to 44 percent among women. The Los Angeles Times reported that the results from its poll showed male voters favored Mr. Wilson by a margin of 10 points while female voters favored Ms. Feinstein by 7 points.
''This tells us the gender gap has evened out, disappeared,'' said Mr. Wilson's campaign manager, George Gorton. Eileen Padberg, a Republican political consultant who ran George Bush's campaign in California in 1988, theorized that with the possibility of war in the Middle East and a recession, women were turning to Mr. Wilson, as a Senator, for his experience.
But the Feinstein camp found it encouraging that two-thirds of the undecided voters were women.
Ms. Feinstein, who came from far behind to capture the Democratic nomination, has portrayed herself as a bright new face in California politics, an agent of change for a troubled state. In the Los Angeles Times poll, 59 percent chose her as the candidate for change, as against 13 percent for Mr. Wilson.
 
'Tale of Two Cities'
Mr. Wilson, a moderate in the Republican spectrum, has based his campaign largely on what he calls the ''tale of two cities,'' a comparison between his record as a Mayor and Ms. Feinstein's, arguing that he reduced taxes in San Diego while she was raising them in San Francisco. In an appeal to women, he comes down hard for long prison terms for rapists, saying women ought to feel safe when they walk alone at night.
Ms. Feinstein assailed Mr. Wilson for missing votes in the Senate, and he returned to Washington Monday to take part in the budget debate. Although Ms. Feinstein had Mr. Wilson on the defensive, neither candidate can be confident.
The candidates have carefully tailored middle-of-the road platforms that are especially Californian. They both present themselves as supporters of the right to abortion, as backers of the death penalty and as stalwart defenders of the environment, differing in details and attacking each other's sincerity on each issue. For example, Ms. Feinstein has endorsed a far-reaching measure, called ''big green,'' that would rewrite California environmental law, while Mr. Wilson says it tries to do too much and would undermine the Governor's authority.
They have clashed directly on some issues. Senator Wilson supports a ballot measure that would impose strict limits on the terms of state legislators, while Ms. Feinstein opposes it. Ms. Feinstein has proposed a special state commission to manage growth, while Mr. Wilson says such decisions are more properly made at the local level. Mr. Wilson backs merit pay for teachers; Ms. Feinstein, backed by the main teachers' union, is against that.
 
Campaigning in Wilson Territory
As Mr. Wilson spent this weekend in Washington, Ms. Feinstein took full advantage, with numerous campaign events in Southern California, including a breakfast with black ministers in Los Angeles, a brunch with abortion rights groups in Santa Ana, a fund-raising event in Long Beach and a meeting with leaders of Kids First, an education advocacy group.
''We need to do well in Southern California,'' said her press secretary, Dee Dee Myers. ''We'll be spending the bulk of our time here.''
Her campaign manager, Mr. Carrick, suggested she planned to tie Mr. Wilson to the budget troubles in Washington. ''He's part of the mess,'' he said. ''We are basically waiting for the car wreck. Whenever it is, to associate him with that is a plus for us, particularly when people are looking for someone not part of the Washington-Sacramento political culture.''
At their only debate so far, on Oct. 7, Mr. Wilson tried to turn public resentment at politicians to his own advantage, announcing that he was backing a ballot measure, Proposition 140, that would limit state senators and statewide elected officials to a total of eight years in office and State Assembly members to six years.
 
Feinstein Benefits From Ruling
While that got Mr. Wilson the debate headlines, his campaign manager, Mr. Gorton, said that it had not provided much of a lift for him and that the campaign intended to focus more on issues of taxation and the economy. ''Our polls show the economy has gone from fourth to first - people do not want their taxes raised,'' he said.
Further complicating matters was a Sept. 25 ruling by a Federal judge voiding the state's limits on campaign contributions. With only $686,733 in the bank compared with Mr. Wilson's $3.3 million, Ms. Feinstein quickly raised $750,000 from such diverse sources as the California Association of Highway Patrolmen, the California Teachers Association, Ted Field, the Hollywood producer, and Chevy Chase, the comedian.
The victory may turn on who is better at what political consultants call ''the ground game,'' the unglorious but crucial effort to get out the sympathetic vote and discourage other voters. Republicans are making an enormous effort to distribute absentee ballots to Republican voters, while the Democrats see moderates, independents and Republican women as targets of opportunity. The Democrats also hope that conservative Republicans, many of whom are unhappy with Mr. Wilson's stands on abortion and his opposition to offshore oil drilling, will stay at home.
So far the campaign has been comparatively polite by national standards, but members of both camps say it might become more negative in the final stretch.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Agree on Immigration Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Congressional negotiators will meet early next week to work out final details of a bill that would allow a substantial increase in legal immigration to the United States.
The compromise bill would allow 700,000 immigrants a year in 1992, 1993 and 1994 and 675,000 annually in subsequent years. The United States has been admitting about 500,000 immigrants a year, not counting refugees, people who are fleeing persecution.
Under the bill, the United States would increase the allowable number of skilled immigrants, including scientists, engineers and medical technicians, so as to compensate for expected shortages of skilled labor in the 1990's. Congress, the Labor Department and many economists see immigration as a way to correct the imbalance between labor supply and demand. 
 
'An Excellent Compromise'
Representative Bruce A. Morrison, the Connecticut Democrat who heads the House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, said he and other key members of the House and the Senate reached the agreement on Friday night.
''There are details still to be worked out,'' Mr. Morrison said in an interview. ''But the basic outline of the bill is agreed to. It is an excellent compromise.''
The tentative agreement was unexpected. The Senate passed a version of the legislation in July 1989, and the House passed a major immigration bill on Oct. 3 of this year. But disagreements among lawmakers responsible for immigration policy were so profound that the Senate, which wanted to set immigration levels much lower than the House did, refused to enter formal negotiations.
But after four hours of informal talks on Friday, senators and representatives agreed on the outline of the compromise. They plan to convene a formal conference committee early next week. Much of the conference report has already been written by Congressional aides.
The conference report is subject to approval by both chambers and by the President.
 
Splitting the Difference
The compromise sets the total number of immigrants in between the 630,000 a year specified in the Senate bill and the 775,000 in the House measure.
Under the compromise, the 700,000 immigrants permitted in each of the first three years would be chosen as follows: 465,000 would be relatives of United States citizens and permanent resident aliens; 140,000 would be workers with special job skills, or close family members (an increase in this category of more than 80,000); 40,000 would be residents of countries that have been allowed to send relatively few immigrants to the United States in recent years, and 55,000 would be spouses and children of aliens who gained legal status under the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986.
In 1995 and later years, the 675,000 immigrant visas would be distributed as follows: 480,000 to relatives of citizens and permanent resident aliens; 140,000 to workers with special skills and their relatives, and 55,000 to citizens of countries that have sent relatively few immigrants to the United States in recent years.
 
Reservations Voiced
Mr. Morrison said: ''The basic goals of the House bill that I sponsored have been attained. We will get a substantial increase in employer-sponsored immigration. We have expanded family immigration. And we will have a substantial program for countries previously disadvantaged under the immigration law, like Ireland, Poland and Italy.''
Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the sole Republican member of the Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, said in an interview after the informal negotiations on Friday night: ''We struck a deal. We haven't got it all in writing, but we struck an oral deal, and I think it's in the national interest.''
Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat who has worked closely with Hispanic groups, said today that he endorsed the overall agreement on numbers of immigrants, even though he had reservations about some parts of the compromise bill.
''It is better than existing law, but it's a far cry from the House bill,'' which was more generous to aliens wishing to join relatives already in the United States, he said.
Mr. Morrison said he believed the House-Senate conference would be ''smooth sailing because we have sailed all the rough waters already.''
 
'Far From Over'
But Rick Swartz, an immigration lawyer in Washington, said it was possible that Hispanic groups and some religious organizations would find the agreement unacceptable because of the way it treated family-related immigration. ''This process is far from over,'' he said.
Under current law, there is no immigration limit on American citizens' immediate relatives, who include spouses, unmarried minor children and, in some cases, the citizen's parents. The compromise bill would count immediate relatives under the overall ceiling for legal immigration.

HEADLINE: Allies Say Budget Impasse Could Hurt World Economy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
For America's allies, the budget fiasco in Washington has created an image of a rudderless, indecisive Government, the prey of special interests. It is not an image they savor.
''It's horrifying to see all this from the outside,'' said Hans-Jorg Rudloff, chairman of Credit Suisse-First Boston, a leading investment bank in London. ''It says a lot about the weakness of America because America will inevitably lose its position in the world if it can't put its financial house in order. Sure, America's military might is still there, but the same economic might is not there.'' 
For years, many economists and executives around the world have said that unless the United States budget deficit is brought under control, it will spell trouble for America's and the world's economies, since it could mean higher interest rates in the United States and elsewhere and increased difficulties for Washington in attracting foreign investors to finance its deficit. With the current turmoil in Washington, those concerns have been reinforced.
 
'Disgraceful Behavior'
Partly as a result of the long stalemate between Congress and the President, Japanese investors are showing greater reluctance to invest in United States Treasury securities, after years of financing as much as 40 percent of Washington's borrowing.
''The attitude of the Japanese is very much like that of other investors around the world: they look at the U.S. budget process as a bit of disgraceful behavior for the Government of the world's largest economy,'' said David Resler, an economist with the Nomura Research Institute in New York.
The budget crisis is just one factor contributing to a net flow of investment funds out of the United States this year. Many foreign investors who once saw America as a land of golden opportunity have pulled back because of plunging real estate prices, a weaker stock market, the savings and loan crisis and fragility among the nation's commercial banks.
An agreement to reduce the Federal budget deficit substantially could reverse this trend, say many economists overseas, because such an accord could mean lower interest rates, a long-term strengthening of the American economy and perhaps a rebound in real estate prices.
''A lot of foreign investors will feel more reassured about America's economic course when they see the deficit brought under control,'' said Michel Develle, chief economic adviser for Banque Paribas, an investment bank in Paris.
 
Others Asked to Sacrifice
Many Europeans say they find it contradictory that American officials urge Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to slash their budget deficits and make other sacrifices as they begin their leap from Marxism to a market economy.
''The battle between a Republican President and a Democratic Congress over the budget has given the post-Communist countries an unfortunate example of how policy can also be mismanaged in a capitalist economy,'' said Christopher Johnson, chief economic adviser to Lloyds Bank in London.
In Eastern Europe and the third world as well as Western Europe, resentment is growing over the perception that because of its budget and trade deficits, the United States is hogging available investment funds, making them less available to other nations.
''A nation as rich as the United States should not be the major importer of capital that is desperately needed in much poorer parts of the world,'' said Mr. Rudloff, of Credit Suisse-First Boston. ''It's America's duty as a world power to put its house in order.''
 
'Need Some Changes'
Many foreign observers have concluded that the standoff in Washington shows that America's budgetary process needs to be revamped.
''The rules of how to resolve the budget situation need some changes,'' said Peter Trapp, vice chairman of the Institute for the World Economy in Kiel, Germany.
In Western Europe, where taxes, social spending and investments in infrastructure like railroads and highways are generally higher than in the United States, there is widespread criticism of the seeming unwillingness of Americans to pay the bill for the level of government services they want and, some Europeans say, need.
Many European admirers of America seem to miss the time when the United States was far and away the economic top dog, and they now talk of a nation with a crumbling infrastructure, a mediocre school system and astonishing urban problems that will make its economy less competitive.

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: Yet Another Incarnation for a Versatile Tax Credit: Child Care Aid

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Embedded in the huge budget packages that have passed the House and Senate is a secret weapon that lawmakers have used for 15 years to give working poor people an income supplement intended to help them improve their economic state and stay off welfare.
The tool is the earned-income tax credit, and through it some low-income workers can receive a cash payment of almost $1,000 this year to offset their tax burden.
But depending on the political climate, the credit changes its stripes. This year, it has been portrayed as an offset to higher Social Security payroll taxes. Just a few years ago, it was presented as the best way to make up for no increases in the minimum wage. And now lawmakers are selling the earned-income credit as a way to help poor families with their child care without creating new social programs and bureaucracies. 
The Senate Finance Committee's budget legislation, passed early Friday, would increase the earned-income credit, along with two other related tax credits, by $16.8 billion over the next five years, with all but $5 billion intended for helping families pay for child care. The $5 billion is intended to offset the increases in gasoline taxes and other use taxes that are also in the legislation.
The plan passed by the House on Tuesday would increase the benefits taxpayers receive through the credit by as much as $22 billion, with $11 billion intended for child care. The two chambers are now trying to work out differences in the budget legislation.
 
Questions on Effectiveness
But while the credit is being promoted as a way to help families pay for child care, experts are questioning how effective it can be for that purpose.
They point to two major weaknesses. One is that the higher taxes on gasoline, cigarettes and alcohol in the Senate bill would fall so heavily on lower-income taxpayers that the entire benefit people received from the earned-income credit would be consumed.
Second, they note that simply giving poor families a big lump-sum payment after they file their tax returns does not necessarily help them with child-care payments through the year, nor does it address the quality of child care centers or the skills of those who run them.
''We're trying to kill so many birds all at once with this credit that we're not going to do any one thing very well,'' said Isabel V. Sawhill, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a research organization in Washington.
In the history of the credit, its periodic repackaging at the whim of politicians is not new. Conceived in 1972 by former Senator Russell Long, Democrat of Louisiana, the credit eventually took effect in 1975, and at that time was intended to offset rising Social Security taxes. But the credit soon took on the mission of keeping low-income workers in the work force and off welfare rolls by giving them a tax break for earning income.
 
How the Credit Works
It accomplishes this by rewarding low-income workers more as their pay grows, up to a point.
As earnings rise to $6,810, a worker is given a 14-cent credit against taxes for every dollar earned. For the 1990 tax year, that will mean the maximum benefit is $953. From $6,810 up to an income of $10,730, that full credit remains in place. When earnings exceed $10,730, the credit begins to decline at a rate of 10 cents for every $1. Finally, at an income of $20,264, eligibility for the tax credit ends.
In the 1980's, particularly in the last years of Ronald Reagan's Presidency and early in the George Bush's, a drive was begun to raise the credit, with backers arguing that it would compensate for the the Administrations' refusal to go along with higher minimum wages.
 
Political Labeling
Only in the last 18 months, as Congress has pushed hard for legislation to improve child care, has the tax credit become the favored vehicle.
The approach is in line with a free-market philosophy of putting the money in the hands of consumers and letting them decide, rather than creating new Federal bureaucracies, regulations and accompanying spending.
''Politically, it has certainly helped to label the current increase as child care, but in fact it can pretty much be all things to all people,'' Ms. Sawhill of the Urban Institute said.
While most of the increase are described in the legislation as a benefit to cover child-care payments, the recipients are not bound to use the money for that.
While the House budget legislation calls for a straight increase in the credit, the Senate measure includes increases in two other programs for the poor as well.
 
Unequal Benefits Cited
One would change the dependent child-care tax credit, making those who owe no taxes eligible for it. Currently, this credit can only be used to offset taxes paid, and some lawmakers have argued that it thus benefits primarily the middle- and upper-income people.
By permitting the poor to receive direct payments for dependent care, the program would channel an added $4.9 billion to poor families over five years.
The second program in the Senate measure is intended to provide $2.9 billion to help low-income workers pay for the health insurance for children. To be phased in over four years, the program would give a maximum tax credit of $375 to those who pay for health insurance for their children, or 5.5 cents for every dollar earned up to $6,810.
There are other issues surrounding the use of the earned-income tax credit. Noting that it is given equally to families that have one or both spouses working, experts say such a system is fine if its aim is simply poverty relief. But if the purpose is to underwrite the cost of child care, the single parent or the family in which both spouses work have much greater costs of child care than families in which one spouse works and the other stays in the home.
Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat from Connecticut, termed it ''ludicrous'' to consider the the earned-income credit as a way of improving child care.
The credit ''is an important aid to the poor,'' he said, ''but there is no way to prescribe on what the money will be spent. I suspect a significant portion will not end up going to child care.''

HEADLINE: Social Security Benefits to Rise by 5.4% in January

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Forty million Social Security recipients will get a 5.4 percent increase in benefits in January, the biggest such increase since 1982.
Under Federal law, the cost-of-living adjustment is made automatically each year. In 1991, it will cost the Government $13.5 billion. 
Money for Social Security benefits comes from the Social Security trust fund, which had assets of $163 billion at the end of 1989. The surplus in the trust fund tends to make the overall Federal deficit look smaller, as the Government generally shows spending and receipts for Social Security along with those for other programs in a single budget.
Like Social Security, several other benefit programs are indexed for inflation and linked to the Consumer Price Index. The programs include Supplemental Security Income for the aged, blind and disabled, Civil Service retirement benefits and military retirement benefits.
 
Welfare Benefits in Decline
The Congressional Budget Office says that such entitlement programs, under which payments must be made to applicants who meet criteria set by law, account for nearly half of all Federal spending, or $550 billion in a $1.2 trillion budget in the fiscal year 1990.
Some benefit programs are not tied to the Consumer Price Index. Thus, for example, the level of benefits in the main Federal-state welfare program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, has not kept pace with inflation. In a typical state, the purchasing power of welfare benefits has declined 39 percent in the last 20 years.
For Social Security recipients the average monthly benefit, now $571, will rise to $602 in January. For an elderly couple, both receiving Social Security, the average monthly benefit will rise to $1,022 from $970.
Social Security recipients got a 4.7 percent increase in benefits last January. The increase in 1982 was 7.4 percent.
 
Method Under Criticism
The indexing of Federal programs, to protect beneficiaries from inflation, been criticized by some conservatives, in both the Republican and Democratic Parties, because it tends to increase Federal spending.
But P. Royal Shipp, senior specialist on social legislation at the Congressional Research Service, said indexing was ''introduced in Social Security as a means of constraining the growth of the program.''
''The 1972-73 legislation pegging future automatic benefit increases to the Consumer Price Index was sought largely by conservatives as a means of curbing even larger ad hoc benefit increases,'' he said. ''The old ad hoc, separately enacted benefit increases of the past might have sometimes exceeded the inflation rate, but each and every increase was also accompanied by a review of its effect on the financial condition of the program.''
With automatic cost-of-living adjustments, there is no requirement for such scrutiny. But Congress can pass a law delaying or reducing a scheduled increase in benefits and has done so on occasion.

HEADLINE: Hispanic Aide's Departure Signals Growing Tensions

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
The resignation of Mayor David N. Dinkins's liaison aide with Hispanic groups underscores a growing frustration between Hispanic political and civil rights advocates and an administration that they fear has been taking them for granted.
The director of the new Mayor's Office of Latino Affairs, William Nieves, said on Wednesday that he would resign at the end of the month. Mr. Nieves said limited resources and a lack of access to the Mayor had hampered his effectiveness as an ombudsman for Hispanic interests.
He said in his resignation letter he had been a victim of ''unjustified character assassinations in the media.'' He later told friends that the attacks had been motivated by mayoral advisers wanting to oust him after he and the Mayor had publicly disagreed over Mr. Dinkins's support for him. 
Advocates of Hispanic rights have criticized the administration's handling of the resignation and warned that simply replacing him without improving the job would be unacceptable. The advocates said the problem went deeper, that the administration had to work to regain its credibility with Hispanic voters who supported Mr. Dinkins's election.
 
'Learning Curve Is a Lot Flatter'
''I don't think anybody anticipated the Dinkins administration would develop such a poor relationship with the Latino community,'' the executive director of the Institute for Puerto Rican Policy, Angelo Falcon, said. ''Their learning curve is a lot flatter than I think anybody anticipated.''
Hispanic voters were part of the coalition that with other ethnic groups and unions helped elect the first black mayor. Some advocates of Hispanic rights who drummed up support for Mr. Dinkins said they felt used. They said they saw Mr. Nieves's appointment as a harbinger of cordial relations with the city government. Mr. Nieves was an early backer of Mr. Dinkins and helped raise money for him.
Their expectations were tempered by the fact that unlike his counterpart in the Koch administration, Luis A. Miranda Jr., Mr. Nieves had a smaller staff and did not have an open door to the Mayor. He had to go through the constituent affairs director, Victor M. Quintana, and Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch.
Relations grew tense when Mr. Dinkins characterized as assassins three men whom Mr. Nieves said he considered heroes. The three were Puerto Rican nationalists who fired on Congress from the spectators' gallery in 1954. The Mayor was criticized again when Hazel N. Dukes, head of the state N.A.A.C.P. and an adviser he appointed president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, made derogatory remarks about Hispanic immigrants, for which she later apologized.
 
'Keeping the Community Remote'
Advocates of Hispanic rights said the the head of the Latino Affairs Office should be able to call on the Mayor directly. Although the organization of the office may be typical of Mr. Dinkins's hierarchical style, some critics see it as a slight to Hispanic residents. ''He is keeping the community remote from him by having all this protocol,'' the coordinator of the Hispanic Coalition for Dignity and Justice, Carmen Canales-Ambert, said.
In what he described as an effort ''to put this issue to rest,'' Mr. Dinkins defended his record yesterday before a group of Hispanic lay people and clergy at the Catholic Center at First Avenue and 55th Street. ''This nonsense of direct access to the Mayor is really a straw man put up by some of my Latino friends who did not support me in the first place, who supported Ed Koch and Rudy Giuliani,'' he said in a departure from his prepared speech.
The Mayor named Hispanic people whom he has appointed like Mr. Quintana and Fire Commissioner Carlos A. Rivera. Mr. Dinkins also distributed a report on programs serving Hispanic New Yorkers.
''Does the Latino community prefer to have a liaison to the Mayor or have people like Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Financial and Economic Development, handling things in the first instance, not by communicating with me?'' he asked. ''She does the job.''
''I don't think this administration has turned its back on the Latino community,'' Mr. Lynch said. ''We have been fair and inclusionary.''
 
Meeting at Gracie Mansion
He added that Mr. Nieves had ample opportunity to talk to Mr. Dinkins. But Mr. Lynch acknowledged that the administration needed to reach out more and said an advisory council of Hispanic civic leaders would be formed. ''We want good public relations from it, but we don't want it just to be a public-relations office,'' he added.
Mr. Dinkins announced his plans for the council at a meeting last month at Gracie Mansion, and Mr. Falcon said, ''The administration is going to have to come up with not a nice new improved office, but nice new improved policies.''
Dennis Rivera, president of hospital workers' union, Local 1199, a major early supporter of Mr. Dinkins, said he had sometimes been impatient with the Mayor's seeming lack of response. But he added that Mr. Dinkins had rightly devoted attention to fiscal problems.
''Some of us who got impatient with David failed to see the immense pressure he has,'' Mr. Rivera said. ''There are those in the financial community and those who didn't vote for him who really want him to fail.''
Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said Mr. Dinkins could ease relations by becoming more involved in Hispanic residents' problems. ''David's heart is in the right place,'' Mr. Ferrer said. ''But he may have to be a little more hands-on on these issues.''
Some Hispanic voters said they, too, had to become more involved, rather than assume that because the Mayor was from a minority group that conditions would automatically improve for all other minority groups.
''I guess you have to fight City Hall anyway, rather than wait for the Mayor to do the right thing,'' said Elizabeth Colon, executive director of the Association of Puerto Rican Executive Directors.

HEADLINE: New York Farms Showed Record Profits in 1989

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
New York farmers earned profits of $807 million in 1989, the highest amount ever recorded in the state, the Agricultural Statistics Service reported last week.
Despite a sharp rise in production expenses, the net income of the farmers last year was 20 percent higher than in the previous record year of 1987, the service said.
''It was a real good year for farmers,'' said Mark F. Emery, a spokesman for the New York Farm Bureau. 
The major reason was a rise in the price of milk sold by the state's dairy farms, which constitute the largest economic segment of the state's commercial farming.
With the increase in milk revenues, all the state's farms showed a combined gross income that topped $3 billion for the first time, reaching a record level of $3.28 billion, according to the statistical service. The previous record of $2.98 billion was reported in 1987.
The figures also reflected a turnaround from 1988, when both gross and net farm income dropped from 1987. In 1988, gross farm income fell to $2.95 billion, and net farm income dropped to $661 million, down from $674 million the year before.
Despite relative stability in milk prices early this year, Mr. Emery said that a projected drop in those prices, along with rising fuel costs, could reduce farm profitability in 1990.
''We are cautiously optimistic about 1990,'' he said.
Richard T. Maquire, the State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, said he did not expect 1990 to be as good a year for farmers as 1989, mainly because of an anticipated drop in milk prices caused by increased production.
The large increase in profits on New York farms last year contrasted with figures from Connecticut and New Jersey. Both states reported higher gross farm incomes, but Connecticut showed a drop in net income and New Jersey only a slight increase.
In Connecticut, gross farm income rose from $427.2 million in 1988 to $434.6 million in 1989, but profits fell from $146.2 million to $138.5 million. In New Jersey, the gross farm income in 1989 rose to $767.4 million from $728.3 million the year before, while the net income increased to $248.3 million from $246.2 million.
Neither of those states has a large dairy sector like New York's, so rising milk prices did not offset farmers' increased production costs. In 1989, Connecticut had 3,900 farms operating and New Jersey 8,100.
In New York, the number of commercial farms operating in 1989 was 39,000, down from 41,000 the year before, according to the statistics service. Of the total, about 11,600 were dairy farms, and those farms accounted for 55 percent of all cash receipts by New York farms. Last year, the dairy farmers sold their milk for a total of $1.56 billion, up from $1.4 billion the year before.
Other segments of New York agriculture also showed increases. Greenhouse and nursery products were sold for $262 million, up from $232 million, vegetables rose from $222 million to $243 and fruit from $142 million to $161 million.
Those increases more than offset the rising costs of production, which were up 8 percent overall last year, from a total of $2.3 billion to $2.5 billion, the statistics service said. Most of the increases came in the costs of pesticides, feed, fertilizer, taxes and labor.

HEADLINE: Photo: Westchester County, which is anticipating a budget deficit for the next year of about $80 million, may be forced to curtail plans for renovations and replacement of rides at the county-owned Rye Playland, above. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times) (pg. 32) As Tax Revenues Drop in Region, Cuts Are Small but Close to Home

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
With tax revenue stunted by the weak economy, state, county and local budgets are being tightened throughout the metropolitan region in ways that are touching nearly everyone in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Just as the entire region charged ahead with New York City in the mid-1980's, the region now is tagging right along with the city's slump into tough fiscal times. Mayor David N. Dinkins's scramble over the last few weeks to close a yawning budget gap is being viewed as a warning by governments large and small to get their own houses in order while there still is time.
There have been few layoffs or substantial cuts so far. But life in the region is being changed in scores of ways that are small but frustrating, and are likely a harbinger of harder times to come. 
 
Decline in Tax Revenues
Professors at the University of Connecticut are emptying their own wastepaper baskets because of maintenance cutbacks. In Holmdel, N.J., only half as many shade trees are being planted this year as had been planned. New Haven has canceled its New Year's Eve celebration. And the Whirlwind roller coaster at Rye Playland may not be replaced right away when its current lease at the Westchester County park expires.
Receipts of important taxes in all three states are lagging behind projections, and the shortfalls are leading officials to contemplate far greater austerity.
''If we make corrections now, we will not get like New York City,'' said Katherine S. Carsky, the Republican head of the budget committee on the Westchester County Board of Legislators.
The chief problem is a drop in the jobs, corporate profits and real-estate values that produce the taxes on which governments run. From town halls to the statehouses, a scramble is on to avoid a full-blown fiscal crisis and to deal with an economic future that was dimming even before the Persian Gulf crisis pushed up the cost of energy and the rate of inflation.
Revenue from sales taxes, income taxes and business taxes have dropped from last year in most places, and property tax revenue has also fallen in many areas. And even where tax collections increased, they have remained below anticipated levels.
New York City's problems are the most severe right now, with Mr. Dinkins considering large layoffs and deep budget cuts, and investment analysts calling for sterner measures and declaring a so-called credit watch, an indication that they believe serious fiscal problems exist.
But the tattered economy has put pressure on government budgets at all levels. And the fiscal trouble facing states means more fiscal trouble for towns and counties, as state aid dwindles.
New York State is not as hard-pressed as New York City, but Gov. Mario M. Cuomo acknowledged in a gubernatorial debate on Friday night that he expects the state to run a deficit this year. Tax receipts are running about $200 million below budget estimates.
In Connecticut, the tax on corporate profits is down about $66 million from last year, an indication of weakness in the state's business sector. Some $36 million of the drop-off is due to changes in accounting methods, said Gordon J. Frassinelli, executive budget officer in Connecticut's Office of Policy and Management. Nevertheless, Connecticut could end the year with a budget gap of $390 million, including a deficit of $157 million carried over from last year.
Because both New York and Connecticut are holding elections for governor this year, fiscal experts believe budget problems are being highlighted but bona fide solutions - like higher taxes and tough cutbacks - tend to be evaded. Wait, they say, until next year.
 
The New Jersey Approach
The situation in New Jersey provides an example. Before last year's election for governor, Standard & Poor's, the investment rating service, declared that New Jersey's economy had topped out and that balancing the first budget after the election would require a tax increase.
Neither candidate for governor agreed. But within months of taking office, Gov. Jim Florio pushed through a $2.8 billion package of taxes.
While taxpayers around the state screamed, some fiscal monitors had a more postive reaction. ''New Jersey has done what it takes before the other states because it had its election a year earlier,'' said Hyman C. Grossman, managing director of the government finance department at Standard & Poor's.
Because of the tax increase, Standard & Poor's earlier this year took New Jersey off the credit watch and raised its credit rating.
Since New Jersey raised its sales tax rate to 7 percent from 6 percent and added paper products, telephone calls and many other items to the list of those covered by the tax, revenues for the first quarter are up sharply from last year's. But state officials are worried because corporate taxes, realty transfer taxes and other revenue sources are falling behind expectations.
 
Lots of Little Cuts
Disappointing tax collections have forced Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk counties to restrain spending, primarily by putting a freeze on all hiring. Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin recently proposed holding the line on taxes, but said that to do so he would have to lay off 295 county workers next year.
Counties and municipalities, which rely primarily on property taxes, are being hurt by the real-estate slump. The drop in prices has led to an explosion of property tax appeals, many of which end up in tax reductions for homeowners and headaches for local officials.
Few governments have taken steps as drastic as layoffs. But the many little steps to save taken together form a pattern of annoyances, inconveniences and frustrations.
For instance, $10 million was taken from the $117 million budget for New Jersey's Division of Motor Vehicles, which runs the state's auto inspection stations, where drivers must have their cars inspected once a year. The cuts forced the division to scale back hours and eliminate Saturday inspections all together.
The changes took effect July 2. Soon, lines of cars were snaking around the stations and frustrated drivers howled in anger. So loud were the protests that Governor Florio agreed to restore some of the lost funds, which shortened lines, although the stations remain closed on Saturdays.
Other side effects of the budget crunch are being felt throughout the region. Benches and swings in Connecticut state parks are going longer without fresh paint. The Plainfield Symphony Orchestra will have to play on a flat stage instead of a raised platform because it lost a $10,000 grant from the New Jersey Arts Council and cannot afford the cost of moving the platform.
 
No Leaf Pickups
When Connecticut imposed a 5 percent across-the-board budget reduction this summer, the University of Connecticut eliminated a dozen custodial positions. For safety reasons, bathrooms and locker rooms still are cleaned every day, but faculty offices are being skipped, leaving professors to carry their own wastepaper baskets out to the dumpsters behind their buildings.
In Stamford, Conn., homeowners in the northern, more suburban half of town will have to find their own way of disposing of autumn leaves, because the city has suspended pickups there to save money. It suggested that residents rake leaves into the woods or compost them.
In Holmdel, a suburban township in central New Jersey, officials have been pinching pennies to keep taxes from rising again. This year, said Mayor Peggy Lasky, some $300,000 worth of road repairs and other capital improvements were delayed and the shade tree commission's appropriation was halved to $2,500.
In New Haven the city's six-person Department of Cultural Affairs was shrunk to a one-man bureau.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Fashion in Paris: Irrelevant, but Who Cares?

BYLINE: By WOODY HOCHSWENDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 20

 BODY:
Fashion is different here. The French seem to take a special delight in pure style, style as an end in itself, independent of business. So while Seventh Avenue is in a dark mood, amid talk of war and recession, the Paris fashion scene this season retains its ebullient kick and unabashed sense of fun.
The spirit is dramatically evident at the current round of spring ready-to-wear shows, many of which have held fast to their tradition of outlandishness and blatant irrelevance to women's lives. At Thierry Mugler's extravaganza Thursday, celebrities like Diana Ross, Lauren Hutton and Jade Jagger came down the runway to the roars and whistles of a crowd that included Madonna and Danielle Mitterrand, the wife of the French President; the clothes themselves were manifestly unwearable.
 
A Prosperous Feeling
Where would you go in a fairy-godmother skirt 10 feet wide? Or a skin-tight vinyl bodysuit? But then again, who cares? These are styles of the future, clothes to play with your robot in, as one model did on stage. A separate, more commercial line was shown privately to the stores. 
There is a prosperous feeling here, and the fashions show it. The Europeans, while not unconcerned, do not believe events in the Middle East will hurt their businesses much, French executives said, except insofar as it affects their customers in the United States.
Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, some French couture houses have had orders canceled. Nina Ricci, which sells 60 percent of its made-to-order clothes to Arab clients, has probably suffered the most. But Persian Gulf clients account for only 8 percent of couture sales over all, said Jacques Mouclier, the president of the Chambre Syndicale, the trade organization of French couturiers.
While the buying power of the American stores has been substantially reduced by both financial problems and the relative decline in the value of the dollar, manufacturers here believe that any loss of American orders will be offset by their growing business in Asia, especially Japan, which is now second only to the home market as an outlet for French luxury goods.
In many ways Paris is on a roll, its $16 billion-a-year fashion machine fueled by the great commercial houses like Chanel, Yves Saint Laurent and Christian Dior, who show later this week.
While no new stars have arisen here lately - and few strikingly new looks have been produced - the city has had a continual influx of novel talent. There were the Japanese, in the early 80's. Then there were the Italians, like Romeo Gigli, who made a splash with his exotic clothes two seasons ago but retreated to his showroom this season. Most recently it has been the English, and most notably John Galliano.
On Wednesday in one of the big tents set up in a courtyard outside the Louvre, Mr. Galliano showed the kind of a collection about which veteran fashion editors - fashion nuns, as they are sometimes called - grimly shake their heads, or say something sublimely ambiguous like: ''The clothes looked better from the back.''
The models, all at least six feet tall and seemingly hired from a genetic engineering company, appeared on the exalted fashion catwalks in patchworked psychedelic jeans; these were followed by big washer-women's skirts layered over insulation batting and paired with tank tops. From the waists, loose suspenders dangled, and heads were topped with little Tyrolean hats. This is what is known as ''a lot of look.''
Some of the department store buyers looked stunned. ''They are all just looking for another blazer,'' scoffed a fashion photographer. Well, Mr. Galliano gave it to them. There were men's-style pinstriped jackets, but with an extra sleeve worn as a scarf - or a sling. Where this will sell, other than near an orthopedic hospital, is not clear.
Continuing his deconstruction of clothing, Mr. Galliano then sent his Valkyrian troop out clutching enormous clumps of the aforementioned batting material to their unclad bodies. It looked like shearling, but no fur for Mr. Galliano; he is pro-insulation.
 
Wedding Dress of Paper
 None of this is to gainsay this designer's achievement. He showed chiffon slip dresses, very close to the body, very sexy, that many women would instantly find appealing.
For the finale - traditionally a wedding gown - the model came out in a sculpted white paper dress, which makes everything about the honeymoon night a lot easier.
The original fashion deconstructor is Jean-Paul Gaultier, a dyed-blond Frenchmen, who is revered here. Fashion groupies who don't even dream of getting into his shows stand outside and beg for copies of the program. This season it was a large pop-up card with a serpent and nude figures.
The theme of his show Friday, held in a theater on the Champs-Elysees, was ''Rasta Adam and Eve for Today.'' The models, in dreadlock wigs, came out as couples dressed for some bizarre new Eden. The first wore nothing but spandex bicycle shorts and leafy codpieces as the sound system played a version of M. C. Hammer's ''Can't Touch This.''
Here again was Madonna in the front row, in a black dress with chiffon sleeves and a rosary bead necklace, accompanied by Steven Meisel, a New York photographer, who wore his trademark floppy rabbit fur hat with ear flaps throughout the show. It was only about 90 degrees.
Her current boyfriend, Tony Ward, modeled in the show, and at one point presented her with a little Madonna doll in a Gaultier pin-striped suit slashed at the rib cage, like the one she wears in concert. For some reason, she undressed it immediately.
 
Jackets with a Twist
 For all the frisson generated by the audience, there was real excitement in the clothes, which were a departure from the Gaultier collections that broke clothes down to their underpinnings and always seemed to hint darkly at bondage. This collection was rosy and cheerful, a loving statement about the possibilities of dressing.
The models reflected the new softening. There was a distinguished elderly women with silver hair who wore a jeweled suit and embroidered stretch T-shirt with quiet dignity and a pregnant model who wore a pretty floral maternity dress. There was lots of see-through vinyl, rose-printed leggings and, as always, jackets with a twist - seams held together by knots of fabric or a pinstripe men's suit that was all one piece.
The French maintain that fashion was born in France (they don't give a date), so it is only natural that they should come to it more able to absorb its outrages, more attuned to its subtle messages. Indeed, here the real fashion show is often before and after the runway productions.
Last Tuesday a young avant-garde designer, Olivier Guillemin, held his show in the Musee de l'Homme, in the section devoted to the dawn of man. For this event, the men in the audience outfitted themselves in patent leather jeans, with patchwork print blouses and chiffon scarves tucked under their motorcycle jackets. The women wore, variously, black tights with shiny Beatle boots, striped velvet pants suits, or bright red 60's shifts with dangling pink plastic jewelry.
But the strangest scene was outside the fashion show of Mugler. His shows are always extraordinary theater, but when word got out that Diana Ross and other celebrities might appear as models, it became the hottest ticket in Paris.
A mob of chic elite waited hours in a drizzly rain to get in. At one point, a melee erupted as the diminutive designer Azzedine Alaia demanded entry from within the writhing maw of pressing bodies.
 
Steel Hot Pants (Scary)
 As he was admitted, the crowd surged against the metal barricades. A well-dressed woman fainted. She was carried in, her patent leather shoes dangling limply, just like in an old movie.
''That's how she's getting in,'' said someone in the crowd.
Once inside the long, narrow, sweltering room, the privileged 500 or so fanned themselves frantically with their programs as Ms. Ross shimmied and vamped along with all the other supermodels in what was a burlesque of a fashion show. Very few of the styles shown here - the chunky plastic red robot suits, the jeweled see-through body stockings, or the polished steel helmet, bra and hot pants (scary) - will ever be sold. Mr. Mugler designs and produces a separate collection of wearable clothes in friendly fabrics like wool and cotton that are sold in thousands of department stores around the world.
Nevertheless, the crowd loved it. There was Madonna again, in Pucci tights and faux-fur-trimmed parka, next to Mr. Meisel in his bunny hat. The temperature was at least 115 degrees, but he never took it off. Now that is fashion.

(Bill Cunningham for The New York Times) (pg. 18)

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE;
BUSH TERMED OPEN TO TAX RATE RISE ON UPPER INCOME

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20

 BODY:
In a break that could lead to a compromise in the budget negotiations, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has told lawmakers that President Bush could accept an increase in the tax rate for the wealthy to 31 percent from 28 percent now, staff assistants from both parties said today.
No specific word seeped out of the private tax negotiations that went on all day. But a variety of political advisers to senior lawmakers and tax experts who are familiar with the issues and the views of the participants said that Mr. Bush's concession on a rate increase brought the shape of a possible compromise into sharper focus. 
They said other aspects of the compromise would probably include a surtax on the very rich, a limit on the itemized deductions the wealthy could claim and a modest rise in the Federal gasoline tax. Is a Smaller Rise Acceptable? Mr. Bush had previously said he would reject any budget deal that provided for a top tax rate of 33 percent, a level that would be imposed under a budget bill passed by the House last Tuesday. But he had been less explicit as to whether a smaller increase would be acceptable. Over the last month, Mr. Bush has gone back and forth about how high a rate he would accept if taxes on capital gains were not cut, but this is the first time that one of his top advisers has told Congress explicitly what the President would take.
With President Bush's top policy advisers looking over their shoulders, Senators George J. Mitchell, Bob Dole and Lloyd Bentsen, Representative Dan Rostenkowski and a few other lawmakers huddled today trying to work out the final tax deals that are the most controversial aspects of a budget plan that is supposed to reduce the Federal deficit by $40 billion in the 1991 fiscal year and $500 billion over five years.
''It's suddenly starting to dawn on people that they're not too far apart, that this may not be so hard after all,'' said a staff assistant to one of the main negotiators.
 
Demands of Bush and Democrats
The main difficulty the negotiators face is to reconcile the political needs of the President, who insists that tax rates not be raised significantly, with the demands of Democrats that the wealthy bear the brunt of deficit reduction.
Last Tuesday, the House, voting along party lines, approved a Democratic bill that would raise taxes by $149 billion over the next five years, 68 percent of it from taxpayers with annual incomes above $100,000. The central part of this bill would increase the tax rate on the richest taxpayers to 33 percent from 28 percent.
On Friday, the Senate passed a bipartisan bill, supported by Mr. Bush, that would raise $146 billion, 42 percent of it from households with incomes above $100,000. Tax rates would not be increased under this measure, but the Federal gasoline tax would be raised to 18.5 cents from the current 9 cents.
The conference committee that is working on the differences in the two versions hopes to finish by Sunday night. The full House and Senate must pass the compromise and President Bush must sign it for it to become law.
Under a measure enacted Friday, the Government's authority to spend money will lapse at midnight Wednesday.
 
Elimination of 'Bubble'
Mr. Brady said Mr. Bush would agree to a top tax rate of 31 percent, so long as the ''bubble'' was eliminated from the tax code. The bubble is the anomaly in the current tax law that forces families with taxable income from about $80,000 to $200,000 to pay 33 percent on the portion of their income that falls in that range. No taxpayers now pay more than 28 percent of their total income in taxes.
One effect of such a change would be to raise the taxes of those with incomes of more than $200,000 a year and to lower the taxes somewhat of those with incomes of $80,000 to $200,000.
Another effect would be to permit an increase in the alternative minimum tax rate to 23.25 percent from 21 percent. This is paid by high-income people who have so many deductions that their rate falls below the minimum tax level. The rate of the alternative minimum tax is determined by taking 75 percent of the top rate.
These changes would not raise much money, perhaps as little as $3 billion over five years. But they would give Democrats the political benefit of having forced the President to go back on his pledge not to raise tax rates.
Moreover, other changes under consideration could actually push the top rate for the wealthy above 33 percent.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the Administration's budget director, met this morning with Senator Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, the top Republican on the Finance Committee, in Mr. Dole's office in the Capitol. Down the corridor, Senator Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, and Senator Bentsen of Texas, the Democratic chairman of the Finance Committee, were also plotting strategy.
Several times, Mr. Dole and Mr. Packwood, with stacks of paper under their arms, left Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu behind and walked down the hall to confer with Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Bentsen.
On one such trip, the two Republican Senators were hailed just outside the Senate chamber by Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska. He wanted to introduce them to his weekend companion, the actress Debra Winger. That may have been the only meeting today in public.
This afternoon Representative Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the Ways and Means Committee and dominates the House negotiators, walked over from his office across the street to meet in Mr. Mitchell's office.
The strong support of Mr. Rostenkowski and his House Democratic colleagues is essential to any compromise, since most Republicans in the House will probably vote against whatever the negotiators produce. The House Republican whip, Newt Gingrich of Georgia, said as much in a speech on the House floor today, maintaining that any new taxes would further damage the economy.
Although they had no direct word from the talks, experts following the negotiations from the outside sketched out a possible compromise that would raise $160 billion over five years, giving the lawmakers about $15 billion extra that they could use to reduce cuts in Medicare benefits or to pay for tax breaks that might be needed to win votes for the final package.
These are the elements that such a compromise might include:
Deduction Limit. The Senate bill would reduce itemized deductions by 5 percent of all adjusted gross income above $100,000. If the limit were raised to 10 percent, that would generate $56.5 billion over five years and would have the effect of making the tax rate of those affected as high as 34.1 percent.
This provision, probably acceptable to the Bush Administration, is opposed by lawmakers from high-tax states like New York and California. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said he feared that it would be the first step toward further limitations on deductions. But Mr. Moynihan is the only lawmaker from New York or California among the tax negotiators.
Surtax. The House bill would place a 10 percent surtax on incomes over $1 million. If the income level were lowered to $500,000, it would raise $11.7 billion over five years. The Administration opposes the surtax, but few in Congress have objected to it. It would mean, in effect, that the tax rate on the very rich would be as high as 44.1 percent.
Gasoline Tax. The Senate bill would more than double the gasoline tax, now 9 cents a gallon, to 18.5 cents. That steep a rise is unacceptable to House Democrats, who say it would put too much of a burden on the poor and middle class. But Mr. Rostenkowski has favored a higher gasoline tax in the past and might accept a 5-cent increase. That would raise $21 billion over five years.
Payroll Tax. The Senate bill would require state and local employees, who are entitled to Medicare benefits, to pay the Medicare payroll tax. Mr. Rostenkowski is adamantly opposed, apparently because of the effect on public employees in Chicago and Illinois. But if his objection can be overcome, it would generate $5.2 billion over five years.
Corporate Interest Deduction. The Senate bill would not allow companies to take a deduction for the interest they owe on back taxes. If the House accepts this provision, it would raise $4.1 billion over five years.
Gas Guzzlers. The House bill would double the Federal tax on cars with low gasoline mileage. This could raise $500 million over five years.
Many provisions of the House and Senate bills are identical or so similar that compromises should be easy to work out.
These include higher taxes on alcoholic beverages and tobacco products; a 10 percent luxury tax on expensive cars, boats, planes, jewelry and furs; an increase in the amount of annual wages subject to the Medicare payroll tax, and an increase in the tax credit for poor workers.

Mitchell, Senate majority leader; Lloyd Bentsen of Senate Finance Committee and Representative Dan Rostenkowski of House Ways and Means Committee. (Associated Press) (pg. 28)

LENGTH: 1458 words

HEADLINE: Leadership Is Changing at Board of Elections

BYLINE: By JAMES FERON

 BODY:
A LONG-STANDING impasse at the county's Board of Elections, where voting results have been delayed by what state investigators described as the two Commissioners' ''inability to properly function together as a team,'' appears to have been resolved.
The Republican Commissioner, Antonia R. D'Apice, has announced her retirement after more than 20 years of government service, effective Nov. 24. Her probable replacement is Carolee Sunderland, the vice chairwoman of the County Republican Committee and executive director of the County Republican Party.
Mrs. D'Apice's Democratic counterpart, Marion B. Oldi, may also be replaced before the end of the year, but not because Mrs. Oldi is seeking retirement. ''I want to finish out my 20 years,'' she said. ''Then I'll retire.'' The issue will be decided by the executive committee of the county Democratic Party, which heard Mrs. Oldi's plea for re-appointment Wednesday night. 
 
A Priority for Political Leaders
Whether she is replaced or re-appointed for a final two-year term, her successor will probably be Lloyd King Jr., the Democratic deputy commissioner at the Board of Elections since 1984. Mr. King, who has a law degree, worked for the Internal Revenue Service, the Office of Economic Opportunity and the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity before coming to the Board of Elections.
A change in the leadership of the Board of Elections had become a priority for county Republican and Democratic leaders since the apparent inability of the two Commissioners to work together became a factor in the board's operations and caught the attention of the state's Director of Election Operations, Thomas R. Wilkey.
Mr. Wilkey came to Westchester in February last year to review the election process following what he said was the ''hectic'' atmosphere in counting Westchester's 1988 general election results. He made 30 recommendations, but indicated that most of the board's problems could be ''solved by resolving the personal attitudes and indifference of its two Commissioners.''
A follow-up visit earlier this year revealed little or no improvement in the situation at election headquarters at 134 Court Street in White Plains. The reason, he said, was ''the two commissioners' inability to establish any form of communication with one another.'' He described assessing Westchester's election procedures as ''an exercise in futility.''
Mr. Wilkey met with members of the county Board of Legislator's Community Affairs and Housing Committee. Timothy S. Carey, the committee chairman, said, ''He told us the Westchester County Board of Elections was the worst in the state of New York.''
 
Meetings on Solving the Problem
That led to a meeting with County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, who suggested that the legislators meet with their party leaders to solve the problem of the Commissioners, adding that ''perhaps both should be let go.'' Election commissioners are selected by the parties; the Board of Legislators can approve or reject the candidates, but it cannot select them.
John E. Hand, the Republican chairman of the Board of Legislators, said earlier this year that the county's Republican leaders ''in particular'' should be ''doing more'' to solve the problem as Mr. O'Rourke and the majority of legislators were Republicans.
Mr. Wilkey had avoided comparing the work of the Commissioners, although he did point out that Commissioner Oldi, in a lengthy response to his critical report, sought to make changes or explain why they could not be made, while Commissioner D'Apice's reply, he said, was ''brief and inadequate'' as well as difficult to interpret.
Finally, the county's Republican and Democratic leaders, Anthony J. Colavita and Dennis Mehiel, met to seek a resolution of the problem. Last week, Mr. Mehiel recalled that ''Tony and I felt it was essential that somebody be replaced.'' Mrs. D'Apice said last week that she ''was not asked to leave.'' ''But once the thought of retirement had been created,'' she said, ''I thought, well, that's fantastic. I'll do a little traveling - I'm going to Italy for the first time in March, without having to think about village elections - and get involved in politics, perhaps helping a candidate who represents my feelings.''
The party leaders, at one point, had felt it would be unlikely for one Commissioner to remain while the other left. But that apparently is not the case now, with Mrs. D'Apice's retirement firmly fixed. Mr. Mehiel said it had ''given us a chance to reconsider Marion's situation.''
Mrs. Oldi has made it clear that she would like to stay ''to finish out my 20 years'' in government service ''in the job I'm in right now.'' She said she had ''two years and a couple of months to go'' for her pension. ''At that point I will graciously bow out with dignity,'' she added.
Mrs. Oldi said she would accept another county job or a state job, either of which would count toward her pension, ''but with the budget crunch in Albany the Governor's office has nothing.'' As for a county job, ''They're going to be laying off people,'' she said. ''In any case, a Republican-controlled county isn't going to create a job for a Democrat.''
 
A Vote After Election Day
Mrs. Oldi's fate, therefore, will be determined in large measure by the party's executive committee, of which she is a member. She presented her case before the committee at a regularly scheduled meeting Wednesday evening. Mr. Mehiel said they had agreed beforehand not to vote on the matter until after the Nov. 6 election.
All of this has been a bit awkward for Mr. King, Mrs. Oldi's apparently designated replacement, as they work together at the Board of Elections. Mr. Mehiel described Mr. King as ''eminently qualified and well liked in the party.'' Mr. King was recently named to a statewide technology task force to explore improvements in electronic voting machines and ballot counting.
Born and raised in Manhattan, Mr. King attended schools there, served in the Army, graduated from New York University with a bachelor's degree and from Brooklyn Law School in 1956. He said that in New York City he was a member of several political clubs.
''I worked in support of Hulan Jack,'' the former Manhattan Borough President and a friend of the family. ''My father was his best man,'' Mr. King said. ''He was very involved in politics, so it came naturally for me.''
 
From Law to the I.R.S.
Mr. King worked as a legal apprentice for a Manhattan law firm but did not pursue a career in the law, switching to the Internal Revenue Service where he became a supervisor of audit-enforcement procedures and the officer in charge of civil tax enforcement.
In 1967, after 11 years with the I.R.S., Mr. King joined the Office of Economic Opportunity as a fiscal manager. He determined the resolution of audits of 200 community-action agencies financed by the Federal office and prepared fiscal projections for an yearly budget exceeding $125 million.
He served briefly as Director of Urban Affairs for the International Council of Shopping Centers and then spent nine years with the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, becoming executive vice president and vice president of Westchester and Putnam affirmative action programs.
He lived for 17 years in Mount Vernon, where he was president of the local branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, before moving to Larchmont 18 years ago. Mr. King and his wife, Barbara, who were married in 1953, have two sons, Jeffery, 31, a construction inspector with an environmental engineering company, and Todd, 28, who works in marketing and sales for a telephone company in Albuquerque, N.M.
 
The Republicans' Choice
Carolee Sunderland, the Republican choice to replace Mrs. D'Apice, has been a Rye Town resident for 20 years, coming originally from Ossining. For the last 10 years, she has been an active member of the county Republican hierarchy. She started out volunteering, she said, ''and came on board at county Republican headquarters as a typist in 1980.''
''I worked closely with Margaret Soter,'' the former deputy county chairwoman, ''who taught me how to run the office,'' Mrs. Sunderland said. ''I do all the conventions, including the organization of the county delegation to New Orleans in 1988, when Bush was nominated.'' A major part of her work has been organizing the election petitions that she will soon be inspecting as an elections commissioner.
Mrs. Sunderland's husband, Kenneth, is a machine mechanic for Arnold Bakery in Greenwich, Conn. They have two sons, both students at Archbishop Stepinac High School in White Plains. Kenneth, 18, is a senior and Keith, 14, is a freshman.
