PUB-DATE: October 21, 1990

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1, Column 5; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2248 words

HEADLINE: S.& L. Crisis Hurting State's Economy

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
THE problems facing the nation's troubled savings and loan associations and the methods used by Federal regulators to solve them are undermining the state's economy in ways that will ultimately be felt by almost all New Jersey residents, experts say.
Banking officials, legislators, economists and construction industry representatives say the savings and loan bailout is resulting in tighter credit for all borrowers, substantial reductions in new construction and an increase in unemployment across the state.
Paradoxically, however, the slowdown in the building industry may increase values of existing homes to even higher levels than those seen in the middle to late 1980's.
To date, the Federal Government has ordered the takeover of 13 New Jersey savings and loan associations, including United Savings, FSB, of Paterson; the Elysian Federal Savings Bank of Hoboken and the City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bedminster. The largest takeover was that of City Federal, with 75 New Jersey branches. 
The effects of the bailout on the state's economy are compounded by the already sluggish real-estate market that has slashed property values, the impact of sales and income tax increases and the threat of a nationwide recession.
''We are seeing the beginning of an enormous credit crunch in real estate,'' said Dr. George Sternlieb, professor emeritus of city planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. ''The banks are in feeble condition, and their answer is, 'Don't lend on real estate.' And in this business, when the banks catch a cold, the man in the street sneezes.''
Dr. Sternlieb stressed that depositors' bank accounts were safe; under Federal regulations every account up to $100,000 is insured. But banks, he said, must be more than a safe haven for savings. ''They provide the lubricant that keeps the state's motor running,'' he said. ''And when that lubricant is missing, the motor grinds to a halt.''
The catalyst that sent the credit market into its current tailspin, Dr. Sternlieb said, was not so much the savings and loan crisis as the Government's response. As Congress realized the the threat posed by the failure of savings units across the country, he said, it passed legislation that would prevent the associations from repeating mistakes of the past.
 
No More Good-Will Loans
That legislation, the Financial Institutions Restructuring and Regulatory Enforcement Act of 1989, strictly limited the amount of money that savings and loan associations could lend to borrowers, Dr. Sternlieb said. Before that act, he said, savings and loan associations had been making loans secured by intangible collateral like good will or the anticipated value of a project or a business.
In addition, Dr. Sternlieb said, the savings and loan associations were lending out higher percentages of their available capital, and were maintaining lower reserves against bad debts, than state-chartered savings banks and commercial banks. The 1989 legislation increased the capital requirements and reserves against bad debts, putting the savings and loans on a more even footing with the other lenders.
In the rapidly rising real-estate market of the mid-1980's, those practices posed no major problem. But when real-estate values began to decline, much of the collateral on which savings and loan associations had based their loans evaporated. At the same time, developers, finding it difficult to sell their properties, began falling behind in their loan payments.
And that, said Patrick O'Keefe, executive vice president of the Plainsboro-based New Jersey Builders Association, began a decline in the construction industry that continues to this day.
''Historically, when we have gone into a recession, the reaction of the financial community was to cooperate with the builder, to rearrange financing and ride out the storm,'' Mr. O'Keefe said. ''But this time around, the financial institutions are much more skittish, and I think we are all paying the price.''
 
Other Lenders More Vigilant
The increased caution by lending institutions, Mr. O'Keefe said, has resulted in the withdrawal or reduction of lines of credit for many builders. ''And when the cash flow is cut off, that can leave an otherwise viable project dead in the water,'' he said.
Though the 1989 legislation applies primarily to Federally chartered savings and loan associations, even state-chartered savings banks and commercial banks have become more vigilant in their lending policies, particularly for real-estate development.
''The problems of the savings and loans have now infiltrated the commercial banks,'' said Lewis Fromkin, president of Samuel Fromkin Construction in Wall Township.
''You have a bunch of scared rabbits in the banking industry who are absolutely mortified to make a loan in the real-estate sector without 100 percent collateral,'' Mr. Fromkin said.
 
Borrowing in Singapore
Mr. Fromkin said his company had shrunk to two full-time employees from 12 in the last year. In addition, he said, he has not been able to obtain any financing for new projects from lending institutions in the area, including those that his company has been doing business with for years.
''They have flatly turned us down,'' Mr. Fromkin said. ''They tell us, 'We're not interested in New Jersey real estate.' ''
Mr. Fromkin said he was able to secure only three new loans in the last few months; his lending banks were in Denmark, Britain and Singapore. ''I just can't get money here in the state of New Jersey,'' he said. Edmund Lawlor, president of the New Jersey Savings League, in Cranford, a trade organization of 132 savings and loan associations, said current regulations had indeed limited the amount of money that can be lent to individual developers. But the main reason for decreased borrowing, he said, is decreased demand for loans, resulting from the depressed real-estate market. ''The major impediment is the market itself,'' Mr. Lawlor said. Kurt E. Schaub, a spokesman for the New Jersey Bankers Association, a Princeton-based trade organization of 123 commercial banks, also acknowledged that developers were finding it more difficult to obtain loans, but said that customers of commercial banks would not notice major changes in policy.
For the commercial lenders, Mr. Schaub said, ''It's business as usual.''
Commercial banks, Mr. Schaub said, have always operated under stricter lending guidelines than savings and loan associations.
Representatives of state-chartered savings banks say their lending practices are also unchanged.
''Our underwriting practices have always been more stringent, and therefore our lending policies have not changed,'' said Samuel Damiano, president of the New Jersey Council of Savings Institutions, a trade organization based in West Orange.
''All lenders were caught up in the economic downturn,'' Mr. Damiano said. ''But those who were more conservative experienced less of an effect.''
State banking officials acknowledge that New Jersey builders are experiencing serious problems obtaining financing.
 
'Changed the Rules Overnight'
''I'd say that we perceive it the same way they do,'' said the State Banking Commissioner, Geoffrey M. Connor. ''There certainly is a credit crunch in the home development business.''
Last June, he said, the State Department of Banking held a daylong hearing on the issue. Legislators, economists, state and Federal business experts and representatives of the banking and construction industries provided testimony.
One of the conclusions drawn from the hearing, Mr. Connor said, was that the new Federal savings and loan regulations were enacted without an adequate transition period. ''They changed the rules overnight,'' he said. One major change in effect limited the amount of money a savings and loan association could lend to one borrower.
Before the law, Mr. Connor said, a savings and loan association could lend an individual borrower up to 10 percent of the bank's total deposits or 100 percent of its net worth, whichever was greater. Under the new law, a savings and loan can lend an individual borrower as much as $500,000 or 15 percent of its tangible capital, whichever is greater.
As a result, some developers who had received promises of large loans under the old regulations saw that the amounts they could borrow were substantially reduced under the new ones.
''Many of the borrowers were cut off in midstream,'' Mr. Connor said.
 
Banks 'Don't Have the Capital'
When those borrowers began to look elsewhere for loans, Mr. Connor said, they found that new financing sources more difficult than ever to locate. The savings and loans, he said, ''basically stopped making construction loans.''
''What's happened since,'' he said, ''is that many of the commercial banks have also slowed down in making those loans as well.'' And that, some economists say, will have a direct effect on everyone. ''It's going to be far tougher to get a mortgage,'' said Dr. Paul Nadler, professor of finance at the Rutgers Graduate School of Finance in Newark. ''The banks simply don't have the capital.''
Home mortgage loans are likely to be more selective, Dr. Nadler said, and those loans are going to be based more and more on the earning power of the buyer rather than on the value of the collateral, he said.
 
Some Benefit to Homeowners
That, however, may result in an unexpected benefit to homeowners who have watched the value of their real estate dwindle over the last few years.
Under ordinary circumstances, construction experts say, tighter credit would result in a decline in property values. But ''in a perverse kind of way there will actually be a benefit from the credit crunch,'' said Mr. O'Keefe of the New Jersey Builders Association.
With construction money difficult to obtain, fewer new homes are being built. As a result, he said, there will be an increasing demand for existing housing, which will lead to increased prices.
''We may quickly be back to the days of high rates of appreciation,'' he said.
But some builders see that as a two-sided coin: high property values for sellers will simply mean higher costs for buyers.
''Sure, the demand is going to be there,'' Mr. Fromkin said. ''But if you're going to buy a house, you're going to end up with the same problem you had three years ago.''
 
Unemployment in Construction
Unemployment in the construction industry and associated trades is approaching a crisis, industry experts say.
Frank Spencer, president of the Carpenters Union Local 1578 in Camden County, testified at the June hearing that the effect of tight credit was ''devastating to the construction industry'' and that severe unemployment would result.
''I was right on target,'' Mr. Spencer said in a recent interview. ''We've probably got 175 guys out of work. And as construction workers get laid off, then all the businesses that are supported by the construction industry - lighting fixtures, carpet, ceramic tile - they all slow down too.''
That, he said, puts additional strain on social services and can cause serious financial problems for families facing long periods of unemployment.
''If workers are out of work for a long period of time, they start to lose their health benefits,'' Mr. Spencer said. ''Then you're just digging a deeper hole.''
But even those in the industry who have managed to find work for their employees are having a difficult time getting paid for their services.
''The banks created the situation we're in by lending money to people who shouldn't have gotten money,'' said Frank A. Speziali of Spease Inc., a Glassboro carpenter contractor who has built about 400 homes in the last seven years.
''The builders end up losing their projects back to the banks, and contractors like myself are out on the hook and suing people to get our money,'' Mr. Speziali said.
''A year ago I had 150 to 200 men working for me on a number of different projects,'' he said. ''Now I've got six carpenters working and hundreds of thousands of dollars out on the street. It's killing me.''
 
INSTITUTIONS TAKEN OVER
To date, Federal regulators have ordered the takeover of 13 New Jersey savings and loan associations, said Andrea M. Plater, spokeswoman for the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency responsible for managing the failed institutions.
Of those taken over, three have been sold, in whole or in part, to other banks in healthy financial condition. They are:
City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Bedminster.
Elysian Federal Savings Bank of Hoboken.
Metropolitan Federal Savings and Loan Association of Denville.
The following associations are currently under the management of the Resolution Trust Corporation:
City Savings Bank, FSB, Bedminster (which represents the 66 branches of the City Federal Savings and Loan Association that have not yet been sold).
Colonial Federal Savings Association of Roselle Park.
First Atlantic Federal Savings and Loan Association of Plainfield.
Mainstay Federal Savings, FSB, of Red Bank.
Mercer Savings Bank, SLA, of Trenton.
Mutual Aid Federal Savings and Loan Association of Manasquan.
Nassau Federal Savings and Loan Association of Princeton.
North Jersey Savings and Loan Association of Passaic.
United Savings, FSB, of Paterson.
United Savings and Loan Association of Trenton, N.J., FA.
Yorkwood Federal Savings and Loan Association of Maplewood.

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Start Converting Shoreham to Gas

BYLINE: By THOMAS A. TWOMEY Jr.Thomas Twomey Jr., a member of the Long Island Power Authority, headed the committee that recommended converting Shoreham to gas.

 BODY:
THE final debate over the fate of Shoreham is about to begin.
The Long Island Power Authority, created by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature, has released a report that concluded that converting Shoreham to a natural-gas plant is technically, economically and environmentally viable. The study determined that a conversion could provide an economical power supply for Long Island.
The analysis was favorably received by the trustees of the authority, many of whom have long opposed the operation of Shoreham as a nuclear plant. By a unanimous vote, the trustees authorized the hiring of a project manager and other technical experts to help decide whether or not to proceed with the conversion by the end of the year. 
Long Island officials, once divided over the fate of Shoreham, seem united in support of the conversion. Suffolk County Executive Patrick G. Halpin and Representatives George Hochbrueckner, Thomas J. Downey and Robert J. Mrazek all issued statements supporting the conversion.
Leaders of Long Island's business community, who in the past have been advocates of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station, have also expressed support for the conversion proposal.
So who is opposed to the idea? The Bush Administration is accelerating its efforts to reopen the Shoreham as a nuclear plant. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins recently urged the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission to deny the Long Island Lighting Company the right to transfer the plant to the Long Island Power Authority for decommissioning.
The Energy Department argues that Shoreham should operate a nuclear plant to reduce Long Island's dependence on oil imported from the Middle East.
But Lilco's oil doesn't come from the Arab nations. The vast majority of it comes from Venezuela. And by converting Shoreham to domestic and Canadian natural gas, we will reduce our dependence on oil even from South America, and we will do that with a clean, safe and abundant energy supply.
Natural gas does not deplete the ozone level, does not create acid rain, and adds very little to the greenhouse effect. It does not create a costly ash or radioactive-waste disposal problem. With natural gas, there is no decontamination problem at the end of the useful life of the plant, saving ratepayers millions of dollars. And our grandchildren will not be paying for the storage of nuclear waste created by the electricity we use today.
Best of all, there is an abundance of this clean fuel in America and Canada. Pipelines already exist, carrying natural gas to Connecticut from the Southwest.
The Federal Government seems about to approve an application by the Iroquois transmission system for a new pipeline from Canada down to Connecticut and then across Long Island Sound to Commack. It would connect Connecticut with the pipeline from the Southwest, thereby flooding Long Island with large quantities of natural gas never before available.
By using Shoreham as a natural gas plant, substantial savings to the ratepayer can be achieved. The non-nuclear Shoreham equipment, including transformers, switches, cooling systems and the turbine, can be harnessed in a conversion.
By using this equipment, a conversion to a 900-megawatt plant would cost approximately $550 million. To build a plant of the same size at a new site without using the existing Shoreham equipment would cost about $960 million. In addition to this 80 percent increase in cost, there would be the difficulty of finding a suitable site on Long Island for such a plant.
But even if a gas-fired plant is technically feasible and environmentally sound, does Long Island need one? Given its projected load growth and its current resource plan, Lilco expects to meet all of its obligations, including its reserve requirement, through the year 2005 without a converted Shoreham.
However, included in Lilco's plan are upstate sources of energy that would be more expensive than the electricity from a converted Shoreham.
By converting Shoreham, we would have available a cheaper energy source. And because the power would be generated on Long Island rather than imported through cables from upstate, it could prove to be more reliable. The conversion could be designed to permit Long Island to put into early retirement some of Lilco's current oil-fired plants, which use oil imported from Venezuela, thereby reducing the amount of imported oil consumed for electrical power.
The savings from a converted Shoreham would be increased by an aggressive energy-conservation program. The power authority estimates that Long Islanders can save 12 percent of their electrical consumption by installing energy-saving devices and better refrigerators, freezers, lighting fixtures, furnaces and hot-water heaters.
Utilities in other states have assisted in paying the cost of such new equipment, producing lower electricity bills for their customers while producing profits for their shareholders. Lilco's efforts to date have focused only on reducing peak load, rather than on reducing the annual use of electricity.
Once Lilco commences a true energy-conservation program, the power authority estimates, it will save about 500 megawatts annually by the year 2000. This is about the total projected output of Shoreham.
The combination of an effective energy-conservation program plus the conversion of Shoreham to natural gas would produce a cohesive energy plan critical for Long Island's economic well-being.
Before the planning for the conversion of Shoreham can commence in earnest, however, the Bush Administration must withdraw its opposition to Governor Cuomo's Settlement Agreement to close Shoreham. The contracts have been ''signed, sealed and delivered,'' so no matter how long the Administration obstructs the transaction, Shoreham will never be operated as a nuclear plant unless, of course, Congress declares war and directs the Federal Government to nationalize Shoreham with many others for our national defense.
Any attempt to reopen Shoreham would result in another decade of litigation, with no progress in developing a cohesive energy policy for Long Island. Meanwhile, the Administration, with its ultraclose ties to the nuclear industry, is costing Long Island about $8 million for each month they delay approving the transfer of the plant to the power authority.
Much of this is the cost of maintaining employment at Shoreham, which is no longer needed. That is about $100 million a year. That money could be better spent on a truly effective energy-conservation plan or even the Shoreham conversion. Instead, it is being wasted.
If Long Island commits itself to a strong and meaningful program of residential and commercial energy conservation and at the same time pursues the conversion of Shoreham, Long Island's energy future will soon be secure. There will be plenty of energy for healthy growth. We will be far less reliant on overseas sources of oil. Best of all we will have saved millions of dollars in energy bills for ourselves and our grandchildren.
After years of confusion and struggle over Shoreham, Long Island now has a rare opportunity to forge a cohesive energy policy. How tragic it would be if the opportunity were lost because of misguided and shortsighted Federal intervention.

HEADLINE: Budget Pinches Day-Care Assistance

BYLINE: By CAROLYN BATTISTA

 BODY:
AT the Norwich office of Infoline, the state's social-service information center, hardly a day goes by without an inquiry from a parent seeking to qualify for reimbursement for day-care costs for low- or moderate-income families. But the answer now is always no. The 16-year-old reimbursement program, which day-care advocates say helps keep working parents off welfare, is accepting no new clients as it struggles to stay within its budget in the state's new era of fiscal austerity.
''We get calls constantly from people who are struggling to pay for day care and make ends meet at the same time,'' said Mary Kraemer, the child-care coordinator at the Norwich Infoline office. ''Many people would qualify for the reimbursement program, but because of funding, the state cannot service any more people.'' 
Connecticut's Commissioner of Human Resources, Elliot A. Ginsberg, acknowledged the ''overwhelming need for the program.'' ''But we're not opening it up,'' he said. ''We have to stay within the budget.''
State Senator Kenneth L. Przybysz, Democrat of Uncasville, called the reimbursement program a success. But he noted Connecticut's ''very difficult financial times'' and the need for cost containment and budget cuts in many areas.
 
Pushing Families to Welfare
The program ''is the saving grace for single mothers who have job skills,'' said Gail Joslin, who coordinates family-life programs for the Connecticut Conference of the United Church of Christ. She noted that single mothers in jobs paying about $13,000 a year were hard pressed to pay day-care costs, which generally run from $70 to $130 a week for each child.
Daisy Martin, of Meriden, said she found the program closed to her. ''It puts me in a situation where I cannot afford the day care I would like,'' she said.
Mrs. Martin, a widow, is raising her 5-year-old grandson and must leave him with a friend while she works, she said. But the boy has problems, including seizures, she said, and she would like him in a day-care program with a trained staff. She noted that he is in a school program for only 10 hours a week.
Ms. Kraemer said that being denied the benefits of the reimbursement program could impel some single parents to go on welfare rather than going to work. ''That would be the natural thing to do,'' she said, if paying the full cost of child care took up most of a paycheck.
Since its inception in 1974, Purchase of Services, as the reimbursement program is officially known, has provided payments on a sliding scale and permitted clients to choose any form of day care approved by the state, from professionally staffed centers to relatives' homes. Over the years, the reimbursements have become larger and available to more families.
In 1985, the program served families with incomes up to 55 percent of the state median and provided up to $40 a week in reimbursement for the first child and smaller amounts for additional children. Now, families with incomes of up to 70 percent of the state median qualify; the maximum reimbursement is $75 a week for each child, and the average payment is $45 a week. In June 1989, the program served 4,843 families; by June 1990, it served 6,634 families.
 
Rolls Closed in May
Growth brought problems. In the 1989-90 fiscal year, the program overran its appropriation from the legislature and was given a $4.5 million deficiency appropriation.
For the 1990-91 fiscal year, the program has been given $19.7 million, including $1.5 million in Federal funds, but the Department of Human Resources announced in May that it would not accept any new clients because to do so could put it over budget again.
''We don't want to put people on and then be forced to make some other drastic move,'' Commissioner Elliot said. The department will continue to review its figures each month, he said, adding that he could not predict when it could accommodate new families. Turnover in the program is low, he said.
''This situation severely limits parents' choices, which puts a lot of stress on the family system at a time when the stresses are already escalating,'' said Nancy Scoyers, a spokeswoman for of the Connecticut Commission on Children. ''Where is our commitment to working families?''
Terri Cutler, who operates the Asylum Hill Family Development Center, in Hartford, said the department's action on the reimbursements could mean a loss of clients at day-care centers like her's. Parents may seek unlicensed care, she said, or resort to ''the day-care shuffle,'' taking children for place to place.
''I love the day care my son is in now, and he loves it,'' said Angela Berry, a single mother who lives in Hartford and works for the State Education Department. But she said that if she did not receive the state reimbursement, she probably would have to make other arrangements for her son's care.
''Some parents I know would have to stop working if they didn't have the program,'' Ms. Berry said.
 
'Tough Decisions'
Carol Mingo-Revill, child-care coordinator for Catholic Family Services, in Meriden, noted that the Connecticut Department of Income Maintenance provides child-care reimbursements to its clients for several months after they enter the work force. She said that the new limits on Purchase of Services might cause some people to go on welfare for a time, so they can qualify for child-care reimbursement when they return to work.
Officials said they were worried about future financing of the reimbursement program. It ''cannot grow without Federal dollars,'' Mr. Ginsberg said.
''These are some tough decisions for financially tough times,'' said Senator Przybysz, chairman of the legislature's Human Services Committee.
But advocates like Ms. Scoyers criticize cuts in spending on the program as a false economy.
''Some of these families are going to end up on welfare,'' she said. ''And that's going to cost more. This is a short-term investment to keep families working and a long-term investment in our children.''

HEADLINE: Raising the Standards for Appraisers

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Real Estate appraisers, under fire for their role in the savings and loan crisis and hurt by a housing recession that has spread from Montauk to Malibu, are facing tough new requirements for education, licensing and scrutiny of their work by state and Federal regulators.
An appraiser's charge has always been to exercise independent judgment about property value. That responsibility made them key watchdogs against excessive, unsustainable price escalation - and it has now put them at the center of the storm over what caused the boom-and-bust cycle that is buffeting down values.
At worst, critics say, the appraisal industry engaged in widespread fraud during the boom of the 1980's, ignoring professional standards, surrendering to pressure from lenders and sanctioning highly inflated real estate prices. At best, according to many analysts, too many appraisers were simply asleep on their watch. 
''An appraisal is supposed to reflect economic reality, and the assumptions that were made in the late 80's were unambiguously wrong,'' said David Shulman, director of real estate research at Salomon Brothers, the securities firm.
Even within the appraisal industry, executives acknowledge deep lapses. Although many appraisers are highly trained, they say a lack of uniform standards, combined with the rush atmosphere of the 80's, drew into the field many with little or no experience.
In many communities, the brokers selling houses were called upon by banks to appraise them, thereby collecting two commissions. In others, the credentials necessary to appraise a house seemed indistinguishable from those needed to lead a Boy Scout troop or a Welcome Wagon steering committee.
''We had barbers and cosmeticians appraising real estate,'' said David S. Bunton, executive vice president of the Appraisal Foundation, a group established in Washington by the nation's eight separate appraisal trade associations to write new standards for the industry and advise the Federal Government on new requirements. ''It was bound to lead to problems.''
The fallout is particularly severe in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where property values soared at the highest rate of appreciation in the nation during the 1980's, and have now fallen back. To whatever extent the blame lies with inflated appraisals, officials say it must be shared by banks and thrift institutions, which aggressively sought to expand their real estate loan portfolios, and often conveyed to the appraisers the values needed to make their deals.
''Appraisers told us that if they didn't tell banks what they wanted to hear, they wouldn't get any more assignments,'' said Lou Grossi, an examiner and appraisal industry specialist for the Connecticut Real Estate Commission.
''It was common practice,'' Mr. Bunton said. ''They called it 'hitting the numbers.' ''
Now, with much of the real estate industry reeling under the weight of foreclosures, sinking property values, failed savings and loans and deep loan losses at large commercial banks, the appraisal industry is poised for an overhaul.
Some of the changes have already been ordered by Congress, which has required all states to regulate real estate appraisal more stringently under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989, better known as the savings and loan bailout bill. The law requires all appraisers working for federally chartered or insured lending institutions after July 1, 1991, to be licensed or certified by their states. Even experienced appraisers will have to enroll in courses and pass examinations to conform to the law.
Other provisions, enacted over protests from banking lobbyists, require professional appraisals for all real estate transactions in which more than $50,000 changes hands. The banks, which have argued that the appraisals are not necessary for transactions under $100,000, maintain that the provision adds unnecessary costs, which will be passed through to consumers, in small transactions.
So far, 38 states - including New York and Connecticut, but not New Jersey - have conformed to the Federal rules setting up certification courses and examinations, or establishing state commissions to enforce the Federal mandate. Not everyone is satisfied with the initial results.
''We are very concerned that this will become a process of self-regulation and of special interests overwhelming the public interest,'' said Gail S. Shaffer, the New York Secretary of State, who opposed a law, signed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in September, that gives a framework for meeting the new Federal appraisal rules.
The New York State law will establish a nine-member board, with six of the members chosen from the appraisal industry, to create courses, examinations and licensing and certification standards. Mrs. Shaffer had advocated greater state control, and objected to making appraisers a majority of the board.
Connecticut ithat anticipated Federal scrutiny and have already adopted conforming rules. The requirements for training in Connecticut, which take effect for appraisers on Jan. 1, establish two levels of credentials. One is a state license for those appraising residential real estate financed by state-chartered lenders. The higher credential is a Federal certification for those dealing with federally chartered or insured lenders, or appraising large commercial properties.
Connecticut's appraisers will have to take 165 hours of course work and have two years' experience to obtain the Federal certificate.
The new rules are still being debated in New Jersey, where a bill in the state Senate calls for separate credentials for appraisers working with state chartered and federally chartered or insured lenders. To conform to the new Federal law, the state must adopt a detailed plan by the end of the year.
Perhaps the most important aspect of the new rules, many experts say, is that they should make appraisers more independent of pressure from lenders and more accountable for their work. In future cases of real estate foreclosures or failures by lending institutions, both state and Federal regulators will review the work of appraisers, and revoke the certification or license of those who have shown themselves inept.
For home buyers, the down side of the new regulations may be higher closing costs. In most home purchases, buyers pay the fees of appraisers, even though the appraisers are selected and given their instructions by lenders.
Bank executives have sharply opposed some of the new rules, saying they will create a temporary shortage of qualified appraisers who have completed the required course work. At many small lending institutions, lending officers have for decades assumed the role of appraisers, and enrolling them in licensing and certification courses will be an added cost, the lenders say.
''Whether it's a small rural bank that suddenly has to hire outside appraisers or a bigger institution that must have its employees pass exams, there will be a cost,'' said John C. Rasmus, senior counsel for the American Bankers Association.
Others maintain the costs will be insignificant, particularly compared to the huge price now being paid because of the inflated appraisals that contributed to the savings and loan crisis. Congressional investigators, after reviewing records of failed savings and loans, found that more than 8 in 10 had glaring errors in appraisals on their books.
''The appraisers did not cause the crisis, but the various schemes by savings and loan executives would never have worked unless appraisers stepped up to the plate,'' said Peter Barash, a Washington lobbyist who last year served as staff director for the House Commerce, Consumer and Monetary Affairs Committee, which investigated the savings and loan debacle.
Congressional testimony brought many examples to light. In one, a savings and loan in Los Angeles had a piece of undeveloped property to be subdivided for houses appraised at $3.5 million, but its appraiser's report intentionally did not mention that the land had been used as a toxic waste dump. A later appraisal put the value at $300,000.
Although no one knows how much of the thrift industry debacle would have been averted if appraisers had done a better job, Mr. Barash said studies have concluded that 20 to 25 percent of the cost of the public bailout would have been saved. The cost of the bailout is now projected at $300 billion to $500 billion.
Experts say the new requirements will force appraisers across the nation to proceed in a much more uniform way. Once training and certification programs are established in the states, uniform reporting requirements are to be established and required by the Appraisal Subcommittee, a group established by Congress with representatives of the Federal Reserve Bank, Comptroller of the Currency and other Federal agencies that oversee the banking system.
A result is likely to be much more standardized appraisal methods than those historically used. The most common in residential real estate is the ''comparable sales'' method in which appraisers examine recent selling prices of similar properties. Critics say many appraisal mistakes of the 80's were based on comparable sales analysis.
In many states where training and licensing requirements were lax or nonexistent, determining a comparable sale often meant little more than a phone call to a brokerage and an owner of a small business living in the neighborhood where a sales contract had been signed. More often, bank lending officers did the appraisal themselves. They relied on their knowledge of selling prices and assumed that values would rise quickly, thereby covering any mistakes that might be made in a slightly inflated appraisal report.
Other, more sophisticated appraisal methods are to be covered by the new law. One is the ''replacement value'' analysis, in which appraisers estimate land values, construction costs and other costs required to replace an existing building.
The other method, used to appraise commercial buildings, requires complex projections of rental income and vacancy rates, the amount of time rental property is likely to be vacant between tenants, and other variables.
Appraisal industry executives say the new Federal rules are not the only source of pressure for change. They maintain that banks and thrift institutions, which continue to pay the appraisers' commissions, have made a rapid about-face in their expectations of what appraisal reports will show and in their willingness to finance a deal in which an appraisal might be too high.
''There is definite pressure to keep values low,'' said Scruggs Love Jr., president of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, the nation's largest organization of appraisers who work on commercial real estate deals. Responding to the pressure on the industry, Mr. Love's organization is merging with the National Society of Real Estate Appraisers, the largest industry group that specializes in residential appraisals.
''Appraisers are used to pressure, but things may now have swung too far,'' Mr. Love said. In one example, he said, the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency established by Congress to dispose of real estate held in the portfolios of failed thrift institutions, has adopted a policy that may lead to imprudently low appraisals.
Under the policy, announced in Washington earlier this year, the agency will assign properties to regional asset managers who will seek appraisers through competitive bids. But the asset managers will receive a bonus if the properties are sold within a year, thereby putting pressure on them to discourage appraisals considered high enough to block quick sales.
''There is a strong interest in having appraisals set low,'' Mr. Love said. ''As an appraiser, I don't think this is satisfactory procedure.''
Bankers said they, too, were encouraging their appraisers to evaluate property conservatively.
Peter Brooks, senior vice president for corporate services at Chemical Bank in New York, said ''the message now is don't give us a Mercedes appraisal when the market calls for a Ford appraisal.''
Perhaps the biggest problem for appraisers is that making an appraisal today is more difficult that at any time in memory. One reason is that the number of sales has slowed dramatically in many regions, making it much harder to find comparable sales data. Another is that the value of property has declined and may continue to sink.
''For appraisers, double-digit inflation hides a multitude of sins,'' said Mr. Bunton of the Appraisal Foundation. ''But in a declining market, no one knows when we will hit bottom. It requires appraisers to also play the role of economists, and no one can be very comfortable with that.''
''The abuses of the 1980's have led to a broad effort to make more realistic appraisals,'' said Mr. Shulman of Salomon Brothers. ''The problem is knowing what values really are.''

HEADLINE: Perspectives: New York City Planning;
Shaping a Role in a Time of Transition

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
After six months as chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, Richard L. Schaffer is making his mark as a thoughtful and academically trained professional in a position that in the past has gone to an experienced operator in city affairs.
His temperament and professional background no less than the development climate itself seem to herald a loftier, but perhaps less involved, role for the commission he heads in the development affairs of the city.
The contrast to such predecessors as Sylvia Deutsch, Herbert Sturz, John Zuccotti and Donald H. Elliott is notable. All were close to the mayors they served and heavily involved not only in shaping but also in advancing the zoning and land-use proposals they supported through the institutions of government.
They were activists. But they were operating in environments where development activity was either strong or deemed worthy of stimulation by public action. In contrast, after a burst of approvals of major long-term projects by the Board of Estimate before it was dissolved last summer, development activity and private applications for land-use changes have subsided. 
It may be time, many are saying, for long-term planning. The term is inherently vague. It could lead to a broad restudy of zoning. But it is being emphasized at a time when the City Council can be expected to move independently to reshape or undercut site-specific plans during a review procedure.
This is a period of institutional readjustment, wrought by the revised City Charter. The City Council has replaced the Board of Estimate as final decision-maker on all major land-use decisions, and, as it may turn out, minor ones as well. It is not clear how actively the office of Mayor David N. Dinkins will lobby in the Council for approval of Planning Commission decisions, or how successful it would be if it did.
In an interview, Mr. Schaffer stressed the process side of the planning function rather than substantive goals that have made some planners, in eras of urban growth of the past, play the role of civic visionary. The Planning Commission chairman is also the director of the Department of City Planning, guiding the work of a large professional force.
''Planning should be a process for managing urban change in which you balance efficiency, equity and citizen participation,'' said Mr. Schaffer, who has taught urban planning at Columbia University and the New School for Social Research. Efficiency refers to the physical conditions necessary for economic functioning. Equity refers to the relative distribution of benefits and burdens. And citizen participation, the open involvement of the public in influencing decisions, must be ''meaningful,'' he said.
Mr. Schaffer was not one of Mayor Dinkins's earlier appointments. He took office only in April, and basically supported the major, often controversial, proposals that other agencies or the Mayor's office managed to shepherd through the Board of Estimate.
He sees planning largely as an attempt to balance values and build a consensus. With development activity down, the opportunity to do this on private land-use applications is minimal. The 13-member Planning Commission has mainly been involved in exhaustively reviewing applications by the Department of Social Services for lease renewals at numerous day-care centers around the city.
Another major activity has been the preparation of a Charter-mandated document stating the criteria for choosing sites for city facilities. It will be issued in November and followed a month later by a mayoral ''statement of needs,'' in which all the facilities anticipated over the next two years are to be specified.
These Charter-mandated tasks were imposed at a time when the city's choice of sites for new transient housing for the homeless was a divisive public issue. But the statement mentions no specific type of facility, and is instead a generalized and bland statement, more notable for what it does not say than for what it does.
What it does not say is that facilities should be classified merely as beneficial or burdensome to their host communities, and that each community should have a balance of each. Instead, it distinguishes between neighborhood and regional facilities (libraries and fire houses on the one hand, for example, and garbage transfer stations and shelters for the homeless on the other) and suggests that where feasible the regional facilities should be well-dispersed.to be applied as a guide for siting choices over the next two years. A mayoral ''statement of needs'' listing these facilities is due in December.
Mr. Schaffer chairs a Planning Commission on which there is no shortage of members with a planning background. Eugenie L. Birch is director of the graduate program in urban planning at Hunter College. Victor G. Alicea holds a doctorate in urban planning. Maxine Griffith heads a planning and design firm. Amanda M. Burden directed the development of design guidelines for Battery Park City. And Ron Shiffman, who has been a force in planning and housing affairs since 1963, heads the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development.
Planners are talkers. There has been much talk over seemingly not overwhelming issues at Planning Commission hearings since the summer, according to observers, as commissioners struggle to put minor planning decisions in a suitable planning framework.
They could find none, it seems, to justify the application of Clorinda Romano, an infirm widow living at 162 East 83d Street, for a curb cut to allow her to install a driveway and use a first-floor storage area in her town house as a garage. A similar privilege had been granted previously to a neighbor. After a year of effort by her architect, 75 blueprints and a positive recommendation by the Planning Department, the commission rejected the application 7 to 2. Mr. Schaffer was in the minority.
And it was only after exhaustive discussion that the commission consented to allow a Brooklyn developer, Stephen B. Jacobs, a rezoning of a 100- by 150-foot plot for a building on Fourth Avenue that conformed to a more far-ranging zoning plan that the department's planners intend to put forth. There was hesitation about getting out ahead of the rezoning itself.
But Mr. Schaffer is sanguine about the thoroughness of the deliberations. ''Many of our commissioners believe that planning is a combination of physical, social and economic analysis,'' he said.
Once the commission acts positively, however, the applicant still faces the possibility of an adverse outcome in the City Council. Lawyers who represent major applicants planning projects already report that they are trying to involve members of the City Council's Land Use Committee, and especially its subcommittee on zoning, planning and landmarks, at an early stage of plan preparation. Undoubtedly it is too soon to judge how the City Council and the Planning Commission will interact, but applicants and their counsel plainly feel that getting projects through will require even more preliminary consultation than it has heretofore.
On the first test of the new Borough President's appeal procedure - the ''triple no'' - the City Council has shown itself prepared to overturn a land-use decision made unanimously by the Planning Commission if a Borough President protests.
In this case, a College Point, Queens, developer, Philip Schorr, was seeking a small street demapping to permit the construction of six two-family houses. The ''triple no'' refers to Borough President Claire Shulman's appeal to the Council after she and Community Board 7 in Queens had previously voted against the application, before the commission approved it. The Council voted it down last week, providing no written record of the reason. Mayor Dinkins had five days to veto the Council's action, but he let it stand.
The episode provided no reason to expect the Planning Commission or the Mayor's office to take a forceful role before the Council in backing land-use decisions in ''routine,'' if locally controversial, matters.
''It should not be expected that the City Council will agree with us in every case,'' said Mr. Schaffer. ''They didn't here. But we are at the beginning of a new process, and it's a new role for the City Council too.''
The full test of New York City's new land-use review system lies ahead.

HEADLINE: Q and A

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:

Inheriting a Co-op
 
Question: If a co-op owner leaves the apartment in a will to an adult son or daughter, is the co-op board obliged to approve the new owner because of the family relationship? . . . Charles Bannett, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. According to Stuart Saft, a vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, most co-ops do not allow the transfer of shares and the assignment of a proprietary lease without board approval, even to the children of shareholders.
In considering approval, Mr. Saft said the board would be looking primarily for evidence that the person who has inherited the apartment would be able to handle the maintenance and mortgage payments. 
 
Buyer Beware
 
Question: With a friend, I recently bought a weekend home about 100 miles north of the city. Next to our property is a parcel owned by a group called the Ancram Landowners Association that we were told functions ''occasionally'' as a picnic site. But on our second weekend were were awakened by the sound of gunfire. The association, it seems, uses the property as a rifle range.
The shooting continued all day. We believe this information was withheld from us by both the realtor and the owner. Do we have any recourse? . . . Jan Michael Hanvik, Manhattan.
 
Answer: Maybe. According to Brook Boyd, a lawyer specializing in real estate matters, most sales contracts include a clause saying the seller makes no representations other than those in the contract. But this clause, he said, would not prevent a purchaser from getting a judgment for fraud.
''The broker,'' said Mr. Boyd, ''may be liable for fraudulent misrepresentations. And the seller may also be liable, since a broker ususally acts as the seller's agent.''
If, however, the open space was also used as a picnic area, the broker and seller may be liable only if the broker knew that the property was also used as a shooting range and it would have been difficult for the buyer to discover this on his own. He advised buyers to investigate not only the property they intend to buy, but also adjoining properties.
 
Convertible Mortgage
 
Question: I have a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage with a convertible feature. The convertible rate is based on the required net yield for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages, covered by 60-day mandatory delivery commitments.
My mortgage bank can give me the 60-day figure on the first day of each month on the telephone, and some newspapers publish figures for the 30-day mandatory delivery commitment.
I want to know if it is reasonable for me to monitor the 30-day rate in the newspaper as an indicator of which direction the the 60-day rate may go? . . . Mark Teteris, Manhattan
 
Answer: Maybe. According to Arthur Saitta, an assistant vice president at the East River Savings Bank, for the past six month there has been a correllation between the two rates - a difference of .05 percent - but this is not always the case.
''Any time there is an adjustable-rate loan,'' said Mr. Saitta, ''the bank is required to disclose the performance of these indicators on a set day and month. The 30-day rate will be lower, but the margin is not always as consistient as it has been lately.''
He suggests you contact the Federal National Mortgage Association - known as Fannie Mae - for this information.

HEADLINE: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;
Danbury Mall Spreading Retail Ripples

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
A shoppers' bonanza generated by the Danbury Fair Mall on the outskirts of Danbury is expanding, fed by a stream of seemingly recession-proof customers - some 10 million a year.
Most drive in on Route 84, a six-lane state highway that connects with major routes from New York, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Rhode Island and other parts of Connecticut.
In March, construction began on 200,000 square feet to be added to the 1.3 million-square-foot mall, which opened in 1986 and is the largest in the state. The new space, scheduled for completion next March, includes an 85,000-square-foot Lord & Taylor department store, a 50,000-square-foot building with 20 shops and a 1,500-car garage. Financing for the $38 million project was arranged by Aetna Life Insurance Company's Realty Investors unit. 
In addition, one of mall's four anchor stores, G. Fox, a unit of the chain based in Hartford, is adding 40,000 square feet.
The May Company of St. Louis, which owns 14 department store chains, acquired the Lord & Taylor stores in 1986, including one in the Westfarms Mall in Farmington and another in Stamford.
''We are in a $3.6 billion expansion project,'' said Jim Abrams, May's vice president for communications, ''expecting to open 90 new stores among the various chains through 1994, most of them located in malls.''
John Kraus, president of the management division of the Wilmorite Corporation of Rochester, which built the Danbury mall, said the site -just off exit 3 of Route 84 and once the home of the Great Danbury Fair - had been ''coveted by every developer in the country.''
''There was nothing serving that whole area out toward Brewster, N.Y., and Interstate 684,'' Mr. Kraus said.
Wilmorite, which has developed 20 malls, mainly in the Northeast, is also building the additions.
Along an eight-mile stretch east of the mall, from exit 3 to exit 8, a host of retail establishments sell a range of goods and services, including cars, furniture, clothing, electronics, food and travel packages. Mall stores tend to be more expensive and include Laura Ashley, Lenox China, Ann Taylor and Godiva Chocolates. They have attracted customers who in turn created a market for more moderately priced merchandise. Less expensive and discount stores are nearby, as are dozens of sit-down and fast-food restaurants, supermarkets, movie theaters and bowling alleys.
The growth in retail activity has sent commercial rents to $25 a square foot from $12 in the last two years, said Michael Ryer, president of Ryer Associates, a local realty firm. ''And there are few vacancies,'' he said. Rents at the mall range from $45 to $65 a square foot.
The mall generates about $400 million in annual sales and $1.8 million in tax revenues for Danbury. ''The payroll of 2,000 employees is being recycled back into the local economy,'' said Clarice Osiecki, director of the Danbury Chamber of Commerce.
The mall manager, Patricia Frisaro, said its 225 shops and 20 restaurants are 98 percent leased, and business is brisk at the four anchor department stores, G. Fox, Macy's, J. C. Penney and Sears. Surface parking for 6,000 cars is spread over the 108-acre tract.
Separated from the mall by lawns and a large duck pond is a 196,000-square-foot shopping center called Danbury Square. Developed by Zoldan Equities of White Plains, the 20-acre complex opened in 1989 with almost all of its 30 shops preleased at around $25 a square foot. Loehmann's, Innovation Luggage, Toys R Us and Herman's World of Sporting Goods are among them.
''I think retail opportunities have been ignored,'' said Alex Zoldan, the president of Zoldan Equities, ''and we will be seeing a lot more fill-in projects like ours, with stores that benefit from being near a mall but can't afford mall rents.''
A Jordan Marsh department store that closed on Federal Road in July is to be converted into a complex of furniture, home improvement and other specialty stores called Danbury Place. ''We will complement the mall,'' which is about three miles to the west, said Alexius Conroy, president of the Conroy Development Company of White Plains, the new owner.
Mr. Conroy said he was attracted to the site by Stew Leonard's, which sells dairy products, meat and produce in a huge tent for around 20 percent less than most retailers. ''Their presence makes this a destination location off exit 6 or 7,'' Mr. Conroy said.
Work is expected to begin on the 21-acre site next July, with completion by the summer of 1992. The project is expected to contain a maximum of 300,000 square feet, either through enlarging the present 170,000-square-foot building or demolishing it and rebuilding.
''We will accommodate tenants ranging in size from 2,000 to 100,000 square feet,'' Mr. Conroy said.
Stew Leonard's is building a 205,000-square-foot store on 42 acres behind the tent. Plans for the store, which is scheduled to open next August, call forlife-sized animated cows and singing milk cartons, live musicians and a petting zoo.
An older retail complex off exit 8 of the highway contains four contiguous shopping centers called Berkshire, Nutmeg Plaza, Plumtrees Plaza and Route 6 Plaza, where rents are $11 to $15 a square foot. Tenants include Service Merchandise, Bradlee's, Marshall's, Waldenbooks and Radio Shack.
''We started with 125,000 square feet in 1981,'' said Ervie Hawley, the developer. ''Now we have 650,000 square feet.''
But the success of the mall and nearby shopping centers has often been at the expense of merchants in nearby communities.
James O. Rogers, president of the Connecticut Retail Merchants Association in Hartford, noted that in larger cities, malls have ''separated shopping from other forms of commerce, because of a perception that downtown is unsafe, and parking is extremely inconvenient.''
''Now, even small towns are losing business to the malls,'' Mr. Rogers said.
Increasing vacancies on Main Street in Ridgefield and other communities in the Greater Danbury area have persuaded local merchants to band together to study options for keeping customers.
''We didn't want the Danbury mall to be there,'' said the president of the Ridgefield Chamber of Commerce, Pat Freeman, ''but it's a fact of life and we are going to have to deal with it.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Lord & Taylor, right rear, near Macy's, a part of mall expansion. (Jim Estrin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Upper Madison Avenue;
Three Modest Projects for the 'Best Street in the City'

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Contrary to the growing quiet in real estate development, upper Madison Avenue may actually undergo a kind of building boomlet in coming months, with three projects approved for construction from 64th to 72d Street.
While each is modestly scaled, they might have a significant cumulative effect on that portion of the avenue within the Upper East Side Historic District, whose skyline has remained relatively unchanged in recent years even as storefronts changed constantly.
From south to north, the first project is 720 Madison, an eight-story office and retail building, with 18,000 square feet of space, near the southwest corner of 64th Street. It is being designed by Beyer Blinder Belle, of Manhattan, and developed by Joel Seiden of Kushner/Seiden Properties, also of Manhattan. The project won approval from the Landmarks Preservation Commission in January. The site is now vacant. 
Mr. Seiden said he was negotiating with ''several multi-national retail tenants'' and may get a single user for the whole building. ''The building will provide a world-class home in the best retail location,'' he said, ''and we are excited about its development.''
The next project is Madison House, a 16-story apartment building on the northwest corner of 65th Street. It is being developed by David F. Frankel, of Manhattan, to designs by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, also of Manhattan. The project, on a site now occupied by a two-story taxpayer, was approved by the landmarks panel last month.
The third project, also designed by Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer, is 888 Madison Avenue, a four-story commercial building with 20,000 square feet of space above grade, on the southwest corner of 72d Street. It is being developed by Lawrence and Melvin Friedland of Manhattan. The landmarks commission approved it in April. A two-story taxpayer will be expanded and reclad in the process.
Lawrence Friedland said the construction job had been put out to bid. ''We hope to be getting our numbers back in the next month or two and commence immediately thereafter,'' he said. ''We are at present speaking to some very high-end users that are contemplating leasing the entire building. We hope to find the proper single tenant.''
''I think Madison Avenue - so far - has been very recession proof,'' he said. ''Upper Madison Avenue is probably the best street in the city - that and 57th Street.''
By Mr. Friedland's estimate, the brothers' portfolio includes a dozen buildings in the East 60's and 70's. ''We are probably the largest owners on Madison Avenue of retail space,'' he said. Besides No. 888, where seven shops were vacated for the rebuilding project, their only other vacant store on Madison is No. 744.
Retail rents on Madison Avenue, from 61st to 72d Street, range from $175 to $325 a square foot, according to figures published by the Real Estate Board of New York. Only Fifth Avenue, from 51st to 59th Street, commands a higher price - $250 to $500.
''Rents on the street are very high,'' said C. Bradley Mendelson, managing director of Edward S. Gordon. ''They are not high in comparison to the Ginza in Tokyo or 57th and Fifth, but they are high in the general context of New York City.
''The typical retailer wants 2,500 to 4,000 square feet and wants to enjoy - quote - the European shopping experience. People who go there don't go with the expectation of a large retail return at the sales level. They go for the advertising and public relations prestige.''
What about the ''mom-and-pop'' stores that also have contributed so much to the character of Madison Avenue?
''It's not a cheerful subject - I've had the worst month ever,'' said Jane Stubbs, proprietor of Stubbs Books and Prints, at 835 Madison Avenue, between 69th and 70th Streets, which specializes in architecture, with sidelines like social history, food and wine and English books from the 1930's.
''Things are slow in general,'' said Anna Christensen, owner of Chocolate Soup at No. 946, between 74th and 75th Streets. ''Everybody seems to be feeling that.'' Her 23-year-old store, which has been on Madison Avenue since 1980, specializes in children's clothing, accessories and toys. ''There are hardly any stores like mine left on Madison,'' she said. ''Most of the stores now are European. It's starting to look like Rodeo Drive.''
Among the chic European boutiques are several ''For Rent'' signs. Fourteen storefronts between 61st and 72d Streets, not counting 888 Madison, are currently vacant. Perhaps only one in three of these spaces is actually available for immediate lease, Mr. Mendelson said, with others already spoken for or tied up in larger deals involving the whole building. Yet the psychological effect can be discouraging.
''It's the principal shopping street in America,'' Ms. Stubbs said, ''and to have these vacancies is quite grim.'' Or as Mr. Mendelson described 888 Madison in its current condition: ''For the lay person on the street, it looks like a depression.''
''The stores that are empty eventually get filled,'' said Halina Rosenthal, president of the Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts, a preservation group that keeps a close watch on the area. ''The problem is that the rents are totally out of sight. What do you have to sell in order to make that? How many handbags? In the long run, the only people who can afford it are people who are using it as a showcase. They don't count on the store to make money. All they need is the presence on Madison. The smaller shops that have to sell - I don't see how they can make it.''
With varying levels of enthusiasm, the preservation group supported all three of the new Madison Avenue developments.
Perhaps the greatest enthusiasm was expressed for 888 Madison, whose facade is divided into limestone and terra-cotta bays. The landmarks panel said the building would be ''richly articulated in the tradition of late 19th- and early 20th-century buildings, expressed in a modern vocabulary of materials and design,'' that it would be ''in keeping with the scale and massing of other buildings in the streetscape'' and ''sensitive to its prominent corner site.''
Although zoning rules would have permitted an apartment building two and a half times larger than the commercial development, the landmarks commission would probably have taken a very dim view of a tower at that corner. Also, Mr. Friedland said, a big residential development was not what he and his brother had in mind. ''We were really not looking to make a great deal of money,'' he said. ''We were just interested in doing a nice project. We never wanted a larger building. That's not our thing.''
Asked why 720 Madison Avenue was kept small, John H. Beyer, the architect, said: ''We decided on eight stories because of the design context. A 12- or 15-story building would have been terrible. There is no way Landmarks would have approved it.''
Also, he said, the size of the elevator and mechanical core needed for a taller building would have been impractically large, given the small size of the building lot.
The first Madison House proposal called for a 22-story tower and the razing of two adjacent brownstones. Preservationists were adamantly opposed. The architect, Hugh Hardy, returned with a second proposal, for a 15-story building that would not require demolition of the brownstones. The project went through a third change, to improve the marketability of the apartment layouts.
One project that preservationists wanted nothing to do with was an 11-story building proposed for the southeast corner of 67th Street by the developer Burton Handelsman and the architect Thomas diCarlo.
In denying the application last month, the landmarks commission criticized the building's scale and the way in which three row houses on the site, dating from 1871, were incorporated into the new structure.

HEADLINE: Minority Firm Joins Davis, Brody Architects

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
One of the most prominent minority-owned architectural practices in New York, Bond Ryder & Associates, was absorbed last week by the much larger firm of Davis, Brody & Associates.
Although the 21-year-old Bond Ryder office had managed thus far in the recession to stay busy, its melding with Davis, Brody was partially a hedge against the lean and bruisingly competitive times faced by the profession, particularly small firms.
As part of the change, J. Max Bond Jr. has become a partner at Davis, Brody. Nine of his 12 colleagues moved with him from mid-Manhattan to join some 100 architects in the Davis, Brody offices at Hudson and Spring Streets. The firm, founded in 1952, is best known for big residential projects in Manhattan - Zeckendorf Towers at Union Square, Waterside on the East River and Riverbend Houses in Harlem, for example - as well as academic, commercial and institutional buildings. 
A founding partner of Bond Ryder, Mr. Bond is also dean of the School of Architecture and Environmental Studies at the City College of New York and a past member of the City Planning Commission.
The other founding partner, Donald P. Ryder, is retiring. It was his decision to do so that prompted Mr. Bond to restructure the practice.
Among Bond Ryder's better known works are the Martin Luther King Center for Social Change, in Atlanta, which includes Dr. King's tomb; the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, on Lenox Avenue, between 135th and 136th Streets; the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, near Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard and the Towers on the Park apartments on Frederick Douglass Circle, at the northwest corner of Central Park.
''That is a firm with a tremendous history,'' said David Castro-Blanco, of Castro-Blanco Piscioneri & Associates of Manhattan, who recently headed the minority resources committee of the American Institute of Architects.
''Bond Ryder created a climate of good work and an aura of success, which is so much needed in the minority community,'' he said. ''So in that sense, it's a loss. But it comes with a gain. It enhances the opportunities for Bond Ryder to do work that they would otherwise have been excluded from and, from a professional point of view, that is terrific.''
''We view it as very positive,'' Mr. Bond said in an interview conducted among packing crates and mailing tubes during the last hours in his old office at 244 West 49th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.
''This would make a firm that is far more representative of the diversity in the New York community,'' Mr. Bond said. ''There are very few black partners in really good firms. I hope this would represent another kind of opportunity for black and minority architects.''
''I don't think, personally, that there will be any loss of identity,'' he said. ''It will really increase the resources we can provide to the clients we've traditionally served.''
Both Mr. Bond and Lewis Davis, a partner in Davis, Brody, said their firms share a broad philosophy.
''We always felt that architects had a social responsibility,'' Mr. Davis said, ''that it wasn't enough to do a little gem, that we had to do more. Each firm was interested in housing from the outset.''
Mr. Bond got together this past summer with Mr. Davis, a longtime friend and associate, who recalled their breakfast this way:
''Max looked a little solemn. He said: 'Don Ryder has decided to retire. For me to be dean and run the office is going to be impossible. I have several options. I could disband the firm completely and be an academic or I could work with somebody.' I looked at him and said, 'Why don't you join us?' It was a spontaneous reaction.''

LENGTH: 971 words

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Of Belts and Bags and Baby Seats

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
My daughter picked up her first new car last Wednesday. Her name is Jonalyn, and she and I spent a lot of time in the dealer's lot trying to figure out how well the mechanized seat belts would work with the child-safety seat.
She is the same age that I was when I bought my first new car, but there are differences. There were no serious baby seats in 1962, and my car was a harvest gold Corvair Monza because I was hot for a sporty coupe. Jonni is interested in safety and practicality and her car is an alabaster Ford Escort station wagon. 
Safeness is the trend today, whether in general well-being or as it relates to risk and automobiles, and Jonalyn is at one with her generation. But buyers - and legislators - of any age have become more concerned with safety at the wheel. As an example, 36 states and the District of Columbia now have laws requiring seat-belt use, and all 50 states require safety seats for infants.
As it turned out, the manual lap belt in Jonni's new Ford worked just fine. The motorized shoulder belt that had worried us just went buzz-zoom and swooped up and over the child seat. In fact, my 3-month-old grandbaby was probably the safest person in the car, riding backward and strapped in tight enough to trap a gurgle.
The Escort is a neat little car, a clone of the Mazda Protege, and I was pleased when my daughter and son-in-law sought my approval of their purchase. But, like a lot of automobiles these days, Ford's Escort does have those infuriating motorized belts that trundle across the top of the door to provide shoulder protection.
They meet 1991's Federal edict on passive safety, but they are less than safe because they don't complete the job of buckling up.
A lap belt is crucial for protection in a crash, and the Sturm und Drang of all that motorized buzziness lulls an occupant into forgetting that the lap belt still must be latched by hand. In addition, the robot belts are annoying, startling the unwary, prone to choke you, and intent on knocking things out of your hands.
They are, however, the main form of compliance with the passive-restraint law, at least until air bags become universal. Happily, that is happening, and most of the early critics, this one included, are now convinced that the balloons work, inflating and deflating in a fraction of a second to protect drivers from serious harm in frontal collisions.
Chrysler claims to be the world leader in air-bag production, and all of its American-made cars now have a bag in the hub of the steering wheel. General Motors will triple the number of its cars with driver-side bags during the 1991 model year, and the corporation says that its entire fleet will have them by the fall of 1995. Ford, too, will have them in all of its cars by the mid-90's, and driver-side bags now are standard on nine of the company's lines.
Foreign makers also offer air bags in many of their cars, and Mercedes-Benz was the first of the world's manufacturers to make them standard, adding them to a couple of 1985 models. The following year, the company made them standard across the line. Generally, the bags, known as supplemental restraint systems or S.R.S., are installed only on the driver's side, but more and more passenger bags are being offered as standard or optional equipment.
Detroit has had its share of brickbats when it comes to safety, but it was Cadillac that first attempted to sell air bags, making them available as an option in 1974. The experiment was a dismal failure and it proved what the auto makers thought they had known all along: In those days, and earlier, safety just didn't sell.
Ford had learned the lesson the hard way back in 1956, when it added such features as ''deep-dish'' steering wheels, seat belts, padded dashboards and safety door latches. The company mounted a Lifeguard Design ad campaign - and lost a vast number of sales to Chevrolet, no matter that the ads featured a cuddly ''safety bear'' who pointed out the sensibility of the new devices.
There may have been other elements that hurt the company's marketing performance, but Ford quickly ended the campaign, while keeping the improvements. In Detroit, at the time, the saying was that ''Ford sells safety but Chevrolet sells cars.''
All of that has changed, and new-car dealers now say safety ranks with quality in the top considerations of their customers. In fact, a survey by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety shows that 68 percent of buyers rate safety as the most important criteria in making their choice.
Next to air bags and three-point seat belts, antilock brakes are perhaps the most important new technology, but better handling, all-wheel drive and improved vehicle structures also contribute to making automobiles safer than ever. Unfortunately, though, even the best technology can't defeat the laws of physics, and the size of a car is still a major factor in its safety. All things being equal, the larger the car the safer the people inside.
According to the insurance institute, the problem with small cars isn't confined to crashes with larger vehicles, although it is true that the occupants of the smaller cars fare worse. But even in single-vehicle accidents, the death rate for occupants of small cars is more than double the rate for larger cars.
Figures from the insurance institute also show that claims for crash damages are much higher for small cars than for large ones, and all of that can be particularly dismaying as soaring gas prices spur ever lighter and tinier automobiles.
Economy is important, of course, and compromises must be made. My daughter's Ford Escort is one of those small cars that we are talking about, and one can only hope it doesn't get bent in any serious way. After all, the grandbaby is my first. His name, by the way, is Henry Marshall.
