HEADLINE: Rupert Murdoch's Biggest Gamble

BYLINE: By Roger Cohen; Roger Cohen is a media reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch, who lives in New York but rides planes the way most New Yorkers ride the subway, has been in London for less than 48 hours. That's long enough to size up the situation at his five national newspapers, part of a $6.7 billion media empire that sprawls across three continents. A sharp advertising recession, the worst in two decades, is biting. He has summoned his two top British aides, Andrew Knight and August Fischer, and is telling them money is being wasted because presses are not being used efficiently, that his tabloid newspaper, The Sun, is not as good as it was, and that there are too many pages in the flagship Sunday Times.
''We have to get The Sunday Times down-paged,'' he says in his lazy Australian drawl. ''There is too much. This serialized novel - nobody reads that. The paper must be very firmly down-paged.''
The dapper Knight, who recently gave up the editorship of The Daily Telegraph to become executive chairman of News International, Murdoch's British subsidiary, assures his boss that he has pressed for a smaller paper. But the staff has been stalling. And, besides, Andrew Neil, editor of The Sunday Times, has been out of town. 
''Too damn bad; too damn bad,'' Murdoch retorts, his voice becoming loud and derisive, his body stiffening from its customary slouch. ''I can tell you how to get eight pages out of that paper in half an hour. I bet I can do it better than they can. Those extra pages are costing us money.'' However annoying, the eight pages are a mere trifle compared with some of the other pressures on Murdoch's finances these days. Sky Television, his nascent four-channel satellite service in Britain, has cost about $540 million since its inception in February 1989. After a heady period of expansion, News Corporation, Murdoch's international media conglomerate, has seen its debt rise from less than $1 billion in 1985 to about $8.7 billion today, or roughly half the foreign debt of Colombia.
This burden is taking its toll. On Aug. 23, News Corporation announced that its profits for the year ended June 30 plunged 46 percent, to $216 million, from the record $403 million earned in fiscal 1989. For a company that had achieved 34 percent annual growth in earnings per share over the previous eight years, this is a striking reversal. In the nervous market of the last three months, News Corporation's stock price has plummeted to about $11 from $19.
Thirty-seven years after he inherited two modest papers from his father in Adelaide, Australia, Murdoch appears to have entered the most intricate phase of his career. He is within sight of an extraordinary goal - ''the creation of the world's first global television, publishing and entertainment operation,'' as Glen Renfrew, managing director of Reuters, puts it.
News Corporation owns 10 magazines, seven television stations, the Fox television network and movie studio, two newspapers, and a book publishing house in the United States. In Britain, Murdoch has five national newspapers, eight magazines and the Sky TV venture. In Australia, he owns Ansett Airlines (the nation's largest domestic carrier), nine magazines and more than 100 newspapers accounting for nearly 60 percent of the country's press circulation. Yet Murdoch is stretched thinner than he's ever been, at a time when the world economy is jittery and heavily indebted companies, the fad of the 80's, have gone right out of fashion. ''For the game he's in,'' says Andrew Tuckey, a managing director of London's Baring Brothers, a merchant bank, ''Murdoch needs a long pocket and nerves of steel.''
While grappling with current difficulties, Murdoch still has his eye on the future - the industry's and his own. He is easing News Corporation away from newspapers, which he believes are in long-term decline, and toward electronic media. Newspapers still represent the single largest source of the company's revenues, but television and filmed entertainment are catching up fast.
At the same time, Murdoch, who will turn 60 next year, is trying to delegate authority, and to put more structure into a company that has always taken pride in its creative disorganization. He has, if only tentatively, chosen a successor - Andrew Knight. And he is preparing his wife and his children for major responsibilities.
None of this comes easily. Seated, before his trip to London, in his office at his Fox television and movie studios in Los Angeles, he says: ''I like to be where we're doing new things. If the head man in a company is not working 12 hours a day, doing things, taking risks, but also standing with his people in the trenches at the most difficult of times, then the company loses something. But we've become pretty spread out around the world. You can't be everywhere.''
He cites an example. When the Fox Broadcasting Company's television stations were bidding to become America's fourth network in 1986, Murdoch was simultaneously fighting Britain's labor unions as he moved his press operations eastward from Fleet Street to Wapping and introduced new printing technology. In the end, he won the battle of Wapping. The British labor movement was emasculated. Production costs plunged; a host of new newspapers appeared.
''But I should have been spending more time with the Fox start-up,'' Murdoch insists. ''It's no secret that I thought we should have been doing better earlier. But it's coming good now. One of the great things about television is'' - his voice, often no more than a murmur, suddenly surges - ''you must not look back. Bury your mistakes.''
Slouched on a sofa, in a plain gray suit, Murdoch looks an unlikely figure amid the gaudy chic of Hollywood. In a town of loud ties and sharp Italian suits, his preference is for solid British tailoring. There is no pretension about his language, either, which is down-to-earth Aussie. In the Murdoch world, what's bad is ''bloody awful''; what's good is ''a knockout.'' Although his tone is generally moderate, there is an occasional brusqueness to his manner, that speak of a man quickly dismissive of fools. ''That fellow could not lead a flock of homing pigeons'' is a favorite phrase. Colin Chapman, a former deputy editor of The Australian, used to play doubles tennis at Murdoch's Australian farm, Cavan. ''I would serve two double faults,'' he recalls, ''and he would turn around to me and glower.''
It was this glowering reputation that led to his frequent portrayal as a marauding media mogul - a 1977 Time magazine cover put his head on the body of King Kong striding over the rooftops of Manhattan. But he appears to have quieted down. Indeed, since he burst on the American scene in 1976 with his acquisition of New York magazine and The New York Post, he has become more private. The battles with New York newspaper unions, the public clashes with Clay Felker, former editor of New York magazine, and the political fallout from his close association with Edward Koch, the former Mayor of New York, are all in the past; and Murdoch says he tries now to spend more time with his family. ''He has not fulfilled the horror scenarios,'' said David Schneiderman, president of The Village Voice and its editor when Murdoch owned the paper. ''He is more accepted here now.''
Those scenarios were tied to Murdoch's reputation as the king of the sleazy tabloid, the man who bought Britain's ailing Sun newspaper in 1969 and, with a constant diet of bare breasts and scandal, turned it into the country's best-selling daily. It was The Sun that, during the 1982 Falklands War, trumpeted ''GOTCHA!'' across its front page after a British submarine sank an Argentine cruiser with the loss of 368 lives; and it was Sun-style journalism that prompted a recent Government report warning the press to restrain its invasion of people's privacy or face the creation of a tough regulatory body. In the United States, he created The Star, a crass supermarket publication to rival The National Enquirer, and took The New York Post down-market.
But there are signs of a shift. Murdoch has sold The Post and The Star; and in Britain, he recently appointed Simon Jenkins, a widely respected journalist, as editor of The Times. The move has been heralded as a commitment to restoring the understated authority of the paper, which many saw being undermined by a shrill commercialism over the last decade. At the same time, the quality of the news channel on Sky Television has earned respect. ''He is maneuvering his empire back toward central ground,'' says Peter Preston, editor of The Guardian, a liberal daily. ''He now gets very angry when one of his tabloids goes over the top.''
Murdoch, it seems, is looking for balance, both in his editorial tone and in his business. Think of him as an inspired juggler, inventing tricks that the world had not imagined possible. Among the balls he now keeps in the air: Sky's pioneering attempt to diversify British television; the fledgling Fox television stations now growing rapidly on the back of ''The Simpsons''; a new international book business, based in New York, called HarperCollins; a quickly assembled stable of American publications ranging from Mirabella to New York magazine to Automobile; the 20th Century Fox movie studio; British papers that cover the full spectrum, from the up-market Times to the vulgar News of the World, and his Australian press holdings.
The balls are moving with increasing speed, ever more fantastic in their parabolas, across a world that technology is making smaller. In the last six years alone, News Corporation's revenue has more than tripled from $1.8 billion to $6.7 billion - a performance that makes other major communications companies look like slouches. And Murdoch drives the mighty machine: two days in Los Angeles, three in London, one in Budapest, an occasional foray to his native Australia, where his company is incorporated, and then back to New York, which he now calls home.
It's a grinding schedule, in pursuit of . . . what? Not the trappings of power, it would appear. Friends say Murdoch shuns ostentation: driving up to the Istanbul Hilton recently in a limousine provided by Turkish officials, he turned to his wife, Anna, and said, ''I hope the kids don't see us in this car.'' Nor does wealth seem to be the point, although Murdoch is a very wealthy man indeed. ''Hell, no,'' Murdoch says. ''Money is not the motivating force. It's nice to have money, but I don't live high. What I enjoy is running the business.''
 
The business is very big news corporation, which had revenues of less than $1 billion at the beginning of the 1980's, is now the world's second largest communications concern after Time Warner. No other company of its kind is so geared to bringing a package of news, entertainment and advertising to the global village.
Murdoch's share of News Corporation is 43 percent, making the company takeover-proof. But this insurance comes at a steep price. It is largely because Murdoch has always preferred to finance his acquisitions by borrowing, rather than dilute his holding in the company, that News's debt has risen so sharply.
''The desire to retain family control has significantly affected the company,'' says Lord Rees-Mogg, a former editor of The Times. ''If some of the debt were converted into equity, it would be very positive.''
Murdoch bridles at the suggestion that he should have sold some of his stock to raise money. ''Oh sure, sure, they always say that - too much debt, too little equity financing,'' he says. ''But the fact is that if our family had let our stake down to 20 percent, there would have been a bunch of investment managers who would have risen up and fired me when I started Fox Broadcasting in 1986 and again when I got into Sky in 1988. If you don't have a major, major shareholding, you can't take the same risks.''
But News Corporation's debt load, $2.4 billion of it short-term borrowing due within a year, is now too onerous even for Murdoch's taste. Over the last year, he has sold assets for nearly $1 billion. He vows that he will not buy anything major in the foreseeable future. Moreover, he concedes for the first time that ''it is arguable we may have paid $500 million too much'' for TV Guide, which he bought for $2.8 billion in 1988, adding heavily to News's debt. (The magazine's circulation has slipped slightly since it was bought.) ''My guess is that if News had $3 billion less debt and no TV Guide,'' says one banker, ''the stock would be a lot higher.''
Because of Murdoch's proven record as a businessman able to build the value of his assets, banks remain generally confident in him. Nevertheless, in a sign of some skittishness in financial markets, News Corporation's attempt last year to set up a new financing vehicle - a partnership managed by Murdoch - collapsed when the money for it could not be raised. Some minor banks have sought to call in their loans to the company.
Moreover, Australian accounting rules allow the company to present its situation in a rosier light. At the end of the 1989-90 fiscal year, for example, the company revalued its mastheads and television licenses by $2.2 billion. In effect, the company decided that what it owned was now worth more and wrote that into its books.
Murdoch himself seems to have few illusions about such accounting devices. He acknowledges his problems and vows he will grow out of them. He believes that by 1992, the company can make what he calls ''the big leap,'' bringing News to profit levels considerably above the record $403 million made in 1989. This, he argues, will be based on the success of his two big start-up projects of recent years - the Fox TV network and Sky TV in Britain. Despite persistent rumors, he insists no major asset sales are planned.
''I think we have seen the bottom,'' says Carla Tammenoms Bakker, a media analyst at Morgan Stanley who recently completed an extensive study of News Corporation, adding, however, that ''Murdoch has a terrible cash squeeze.'' Andrew Tuckey of Baring Brothers says: ''The market view is that Murdoch is not in great shape, but he will get through it.''
Up to now, Murdoch has certainly seemed comfortable with big financial risks. Like the Japanese, he is prepared to take the long view. The Australian, the country's first national daily, which he started in Canberra in 1964, lost money for years before it became a financial success. Fox was a laughingstock - and a money pit - for more than two years.
''He thinks in time spans that nobody else does in his field,'' says Lord George Weidenfeld, the British publisher. Barry Diller, chairman of Fox, adds: ''Murdoch is O.K. with risk. I've seen others - before you're able to prove it out, your money will be gone.''
The flip side of this long-term view is an impatience with convention that allows him to place big bets on change. An outsider even in Australia (he became an American citizen in 1985), Murdoch shuns the establishments of Hollywood, New York and even London, operating with a cultural detachment that gives him the freedom to tackle pioneering projects on a vast scale. Barry Wright, director of one of the companies installing Sky's satellite dishes, recalls that when, earlier this year, he asked Murdoch what market share he was aiming for, the reply was: ''We don't deal in market share. We create the market.''
On an industrial estate near Heathrow Airport outside London sits a rather tacky set of buildings, painted in bold green, yellow, red and blue. They look as if they have been put together in a hurry - and they were. The makeshift structures house Murdoch's four-channel Sky Television venture. What goes on here will be crucial to the success or failure of his peripatetic juggling act.
Sky is an enormous gamble, even for Murdoch. It consists of four new channels - Sky One (entertainment), Sky News (the only competition in Europe to Cable News Network), Sky Movies and Eurosport, which carries sporting events from all over the world. Murdoch has already invested more than half a billion dollars in Sky, certain that he can change the viewing habits of the British. Murdoch thinks that they are sick of the duopoly that has dominated British television - the state-owned BBC and independent ITV, each with two channels - and that, like Americans, they will pay for choice. Right now, he is losing more than $3 million a week on the venture.
The gamble is bigger because he is not alone. Closer to central London stands the Marcopolo Building, whose towering arched windows and atrium recall one of New York's monuments to corporate power. This is the headquarters of Sky's archrival and would-be nemesis, British Satellite Broadcasting, or BSB, which began its five-channel service in April, just over a year after Sky.
Backed principally by leading communications companies, including Pearson PLC (the publishers of The Financial Times), Reed International, Granada and Chargeur of France, BSB has a staggering $2.4 billion in capital - making it the largest consortium in Britain after the Channel Tunnel project. And it plans to use that money to blast Murdoch out of the sky.
The rivalry is intense, the stakes enormous. Each company is gambling that it can emerge the winner in what would be the biggest revolution in British consumer electronics since the introduction of the videocassette recorder. ''There are two of them and there should only be one,'' says Steven Rattner, head of the media department at Lazard Freres in New York. ''Sky and BSB are going to have a long, bloody slugging match.''
Anthony Simonds-Gooding, the flamboyant chief executive of BSB -his yellow socks clash dramatically with his dark blue Jaguar - says the company has done sweeps in its offices against Sky bugging devices. Sky, already on the air last year, dismissed BSB in an ad campaign as ''hot air''; BSB came back with a campaign portraying Murdoch as a sinister Citizen Kane. BSB is planning to spend $550 million on marketing alone over the next three years.
From the Sky buildings, programs for the four new channels are transmitted to a so-called teleport in the London docklands area. This consists of two enormous dishes that transmit (or ''uplink'') the programs to a satellite called Astra, hovering over the equator. Astra, owned by a consortium of Luxembourg companies, carries 16 transponders, or channels, 4 of them leased by Murdoch. Like a huge, magnifying mirror, it increases the power of the signals and beams them back to the small white Sky dishes now appearing on British homes.
BSB, meanwhile, owns two entire satellites, with a signal eight times as powerful as Sky's. Like Sky, it has movie, sports and entertainment channels, but no news channel. Instead it has rock music (''Power Station'') and a catch-all channel called ''NOW'' carrying everything from gardening shows to American business reports.
''Look, Murdoch's done newspapers; now he's excited about TV,'' says Simonds-Gooding, his tie emblazoned with a couple of Gauguin's Tahitian nudes. ''His attitude is: Who will not bow to me? But Sky is American-Australian, and people here are quite conservative. If they had to watch American TV, they'd be appalled.'' Murdoch counters: ''They are saying they are like the BBC, and people are saying, 'Jolly good for you, but we can get that already for nothing!' ''
Simonds-Gooding notes that the major shareholders of BSB have a combined capitalization five times greater than News Corporation's. ''This is the big game or no game,'' he says. ''It's like drilling for North Sea oil. Money goes out. Murdoch will have to carry the heat.''
But for how long? On the best estimate, which is Murdoch's own, Sky will not break even until somewhere between the end of 1991 and mid-1992. Carla Tammenoms Bakker of Morgan Stanley believes this will not happen until 1993. As for BSB, which has been plagued by technical problems and twice delayed its debut, Simonds-Gooding hopes it can stop losing money by 1993, and, after paying off its debts, be in the black by 1995. All analysts agree that if one service reaches break-even, the other's problems will mount.
For Murdoch, Sky is a deeply personal battle. Ever since he entered publishing in Britain, with his acquisition of The News of the World Sunday newspaper in 1968, he has been disgusted by what he sees as Britain's rigid class structure. He had observed it as a student at Oxford University 15 years earlier, and he still has little time for the British Establishment - a moneyed elite that he believes has hindered social mobility and promoted anticommercial attitudes.
''When I came to Britain in 1968, I found it was damn hard to get a day's work out of the people at the top of the social scale,'' he says. ''As an Australian, I only had to work 8 or 10 hours a day, 48 weeks of the year, and everything came to you, you could not fail. Your peers were in the Bahamas, or on weekends in Paris - very intelligent people, cleverer than I, but they were like guardians of the family heirlooms.''
Nowhere has Murdoch observed this elitism more than in television. He has criticized the endless dramatic programs dominated by ''strangulated English accents,'' played out in ''rigid, class-structured settings'' and marked by ''constant sneering at the new Britain'' of Margaret Thatcher.
The elitist attitude Murdoch questions is epitomized by George Walden, a Conservative member of Parliament, who describes American television as ''umpteen channels and nothing to watch.'' Sky, which uses much American programming, is a gamble that Walden is wrong.
One of Sky's converts is Alan Jayes, a wholesale meat worker who lives in a modest, state-subsidized house on Katherine Griffiths Court in central London. Virtually every home on the street - about a dozen of them - now has the Sky dish. ''I got mine about three months ago, and I was the first,'' Jayes says. ''But everyone always copies each other here.''
Jayes is renting the Sky service for about $45 a month, after responding to an advertisement in The Sun. He is very happy. Pointing to the American wrestling matches beaming in on Eurosport, he says: ''You get programs from America that are out of this world. My mum-in-law loves the wrestling.''
Jayes now prefers Sky to the BBC or ITV, and has told his five brothers and two sisters about the service. All of them have taken it. So too have some builders who were in his house a few days earlier, saw Sky, and signed up immediately. Asked about BSB, Jayes says: ''Never heard of it.''
It is clear that Sky has a head start. After a disastrous beginning, which left people mystified by the new equipment in electronics stores, Murdoch decided to sell the service door to door, with a rental package that includes free installation.
The new approach has been a dramatic success. Since September 1989, Sky has been installing about 50,000 dishes a month in British homes. More than 960,000 homes now have their own dishes, with 660,000 more taking the service through cable or large dishes placed on apartment buildings. About 980,000 customers are paying a supplementary fee of $18 a month for the movie channel. Sky officials say the service needs to be in at least two million homes, with two thirds of them paying for the movie channel, to be viable. The channels seem popular. An independent survey conducted in the summer found that Sky had 26.1 percent of viewers, ahead of BBC 1's 20.8 percent and BSB's 9.9 percent.
BSB, by contrast, still appears to be languishing. According to the company, its dishes, sold through retail stores for about $650, rather than rented, have been installed in about 90,000 homes. BSB says it can break even when it is in 3 million homes, if 2.4 million are paying for movies. But Bronwen Maddox, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities in London, predicted in a recently published report that the consortium could lose $670 million this year alone.
Still, it is early in the fight, and BSB has enormous resources. Frank Barlow, managing director of Pearson, a BSB investor, says: ''Our partners are much less highly geared than News Corporation, and this is going to be a costly battle.'' Referring to Murdoch's British media holdings, he adds pointedly: ''I don't think anybody should be allowed five newspapers and four TV channels.''
This was the thrust of a vigorous, but unsuccessful, BSB campaign in Parliament last year aimed at forcing Murdoch to reduce his 100 percent holding in Sky. Current legislation allows newspaper proprietors a maximum stake of 20 percent in a British television franchise. But Murdoch has managed to circumvent this restriction by beaming his programs off a Luxembourg satellite. His action has angered the opposition Labor Party, which already hates Murdoch for his success in breaking the unions at Wapping.
''If Labor gets in,'' says Simonds-Gooding with some relish, ''they will hang Mr. Murdoch by his thumbs within days.''
Murdoch's massive investment in Sky reflects far-reaching changes throughout News Corporation. Last year, broadcasting and filmed entertainment accounted for 28 percent of the company's revenue; that figure will rise to an estimated 31 percent in 1991. While Murdoch's greatest passion remains newspapers, he is convinced that a gradual and inexorable shift away from print and toward electronic media is under way. ''The television screen in the home,'' he predicts, ''is going to be a bigger and bigger factor in all of our lives.''
With Fox and Sky and TV Guide, Murdoch has tried to position News Corporation for this shift. He knows it is coming, even if he does not know exactly what form it will take. Newspapers will not die overnight, he stresses. But in the United States, especially, the trend is downward; and advertising, he believes, will increasingly go elsewhere.
Convinced of the need to adapt, this year he created a new post of executive vice president for development, and gave it to John B. Evans, in charge of classified advertising at The Village Voice when Murdoch bought it in 1977 (Murdoch sold The Voice, which he never liked, in 1985). ''I am not a logical person; I think of myself as an artist,'' says Evans, who is British, by way of introduction. Murdoch calls him ''our lateral thinker.''
Evans envisions a world in which high-definition televisions will allow you to flood your house with a Mozart recording superior in quality to any compact disk; play chess with a friend at the other side of the world; order up your fishing show (which has already led you to drop your fishing magazine), and read the Yellow Pages, the news, a glossy magazine, or even your favorite novel. He is talking to telephone and even utility companies about the possibility of bringing movies or information down their cables to television sets. And he's overseeing News's participation in a project that could bring 108 television channels into American homes from a satellite. ''Look,'' he says, ''26 million American homes have Nintendo. These kids are not technophobic.''
Murdoch's own view is that the place to be in preparing for the future is the United States, which he now sees as the core of News's activities. In 1984, the company earned 27 percent of its revenue in the United States; today that figure has reached 56 percent.
''The future is all over the world, but this is the cutting edge,'' says Murdoch. ''Look, the whole world wants to modernize, and when you look to what they mean by modernizing, they mean Americanize. Would a modern Greek prefer to live in Orange County than Piraeus? Yes. Absolutely.'' This is an unconventional view. But then, News Corporation is a very unconventional company. Extremely lean (there are just 60 people in what is effectively the main office, in midtown Manhattan), virtually devoid of memos, and galvanized by Murdoch, it is, says Evans, ''an emotionally driven and bonded company, where executives don't spend time guarding territories, because nobody has one nailed down.'' He recalls once asking Murdoch if he should report to him or to Martin Singerman, the president of News America Publishing. The reply: ''Consider yourself in orbit around Singerman.''
Murdoch does not like ''yes'' men. In his executives, he says he looks for ''people ready and willing to fight their cause against me.'' At the same time, while allowing his executives free rein, Murdoch can clearly be very hands-on. He says, for example, that he himself made the crucial decision to switch ''The Simpsons'' from Sunday to Thursday for this season, where it now goes up against ''The Cosby Show'' - thus far, with a striking lack of success.
Every week, executives throughout News Corporation receive the Murdoch ''Flash'' - a brief summary of the operating results of the company's various units, showing the budget's target figures, actual figures and the previous year's figures for the current week and the year to date. This is core around which the company's flexibility is built. Says David Schneiderman, president of The Village Voice and its editor under Murdoch: ''You might get one call from Murdoch asking how come paper costs are so much higher than budgeted. He gives you one call a year and it keeps you on your toes for the next 365 days.''
Singerman, who has been with News since the company began its American expansion in 1974, says Murdoch works constantly at avoiding bureaucracy. ''If we're considering a new magazine,'' he says, '' 'Show me an editor.' He's not interested in market surveys.''
This gut-driven approach is pervasive. Rafael Pastor, installed last March as an executive vice president overseeing international development, says: ''Murdoch will say one or two words. You have to make the connections.'' There is, he continues, an ''almost intoxicating sense of latitude'' at the company; his own mission was defined simply as that of taking the company into areas where it is not. Already, this has led to the acquistion of two dailies in Hungary, the possible creation of a Berlin-based daily to be marketed in what used to be East Germany, and talks aimed at bringing a new TV station to Poland. ''The message is, put a lot of things together, and we will stumble onto something,'' says Pastor. Life, in other words, is too unpredictable for grand designs.
Still, one thing is predictable. As he prepares to turn 60 in March, Murdoch is confronting his own mortality. An old friend, the British publisher Paul Hamlyn, says that because Murdoch's father died young of a heart attack, ''Rupert always thought he might die young, so everything has to be done fast.'' Now he is trying to insure that his hectic accumulation of assets will be in safe hands, even without him. Already this year, Murdoch has increased the number of annual board meetings from one to four. Moreover, he has installed his wife, Anna, a novelist, as a board member. ''It's time for a little discipline,'' he says. ''I am nearly 60 and she is 13 years younger than me. And, if something happened to me, it would be a few years before any of the children who would be likely to want to come in would be ready for it. I guess it's a defensive thing to have a member of the family on the board.'' Murdoch has three children by Anna - Elisabeth, 22; Lachlan, 19, and James, 17. His eldest child, Prudence, by his first marriage, is not interested in executive responsibility at News.
At the same time, Murdoch is speaking openly about his successor: Andrew Knight. ''I don't intend to go under a bus tomorrow,'' Murdoch says, ''but if I did, probably Andrew Knight would become the chief executive. He is the most rounded, the most international, with the most journalist-based skills.''
Knight, now 50 and a former editor of The Economist and The Daily Telegraph, has been with News less than a year, but he has a reputation for toughness and shrewdness - he turned The Telegraph from a loss-maker to a major money-spinner. One person familiar with the company and close to Murdoch says: ''What he is doing is creating an insurance system. He wants to be able to sleep easily at night. But he believes he will go on for years, and one day, one of his children will take over.''
But what will his children find? It is possible to paint a very bleak scenario for News: a continuing worldwide advertising slump; higher interest rates, particularly in the United States, where News has most of its debt; a sudden success for BSB combined with problems for Sky; a Labor Party victory in Britain and an ensuing campaign against his cross-media holdings; an Australian recession; regulatory problems for Fox in its bid to be effectively a network while continuing to syndicate its own shows.
On the other hand, the outlines of a genuine global communications network are coming into focus. Fox has moved firmly into the black this year, and other American television executives are talking enviously of its young viewership, which is the most attractive to advertisers. Meanwhile, Sky is showing signs of life. Already, Murdoch can take a hit show like ''The Simpsons'' from Fox TV, put it in book form through HarperCollins, in movie form through 20th Century Fox, pass it along to Sky TV in Britain, and serialize it in newspapers and magazines throughout the world.
With the notable exception of The New York Post, and his 1983 purchase of the ''Hitler Diaries,'' which turned out to be fake, most of Murdoch's shots have been on target. The businesses he has acquired or started have grown enormously in value. For example, he bought The Village Voice and New York magazine for $17 million in 1977. In 1985, he sold The Voice for $55 million, and New York is now worth at least $200 million. As a result of such coups, News Corporation has a breakup value of more than $20 billion - useful insurance, especially with his annual interest payments running at $800 million.
But if the television operations really come good, Murdoch's juggling act could become less frenetic, less alarming to behold. News Corporation, with its properties in every medium all over the world, would then stand prepared - perhaps more than its cautious competitors - for the Golden Age of Information that Murdoch sees looming in the 21st century.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Flying Blind: An Unexpected Change of Airline

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
The airline name you see on your ticket may not mean you will be flying on a plane of that line, sometimes because of a practice the airline industry calls ''code sharing.'' Code sharing does not signify much to the average traveler. But like people with hotel reservations who are ''walked,'' or sent elsewhere because of overbooking, passengers quickly learn about code sharing when they end up on another airline.
Take Dr. Sandra K. C. Lim and her husband, Dr. Andrew C. K. Cheng. This spring the couple, who live on Long Island, decided to visit Mauritius, in the Indian Ocean, where Dr. Lim was born and her family still lives.
Dr. Lim left 26 years ago, and it was to be her first trip back, so Dr. Cheng urged her to buy first-class tickets. She booked first class with Lufthansa, at a round-trip cost of $6,300 a ticket. 
They left Kennedy International Airport on Flight 405 on May 25. In Frankfurt they boarded the continuation of their flight, No. 6474, which turned out to be on an Air Mauritius 767 plane.
The first-class cabin was not clean, Dr. Lim said, adding that the cabin and service were ''below par.'' Worse, there were only two rows in first class, their row and the smoking row behind them, which meant a 12-hour flight in smoky air, to which Dr. Cheng is very sensitive. Their travel agent did not tell them that they were changing lines, Dr. Cheng said; their travel agent said later that she did not know. Practice Gains Acceptance The effects of code sharing, joint operations, leases and pooling agreements are becoming increasingly widespread: in a period of recession with virtually no domestic regulation, when the European Market countries are moving toward full internal competition, almost any passenger can end up on a plane with an unexpected name and crew.
In the case of the Long Island couple, they were expecting Lufthansa service at the $6,000 level and considered that they did not get full value. Code-sharing began in the 60's, when Allegheny Airlines began to use its code, AL, in front of the flight numbers for its connections on smaller regional airlines. In the early 80's, other big airlines followed suit. The ticket, for example, would show Delta as the carrier all the way to Albany, Ga., but the Atlanta-to-Albany leg would actually be on a 24-passenger plane operated by Atlantic Southeast Airlines, ''the Delta connection.''
Opponents of this practice, which then included 12 independent regional lines, plus American and United, said it was deceptive, giving travelers the idea that they were making a connection on the same airline when they were actually changing lines.
In September 1984, a spokesman for United Airlines was quoted by the Official Airline Guide magazine Frequent Flyer as saying: ''It misrepresents two airlines with different levels of service which are indicated as one airline. We think it misleads the public. It's like buying an Oldsmobile with a Chevy engine.''
But at that time, it was easier for the traveler to find out whether there was a switch of airlines. One tipoff was that only commuter flights had four-digit numbers, so experienced travelers and travel agents would recognize that the trip would be aboard a hedge-hopper. ''Then we ran out of numbers,'' said Bill Jackman, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, and the four-digit designation came into use on non-commuter flights as well.
Code-sharing was accepted by the Federal regulators and the practice moved into the international field, with big lines coordinating arrival and departure times, and using each other's terminals. Sometimes one airline flies the outbound trip and the other the inbound. Airlines in Europe were then able to advertise that they served Houston as well as New York, and domestic airlines were able to offer cities they did not fly to. As a sales device, it was significant because two flights with a shared code may be handled in the computer as a direct flight, meaning a flight where you do not change planes although you may stop en route. Direct flights appear on the computer screen before connections, and this means that an agent would be more likely to pick this than a connecting flight.
The practice became widespread and American and United changed their minds. United began to share codes with regional lines in 1986. In January 1988 United worked out a code-sharing agreement with British Airways that allows British to offer flights to and from Seattle and other places in addition to Chicago, one of its ports of entry.
In fact, a Department of Transportation policy requires airlines ''in any direct oral communication'' to alert consumers as to what line they will fly. The policy does not refer to any travel agent's duty on this, although Hoyte B. Decker Jr. of the department's consumer affairs division says that in this context, a travel agent is acting as an agent for the airline and shares the obligation to inform the consumer. Sources May Be Confusing These days, travelers dealing with cheap-ticket offices, or even with full-service travel agencies, are almost always dealing with someone using a computer. An overworked agent is normally reluctant to pause and call an airline to get added information on a ticket that is virtually sold. And the giveaways on shared codes, joint operations and pooled flights vary among information sources: the printed edition of the prime reference work, the Official Airline Guide; the electronic version; the airlines' electronic timetables, and the airline computer reservation systems.
For a trip from Copenhagen to Houston, for example, the information is pretty clear. The O.A.G. Electronic Edition shows Scandinavian Airlines' Flight 911 connecting with Continental Flight 767 in Newark. Directly beneath it is a listing for Continental Flight 8911 from Copenhagen connecting in Newark with the same flight to Houston. A footnote says ''CO 8911 operated by S.A.S.'' In fact, 911 and 8911 are the same thing. In the O.A.G. book, Continental 8911 is marked with a star indicating ''dual designated carrier,'' and one can figure out the name of the carrier because the listing above, for 911, credits S.A.S. In the case of the Lufthansa-Air Mauritius flight, the printed O.A.G. lists both legs of the trip as Lufthansa flights; there is no indication that Lufthansa shares its code with another line. According to Lucille Hobshabjian, a spokeswoman for Lufthansa, the line's electronic timetable for the time the ticket was booked listed the flight twice, with the Frankfurt-Mauritius leg entered with the LH of Lufthansa and with the MK of Air Mauritius.
However, the Lim-Cheng tickets were sold from an electronic directory maintained by Sabre, one of the big four computerized airline reservations systems. There, the two entries for the flight were widely separated by other entries. The tickets were sold by the Flushing Travel Agency, a branch of Orient Clipper Travel of 217 Park Row in Manhattan, a consolidator, or agent for sale of deeply discounted tickets bought at wholesale from the airlines. Rudolph Den, the owner, said that the first-class Mauritius tickets were not discounted, but that the Long Islanders had been customers for some years and came to him for the tickets anyway. The tickets were issued by Lanny Wang, an assistant who said that on the basis of the Sabre data, she had assumed that the flight was Lufthansa all the way and did not learn differently until Dr. Cheng returned from the trip and complained. She said that she did not know that Lufthansa owned no 767's.
Inder Sethi, the manager for North America for Air Mauritius, said that the airline, which owns two planes, both 767's with 12 first-class seats in two rows, had many and varied agreements with other airlines serving his country. He ran through a list, and volunteered that the situation was confusing for the traveler.
As for telling the Lufthansa ticket-holders that they are going to arrive aboard Air Mauritius, he said: ''I doubt if the agents are aware.''
Once again, even with the Federal policy, the burden is on the traveler. If it matters, he or she should ask the travel agent to call and find out whose plane will be used.

PUB-DATE: October 21, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 570 words

HEADLINE: America's Best Weapon: Patience

 BODY:
The siege in the Persian Gulf is not yet 12 weeks old, but the patience of some Americans already seems exhausted.
First came the Hasty Hawks, certain that support for sanctions against Iraq would evaporate, and thus eager to ''take out'' Saddam Hussein with a ''surgical strike,'' oblivious to the cost in American lives now and Arab hostility forever. Enter now the Nervous Doves, their case urgently pressed by Jimmy Carter in Time magazine. 
Curiously, both schools of thought proceed from the same dubious premise - that Saddam Hussein has greater staying power than the awesome coalition arrayed against him. This flatters a dictator and devalues democracy.
Fortunately, President Bush's policy presumes otherwise, and assumes more of Americans. If the need to keep forces abroad for the long haul is presented clearly to the public, it will support a prolonged and costly commitment. It has done so for 40 years, for example, in Korea.
Mr. Carter raises familiar alarms. Oil prices are rising, Arab and Soviet support for global embargo of Iraq isn't solid and a world of short attention span is bound to turn to other matters. But whereas Hasty Hawks would initiate hostilities, he would initiate peace talks.
There's nothing wrong with taking soundings in Baghdad, or in encouraging any intermediaries, including King Hussein of Jordan, to talk with Saddam Hussein's emissaries. A senior Soviet official who recently traveled to Iraq may make plain to its leaders that there can be no partial solutions. What would be folly is to let Saddam Hussein believe he can engage in serious negotiations before unconditionally withdrawing from Kuwait. Any softening of that demand would undermine the whole purpose of this exemplary instance of collective action.
After only three months of embargo, Iraq is squirming. Gasoline, of all things, is about to be rationed. Baghdad, desperate for cash, is now offering to sell its oil for half price to anybody willing to violate the embargo. Food appears to abound in Baghdad, but as The Times's John Burns reports, shortages are crippling factories dependent on imported raw materials and spare parts. Disabled or idle equipment is a common sight. And hundreds of thousands of foreign workers have fled Iraq and Kuwait, taking with them their skills and their willingness to work at menial jobs.
No longer quite so defiant, Saddam Hussein now hints that his ''irreversible'' annexation of Kuwait might in fact be reversible - if the world rewarded him with access to the Persian Gulf and possession of disputed islands and oil fields. This sounds like the first squeak from a cornered bully. Even at this early moment, the siege seems to be starting to work; what a stunning miscalculation and waste it would be to weaken now.
Early fears about the allies' Desert Shield have proved unfounded. The coalition has held, with negligible wobbles. The rapid buildup in Saudi Arabia has gone forward without serious incident. Wisely and correctly, the Pentagon has informed Congress that the siege might last many months.
Opinion polls show some falling off in the initial overwhelming American approval for Mr. Bush's gulf strategy. This was inevitable. But now, as in Korea and Europe, most Americans understand that the presence of U.S. forces can keep the peace, protect economic lifelines and deter aggression. What the Siege of Iraq needs most is time to work.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 18, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 673 words

HEADLINE: The Truth Behind the Mideast's 'Great Lie'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Israel has come under heavy criticism for the way in which Israeli police responded to a Palestinian attack on civilians praying at the Western Wall in Jerusalem. This criticism includes the charge that Israel could be responsible for a collapse of the Arab-American alliance against Saddam Hussein, as the Arab world joins with the Iraqi dictator in a holy war against the Zionist state and its imperialist United States ally.
This criticism of Israel exposes the ''great lie'' of the Middle East. The great lie is that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict is a border dispute between two rational, reasonable, peace-seeking groups of people: one of whom has been needlessly oppressing the other while preventing any restructuring of the borders so as to bring peace to the entire region. 
If only Israel would permit a Palestinian homeland in the West Bank and Gaza, the great lie reasons, Israel and its Arab neighbors would live in peace. Only Jewish paranoia (or better, the paranoia of the Israeli ''right,'' embodied in the Likud Government of Yitzhak Shamir, fueled by a religious dream of a Greater Biblical Israel) prevents this redrawing of the Middle East map and concomitant regional peace.
Now, however, the suggestion that an Israeli response to a Palestinian attack at the Western Wall could cause the collapse of the U.S.-Arab alliance against Saddam Hussein should shine the light of truth on the great lie. Neither the Israeli-Palestinian conflict in general, nor a specific incident between a Palestinian mob and Israeli police, has anything to do with Saddam Hussein's conquering of Kuwait, terrorizing its people and pillaging the entire country.
The United States, while clearly in Saudi Arabia to protect U.S. oil interests, is just as clearly protecting the interests of Saudia Arabia and other Arab states from Saddam Hussein. There is no other circumstance that would have prompted the Arab world to permit U.S. and other allied ground forces to establish a military presence on Persian Gulf soil.
Saddam Hussein has violated the mythology of Arab brotherhood and now poses an enormous threat to every Arab state. Yet, despite the fact that he has thrown the world into a turmoil over the price of oil that could destroy the world's economy, and despite the threat he poses to the ultimate existence of other Arab rulers, we are told that the Arab world would turn on the U.S. and realign itself with Saddam Hussein against Israel and its American ally over the response of Israeli police to a Palestinian attack at the Western Wall.
If the Arab world is capable of such an incredible realignment out of its hatred of Israel, is there anything Israel could ever do to appease that world? Israel is the enemy of the Arab world by virtue of its existence, not its policies. And though in a moment of crisis Saudi Arabia welcomed an American protector, both Israel and its infidel ally, the U.S., remain the eternal enemy of the Islamic fundamentalist Arab world.
It is not Israeli intransigence that blocks peace in the region. It is Israel's existence. No creativity with the Middle East map will cap the well of Arab hatred for Israel's existence.
The crux of the Middle East dilemma is that there are no rules by which Israel can play. Israel is not dealing with an adversary prepared to arrive at a rational, reasonable and peaceful solution to a border dispute. In such a context, a Western-oriented, rational, reasonable handling of or solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict is virtually impossible at this time.
This should never excuse unbridled or unnecessary violence by Israel against Palestinians or any Arab population. But it should open American eyes - and, indeed, Jewish American eyes - to the extent to which Israel is in a no-win situation. Rather than criticism, Israel merits understanding, compassion and respect for the extent to which it has been able to cope in such an irrational and hostile environment.
 
MARK S. GOLUB
 Stamford, Conn., Oct. 12, 1990

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUB-DATE: October 21, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 19, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 768 words

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Bush: No Mo Big Mo

BYLINE: Tom Wicker

 BODY:
No matter what kind of Federal budget finally comes out of the unseemly scramble that has so demeaned Congress and the White House in recent weeks, a long-suffering public is more likely to remember the process than the product. Seldom, if ever, has Washington looked more self-serving and less effective.
There's plenty of blame and ridicule to go around, but on first analysis, the big loser - certainly of what he once called Big Mo - seems to be George Bush. But the President has lost a good deal more than the political ''momentum'' he had earned from his adept mobilization of the collective-security effort against Saddam Hussein in the Middle East. 
Most obviously, Mr. Bush's overall approval rating dropped meteorically, from a nearly incredible 76 percent in August to 60 percent last week, in the continuing New York Times/CBS News Poll. That's still pretty good, but it was a new low for the Bush Presidency. Worse, on specific questions, the President got even lower marks - 52 percent disapproved of his handling of the economy, 58 percent opposed his conduct in the budget debacle and 46 percent criticized his savings-and-loan ''rescue.''
Less demonstrably but not less plausibly, the President's bob-and-weave performance in budget negotiations with the Democrats combined disastrously with his earlier abandonment of his ''no new taxes'' pledge. Together, they undermined the public belief that Republicans, and Mr. Bush personally, were more responsible and reliable than Democrats in fiscal matters.
The one point on which the President and his aides seemed most nearly adamant, moreover, was their resistance to an income-tax increase on the rich - even as the President kept insisting on a capital-gains tax break for the same rich. Mr. Bush was willing, however, to accept a gasoline tax and ''sin taxes'' on whisky, beer and cigarettes - all of which bear down hardest on the poor and middle class.
Never mind that Democratic negotiators accepted these levies, too. It was the President who was threatening to veto anything else, and it was the Democrats who were also demanding higher taxes on the wealthy - even pushing a bill explicitly designed for that purpose through the House. The net result may be that blue-collar and ethnic groups that voted Republican in the 80's - Ronald Reagan's greatest gift to his party - will come to the predictable conclusion of Ron Brown, the Democratic national chairman: ''The Republican Party favors the wealthy and the Democratic Party favors the average American.''
Beginning with his abandonment of the no-new-taxes pledge, and continuing through the ups and downs of the budget negotiations, Mr. Bush's performance also displeased the Republican right wing. The President failed either to take a hard-right ideological stand, or to provide tough leadership for whatever position he did take at any given moment - which was sometimes hard to tell without an interpreter of Bushspeak.
A modern Republican President can ill afford to offend his right wing, which dominates Republican national conventions and ideological debate within the party, and is seldom willing to lower its voice in the interests of party unity. At least in these precincts, Mr. Bush in the budget scramble might even have resurrected the wimp's reputation that he and Willie Horton, with the aid of bloodshed in Panama, had so nearly buried.
Even Mr. Bush's respect for the ''vision thing,'' never much in evidence, must have seemed to many onlookers less compelling than usual. A President presumably should have a sense of where he wants to take the country, in economic as well as other terms. Mr. Bush appeared, instead, to have no central conviction for which he was willing to fight (other than the capital-gains tax break), and to be more concerned about escaping blame than asserting leadership. As such caution often dictates, he managed neither.
The nation may be the winner in one respect. Polls also show declining approval of the U.S. military presence on the Saudi Arabian border. Either from second thoughts about Operation Desert Shield or declining confidence in Mr. Bush's general leadership, support for his handling of the Middle East crisis already has plunged from 76 to 57 percent.
This sharp drop suggests that there would be little support for an actual war in the desert, either to liberate Kuwait or to bring down Saddam Hussein. For that reason, Mr. Bush may think long and hard, and more than twice, about taking the nation into such a war - probably without allies in the region and with too little enthusiasm at home.

LENGTH: 810 words

HEADLINE: The President: Read His Slips

BYLINE: By James Reston; James Reston is former Washington correspondent and former executive editor of The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Most Presidents run into unavoidable trouble by the time they reach midterm, but George Bush is different. Many of his troubles were not only avoidable but predictable, and this has hurt him because they raise questions about his judgment.
In a way, the criticism of his budget difficulties has been extreme if not unfair. Fights between Republicans and Democrats over how to raise and spend money are unavoidable. Put a few hundred billion on the table and they usually pounce on it like pit bulls. But the main thing is not that they disagreed about how to cut it up, but that they agreed to reduce the deficit by half a trillion dollars in the next five years. This may be the single most important economic decision of the last two years. 
George Bush is better at the big things than the little things. His objective on the budget was admirable but his handling of it was comical, and when he's mocked as weak or indecisive, he's unpredictable. We saw this in the campaign when he overcame his better qualities and followed John Sununu, Lee Atwater and James Baker down the low road.
After he won, he promised to nominate the best advisers available and told us we were living in an age of terror when life was fragile, and then picked Dan Quayle of Indiana for Vice President. This was clearly an avoidable blunder, and an injustice to both Mr. Quayle and the country, which fortunately can be corrected next time if his party thinks about it.
The odd thing about George Bush is that he plans his fumbles. He didn't have to promise not to raise taxes in a future he could not possibly foresee, or remind the country about his infamous wisecrack, by telling the reporters during the budget mess ''read my hips.'' They read his flips instead.
He has done some very good things. No President since the last great war has made a greater effort than George Bush to reach out to the opposition leaders for compromise and understanding. He has been on television almost as much as Dan Rather, and has held more press conferences in more strange places than any President since the inception of that jumping-jack institution. He has many other good qualities, but foresight isn't one of them.
When he ordered 200,000 men into the Arabian desert, he went on vacation and delivered his war communiques from the back of a golf cart, and was genuinely surprised that most people didn't think this showed ''grace under pressure.'' In the middle of the budget crisis when he was trying to get the support of the leaders of the Democratic Party, he took time off to campaign in North Carolina for the re-election of Senator Jesse Helms, of all people. He was determined at the start to ''hit the ground running,'' forgetting that this is what John Kennedy did when he ran into the Bay of Pigs, and Lyndon Johnson did when he ran into Vietnam.
These are the ''little things'' that trouble even many of his most loyal supporters, and some of them are not so little. One of his major foreign policy objectives was to persuade Mikhail Gorbachev not to use military force to achieve political objectives in the Baltic states and Eastern Europe, but he invaded Panama against his treaty commitments to the United Nations in order to capture a two-bit dictator, and didn't know what to do with him when he caught him. Having defied the U.N. in Panama, he then relied on it in Iraq.
It wasn't enough for him to blockade Iraq and punish Saddam Hussein as ''another Hitler,'' but he insisted on sending the biggest U.S. Army since the last war into the desert, not wanting to use it, not knowing how to get it out and facing once more the taunts of the armchair warriors, who say he must not only restore the independence of Kuwait but also get rid of Saddam Hussein and the threat of Iraq's Army as well. This is a dangerous situation for a President dropping in the popularity polls and facing both a deficit crisis and a mid-term election.
In such a pickle, a little half-time skull practice wouldn't hurt, but sometimes he's all bones and no skull, and can't sit still and think. He's all over the lot - fighting for the rich, campaigning not only in North Carolina but in California, driving in from Camp David to conserve gas and letting his helicopter return empty, jogging in the morning and flying to the world series in Cincinnati at night, always on the move, always pleasant and even cheerful.
He is the first President in memory who has not been able to get the votes of a majority of the members of his own party for a major bill in the Congress, but he has even tolerated Newt Gingrich, the Republican whip in the House, who has not only defied the President on the budget but hasn't even had the decency to resign.
He may come smiling through and even be re-elected, but it will take him a while to recover from the planned fumbles of the first half.

HEADLINE: The World;
Arabs Ponder Ways To Fix Arab Problems

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan

 BODY:
While most of the world is trying just to muddle through the crisis in the Persian Gulf, a few Arab thinkers - some would say dreamers - have begun drafting proposals to meet the widespread yearning of poorer Arabs in this undemocratic and inegalitarian region for greater democracy and a more equitable distribution of wealth.
''I think that in the wake of this great crisis, this great shock to the region, there will be a sense of humiliation among the Arabs,'' said Boutros Ghali, the Egyptian Minister of State for Foreign Affairs. ''So a consensus is growing that we will have to present some new ideas to help restore the Arab image and reignite a sense of confidence in the region and its future.''
In capitals whose governments have adopted radically different approaches toward getting Iraq out of Kuwait, specific and remarkably similar proposals are being crafted. Mr. Ghali, for example, has suggested the creation of an Arab parliament and an Arab ''petrobank,'' ideas he said he discussed with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d during a visit to the United States two weeks ago. 
Mr. Ghali asserts that a pan-Arab parliament - perhaps under the aegis of the 21-member Arab League - would be less threatening than domestic parliaments, a concept anathema to conservative gulf monarchies. A pan-Arab forum would give these states experience in a democratic institution, and might diminish suspicion of parliaments in their own states, he said.
But only a few Arab countries have functioning parliaments, almost none in the Western sense. While Egypt and Jordan have parliaments, power resides primarily with President Hosni Mubarak in Egypt and with King Hussein and his court.
Ahmed Khatib, who helped lead the democratization movement in Kuwait before Iraq's invasion, noted that pressure from Saudi Arabia and other gulf states helped prompt the ruling al-Sabah family in Kuwait to dissolve its own obstreperous parliament in 1986. He said the gulf states were not likely to approve of an experiment in parliamentary democracy anytime soon.
Moreover, the meeting of Arab League foreign ministers in Tunis last week reflected the disarray in the most enduring Arab organization, which was created in 1945 to enhance cooperation and unity. The session, called to discuss Israel's bloody suppression of Palestinian rioting in Jerusalem, nearly collapsed when a dispute over the wording of a resolution condemning Israel, but not the United States, led half of the delegates to walk out for several hours.
''The Arab League is in shambles,'' said a senior Arab foreign minister. Given the turmoil in this oldest of Arab cooperation groups, it was not likely that the states would agree to a new pan-Arab assembly.
Yet the allure of such a forum remains. The re-establishment of a real parliament was discussed last weekend by some 700 Kuwaitis in Jidda, Saudi Arabia. And the need to restore Kuwait's quirky version of democracy was conceded in principle by Crown Prince Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, who pledged unspecified democratic reforms once the government is restored. Moreover, Jordanian officials credit their parliament, first freely elected last year and dominated by Islamic fundamentalists, with helping to defuse political tensions.
Mr. Ghali's suggestion that the Arabs establish a regional ''petrobank'' has had far greater Arab resonance, particularly among representatives of poor, non-oil producing states like Jordan. In an interview last week, King Hussein called for such a development fund ''to bridge the gap between haves and have nots'' in this region, where, the World Bank says, annual per capita income figures ranged in 1988 from $15,770 in the United Arab Emirates to $480 in Mauritania and the Sudan. ''We need such an institution,'' the King said, ''so that a million Sudanese will not die of hunger this year while millions are being wasted.''
The King's younger brother, Crown Prince Hassan, proposed several years ago what he called an oil stabilization and development fund consistent with the spirit of Mr. Ghali's petrobank proposal. Under Crown Prince Hassan's proposal, Arab oil states would put a designated percentage of oil revenues over a specified price per barrel into a joint fund. If the market price dipped below that level, the money would be used to compensate for the revenue losses. But if the market went above the marker, excess revenues would go to development projects in poorer Arab countries.
King Hussein knows first-hand the risks of the current system of distribution of oil wealth - based on the whim of fellow Arabs. Between 1978 and 1988, the Arab states pledged billions to Jordan. Qatar and Abu Dhabi stopped making payments in 1983, Algeria made only one payment, and Libya never paid at all, aides to the King said. By 1988, Jordan's $6 billion deficit - equal to the money pledged and spent but never paid - was jeopardizing the country's economic stability, so the King appealed to Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, the Emir of Kuwait.
The Emir was unsympathethic. ''His answer to me was: 'It's your fault. You're not a gulf state. You're not an oil-producing state,' '' King Hussein recounted. '' 'Why do you have these ambitious development plans, the universities and all that? You can't afford them.' ''
Jordan, the Sudan, and other poor Arab states have grown increasingly resentful of these humiliating appeals for handouts from fellow Arab ''oilogarchies,'' as one Jordanian called the oil-producing nations. While Kuwaiti officials have expressed an interest in an Arab petrobank, gulf states that have not been invaded have been silent, and few are likely to endorse the concept.
But Mr. Ghali says the mood has shifted. ''Everyone in the Arab world in the wake of this crisis now understands that things must change.''

HEADLINE: PUBLIC & PRIVATE;
Our Bad Dreams

BYLINE: By Anna Quindlen

 BODY:
 The salvation in the Great Depression, or so I'm told, was the sense that we were pulling together. For those in trouble in recent years, the poison has become the isolation, the sense of being the lone diminished American in the land of boffo birthday parties and leveraged buyouts. But even the lucky ones knew this time was coming. Like characters in an Ayn Rand novel, we felt it in the 80's, all the small awry things that gave a jerry-built feeling to the helium real estate boom and the feeding frenzy of the 27-year-old art collectors. Unlike an Ayn Rand novel, no hero has arrived, with mythic shoulders and a Gary Cooper profile.
 You can feel the bad times to come in the documentary Barbara Kopple has made about the meatpackers' strike that paralyzed Austin, Minn., in 1985. It's rare that I cry at documentaries, but "American Dream" is painful to watch, like looking at a train speeding down the track. Part of the pain is knowing that the train is going to run right into these decent people, all these hard-working women with trivets on their walls and dried flowers on their kitchen tables, all these hard-working men with plaid shirts and billed caps. Part of the pain is thinking the train is someday going to hit you. 
 The people at the Hormel plant believed in a certain kind of America. They went on strike because the company wanted to cut wages to stay competitive. "It's ridiculous,"' one man says at a meeting at the beginning of the film, clutching pay stubs that show his weekly gross has gone from $637 to $400 to $312 a week. Some of these were second-generation meatpackers, and from their earliest years thay had known certain truths: that the union was their strength, and that the company needed their labor as much as they needed the company's money.
 The truths were false.
 Five months after the strike began, when the sunshine and the esprit of August rallies had given way to snowbound picket lines illuminated by trash cans filled with blazing logs, the strikers stood and yelled "scab" as 2,000 people appllied for their jobs. Some of those who came had not worked for years, and any shame they might have once had about crossing a picket line had long since evaporated with their incomes.
 In one scene in the film, two workers go to the big white house of the chief executive officer. And from behind the opaque safety of the screen his wife harangues them about how many people would be happy to have their jobs, even at a cut rate.
 The hard thing about watching "American Dream" is that you know she is right. When 1,500 people went out on strike for a principle, a principle was just about what they got. Most of them were replaced. Their children lived on rice and kitchen-table speeches, and Spam kept rolling off those assembly lines. Some crossed the line and made lifelong enemies out of lifelong fiends. The union, wallowing in tactics, personalities and bravado, failed them. A grown man sits in front of Ms. Koppel's camera and says, tears running into the ruts of his face, "All I want to do is go to work."
 Meatpacker, meet red foulard tie.
I don't know how economists define a depression. I only know that I went to three board meetings last week, and they all began the same way: "The news is not good." Five years ago people at those meetings used to talk about the boom and say giddily, 'It can't last.'
 Even then, when every day there seemed to be more newly minted men made of money, people like the people in Austin, Minn., were learning there were hard times just around the corner. Every day those people are more worried about the delicate balance, that delicate balance between the paycheck and the bills, that balance that can be knocked out of whack by a bum muffler.
 Webster's says a depression is "a period of low economic activity marked esp. by unemployment" as well as "a state of feeling sad." That covers it, I think.

HEADLINE: Rezoning to Meet Silicon Valley's Housing Needs

BYLINE: By JOHN McCLOUD

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, CALIF.

 BODY:
 A quarter-century ago, San Jose designated 2,900 acres in the north end as an industrial zone, excluding all other uses save for existing farms and orchards that had not yet been converted to manufacturing, a few small retail areas providing services for local businesses and three mobile-home parks, which were considered temporary.
Twenty years later, with about half the acreage developed, problems were evident. Local freeways were jammed with rush-hour taffic as workers traveled from other communities to reach their jobs. Prices on what little nearby housing existed had skyrocketed. Companies began to consider relocating to escape the congestion and provide access to housing for their employees. 
At the prompting of a coalition of business leaders called the Santa Clara County Manufacturing Group, San Jose and five neighboring cities that faced similar situations formed what became known as the Golden Triangle Task Force to deal with the problem. The name came from the shape of the area formed by the intersections of the three principal freeways serving Silicon Valley -- Routes 880, 101 and 237.
In 1985, the task force issued a report delineating three major objectives for each city: developing a growth-management plan, implementing a transportation-management program and rezoning enough land to accommodate a six-city total of 15,000 new housing units above the number already targeted by the individual cities. In 1987, the housing goal was up to a total of 65,000 new units by the year 2000.
"Based on job projections, the actual number of housing units needed was about 125,000," said Mike Evanhoe, executive director for the Golden Triangle Task Force. "It was decided that half that amount was a reasonable goal, with the remainder having to come from adjoining communities."
To meet that goal, the task force reasoned that the cities would have to convert commercial and industrial lands to residential use.
"The approach makes sense from three perspectives," explained Tom MacRostie, a principal planner for this city. "Not only does this provide more land for housing development, but it also reduces the land given over to commercial development, dampening housing demands. At the same time, it allows people to live closer to their jobs so that they don't have to drive as much, reducing both congestion and pollution."
River Oaks is the largest single development to come out of the ground so far in response to the Golden Triangle report. Now under construction by A-M Homes of Sunnyvale and Shea Homes of San Jose, the project, which comprises 1,100 rental apartments and 900 for-sale town homes, occupies undeveloped agricultural land originally intended for an industrial park. The utility lines and roads have been in place for 16 years.
About three-quarters of a mile away, A-M Homes, in conjunction with the Gibson-Speeno Company of San Jose and New England Life Insurance Company of Boston, are planning Renaissance Village. The group bought the 56-acre site for $25 million in 1989 from the Campeau Corporation of Toronto.
That project, of 1,140 apartments and 420 town homes, is now moving through the approval process, with construction expected to begin early next year.
Last year, the city rezoned a third parcel in the area, a 93-acre farm, for additional housing.
"Our biggest problem," said Mr. MacRostie, "has been finding properties under individual ownership that are large enough to create a total residential neighborhood environment. Building a few hundred units here and there won't work because people won't want to live someplace where they feel surrounded by businesses and factories. The idea is to create somewhat self-contained villages within a few minutes of workplaces."
The site for Renaissance Village lies along Santa Clara County's new light-rail system, as does the recently redesignated 93-acre parcel. River Oaks is a half-mile from the light-rail line, but the project's developers are providing a free shuttle service to the nearest mass-transit station.
Renaissance Village and River Oaks will each have about 20,000 square feet of retail space to provide daily services. In addition, Renaissance Village is next door to a mixed-use project now under way in the adjoining city of Santa Clara that will include 2,100 residential units, a 150,000-square-foot shopping center and two office towers.
Because the other Golden Triangle cities -- Milpitas, Sunnyvale, Mountain View and Palo Alto (Santa Clara withdrew from the task force) -- are smaller than San Jose, they have had an even more difficult time finding previously undesignated sites on which to develop new housing.
"We have seen projects where warehouses or auto dealerships were converted to housing, but we have virtually no raw land," said Ken Alsman, economic development manager for the City of Mountain View. To compensate, that city is looking toward mixed-use projects that will make more intensive use of already developed areas. "There are a lot of tilt-up industrial buildings from 20 or 25 years ago that are already being replaced. We are just beginning to study the possibilities of using these sites."
Some potential sites present environmental problems. Steve Burkey, an associate planner for Milpitas, mentioned a 300 to 400-acre site in his city that is available for development but that has many environmental unknowns.
"We can't afford to conduct all the environmental studies that would be necessary before that land could be declared suitable for development," said Mr. Burkey. "If a developer wants to come in and do them, that's fine. But it will be at his risk." Another obstacle to meeting the housing goal is the reluctance of some developers to build as densely as the individual cities would prefer.
The reasoning, said Roger Menard, president of Kaufman & Broad South, developer of 910 single-family homes in Calfifrrnia Landing in Malpitas, is that surveys have shown that 90 percent of prospective buyers want single-family homes.
Mr. Burkey said the developer was entitled to 2,000 residential units as of right -- and as many as 4,000 could have been built under certain conditions.
Despite the obstacles, Mr. Evanhoe said that since the Golden Triangle Task Force report was issued, 15,000 units have been either permitted or built and sites for up to 30,000 more units are under study for rezoning at this moment.
"The program has been moderately successful," he said. "When the sites are available, developers have been coming in and developing. So we know the market is there."
Meanwhile, the first town homes at River Oaks are on the market, with prices running about $250,000 for 1,400 to 1,800-square-feet. Rents for the apartments, now under construction, will run from about $700 for a studio to $1,100 for two bedrooms.
Steve Delva, vice president of planning for A-M Holmes predicted the town homes would sell with little trouble, saying, "there's really been no new housing of any magnitude built anywhere in the region recently.
"Last year, only 2,200 residential building permits were issued in the whole city of San Jose," he said. "That's why there's been such a problem. People have been moving one and two hours away in order to find something that they could afford, creating terrible traffic and smog in the process. This program is filling a very real need."

GRAPHIC: Photos: River Oaks town houses in San Jose, Calif.; Interior of one of the three-bedroom units at the San Jose project. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)
