HEADLINE: Campus Life: U.C., Davis;
A Chance to See The Remaking Of Hungary

BYLINE: BUDAPEST -

 BODY:
On their way to class here each morning, students from the University of California and the University of Wisconsin must pass an imposing life-size bronze statue of Karl Marx in the stately foyer of the Budapest University of Economics.
Marx, however, would hardly delight in what this group of students -including for the first time Americans and Eastern Europeans from outside Hungary - is learning, or the conditions the students are encountering at this university, which until recently bore his name.
These students ''are in the midst of a socioeconomic upheaval, and they are getting lectured by the people who are making it,'' said Robert Sarlos, the director of the two universities' joint Education Abroad Program.
The program's instructors, Professor Sarlos said, include ''people who are vitally involved in the remaking of Hungary.'' They include Istvan Rev, a sociology professor and a longtime critic of the Government, and Tomas Reti, an economics professor and active member of the Hungarian free trade union movement. 
Among those who have spoken to the group are Foreign Minister Geza Jeszenszky, who discussed current foreign policy, and Karoly Soos, chairman of the Parliament's Committee on Budget, Taxation and Public Finance, who talked about the nation's current budget troubles.
 
A 'Painful' Transition
Now in its fifth year, the Hungary program is larger than ever, with 37 students from eight California campuses - 15 from the University of Wisconsin at Madison - and now, university students from Estonia, the Transylvania region of Romania and Poland.
Professor Sarlos, who left Hungary in 1956 at the age of 25 and who before his two-year appointment as program director taught theater history at the University of California at Davis, speaks excitedly of Hungary's ''painful'' yet ''momentous'' transition from a socialist to a market economy, or, as he puts it, ''back into the West.''
Many of the students, Americans and foreigners alike, say the political changes that swept the former Soviet bloc countries last year inspired them to study in Hungary, which is struggling to shake itself free from decades of central planning.
''In light of everything that was going on, I was interested in seeing how a country could make that jump to a market economy,'' said Megan Sheehan, a junior majoring in history from the University of Wisconsin.
In addition to an intensive course in the Hungarian language, the students must enroll in at least three other courses, which are taught in English by Hungarian professors. The courses focus on Central and Eastern European politics, economics, art, history and contemporary society.
But the students in the Education Abroad Program learn as much simply by living in Budapest as they do in the classroom. Ms. Sheehan, who grew up in Brooklyn, said she thought Budapest would be ''more different'' from her hometown. Yet one cafe reminded her of a restaurant in Coney Island.
 
As 'Fluent as Possible'
Catherine Davis, a junior from Carmichael, Calif., who is majoring in international relations at the university in Davis, said she hoped to become as ''fluent as possible'' in Hungarian before she leaves in June. ''I just want to be able to go to a Hungarian village and be able to talk to people without having to have someone translate,'' she said.
Iwo Bender, a junior at Catholic University of Lublin in Poland, said he enjoyed studying with the American students because he has found that they are ''open minded'' and ''not ashamed of expressing themselves.'' But Mr. Bender added that the American students seemed more competitive than Eastern and Central European university students.
''People are more laid back here as far as academics are concerned,'' he said. ''You don't get that feeling of nonstop competition.''

HEADLINE: Industry Prods Schools On Educating Students

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
GROWING concern that Long Island students are graduating from high school without the necessary skills to enter the work force is prompting educators and business leaders to look at what schools are doing and should be doing to better prepare their students, and how the schools and the business community can work together on the problem.
The workplace is dramatically changing the skills required for its work force, and schools are being asked to provide programs that will result in more-competent graduates, said Dr. Edward Milliken, Superintendent of Boces II in central Suffolk County. When the last generation graduated from high school, Long Island industry relied on agriculture and manufacturing, he said, adding:
''But now we are a very service-oriented economy. Industries are driven by technology, and there is a greater demand on the part of business to have people who are technologically prepared, who have higher verbal, communications and critical-thinking skills.'' 
If there are not skilled people to fill the jobs, employers will have to look elsewhere to find them, Dr. Milliken said.
 
Larocca Cites 'Growing Gap'
A perception exists that there is a growing gap between the needs of employers and high school graduates coming out of the system, said James L. Larocca, president of the Long Island Association.
Unfortunately, he said, many people think that students, particularly those who are not college bound, are not leaving school with sufficient skills for the workplace. The skills include literature, communication, mathematics and reasoning.
''The concern intensifies as the economy slows,'' Mr. Larocca said, ''and we are now on the upside of the curve in the importance of addressing this issue.''
In a response to the concerns, the Bay Shore and East Islip School Districts are co-sponsoring a symposium on Tuesday on ''Education and the Economy.''
The conference, at the Bay Shore Middle School at 8 P.M., is to cover these questions:
* Are Long Island schools preparing young people to work?
* Will the probelm situation affect Long Island business?
* Will foreign-born workers fill the void?
 
Speaker, Panelists Listed
The keynoter will be Dr. Willard Daggett of the State Education Department. And the panelists will include Michael LoGrande, the former Suffok County Executive who is a management and planning consultant; Alexander Sheer, Chancellor of New York Institute of Technology, and Walter Dunne, vice president of the New York State United Teachers union.
Bay Shore and East Islip are pilot districts for the Excellence and Accountability Program of the State Education Department.
The conference was planned because a need was seen, said Dr. Robert Roelle, assistant superintendent for instruction for Bay Shore.
''Industry is changing so fast that it's hard to keep up,'' he said. ''The reading level of high-tech manuals has gone up dramatically and is comparable to beginning college textbooks.
''The need for skilled workers is increasing, while for unskilled workers it's decreasing. Kids today need to be critical thinkers and team players. If we can't provide skilled people to fill the jobs, employers will turn to immigrant workers.''
There is no longer a big difference between skills required for the work force and those required for college, said Mr. Dunne.
 
Look at Programs Urged
''We must take a look at our school programs and move expectations to a higher level for all students,'' he said. ''We've done an outstanding job based on the measurements we've used up to now, but we can't accept these measurements any more, not just for the Harvard-bound kids, but for all kids.
''A high school diploma is not enough; it no longer means that someone can go out and get a good job.''
There is agreement among educators and business leaders that it is critical for the schools and the business community to work together in a partnership.
Over the last few years, there has been a growing dialogue between the Island's educators and business leaders to help educators better understand the changes in the world of work and the changing required skills so that they can prepare their students accordingly, said Dr. Mary Barter, president of the Nassau County Council of Superintendents.
The council has been working with the Long Island Association to develop a business survey. The goal, Dr. Barter said, is to ascertain what expectations employers have for high school graduates entering the work force and what schools should be doing to prepare them.
 
Partnerships Developed
Over the last few years, more than 25 school-business partnerships have been developed under the sponsorship of School-Business Partnerships of Long Island, Mr. Larocca said.
The partnerships link high school students of a school district with a particular company. The concept is excellent, Mr. Larocca said, but the effectiveness of the partnership depends on how much energy the parties bring to it.
Part of the problem that exists is the illusion of being content, especially in the wealthier districts, Dr. Roelle said.
''The parents of the 'haves' think that everything is working, and it's hard to convince them that there is a problem,'' he said. ''But they're not seeing the larger picture for the future of Long Island. Compared to other countries we fall short, and it's not just the 'have-nots' that we're concerned with.
''The affluent school districts should be just as concerned. If their students are among the future employers of the Island, they will be depending on their peers to be their work force.''
Making changes in the schools will be a slow process, Dr. Roelle said, but the state has recognized the need and is encouraging local districts to experiment with different plans.
One of the biggest impediments is the lack of time, said Crescent Bellamore, the Bay Shore Superintendent of Schools.
''We're trying to do so much more than ever, but we haven't increased the number of hours in the school day,'' he said.
An extended school year has become more prevalent in several Western states, Mr. Bellamore said, adding:
''A 180-day school year goes back to our agricultural society, when youngsters had to go to work on the farms. But that no longer fits today. It's virtually impossible to follow the curriculum, prepare students for the Regents and teach the higher cognitive skills within the available time frame.
''The baby boomers will soon be leaving the work force, and kids who are in school now will be taking over by the year 2000. The bulge will be followed by a trickle, who will be expected to fill the shoes of the baby boomers. In that shrinking population are a higher number of poor, of minorities, of kids from single-parent homes.
''We have no choice but to prepare them for what they will have to deal with.''

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Investments Flowing Out of U.S.

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Foreigners are not the only investors moving money out of American financial markets, some economists and portfolio managers say. Increasingly, domestic institutions as well as individual investors are looking at foreign bond markets as preferable alternatives to staying at home.
The trend to move offshore was clear in the first half of the year, when American purchases of foreign securities totaled $18 billion, more than double the amount bought in the first six months of 1989. 
 Evidence of where domestically based capital has moved since then is mostly anecdotal. But in light of what has, and has not, taken place in the Persian Gulf, Washington and the American financial system since the end of June, it is unlikely that the outflow has slowed.
"We can't quantify it, but we know that dollar-based capital continues to move offshore," said David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services in Chicago.
 
Outflow Is Reported
 Barbara Kenworthy, senior portfolio manager of taxable fixed-income funds at the Dreyfus Corporation, said that over the last few months investments in dollar-based funds had actually risen a bit. But she added that colleagues elsewhere had reported an outflow.
"They don't know where it is going, but it is leaving the country," she said. Since early August, "more people are talking" about investing elsewhere, she added. "Whether they are acting on it remains to be seen."
Evidence of such an outflow may lie in the movement of the dollar, which despite its reputation as a safe-haven currency has plumbed new depths since early August. The decline, Mr. Hale noted, had the complete sanction of the Bush Administration.
"People have been aware that Treasury would be permissive of a fall in the dollar, but I think they are surprised by the extent of it," he said. "Given the banking crisis, there is no constituency in Washington to support the dollar through a rise in interest rates."
 
Financial Fragility Cited
 Bankers say that shoring up sagging foreign and domestic confidence by pushing up the value of the dollar through an increase in interest rates is not what the system currently needs. "There is real financial fragility out there right now," said one New York banker, who insisted on anonymity. "Many people are screaming, 'Where is the Fed, and why is it sitting on its hands at a time when it should be easing monetary policy?' "
Analysts said they remained convinced that the Federal Reserve Board would move to reduce short-term interest rates once a credible Federal budget package was enacted. But some portfolio managers said that additional steps would be necessary to reassure foreigners that American debt securities are worth the risk.
"A credible budget agreement would help," said David Boardman, an executive vice president with Rowe-Price Fleming in London and manager of a $375 million global bond fund. "But a commitment from the Administration of where the dollar should be is also necessary. Right now it looks like a policy of benign neglect."
Absent those two developments, Mr. Boardman said, "there is a real chance of investors cutting their losses and getting out of the United States bond market."
 
Strong Demand Expected
 With the Fed widely perceived to be on the verge of lowering short-term interest rates, demand for bills and notes should remain strong, analysts said. Demand for a $12.5 billion offering of 69-day cash management bills on Friday was surprisingly heavy, Ms. Kenworthy said. And investor response to today's planned auction of three-month and six-month Treasury bills, as well as to a sale of two-year notes on Wednesday, should be good, market participants said.
Predicting demand at three auctions this week of Citicorp's money market preferred stock is much more problematic. Rates on the money market preferred, which resets every 49 days, have been rising steadily in recent months, reflecting a deterioration in confidence in the banking system generally, as well as in Citicorp.
Citicorp, which conducts such auctions weekly, sold reset money market preferred last Wednesday at a reset rate of 8.76 percent. At a reset auction in late August, the 49-day securities were sold at a rate of 6.53 percent, according to analysts at McCarthy, Crisanti & Maffei, a research and credit rating agency.
The response among stock market investors to the downturn in the fortunes of major banks has been even more vicious than what has been seen in the debt market. Last week, the stock market capitalization of the nation's 10 largest banks, which collectively hold just under $1 trillion in assets, was $18 billion, Mr. Hale of Kemper Finanical said. The next 40 largest institutions, which hold assets in excess of $1 trillion, had a market capitalization of around $40 billion. "There is no precedent in the postwar period for this," Mr. Hale said.
 
Gloom on Fiscal Year's Data
 Market participants today will get a final accounting of how the Government fared in the recently ended 1990 fiscal year. Analysts say it does not promise to be an uplifting report.
In September the Government probably posted a deceptively large $20-odd billion surplus, said Susan Hering, an economist at Salomon Brothers, compared with a $6.1 billion shortfall a year earlier.
For the full 1990 fiscal year, the deficit probably grew by almost half, she added, to $221 billion, roughly matching the previous high, set in 1986. A deficit of that size would represent a little more than 4 percent of the gross national product, below the peak reached in the last recession.
With the economy slowing and outlays rising, however, chances are real that a new record could be set in the current 1991 fiscal year.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Former German Front Line Seems Disoriented by Peace

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FULDA, Germany

 BODY:
The two watchtowers stand vacant and silent now, the fence between them ripped and the cracked concrete sprouting sharp-thorned hawthorn.
Their confrontation seems all the more obscure in the beauty of a golden autumn afternoon. The wind whistling through the broken panes brings snatches of a tractor chugging across a distant field or the bark of a dog from the tile-roofed village nestled in the hills. 
 Otherwise nothing moves. Like Shelley's "Ozymandias," whose "two vast and trunkless legs of stone stand in the desert," the watchtowers seem to rise from the forests and fields like monuments to forgotten rivalries and vanished empires.
A scant year ago, heavily-armed men stood in these towers day and night training sophisticated military optics at each other and reporting every move they saw. This was the front line of the cold war, the trip-wire of World War III, where the border between East and West crossed the fabled Fulda Gap, the ancient invasion corridor through which the Soviet Army would try to punch if Moscow chose to challenge the West.
On the western side, men of the United States Army's 11th Armored Cavalry stood at what they called the "frontier of freedom" with the latest in American armor and electronics.
 
'It Can Be Confusing'
 On the other, East German border guards sat watching and photographing the Americans, but even more their own countrymen, who occasionally tried to rush the formidable fortifications at the risk of their lives. Behind the hills to the east, the Soviet Eighth Guards Army manned the periphery of what was still the threatening Soviet bloc.
Master Sgt. Robert McCord still remembers the strange feeling when the "enemy" first came over. "It was unnerving to see an East German officer, whom I clearly recognized from the cameras, walking through Fulda," he said. "That was in December -- he'd been on border patrol in the morning, and came over to shop in the evening."
More recently, he said, Soviet officers have begun to come over, some in full uniform. "It can be confusing -- you develop the perception that this is the enemy, and suddenly he's in your back yard," he said.
Even more disorienting is that the East German soldiers are now allied German soldiers, and their Soviet-made equipment is now on the Western side. "All your life you train to defeat these tanks, and now they're yours," said Sergeant McCord.
The sergeant also remembered the first time he stepped over the border himself. Before the wall came down, the border was the front line, and to cross it was to violate everything the 11th Armored was trained to avoid.
 
Visits to the 'Other Side'
 "We always had strict exercises on not crossing the line. We practiced this, we showed this to our people -- here's the line, don't cross it," he said, drawing an imaginary line through the ground. "So when I did it the first time, I felt I was doing something immoral. It was a very strange feeling."
Sergeant McCord and his German-born wife now visit regularly on the "other side," and friends from there visit them. A newly paved road crosses the former line near Observation Post Alpha.
The 11th Armored is still here at full strength, but the patrols along the border stopped in February, and the officers have been careful since then to keep their tanks and radars "over the horizon" from the former border. The mission now is basically to stay as long as the Soviets stay, and that is likely to take four to five years.
The 11th Armored has had about 4,500 soldiers in Fulda, part of a 60,000 strong force in Hesse, the German federal state on whose territory the Fulda gap lies.
The Americans in Fulda face the 60,000 Soviet troops of the Eighth Guards Armor, stationed around Weimar in the former East Germany. The Soviet soldiers, unlike the Americans, never patrolled the inner-German border themselves, but left the patrolling to the East German border troops.
All in all, 250,000 American soldiers are stationed on former West German territory, 60,000 of whom are likely to be withdrawn over the next four or five years. The number of soldiers of the 11th Armored will not be cut.
 
A Tinge of Longing
 The Soviet troops in what was East Germany total 350,000. Under a German-Soviet agreement signed last week, the Soviet forces will have left Germany by the end of 1994.
The 11th Armored and its 10,000 soldiers and dependents are not among the Americans being withdrawn from Germany. "The 11th A.C.R. will probably be the one to turn out the lights if the United States leaves Germany," Sergeant McCord said.
Though no one says so openly, the reduced mission grates on the career soldiers, especially when many of their comrades are tasting front-line service in Saudi Arabia.
"There's no sense having a bulldog if you don't let it bite once in a while," said Command Sgt. Maj. Richard Morgan at regiment headquarters at Fulda with a tinge of longing.
But if the American troops seem a bit disoriented by the sudden disappearance of the border that used to define their mission, at least they can claim that the broken fence and empty towers are "evidence of mission accomplished," as the commanding officer here said in the unit's newspaper.
 
Stories of Officers' Wives
 On the eastern side, the evidence is of a mission abandoned. The Soviet soldiers are still there, to be sure, but the fearsome guardians of the empire now peddle their service hats, insignia, even their weapons. Officers scour the flea markets to stock up on bargains before they are shipped back, and their wives demonstrate to remain abroad.
In Gotha, a city with a large garrison of the Soviet Eighth Guards Army 55 miles northeast of Fulda, Germans eagerly share the latest rumors about the "Mushkote," as the Russians are popularly called.
At the "Moscow" restaurant in what used to be "Friendship House" near the Soviet barracks, a group of German teachers tells of Soviet officers' wives at a nearby garrison who have been leaving their husbands and looking for Germans to marry. They tell of an acquaintance who bought a Kalashnikov assault rifle for $460 and a pair of pistols for $175 each.
The information cannot be verified, but what is obvious is that the old awe of the Soviets has changed to disdain and pity.
"They're starving," declared one of the teachers, Rupert Kober, to nods from his colleagues. "If you come here in the morning, you'll see that they've ripped up their roof timbers and have burned their furniture because they have no more fuel."
"The Russians are not especially loved or hated here, but everybody's happy they're leaving," said Achim Bosel. "Except one man -- there's a farmer here who's been getting gasoline from the Russians by the tankload for decades and selling it cheap. I haven't had to use a gas station for years. Nobody could touch him, because they assumed higher officers were involved."
 
Withdrawl Would Be Welcomed
 The feelings are different over in Fulda. Here, the "Amis," as the Americans are known, are 10 percent of the population and account for a considerable chunk of the economy. Many live in homes rented from Germans, and about 500 local residents work for the United States Army. In all, the American military pumps about $8 billion annually into the German economy and creates jobs for about 170,000 Germans.
Still, a poll last April by the Allensbach Institute, a conservative polling organization, showed that the number of Western Germans who welcomed the American withdrawal was growing. As reported in the weekly newpaper Die Welt, 49 percent of those questioned welcomed the withdrawal. A year earlier, the figure was 38 percent. In 1982, it was 21 percent, and in 1962, 12 percent.
But then the presence of the "Amis" or the "Mushkoten" hardly means what it used to when the Germanys were the bristling focus of the East-West confrontation, when O. P. Alpha was a front-line enclave where American soldiers moved about in full combat gear and visitors came for a glimpse of the trenches. The gates have been padlocked for some eight months now, and mushrooms sprout at the cracked edges of the basketball court.
The birch cross outside the front where an East German died long ago trying to flee is still there. But there is also a new enclosure of posts and white canvas set up by an unidentified peace group. On it asign pledges to turn "this point of East-West confrontation" into an education center "for demilitarization, the preservation of the environment, social justice, a decrease of government and worldwide solidarity."
The heavy iron fence along the former border is now riddled with gaping holes. Beyond, massive concrete slabs still lie angled to prevent East Germans from crashing through the barrier in trucks or tractors. But hawthorn bushes have sprouted in the track that followed the border.
The old East German tower, 100 yards from O. P. Alpha, stands sprayed with graffiti. Tangles of wires hang from the walls, and the windows from the observation room at the top have been smashed. But the view of the broad scar that was the border zigzagging into the distance still inspires awe: how great was the effort, and how swift its undoing.
 
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare,
The lone and level sands stretch far away.

HEADLINE: Ghost of Reagan in Connecticut Race

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWTOWN, Conn., Oct. 18

 BODY:
When Toby Moffett moved here from the New Haven area last year to attempt a political comeback, Republicans called him a carpetbagger and predicted his long record of liberalism would doom him in the state's conservative, blue-collar Fifth Congressional District.
But the residency issue appears to be fading in Mr. Moffett's race against Gary A. Franks, a conservative three-term Waterbury alderman who is seeking to become the state's first black Congressman and the first black Republican to hold a voting seat in the House of Representatives since 1935. 
 As the Northeast's economy spirals downward, the contest has taken on the aspect of a referendum: Can liberal Democrats, reinvigorated by the current budget fight in Washington, regain the working-class support they lost to Republicans during the 1980's?
"It is dawning on people that Reagan was just on the side of the superwealthy," said the 46-year-old Mr. Moffett, who served four terms as a Representative in Congress before losing bids for the United States Senate in 1982 and for Governor in 1986.
Mr. Franks, who is 37 years old, a Yale graduate and an unsuccessful candidate for state comptroller in 1986, disagreed. He predicted that the district's voters would reject Mr. Moffett's unreconstructed liberalism.
"Toby Moffett is looking at the district with rose-colored glasses on," Mr. Franks said. "He's always believed people in Connecticut were all for Toby Moffett, but the truth is that they weren't in 1982, they weren't in 1986, and they won't be in 1990."
 
Celebrity Endorsements
 As one of only 29 House seats in the nation for which an incumbent is not seeking re-election, the Fifth Congressional District race has drawn national attention. President Bush, Barbara Bush and Marilyn Quayle plan to campaign for Mr. Franks this month. Mr. Moffett meanwhile has brought in the actor Robert Redford, who owns a home in Weston; Stephen Stills, the singer, and Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., the former Democratic House Speaker from Massachusetts.
The seat is being vacated by Representative John G. Rowland of Waterbury, a conservative who is the state's Republican gubernatorial candidate. He was carried into office on President Ronald Reagan's coattails in 1984, upsetting the incumbent Democrat, William R. Ratchford of Waterbury.
This year, whether Mr. Rowland will provide coattails is an important question in the race, which has been overshadowed somewhat by the state's unusual three-way gubernatorial battle in which Lowell P. Weicker, a liberal Republican and former three-term Senator running as an independent is the front-runner.
Although Mr. Weicker has maintained a large lead in statewide polls over Mr. Rowland and the Democratic candidate, Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, Mr. Rowland is expected to carry his home district, which runs across the middle of the western half of the state, from Meriden west to Danbury, and includes wealthy towns like Weston and Wilton, as well as Waterbury and the old mill towns along the Naugatuck River.
Even so, Republican strength in the district may have waned. Democrats around the country have taken the offensive, encouraged by Democrats in Washington who have used the budget battle to attack the Republicans as the party of the rich.
"I don't think you can say this is an area that is Reagan Republican indefinitely," said Terry A. Baney, a professor of political science at Teikyo Post University in Waterbury. "Some of that feeling has abated."
 
Starkly Different Choices
 Mr. Moffett and Mr. Franks aggressively play up their philosophical differences. Mr. Franks calls Mr. Moffett a relic of Jimmy Carter's tax-and-spend liberalism; Mr. Moffett characterizes Mr. Franks as a Jesse Helms type of conservative who would deny aid to the underprivileged.
"I am fundamentally, solidly opposed to what Reagan tried to do in terms of government retreat from cities and from giving people opportunity," Mr. Moffett said. "I am running in part against the Reagan era."
Mr. Franks, one of three black Republicans in the nation running for Congress this year, supports a cut in the capital-gains tax and opposes raising the Federal income tax. He favors a constitutional amendment to prohibit burning the American flag and supports the death penalty for drug leaders.
Like Mr. Moffett, Mr. Franks supports abortion rights, but he criticizes such Government initiatives as family-leave legislation, which would force private employers to provide social services, and the proposed Civil Rights Act of 1990, which he believes would promulgate a quota system. Mr. Moffett supports both bills.
 
Residence an Issue
 Mr. Franks, who was raised in Waterbury, also has continued to criticize Mr. Moffett's recent move to Newtown, a small Fairfield County town in the Fifth Congressional District near Danbury, after having lived for three years in Branford in the Third Congressional District. In his years in the House, from 1974 to 1982, Mr. Moffett lived in Litchfield in the Sixth Congressional District. There is no residency requirement for Congressional candidates.
"He is an opportunist," Mr. Franks said. "He's trying to use this district to go to Washington."
Mr. Moffett, who at one time worked with the consumer advocate Ralph Nader, is now self-employed as an environmental consultant. He has sharply criticized Mr. Franks, who owns his own real-estate company, for not releasing his Federal and state income-tax forms and for owning properties occupied by low-income residents that have been cited for minor building-code violations.
Mr. Franks's race has been dismissed as an issue by both candidates. Blacks make up only about 4 percent of the voters in the district, which is almost evenly divided among Democrats, Republicans and unaffiliated voters.
In recent interviews, however, voters said that race was certainly a factor working against Mr. Franks, particularly in the mill towns in the Naugatuck Valley. "I think he'll lose a few votes," said J. D. Hicks, 32, a general remodeler from Seymour. "I don't think the valley is open-minded."
No public polls have been conducted on the race, but Mr. Franks's polls show a dead heat, and Mr. Moffett's polls give him a narrow lead.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Chemical Results Hurt Occidental

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THE fortunes of chemical producers typically rise and fall with the nation's economy. And in the stock market this year, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation has been aligned more with chemical makers that are hurt by surging oil prices than with the global oil producers that benefit from them.
Occidental's chemical unit contributed three-fourths of the company's 1989 profits, or more than $1 billion. With profits in a broad retreat in the chemical industry, investors have pummeled Occidental's shares. 
 The shares, which traded below $18 earlier this month for the first time in eight years, were at $20.75 on the New York Stock Exchange in midweek. They closed on Friday at $22.625, benefitting from the slide in crude oil prices late last week.
Occidental's market value is down 30 percent this year amid mounting worries of recession, lower demand for chemicals and rising costs for crude oil, a raw material for chemical production. But oil company stocks as a group have risen 10 percent this year despite a selloff in the last two weeks.
Many analysts say that Occidental's shares are now a bargain -- that investors have overlooked the prospect that the company can earn an extra $30 million to $50 million in a year, or 10 cents to 17 cents a share, for every $1 increase in crude prices. Several companies, including ARCO, Chevron, Texaco, Mobil and Exxon, achieve a gain of at least 30 cents a share for every $1 increase in crude oil, said Eugene L. Nowak, an oil analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds.
Occidental's third-quarter earnings report, released Tuesday, underscored the view that it benefits over all from rising oil prices. Operating income in the quarter rose by 68 percent, to $111 million, from $66 million in the same period a year ago. Chemical profits slid 40 percent, to $152 million, but the oil and gas unit posted a fivefold increase, to $78 million. Natural-gas transmission, meatpacking and coal operations also improved. Net income rose slightly, to $109 million, from $108 million.
"Chemicals could be in the doldrums for a year, maybe longer," said Warren M. Shimmerlik, an independent oil analyst in New York. "But it isn't going to last forever. This is an efficient company that will benefit from higher profits in other businesses."
Dr. Armand Hammer, the 92-year-old chairman who maintains an iron grip on Occidental, has rejected any paring of the company's dividend, even though it seems certain that for the eighth time in nine years the payout will exceed income from Occidental's operations. Dr. Hammer owns 1.3 million of Occidental's 295 million common shares and was paid $3.3 million in dividends last year.
Occidental has relied on asset sales and new issues of debt and stock to maintain the dividend. The company needs $738 million this year to cover an annual payout of $2.50 a share. The dividend yields 12 percent and has attracted thousands of individual investors. Another $800 million is required to cover interest on $8 billion in long-term debt.
In an interview, Ray R. Irani, Occidental's president, took issue with recently expressed doubts on Wall Street about Occidental's ability to continuepaying the dividend and its high debt costs without curtailing its spending on oil prospects. The concerns arose after Occidental's debt rating was lowered after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August.
"There is no discussion by management and the board to cut the dividend," Mr. Irani said. "We can continue to serve the dividend from our normal operations."
A spokesman said that although Occidental was unable to pay the dividend from its operating income, a cash reserve for that purpose will increase by $300 million in the fourth quarter, to $2.9 billion by yearend.
Mr. Irani said Occidental's capital spending will decline to about $1.1 billion in 1991, from $1.4 billion this year. The company will scale back spending in chemical operations because industry growth has slowed, he said. Oil spending will decline somewhat because Occidental will soon complete reconstruction of its Piper Alpha platform in the North Sea, which was severely damaged by a 1988 fire.
"We are spending for oil and gas exploration at very high rates," Mr. Irani said. "We have not turned down any important new development." Occidental has a new exploration accord with Yemen.
Yet some analysts believe rising oil profits will not be adequate for Occidental to overcome its troubles in chemicals. "Their main business is getting worse and worse before their second-best business, oil, comes back to fighting strength," said Jim Murchie, oil analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. "Oxy's toughest year will be, if not next year, then the year after." He estimated Occidental would earn 5 cents a share next year.
Many more analysts said Occidental's 1991 profits should reach $1.30 a share or more. George Baker of Merrill Lynch and Mr. Shimmerlik said the company would earn $1.25 a share this year and $1.35 a share in 1991. Mr. Nowak of Dean Witter said he raised his forecast to $1.30 for this year, from $1.10, after reviewing Occidental's third-quarter results. Several analysts put the company's asset values at about $38 a share.

HEADLINE: Report Outlines Signs of Success In City Schools

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Successful urban high schools have sharply defined academic and social goals for students and are strong organizations that solve their own problems, take initiatives and consider themselves more accountable to their community than to higher authorities, a new study has found.
In contrast, the study by the RAND Corporation said, less successful public schools have diffuse programs, allow their students and staff to define their own roles, maintain rigid internal divisions of labor and emphasize compliance with the regulations of central bureaucracies. 
 The study, which analyzed a group of parochial and special public high schools in New York City and Washington, and compared them to less-effective regular public schools, concluded that the features of the successful schools could be widely carried out in cities across the country and should be the core of reform in New York.
 
School-Based Management
 "School systems can make the key features of private and special public schools available for all," said a report on the study, which was made public yesterday. "Such schools can work for even the most disadvantaged."
James S. Vlasto, speaking for the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, said there was much merit in the RAND report. Many of its recommendations, he said, were already being carried out in the Chancellor's trademark program for school-based management, in which committees of teachers, parents and administrators now share authority for decisions at 82 schools.
The study, entitled "High Schools With Character: Alternatives to Bureaucracy," by Paul T. Hill, Gail E. Foster and Tamar Gendler, was conducted by RAND, a nonprofit organization that analyzes national security and domestic problems, at 13 schools serving largely minority and disadvantaged students.
 
50 Percent Graduated
 Included were Catholic schools, specialized vocational or academic public schools and neighborhood public schools. Their operations and organization were tracked, classes were observed and students, teachers, administrators and counselors were interviewed.
The schools were not identified in the report and it was unclear how they were selected. Wide differences separate many of New York City's public schools, educators say, and the study's results would have been different if a good school like Benjamin Cardozo in Queens, or a troubled school like Eastern District in Brooklyn, had been in cluded in the regular schools.
In the successful schools -- where 80 percent of students graduated and 85 percent of the seniors took college entrance tests and scored relatively well -- the study found a heavy focus on student achievement, a determination to mold attitudes and values and a basic curricula that all graduates completed.
In the regular schools -- where 50 percent of the students graduated and only 30 percent took college entrance tests and scored relatively poorly -- the study found an emphasis on program delivery and compliance with regulations, a willingness to let students and staff define their own roles and different curricula for students of different abilities.
The study said that the more effective schools "unhesitatingly place burdens on their low-achieving students," while less effective ones "agree not to demand too much in return for the students' agreement not to cause trouble."
The more effective schools were relatively independent, problem-solving organizations with a distinctive character and a primary commitment to students, parents, neighborhood and parish groups. The less effective ones were internally rigid and accountable mainly to authorities who dictated rules and audited performance.
"The regular urban public high schools are the most troubled of our educational institutions," the report said. "The recommendations we make in this study do not constitute a complete reform agenda. But they do show what each school must be allowed to do for itself, which is to define a clear mission and develop a social climate, curriculum and teaching strategy that are consistent with it."

HEADLINE: Bangor Journal;
Death and Hunter's Trial Pose Tough Questions

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGOR, Me., Oct. 18

 BODY:
In the wooded outskirts of Bangor, five black and orange "NO TRESPASSING" signs warn hunters and curious onlookers not to go near the house where Karen Ann Wood lived.
Two years ago, before the signs went up, the 37-year-old Mrs. Wood, who had recently moved to Maine from Iowa, walked into her backyard and was fatally shot by a local hunter. The hunter, Donald Rogerson, later said he mistook her white mittens for the tail of a deer. 
 The ensuing trial, in which a jury on Wednesday found Mr. Rogerson, a 47-year-old produce manager for a supermarket, not guilty of manslaughter, captured the nation's attention and polarized this small city.
While the verdict has troubled many residents who believe that Mr. Rogerson was hunting recklessly, the trial itself has exposed an even deeper issue: the struggle of a traditional hunting culture trying to survive in the face of increased modernization and anti-hunting sentiment -- values often brought into Maine by people from outside the state. Often those values come in the form of pressure for stricter gun control laws and quests for new housing developments.
"The problem is that your dyed-in-the-wool hunters just believe they have an inalienable right to hunt everywhere," said Michael Foster, a 27-year-old hydroelectric technician who is a Bangor native. "Local, indigenous native Mainers are slightly provincial anyway. To have outside people come in and shape policy, they really resent that."
With lush forests carpeting 90 percent of the state, hunting and fishing have long been a way of life here. Last year, the state, with a population of just over a million, issued about 216,476 hunting licenses, and 30,260 deer were killed. Deer hunting season lasts only a week or so in most other states, but here it is a month long. The sport also generates more than $150 million a year for the Maine economy, the state government says.
Many Maine residents, resenting the bad publicity that the Wood case brought the state, are reluctant to talk about it.
But some who do talk about the case say that while Mr. Rogerson should have been more careful Mrs. Wood failed to follow well-known precautions for the hunting season. Just a few months before the shooting, she had moved with her husband, Kevin, and two infant daughters to a tract of land in Hermon that once had been open to hunters. When she went out that November afternoon, she wore a dark coat and white mittens rather than the bright orange clothing that warns hunters away.
"I say, when in Rome do as the Romans do," said Marty L. Boehmer, a 31-year-old hunter. "The common knowledge around here is that you don't go into the woods during the fall without putting orange on."
A month after the shooting, when a grand jury decided not to indict Mr. Rogerson, Mr. Wood and others pushing for more accountability from hunters cried foul. More than a year later, after a television station reported irregularities in the first grand jury, a second one was convened and handed down a manslaughter charge. Now the verdict is in, and the case cannot be appealed.
Many Maine residents, as well as Mr. Wood, who now lives with his daughters in Bettendorf, Iowa, are bitter.
"I don't condemn the state of Maine in general," he said in a telephone interview. "I do condemn the provincialism that exists there, obviously in Bangor, that creates a bias where injustices like this occur."
Since the case began, many nonhunting residents have pushed for tougher hunting laws, regulations that only shotguns be used in built-up areas and more requirements for hunter education courses. And in some cases they have succeeded.
In Hermon, the town council's efforts to have the state pass stricter hunting laws failed, but town officials have made 750 signs to warn hunters that they are near houses.
Still, the debate between native and newcomer, hunter and nonhunter simmers.
"It used to be safe to hunt in these woods. Nope. No more," said Al Worster, a mechanic from Levant. He said he quit hunting 20 years ago when hunters from New York shot at him, thinking he was a moose.
"I don't mind more people here," Mr. Foster said, "but I truly resent their bringing their big city thinking and urban problems with them."

HEADLINE: THE 1990 ELECTIONS: The 1990 Issues;
Candidates Seek Safe Havens In Storm Over Taxes in States

SERIES: Second article of a series: Taxes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 17

 BODY:
Anyone who finds the politics of taxation complicated in Washington should come here to Illinois.
The tax issue has become so complicated that candidates here are emphasizing positions in ways that defy traditional party definitions. The Democratic candidate for governor and the Republican candidate for the Senate are running as tax cutters, while the Republican candidate for governor and the Democratic candidate for Senate say taxes are needed to pay for good things, particularly schools. 
 And that is just the begining of the mind-blurring complications as Illinois, and the nation, struggle with taxes and spending in the post-Reagan era.
The Democratic candidate for governor, Neil Hartigan, has built his campaign around a promise of a tax cut, even though every other major Democrat in the state, including the leaders of the Legislature and the Mayor of Chicago, have declined to join him.
The Republican candidate for governor, Jim Edgar, has rejected the tax cut and has depicted his stance as evidence of his candor and character. He has campaigned with President Bush, who is still trying to live down his inablity to live up to his "no new taxes" promise of the 1988 campaign.
 
Taxes and Politics
 All this is an object lesson in one of the most important realities of American politics these days. Since the tea was dumped in Boston Harbor more than 200 years ago, taxes have been a central political issue for Americans.
But they are far from a simple one. Unlike the situation at the time of Proposition 13 in California and Ronald Reagan's election when the demand for big tax cuts was at the heart of a voter rebellion, many Americans have shown a willingness to pay their current, or even higher, taxes, if they believe the money will be well spent.
The catch is they rarely believe that their government will spend the money wisely.
And for all the talk about taxes in Washington at the moment, the concern is clearly bubbling up from the local level, not trickling down from Washington.
Taxes and spending are the driving issues in dozens of elections across the country this year, from ballot propositions in Massachusetts, Nebraska and six other states to the governor's race here in the nation's sixth most populous state.
The message that politicians are hearing in the fall campaigns is subtle, mixed and difficult for government to cope with.
"What we're seeing in 1990 is that we're not going to be able to drastically decrease taxes, but the voters want a say in how the money is spent," said John Keast, who monitors ballot initiatives around the country.
 
Distrust of Government
 Talk of taxes and spending cannot be separated from the voters' distrust of government and politicians this volatile election year. "The big issue in this campaign is not the amount of money people are paying but what they are not getting in return," said Mr. Hartigan's pollster, Mike McKeon, explaining his candidate's central issue. "People are not interested in paying more taxes until they see better results for what they are already paying."
Here in Chicago, and particularly in the suburbs around it, people are not talking about the capital gains tax or the top tax rate for the wealthiest Americans, issues that fixate Washington. They are worried about soaring property taxes.
But the tax that Mr. Hartigan is actually attacking is a state income tax surcharge, due to expire next year. The money raised by the surcharge helps finance education and local government, which is why many traditionally Democratic voters are edgy about Mr. Hartigan's pledge to eliminate it. But he assures them that he can actually increase aid to education, even while eliminating the surcharge, by reducing other state spending by 2 percent.
Mr. Edgar, joined by many newspapers in the state, says Mr. Hartigan's plan is a sham. He proposes instead to keep the surcharge, but to curb the growth of property taxes.
 
Search for Middle Ground
 Both candidates are trying to maneuver themselves to a middle ground where they can sound fiscally conservative without promising too much. But they are also responding to the message from voters for government restraint.
Indeed, Mr. Hartigan and Mr. Edgar have promised not to sign any legislation increasing taxes that does not have two-thirds support in the Legislature. That pledge, they say, lives up to the spirit of a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a two-thirds vote that the courts knocked off the ballot earlier this year.
In Oklahoma and Connecticut, the Democratic candidates for governor say they will submit any tax increase proposal to the voters.
In Nebraska, a ballot initiative would limit the growth of state and local spending to 2 percent annually. The Massachusetts measure would roll back recent big tax increases.
The Massachusetts and Nebraska measures have become important factors in contests for governor. Both candidates in Nebraska oppose the 2 percent plan. In Massachusetts, the Republican, William F. Weld, embraces the tax curb, while the Democrat, John R. Silber, has urged voters to elect him so that state government can be restrained "with a brain" instead of in the across-the-board manner of the ballot measure.
In California, several measures of the ballot actually call for tax increases, but they dedicate the money to specific purposes, as the income tax surcharge here is dedicated to education and local government. Voters in California approved a gasoline tax increase for transportation improvement in June and will be asked in November to approve higher liquor and sales taxes to fight drug and alcohol abuse.
"Citizens are becoming increasingly willing to sacrifice tax dollars for specfic services, but not for uncontrolled spending by the legislature," Mr. Keast said.
 
Images of Waste
 On the campaign trail, the debate over taxes is usually less an argument over proper public policy than it is an effort to invoke issues of character and images of waste.
Political consultants in both parties here say Mr. Hartigan's promise to eliminate the income tax surcharge has been less powerful in itself than as part of an effort to keep Mr. Edgar on the defensive and to paint him as a spender and the Republican Party's heir to Gov. James R. Thompson. In 14 years in office Governor Thompson has angered a considerable number of Illinoisans by raising taxes, after saying he would not.
In one of the campaign commercials Mr. Hartigan has used to attack Mr. Edgar, a bumblebee flits through a garden to the strains of "Flight of the Bumblebee" as the announcer asks voters if they knew that Mr. Edgar had spent $375,000 to build a rose garden for Governor Thompson's mansion.
"Haven't we been stung enough?" the announcer asks, as the visage of Mr. Hartigan, currently the Attorney General, appears and the announcer says Mr. Hartigan would rather use the money to expand the minds of Illinois children.
"Gross distortion," said Mr. Edgar's spokesman, Mike Lawrence. He explained that as Secretary of State, Mr. Edgar's office oversees state grounds. The rose garden was part of an external renovation of the governor's mansion approved by the Legislature and the Governor, he said.
 
Close Race
 The contest between Mr. Edgar and Mr. Hartigan has produced an unusual role reversal, with the Democratic candidate's staff making the case against taxes while Mr. Edgar's staff argues that their research shows that better education, safer streets and a cleaner environment are all ahead of taxes on the list of Illinois voters' priorities.
A recent poll illustrates the complex political dynamics tapped by this race. WBBM-TV and the Daily Southtown Economist asked 866 registered voters whether they thought Mr. Hartigan could eliminate the surcharge and still finance education. Two-thirds said that they did not think he could and that he would have to raise other taxes instead, something Mr. Hartigan has carefully avoided ruling out.
Even among those who said they supported Mr. Hartigan, half thought he would have to raise other taxes.
Asked directly whether they favored or opposed keeping the tax surcharge to finance education, 52 percent favored keeping it and 35 percent were for elimination. The survey was conducted Oct. 13-15 by telephone and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Yet even with the overwhelming skepticism and considerable opposition toward Mr. Hartigan's major campaign proposal, the race remains close. Mr. Edgar leads Mr. Hartigan 44 percent to 39 percent, with 17 percent saying they were undecided or declining to express an opinion.
Mr. McKeon, the Hartigan poll taker, said this seeming contradiction is an illustration of how the frustration and cynicism of voters is influencing elections. "Maybe they don't think he can do it," Mr. McKeon said. "But they'd like to see him try."
 
 
 
TAX PROPOSALS ON THE BALLOT IN 8 STATES

 
 
OREGON
 The proposal would reduce property taxes on homeowners to $15 for every $1,000 assessed. Property taxes currently vary, depending on the city or town, but go as high as $35 for every $1,000.
 
CALIFORNIA
 One measure would require that two-thirds of voters, rather than a simple majority, approve any new state special taxes and would limit the rate on new state personal property taxes. Another proposal would impose a new surtax on sales of alcoholic beverages.
 
NEVADA
 Citizens will vote on two sales tax exemptions, one for university textbooks and the other for certain medallions that are authorized to bear the state seal. They will also take the second of two required votes on a constitutional amendment to ban the personal income tax. In the first vite, in 1988, voters approved the amendment.
 
MONTANA
 One proposal would eliminate virtually all state taxes, including income and property taxes, and substitute a 1 percent finance charge on all financial transactions. The other would add 25 cents to the state's 18-cent cigarette tax, which at 43 cents would be the highest in the nation.
 
MASSACHUSETTS
 The proposal would roll back, to 1988 levels, a long list of tax increases and government fees that were imposed in 1989 and 1990.
 
NEBRASKA
 One proposal would limit increase in state or local spending to 2 percent over that of the previous fiscal year unless it is approved by four-fifths of the legislature or a majority of the voters. Another proposal would cancel a sales tax increase and income tax increases used for state aid to schools.
 
UTAH
 The initiative would repeal all sales taxes on food, which vary from 5 to 6 percent, depending on the municipality.
 
COLORADO
 The proposal would limit future increases on taxes and spending and require voter approval for certain state and local tax increases.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The True Roots Of U.S. Decline

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
AS the United States struggles to retrieve its golden industrial past, Americans kick them selves for having dissipated the work ethic and the inventiveness that once made them kings in technology and manufacturing. And now along come some historians who say that the self-flagellation is not justified and the nation's troubles are not the result of a fall from grace.
What actually happened was more mundane, these experts in economic history explain. Americans in fact never lacked for ingenuity, farsightedness, hard work and good management. What set them apart and made the United States blossom as an industrial powerhouse was skill at exploiting abundant natural resources. This special advantage is gone today, through no one's fault, and so is the supremacy that it once bestowed. 
 Gavin Wright, an economics historian at Stanford University, develops this thesis in "The Origins of American Industrial Success, 1879-1940," the lead article in the latest issue of The American Economic Review, the profession's flagship journal. Economists do not often delve into history for explanations of the nation's woes, and Mr. Wright adds a fresh insight to the debate over the loss of status in manufacturing and technology.
"We tend to think that if we could just recapture entrepreneurial skill or improve education, then the United States would once again become the pre-eminent economic power," Mr. Wright said in an interview. "But that is misleading. It loses sight of the fact that a lot of our technological advantage stemmed from our abundant resources."
The Wright argument, shared by other historians, is this: Americans were never better thanothers at developing new technologies. The American advantage, until the 1950's, was in two areas. Nowhere else in the world was there so huge a national market: millions of consumers across a continent. And no other nation harnessed so abundant and varied a supply of inexpensive natural resources so early on.
Manufacturing, until the 1950's, essentially meant the conversion of resources into products. By rushing into the production of iron ore, coal, petroleum, copper, bauxite, zinc, phosphates, food and many other resources, the United States emerged as the superpower of the industrial world. And since the distinguishing American technologies were related to the all-important conversion of resources into products, the United States became the front-runner in technology, Mr. Wright argues.
No one matched the Americans in mining or in farm technology or in mass production techniques, starting with the mass production of weapons in Springfield, Mass., in the early 1800's. Like so many other breakthrough American inventions, the reaper and the combine, for example, helped tobring an abundant resource, in this case grain, to the growing mass of American consumers.
The canals and the nationwide railroads that emerged so rapidly in the United States in the 19th century served the goals of bringing resources to factories and products to marketplaces, says Paul David, another Stanford historian. The upshot was a dynamic economy, highly profitable for corporations, and all functioning prosperously within the nation's borders.
The American advantage disappeared by the 1960's. Mass markets that had developed in Europe and Asia became more prosperous than ever before. And other nations finally tapped their own resources, which then became part of a worldwide pool supplying a Japan or a France as easily and inexpensively as the United States.
Finally, manufacturing began to free itself from resources, particularly in the production of electronic products, which absorb little raw material. The technologies involved in their manufacture cross borders easily and cannot be captured for long as a source of income for a single country. "We are not going to get across-the-board technological leadership," Mr. David said. "It is an illusion that never really existed anyway for us or anyone else."
Other economists acknowledge that the Wright-David thesis offers a valuable insight, although some, like Kenneth Flamm of the Brookings Institution, argue that the American genius for invention is not so closely tied to natural resources. Whatever the truth, Mr. Wright's research suggests that capitalism does not have to be "one-country dominated," as Mr. Wright puts it.
Special circumstances gave Britain the dominant role and then the United States. "One view of capitalism, stemming from this history, is that it requires a world leader: the country with the most advanced technology," Mr. Wright said. "But capitalism can flourish in a world in which several nations function on an equal footing."

HEADLINE: THE BUDGET BATTLE
Behind the Dealing on Deficit Reduction, Deals That Could Swell the Deficit;
While Congress Trims the Budget, It Enlarges Programs (and Debt)

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Even as Congress trims some programs to reduce the Federal budget deficit, it is expanding other programs, and lawmakers acknowledge that savings achieved with great difficulty this year may soon be offset by added spending.
The new spending comes about because of old-fashioned pork-barrel projects, policy choices in favor of new or expanded programs and the deterioration of the economy, which is increasing demand for benefits like unemployment insurance and food stamps. 
 Whether any particular increase is good or bad is a political question with a subjective answer; what seems essential to one lawmaker or interest group may appear wasteful to others. But it is indisputable that Congress has quietly enacted appropriation laws that increase spending, often in districts represented by influential lawmakers, while they publicly proclaim the need for deficit reduction.
"The Federal debt is going from a quart to a gallon," said Gerald H. Miller, executive director of the National Association of State Budget Officers, "but Congress and the President are taking out only a cup."
 
Protests Over Medicaid
 As part of the budget package being negotiated on Capitol Hill, Congress is expanding Medicaid, for example, over vehement protests from the nation's governors, who say they will be saddled with more costs. The expansion of Medicaid would cost the Federal Government at least $400 million a year.
In appropriation bills for the current fiscal year, Congress has approved a $2.3 billion increase in spending for Federal highway projects, to $14.5 billion a year, and is providing $20 billion in new money for specific park, land, energy and water projects.
"This session of Congress has decided to vote again and again for pork barrel, to fund projects that may or may not be better than other competitive projects, and to fund them only because of who one may know on the Appropriations Committee or the leadership," said Representative Steve Bartlett, a Texas Republican who is one of many members of Congress to make such criticisms.
Mr. Bartlett said the largess was bipartisan. "There are projects in here for members of both parties," he said of one bill, which increases housing appropriations by 22 percent, to $9.5 billion in the current fiscal year.
Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, said one subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee recently received 2,800 written requests for park, land and water projects from various senators. "Those same senators then come in here with unctuous, pontificating statements about how, if we just freeze this or that, we could get the deficit under control," Mr. Bumpers said.
 
$5 Trillion Debt Limit
 To cover the increases in spending, Congress plans to raise the debt limit. Under budget plans adopted by the House of Representatives and the Senate, the Federal debt, which represents the accumulated total of all Federal borrowing, would soar to $5 trillion in 1995, from the current $3.2 trillion. When President Reagan took office in 1981, the debt was slighly less than $1 trillion.
A little-noticed provision of the deficit-reduction bill passed by the House would raise the statutory limit on the public debt to $5 trillion. If the higher limit is part of the final bill, Congress could avoid the annual ritual of increasing the debt ceiling. The ritual is politically embarrassing to lawmakers and occasionally brings the Government to the brink of default. When Congress fails to extend the debt limit, the Treasury must postpone new borrowing from the public, as it did last week.
There is virtually no way for the Government to reduce the debt unless it runs a budget surplus. A budget deficit in one year must be covered by further borrowing, which increases the debt and adds to interest costs in future years.
Net interest payments on the Federal debt were the fastest-growing major category of Federal spending in the 1980's. The increase in such payments, from $52.5 billion in 1980 to $169 billion in 1989, exceeded all the savings Mr. Reagan achieved in health, education, welfare and social service programs.
 
Dollars for Home Districts
 Representative Jamie L. Whitten, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, boasted that Congress had earmarked millions of dollars for water projects, highway construction and airport improvements in his Mississippi district.
Congress also earmarked $3.4 million for a highway demonstration project in Pittsfield, Mass., the home of Representative Silvio O. Conte, the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee. There was also money for a veterans' hospital in Northampton, Mass., and for a solar heating plant at the University of Massachusetts campus in Amherst, both in Mr. Conte's district.
The appropriation bills also set aside money for West Virginia University and for more than 20 public works projects in West Virginia, the home of Robert C. Byrd, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee.
Senator Ernest F. Hollings said that the new deficit-reduction package "guts the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law" by making it easier for Congress to avoid meeting the annual deficit targets in the law. Mr. Hollings, a South Carolina Democrat, was a co-author of the 1985 law.
As originally passed, the law stipulated that the budget should be balanced in the fiscal year that began on Oct. 1. The deficit, $221 billion in 1986, hovered in the range of $150 billion to $155 billion in the next three years, but shot up again in the fiscal year just ended. The Office of Management and Budget estimates that the deficit was a record $231 billion in the fiscal year that ended three weeks ago.
 
Cutting Here, Adding There
 Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, ranking Republican on the Veterans Affairs Committee, said he saw a "great inconsistency" in Congress's schizophrenic instincts: cutting some veterans programs by $620 million a year while expanding others by almost exactly the same amount.
Speaking of a new plan to make World War II veterans eligible for "readjustment counseling," Senator Alan K. Simpson said, "It boggles the mind that veterans of World War II, the hideous war that ended 45 years ago, are still having trouble readjusting to civilian life after military service."
Senator Pete Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, observed that "we all say, 'Spend less,' but we have more ideas and we want more things." Here are a few examples:
*The deficit-reduction measures passed by both houses of Congress would expand Medicaid to cover children from poor families longer, through age 12 under the House bill and age 18 in the Senate bill. Under current law, states must cover poor children through age 5. Pediatricians and public health experts applaud the expansion. But states pay, on the average, 44 percent of Medicaid costs, and the National Governors' Association expressed alarm at the cost of an expansion.
*Under the House bill, the Federal Government would pay Medicare premiums for low-income elderly people, and the Senate bill would allow states to offer such protection with a combination of Federal and state funds.
*Congress has just approved an appropriation bill that permits $14.5 billion in highway spending this year, up from $12.2 billion last year. President Bush requested $12 billion.
*House and Senate negotiators agreed last week to provide more than $1.6 billion to help poor people pay home heating costs, as against $1.4 billion last year. Mr. Bush requested $1.05 billion. Mr. Conte said the increase was needed because home heating oil had become "outrageously expensive" as a result of turmoil in the Middle East.
*Senator Claiborne Pell, the chief patron of student aid programs in Congress, is pushing new legislation, the Middle-Income Student Assistance Act, to expand eligibility for Federal grants.
The purpose, he said, was to help middle-income families pay for college and to reverse cutbacks made under President Reagan, when "eligibility was tightened so that only the most needy qualified."

HEADLINE: Salvador Arms Aid: Will Congress's Tactic Work?

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 21

 BODY:
The vote by the United States Congress to cut in half military aid to this country appears likely to cause political instability here. In the short run this may fortify hard-liners on both left and right, but in the long term it could also provide a lever to persuade the army to compromise with the rebels.
 Many labor unions and grass-roots organizations strongly support the decision to cut military aid as the only way to force the Government and army to accept sweeping political and military changes required to break a deadlock at the peace talks, which are to resume in Mexico by Nov. 4. 
 But many political leaders and military commanders here interpret the vote by the Senate on Friday, which followed a similar one by the House on June 27, less as a reaction to human rights abuses, like the slaying of six Jesuits last year, than a sign that Washington has given up on El Salvador and is seeking to end its involvement no matter the consequences.
"El Salvador is a headache that Washington feels it just has to get rid of," said one of the country's most senior military commanders. "Washington is preoccupied with Nicaragua, Panama and the Mideast."
The commander, who spoke on condition that he not be identified, noted that the Bush Administration had begun to talk privately about "Lebanizing" the conflict here, by which it means treating El Salvador like Lebanon: pulling out and waiting to see what happens.
In Washington, White House officials say the Administration is unhappy with the Senate move to cut the aid pending specific steps toward peace in El Salvador. They say that they will try to persuade lawmakers to change the legislation at a conference between the Senate and the House and that no decision on whether to veto it has been made.
 
Hard-Liners Gain Ground
 In El Salvador, military commanders and some Western diplomats say the Congressional vote could fortify hard-liners at both ends of the political spectrum. If the Congressional decision becomes law, they say, it might make the rebels more intransigent and unite military reformists and anti-American extremists, who feel that American aid is not worth the accompanying constraints, including those intended to reduce human rights violations.
The hard-liners on both left and right have appeared in the ascendancy in recent months. Negotiators for the insurgents, under intense pressure from troops in the field, have backed away from the first formal accord reached between the two sides, a human rights agreement signed three months ago. Since then, the insurgents' proposals have been less conciliatory, apparently intended primarily to aggravate divisions within the armed forces.
The new tactics of the rebels stem in large part from divisions within their movement. Once committed Marxists, the most senior commanders now describe themselves as social democrats fighting for pluralism, a mixed economy and a negotiated end to the civil war, which has killed more than 70,000 people. But field commanders and rank-and-file troops have been more hesitant to make the ideological switch. They are now generally more radical and more committed to military victory than the leaders, who spend most of their time outside the country.
 
'What's the Difference?'
 Troops in the field are also more likely to dismiss a Washington decision to slash aid as a meaningless publicity gesture. The rank and file and their commanders say it does not matter if the United States halves the weaponry it supplies if the army continues to use the ammunition to attack the civilian population from helicopter gunships. "One bullet or two -- what's the difference?" a field commander in the northern province of Chalatenango asked recently.
The immediate military effect of the $42.5 million aid cut would likely be small. Forewarned by the debate, the army has forearmed itself by stockpiling weapons, ammunition and spare parts. President Alfredo Cristiani, who already is facing an explosive economic crisis, will have extreme difficulty in fulfilling a pledge to make up the military's financial shortfall by cutting social programs. Military commanders say the army is likely to face material shortages within a year. That, diplomats say, may press it into accepting previously unacceptable guerrilla demands.
But the cut in American military aid, which currently pays for the entire Salvadoran defense budget except salaries, is likely to have an immediate psychological effect. At a recent six-hour staff meeting between the high command and second-level officers from around the country, there was no mention of the killing of the six Jesuit priests, the incident that led to the Congressional campaign to reduce military aid. Instead, members of the high command said, they were questioned about their plans to make up for the impending shortfall.
 
U.S. Accused of Appeasement
 The result already has been new influence for right-wing militants, who argue that the United States is pursuing a policy of appeasement toward the rebels. They are pushing the army to step up the war by cracking down on rebel sympathizers. In a sign of the radicals' increasing influence, a small but growing number of military officers are for the first time in years privately discussing plans to round up and kill leftist civilians. Some officers say they are only waiting for an expected guerrilla offensive to start the operation.
"The brake is coming off," a Western diplomat said. "As the U.S. role decreases, there is less and less reason for the radicals to take a back seat."
In recent months, military hard-liners and their civilian allies have picked up some support from so-called army reformers, who believe the high command is corrupt and inefficient. Convinced that Washington has run out of patience and wants to end the longest American-supported counterinsurgency campaign since the Vietnam War, they are scrambling to prepare for what is coming to be called the "post-gringo era."
The emerging coalition is a clear threat to a tightknit group of so-called pragmatic senior officers viewed by Washington as the key to a negotiated settlement. But so far at least President Cristiani's uncompromising support for the high command has undercut the right-wing extremists' repeated efforts to seize control of the armed forces.
