HEADLINE: New York Banks See The Logic Of Merging

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Doubting their ability to prosper as independent companies, New York's largest banks are eyeing their neighbors, each wondering which of the others would make the best partner.
Faced with rising losses on commercial real estate loans, and prospects of even greater losses on loans of all kinds as the economy weakens, executives at several of New York's largest banks are well aware that big changes are needed. The logic of bank mergers seems irrefutable, offering the combined institutions the cost savings and greater financial strength they need to compete domestically and against more and more powerful foreign rivals. 
 "Mergers involving the New York banks have to happen," said Gary Parr, head of the banking group at Wasserstein, Perella & Company.
Bankers, industry analysts and Federal regulators agree that the first merger among large banks is increasingly becoming a matter of when it will occur, not if it will. Should the economy weaken further, they say, banks will be driven into each other's arms as the losses on loans mount.
 
Logic for Mergers
 For consumers, bank mergers would probably mean that some branches would be shut down, but that little would be changed for such services as credit cards and personal loans. And, in theory, a stronger and more efficient bank, the goal of any merger, should be a more stable and steady source of lending to individuals and small businesses.
Early signs of activity on the bank-merger front abound. Wall Street merger specialists, eager to earn multimillion-dollar fees for helping arrange a deal, have submitted dozens of proposals to their bank clients. Rumors of merger talks circulate almost daily among bankers; the three New York banks most often mentioned as likely merger candidates are the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation.
Leading bankers have acknowledged in recent months that mergers make sense. Walter V. Shipley, chairman of Chemical Bank, has called mergers of big banks "a natural development." Thomas S. Johnson, the president of Manufacturers Hanover, who was the No. 2 executive at Chemical Bank until last December, says the same thing. And Thomas Labrecque, the new chairman at Chase Manhattan, has declared, "The 1990's are going to be an era of consolidation."
 
Federal Reserve's Views
 For its part, the Federal Reserve Board, which regulates American banking, endorses the concept of bank mergers as a way to strengthen the banking system. But Fed officials deny that they are encouraging any specific deals.
The bankers themselves are tight-lipped. Echoing the response of most of his peers on the delicate subject of merger talks, Mr. Shipley of Chemical Bank said, "I won't speculate about hypothetical discussions."
But for all the apparent logic of big-bank mergers, formidable obstacles remain involving finances, tradition and even personalities.
One of the biggest problems, Mr. Parr and other analysts say, is that before a newly merged bank reaps the benefits of cost reductions, it must bear the large one-time expense of making severance payments to employees and closing duplicated offices. With financial conditions already weak, any merger would require deft financial engineering and perhaps also new capital from outside investors willing to help pay the costs of consolidating the merger banks in the hopes of profits later.
 
18 Months of Pain
 "It's a serious dilemma," Mr. Parr said. "Before you get the full savings in 18 to 24 months, you have to bear some pain."
Yet the benefits of a merger involving New York banks like Chase, Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover could be substantial. Chase and Chemical earlier this month announced third-quarter losses of $623 million and $43.7 million, respectively, as well as steep cuts in their dividends.
Manufacturers Hanover has been profitable in recent quarters, but is a far smaller company since it sold its consumer-finance and mortgage finance units and 60 percent of its business-lending unit to raise the cash it needed to survive in the late 1980's.
Assuming that a merger of two banks in the same area would result in a 30 percent reduction on non-interest expenses at one of the banks, the savings could amount to $1.07 billion for Chase, $795 million for Chemical and $619 million for Manufacturers Hanover.
One of the most-often-rumored combinations involves Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover, in part because Mr. Johnson was at Chemical until last December, when he crossed the street to become the heir apparent to the top job at Manufacturers Hanover. Based on his insider's knowledge of both companies, analysts assume that Mr. Johnson could help forge a merger agreement without the cumbersome review of each other's financial health that total strangers would require.
 
Sure-Fire Profits
 In a city where it is not unusual to see two bank branches on one corner, mergers among banks are widely seen as a sure-fire way to increase profits. Besides eliminating duplicate branch offices, mergers would allow big cuts in overlapping administrative and operating costs like computer systems and highly paid executives.
The banking business is so fragmented in New York City that mergers would be not expected to create one institution that could dominate the area.
The job cuts, which would involve thousands of workers, would be a painful jolt for the New York City economy, which has already lost 11,000 banking jobs since 1987.
But for the banks involved, the money saved could be used to rebuild the financial strength needed to satisfy Federal regulators worried about the health of American banks and their ability to compete with big foreign banks.
If New York's banks were financially stronger, they could afford to acquire or merge with other banks. By diversifying their business, they would reduce their vulnerability to a downturn in the local economy.
That is clearly the unfolding strategy at the Bank of New York. J. Carter Bacot, chairman at the Bank of New York Company, has cut more than 3,000 jobs and reduced expenses by more than $150 million annually since acquiring the Irving Bank Corporation in 1988. But as the regional economy has soured, Mr. Bacot said he would prefer to look further afield for his next acquisition.
 
Dangers of Concentration
 "The experience of Texas and New England shows the danger of too much concentration in a single region," he noted.
When the mergers come, they are likely to be much different from the rough-and-tumble takeovers of the 1980's, when Wall Street deal makers could force mergers on unwilling corporations. Given the weakened financial condition of the country's largest banks, the coming mergers are likely to be exchanges of stock shaped by bankers in private meetings. Because Federal law prevents commercial concerns from controlling banks, the universe of potential buyers is limited to other banking companies.
Richard J. Barrett, an investment banker and head of the financial institutions group at Salomon Brothers, said recently: "We may not see some of the big banks move until their condition becomes so unpalatable that they don't have much other choice. The lack of capital to make their own acquisitions could force a lot of banks to seek partners as the best last recourse."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Paris Futures Market Starts New Contract

BYLINE: By JACQUES NEHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
Seeking to expand its base overseas and to bolster its challenge to London as Europe's leading futures market, the futures and options market here began trading a contract last week that is linked to the European Currency Unit.
The futures market, the Marche a Terme International de France, or Matif, is banking on the new long-term bond contract to increase its international allure and give it an edge over London in a running battle to become Europe's main futures market. 
 French officials hope to make the contract available to American and Japanese institutional investors through Globex, the long-delayed off-hours electronic trading system that is expected to begin operation next year.
 
'Very Strategic Product'
 "This is a very strategic product for us," said Gerard Pfauwadel, president of Matif S.A. "It's a way for us to increase international attraction, not only for the Matif but for Paris as a financial center."
Some market professionals said the European Currency Unit contract might face hard going, pointing to the failure of a short-term currency unit futures contract begun by the London International Financial Futures Exchange last fall. That contract is barely alive, currently generating fewer than 100 contracts a day.
"I think it will take the Matif time to get this contract off the ground," said Michael Jenkins, the chief executive of the London exchange. "The ECU bond, whether short-term or long-term, has a very important future, but the big question is when that will be."
 
Enthusiasm vs. Indifference
 He added that while attitudes were changing, the currency unit was still backed by a "small group of vocal enthusiasts, while there's a much larger group who are indifferent."
Matif officials say the decision to introduce a currency unit contract reflects the heady growth experienced by the Matif since it opened in 1986 amid a wave of financial deregulation in France. The market has built its reputation on a long-term French bond contract, called the notional contract, which in recent years has been joined by other products linked to French interest rates and also a contract on the French stock market index.
On the currency unit contract's first two days of trading on Thursday and Friday, volume totaled about 6,400 lots, or contracts, and a Matif spokeswoman called that satisfying. Volume on the notional contract was much heavier, with more than 156,000 lots traded.
 
London Ahead Again
 The Matif established itself as a major rival to the London futures exchange, which was founded four years earlier, in 1982. Last year, Paris overtook London as the leading futures market in Europe with a volume of 25.6 million contracts, compared with 23.9 million in London. This year, London has moved back ahead of Paris.
Even with its essentially French product range, the Matif has been able to attract some foreign interest. Orders originating abroad account for more than 20 percent of the Matif's total volume, and of the exchange's 100 clearing members, 29 are foreign banks or brokers.
"We consider the Matif a leading market on a worldwide scale," said Eric Bertier, general manager of derivative products for Paine Webber France S.A. "If you want to be a player in capital markets, you can't afford not to be on the Matif."
Paine Webber earlier this year joined the Matif by absorbing a 35-member team from Drexel Burnham Lambert France S.A. after Drexel's liquidation.
 
Liquidity and Openness
 Mr. Bertier compared the market favorably with the much larger Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, noting that the Matif offers ample liquidity and openness. "You know what's happening and why," he said. "It's a very pleasant market to work on."
Other clearing members of the Matif include J. P. Morgan; Shearson Lehman Hutton; Bankers Trust; Goldman, Sachs; Salomon Brothers and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
Volume at the Matif continues to be dominated by the long-term notional contract, which is representative of several French treasury bonds with a life of 7 to 10 years and a 10 percent coupon. In 1989, the notional contract accounted for volume of 15 million lots, or about 60,500 a day. An option on the notional contract generated an additional 7.1 million transactions. Together, the two products provided 86 percent of the Matif's volume.
A short-term interest rate contract, linked to the three-month Paris interbank offered rate, generated 2.3 million lots traded last year. An option on that contract was introduced in the spring.
 
Euromark Contract Failed
 The Matif's first attempt to move beyond French products, with a futures contract on the three-month Euromark, met with failure. In the first nine months, the contract generated volume of only 390,000 lots.
In beginning the European Currency Unit contract, the Matif is betting that the unit -- a weighted basket of the 12 European Community currencies currently valued at about $1.35 -- will expand in use and importance as a major world currency. A plan for monetary union, written by Jacques Delors, the president of the European Commission, the community's executive body, suggested that such a currency could be based on the currency unit. That proposal and other aspects of the discussion of European monetary union have led to heated debates among the member nations of the European Community.
 
More Issues Expected
 Even while the debate over monetary union continues, European governments are showing faith in the currency unit by issuing debt in the theoretical currency, and Mr. Pfauwadel expects these issues to expand greatly in the near future. In addition, the new European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, established to aid Eastern Europe, is to be capitalized with 10 billion European Currency Units, he noted.
Since 1981, bond issues denominated in the currency units have soared. By the end of 1989, the value of outstanding fixed-rate currency unit Eurobonds totaled 56.4 billion currency units, with 109 issues worth 10.9 billion units made last year alone.
For now, the new currency unit contract is based on two currency unit French treasury bonds. Within a few months, the Matif plans to reinforce the contract's foundation with two Italian currency unit treasury bonds and a currency unit bond issued by the European Investment Bank.
 
Banks Seen as Prime Market
 Matif officials hope European banks will be the primary market for the new contract because they are currently the major holders of bonds denominated in currency units. The contract would permit bondholders to hedge against interest rate fluctuations that could erode the value of the bonds.
It would also provide spread opportunities for traders seeking to take advantage of fluctuations in long-term interest rates on currency units, French francs or marks.
Dominique Depras, who manages Matif operations for J. P. Morgan, said he was "completely favorable to this project." He predicted that the contract would be attractive "in the early stages for professionals, but as liquidity appears, investors and institutions will come."

HEADLINE: Reviews/Music;
Turning to Gilbert and Sullivan for Salvation

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Over the last year, two of New York's small opera companies that specialize in the Gilbert and Sullivan repertory, the Light Opera of Manhattan and the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players, have fallen prey to financial stresses and curtailed their activities. Both hope to be reborn, and one hopes they will be.
In the meantime, fans of W. S. Gilbert's clever librettos and Sir Arthur Sullivan's witty, hummable music might want to urge the New York City Opera to expand its activities in this well-loved realm. The company does have its foot in the door: Its Lotfi Mansouri production of "The Mikado," which returned to the New York State Theater on Saturday afternoon, is the most enjoyable of the operetta stagings that Beverly Sills brought to the City Opera repertory.
 
 True Savoyards will note, of course, that the production does make some compromises with tradition. When the production opened in 1984, Mr. Mansouri persuaded the singers not to indulge in fake British accents, and he replaced some of the customary horseplay with Patricia Birch's elegantly amusing choreography. Those touches remain, and they seem sensible for a production in a large house. The staging's less controversial attractions are Thierry Bosquet's bright, fanciful costumes and appealingly minimal stage sets.
This season's first cast brings back several singers who have sung their roles from the start and adds a few voices new to their roles. It was an exceptionally even cast, with no real weak points, although one might quibble with aspects of this or that characterization.
For example, James Billings paced his portrayal of Ko-Ko with real mastery and never failed to get the laughs he sought. Vocally, too, he was in fine shape. But at times he seemed to be drawing his inspiration from far and wide without blending his influences into a consistent persona, as he has in previous seasons. A single speech might include plausible imitations of W. C. Fields, Oliver Hardy, Lou Costello, Bert Lahr and Truman Capote, with the seams showing.
The other singers who returned from past seasons included Joseph McKee, whose blend of pomposity and corruption makes for a wonderful portrayal of Pooh-Bah, the multiple-office-holding bureaucrat, and Richard McKee, who easily managed the balance of ferocity and mirth required in the title role.
The newcomers to the production bring greater vocal power and stability to their roles than some past singers and are therefore a welcome lot. Most striking was Carroll Freeman's Nanki-Poo. His sound was tightly focused, if occasionally slightly steely; but he shaped his lines with real sensitivity, and he acted the role with an easy naturalness. Lisa Saffer's sweet, well-supported soprano suited Yum-Yum's music nicely, and she played the role with a comic flair that made her a fine match for Mr. Freeman. And Josepha Gayer was an imperious but not unsympathetic Katisha.
The cast also included William Parcher as Pish-Tush, Bronwyn Thomas as Pitti-Sing and Michele McBride as Peep-Bo.
David Pfeiffer, the production's stage director, moved the singers around the stage economically much of the time, but with flamboyance where it seemed necessary. And the orchestra played with clarity and precision for Chris Nance, who took the score at a comfortably lively pace.

GRAPHIC: Photos: James Billings as Ko-Ko and Lisa Saffer as Yum-Yum in New York City Opera's "Mikado." (Photographs by Martha Swope Associates)

HEADLINE: Trade Talks Stall on Farm Issues

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 21

 BODY:
A four-year round of negotiations to liberalize world trade is threatened with collapse as a result of the European Community's failure to accept even a modest plan to reduce farm subsidies, officials from the United States and many other nations say.
These officials say the inability of the 12 community nations to agree even among themselves to put forward a modest proposal to cut farm subsidies is making it more and more difficult to complete global trade talks. The deadline for an agreement is less than seven weeks away. 
 "Until they can come forward with an offer, there is no basis for negotiations, and time is running out," said Julius Katz, the deputy United States trade representative. "I don't know at what point the situation becomes desperate, but we're getting there."
 
Complaints About Subsidies
 Officials of the United States, Canada, Argentina and many third world countries contend that the community's large subsidies for farmers have encouraged huge overproduction of agricultural products. Officials of these nations, who say their farmers produce at costs far lower than Europe's, complain that European farmers, helped by community export subsidies, dump their excess production on the world market at rock-bottom prices.
American officials say the European practices cost United States farmers billions of dollars in income each year by driving down world farm prices and closing off markets for American products.
President Bush has said that the talks, which involve agriculture and 14 other areas, are his highest trade priority. But he and officials from Canada, Argentina, Australia and several other nations have threatened not to sign a comprehensive trade pact unless they win substantial cuts in farm subsidies.
 
Resistance From Europe
 The European Community has steadfastly resisted large-scale cutbacks in agriculture-protection policies, which economists say cost industrial nations $250 billion a year through higher taxes and higher food prices.
The community's executive commission has proposed reducing subsidies by 30 percent over 10 years, but last Friday the community's badly divided farm ministers refused to back the commission's plan. The community thus missed the Oct. 15 deadline for making negotiating proposals on farm trade.
Britain, Denmark and the Netherlands supported the commission's plan, while the farm ministers of France and Germany led the opposition. They contend that a 30 percent cut in subsidies would imperil Europe's 10 million farmers -- a powerful bloc of voters.
 
A U.S. Proposal
 The French and German ministers suggested that it would be better to have no global trade agreement than one that goes too far to meet American demands to slash farm subsidies. Hurt by drought and plunging livestock prices, tens of thousands of French farmers have demonstrated this year, often violently, to complain that subsidies are already too low.
The farm minister of France, Louis Mermaz, said he did not think a collapse of the trade talks would be catastrophic "if the community doesn't want to sacrifice its agriculture sector."
The farm subsidy debate has created friction within the community's executive commission. Raymond MacSharry, the community's agricultural commissioner, is fighting to keep subsidies high and has clashed with Frans Andriessen, the community's trade commissioner, who wants to take a more flexible, less protectionist approach in dealing with Washington's demands.
On Monday, American trade negotiators made a proposal to slash farm export subsidies by 90 percent over 10 years and cut overall farm supports by 75 percent over that period.
 
Argentina's Threat
 At trade talks in Geneva last week, Argentina's farm minister, Felipe Sola, said his nation would walk out of the negotiations if the European Community did not make a broader offer to cut agricultural subsidies. Mr. Sola said one reason for the third world debt crisis was that developing nations had lost $35 billion a year in farm exports as a result of the industrial world's heavy export subsidies and other trade distortions.
Trade officials say Australia, New Zealand, Canada and other large food exporters might walk out with Argentina if the community remains intransigent on farm trade.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Katz, the deputy trade representative, said that in the farm negotiations, "the situation is a large part of the world versus the European Community."
 
Liberalized Trade Rules
 The current talks, known as the Uruguay Round because they began in Punta del Este in 1986, seek to liberalize some $1 trillion in trade not covered by international trade rules. If the talks succeed, trade in apparel, financial services, telecommunications and pharmaceuticals, as well as copyright rules, would for the first time be brought under liberal international trade rules.
The round of talks, which involves 105 nations, is scheduled to conclude in ministerial-level talks in Brussels from Dec. 3 to Dec. 7.
"It's a brave man who says we can pick up all the pieces in time for Brussels," said a trade official at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Geneva-based organization under whose auspices the trade talks are being held. "We have reached agreement in a whole range of areas, but what's crucial right now is what happens in agriculture."
With the community's farm ministers failing to back a plan, European foreign ministers will seek to agree on a proposal for trade talks when they meet Monday in Luxembourg. If the foreign ministers fail, then the community's prime ministers will wrestle with the issue when they meet next weekend in Rome.
 
No Subsidy Reduction Target
 European officials say Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany recently called Jacques Delors, president of the executive commission, to say the commission's proposal to cut subsidies 30 percent was unacceptable, contending it was far too severe to farmers. Many officials say Mr. Kohl wants to strongly defend farmer interests in anticipation of the first all-German elections on Dec. 2.
The commission proposes no specific target on reducing export subsidies, but hints that such cuts would be discussed. Several European farm ministers said, however, that they were worried about cutting export subsidies, an area that American officials say particularly distorts trade flows.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 23, 1990, Monday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about world trade negotiations misidentified Frans Andriessen of the European Community. He is its trade commissioner. A report in the Currents column of The Home Section on Oct. 4 about the Metro bus tunnel in Seattle misidentified a contributing artist. She is Laura Sindell, not Laura Sidwell.

HEADLINE: Strawberry's Next Steps?

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 21

 BODY:
On the day after the World Series ended, the baseball marketplace opened to prospective free agents, and they included the most intriguing and maybe the most expensive member of this year's class, Darryl Strawberry of the Mets.
Close friends said that Strawberry had left his home on Long Island in recent days and once more had separated from his wife, Lisa. He was said to be staying in Los Angeles, where his mother and brother live and where he has maintained a home. 
 For months, he has wavered on whether he wanted to stay with the team. In June, when the Mets generated their best winning streak of the season, he said he would stay. In September, as they idled in second place, Strawberry intimated that he was leaving. When the season ended in early October, he said he would file for free agency but would listen to the Mets' offer.
 Officials in the Mets' front office reported they had not held serious talks yet with Strawberry or his agent, Eric Goldschmidt of Los Angeles, who did not return calls to his office.
 For the next 15 days, players with more than six years in the big leagues may file letters of intent to enter the free-agent market, if they are no longer under contract to their clubs. But during that time, they may negotiate contract terms only with their old club. Other teams may approach them in general terms, but not in economic terms. However, after 15 days, it's a free market.
A highly placed management official of the Los Angeles Dodgers was asked if the Dodgers would try to sign Strawberry, who has said that they were probably his first choice, if he did not stay with the Mets. "We're going to try," the official said.
Three players who did file for free agency today were the outfielder Rob Deer of the Milwaukee Brewers and the pitchers Joe Price of the Baltimore Orioles and Jeff Robinson of the Yankees.

HEADLINE: Bonn and Tokyo as Global Police

 BODY:
There's rising sentiment in Germany and Ja-
pan, the hated Axis of World War II, to send troops abroad again. But this time it's in the cause of peacekeeping. Should the two countries amend their Constitutions so they can help in situations like the Persian Gulf crisis? Short of that, should they enact laws permitting a non-combat role?
The answer is not easy. War memories linger. Few countries are eager to open doors for such powerful, competitive nations. Yet it's hard to imagine future collective security and peacekeeping operations without them. 
 To sustain such operations requires nations with worldwide interests, money and manpower, and there aren't many. The list always comes down to the U.S., Britain, and sometimes France and Italy, in conjunction with a regional state or two. It's only a matter of time before Americans tire of such a lonely and costly role -- and ask with rising impatience, When will Bonn and Tokyo start carrying their share?
In short, it's likely that future peace operations will depend on the participation of the Germans and Japanese. Many of their leaders understand that and are already calling for constitutional changes. Gerhard Stoltenberg, the German Defense Minister, says it's "unsatisfactory" for German forces to be restricted to the territory of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Prime Minister Kaifu of Japan has gone further. His Cabinet favors legislation that would permit thousands of soldiers to serve behind the lines in Saudi Arabia. But a divided Parliament has to approve a step many Japanese view as a slippery evasion of the Constitution.
The first issue for Bonn and Tokyo is how to participate. Mr. Kaifu proposes economic support plus a non-combat role. It goes without saying that countries as wealthy as Japan and Germany should contribute aid. And while non-combatant status might pass muster with their left-wing parties, it won't wash in the U.S. Genuine collective security has to mean that Tokyo and Bonn are prepared to fight as well as to finance.
The second issue is the constitutional basis for participation. Should they be able to dispatch forces unilaterally? Probably not. The right to unilateral action seems a step beyond what their own political constituencies desire and too much for their anxious neighbors to swallow all at once.
What about limiting themselves to sending forces only if specifically authorized by the United Nations? That's too restrictive. It would preclude sending German and Japanese forces to the Persian Gulf today, or in similar situations.
Perhaps the least troublesome approach would be constitutional changes permitting force deployments abroad only as part of collective security and peacekeeping operations. That would reduce the chances of unilateral action, or inaction. It would also integrate German and Japanese forces into a larger multilateral force.
Both nations have matured as democracies, and as responsible international citizens. They already play full and vital roles in virtually every sector except collective security. Now, in the post-cold war era, they are both needed to make collective security viable, and collective.

HEADLINE: Ancient Tribes Didn't Vanish, They Just Moved

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
Rejecting two generations of academic dogma, archeologists now believe that prehistoric Indian tribes of the Southwest pursued an unusual pattern of episodic settlement until the arrival of the Spanish. They constructed dizzying cliff dwellings or huge settlements in the arid flatlands every few generations, then abandoned them as a snake might shed its skin.
These conclusions, archeologists say, have wide ramifications for understanding how other civilizations evolved.
The early communities of the Anasazi, and the lesser-known Hohokam and Mogollon Indians, waxed and waned in irregular rhythms as their members trekked across a precarious landscape of sagebrush, pinon trees, rocks and sand, stopping every few generations to build towns, irrigate fields and plant and harvest corn and squash before moving on.
Archeologists have long been puzzled by this pattern of abandonment, so different from the lockstep evolutionary progression attributed to the great early civilizations of the Middle East and Europe: from hunting and foraging to farming, from farming to the construction of villages, and from the construction of villages to the rise of city-states and empires.
But George J. Gumerman of the Center for Archeological Investigations at Southern Illinois University said, "We now have the data to show that this was a way cultures evolved before civilization, before the city-states."
"What we're looking at," he went on, "are patterns in which people who had done dramatic building then reverted to simpler forms of existence and didn't have such a dramatic impact on the environment. We've got the data now to see these more ephemeral phases in prehistory."
Paul Fish, an archeologist with the Arizona State Museum in Tucson, said the areas from southern Colorado and Utah to the Mexican border "were like lights going on and off." He spoke at an unusual conference of Southwestern archaeologists at the Santa Fe Institute this month. The conference, like one a year ago at the School of American Research in Santa Fe, was an attempt to look more deeply into the pulsating patterns of development and retrenchment in Southwestern cultures. But the format of the recent conference was a deviation from normal academic patterns.
<> To stimulate experts to think differently about the conclusions they might draw from the burials, tools, pottery, dwellings and garbage they have unearthed, 18 archeologists and anthropologists were closeted for a week with physicists, computer scientists, a demographer, a molecular biologist and a businessman.
The result, Mr. Gumerman said, was "to help set the agenda" for Southwestern archeology for the next few years.
"This kind of thing helps us see things on a bigger scale," said Ben Nelson, an anthropologist at the State University of New York at Buffalo. "Every other conference I've been to is just populated with archeologists. There's been no programmatic attempt to put people from different disciplines together and force them to talk. This has been really spectacular."
Southwestern archeologists, he added, "used to associate early occupations with subsistence survival strategy, then went along a continuum, with the other end being more complex farming and larger groups." But he said careful study of the evidence shows a different pattern: episodic settlement.
The archeologists' conclusions, now working their way into graduate students' textbooks, have in part solved one of the central mysteries of Southwestern archeology: what happenned to the Anasazi (An-ah-SAH-zi)? The question has been posed by generations of scholars and laymen awed by the makers of the multi-storied cliff dwellings in Chaco Canyon in northwestern New Mexico and the complex system of roads that radiated out to other smaller Anasazi sites.
The answer seems to be that they kept building communities and deserting them as long as the new European settlers allowed, but the names by which the Indians were known changed as the range of their wanderings decreased. Instead of "Anasazi," a word from the Athabascan language of the later-coming Navajo Indians which means "enemy old ones," the later generations were known by the names they still carry: Zuni, Hopi, Acoma.
<HD>Answers Provoke Questions
 Similarly, the Hohokam (Ho-ho-KAHM) cultures of prehistoric Arizona, which built huge ceremonial "ball courts" reminiscent of the ancient cultures of central Mexico, and intricate irrigation systems that supported complex agriculture, eventually were known as the Pima, the name some of their descendants carry today.
The resolution of these questions, however, has left a host of new ones still unanswered. In particular, archeologists and anthropologists want to know what factors influenced the episodic odyssey of the prehistoric Indians. Studies over the last decade have combined analysis of tree rings, which can determine annual rainfall, with analysis of water tables to see if the abandonments coincided with periods of drought.
But thus far the studies have proved inconclusive. Although there is ample evidence for a great drought in northern New Mexico and Arizona in the late 13th century, a time when some of the major settlements were abandoned, Linda Cordell, an anthropologist at the California Academy of Sciences, points out that some sites were being constructed in the dry areas at the peak of the drought.
 Other explanations have also proved imperfect. For much of this century, scholars theorized that the Anasazi had moved into the cliff dwellings for defensive purposes and that these Pueblo people were constantly at war, either with each other or with Athabascan and Ute interlopers from the north.
But Steve Lekson, an anthropologist with the Museum of New Mexico, said he believed there was not much evidence for "organized nastiness." In his view, the archeological sites have not turned up enough skeletons with arrowheads in their rib cages, axes in their skulls or other signs of violent battles and deaths to support a theory of abandonments in time of war.
 
Few Clues From Skeletons
 A third possibility explored at the seminar was that disease became more prevalent the longer a community stayed in one place. Deborah Martin, a physical anthropologist at Hampshire College, said at the conference that there were sketchy signs of tuberculosis in some skeletons which long predated the arrival of the Spanish. Overall, Dr. Martin and Dr. Nelson said, the amount of skeletal material from any one site at any one time is seldom adequate to draw any general conclusions about disease and death.
"The question is not 'Where did the Anasazi go?' " said Murray Gell-Mann, a physicist at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena and an avid student of Southwestern prehistory. "The question is, why would many of these complex cultural phenomena disappear and others survive? It happened in 1150, in 1300, in 1425, and curiously enough, the last is the one we know least about."
Chaco Canyon's cliff dwellings were abruptly abandoned in 1150, but the Mesa Verde settlements of the Anasazi on the plateaus of southern Colorado and Utah continued until 1300.Soon thereafter, however, there were only isolated, scattered settlements in this once-flourishing area, and new waves of construction had taken place along the Little Colorado River in northwestern Arizona and along the Rio Grande in northern New Mexico.
Over the next century, however, these central areas of settlement shrank dramatically. Other widely settled areas, like the Casas Grandes culture in the northwestern corner of Mexico, had virtually disappeared by 1450.
For the Santa Fe Institute, a six-year-old group of computer scientists, mathematicians and biologists who study complex systems, the questions raised by the new findings in Southwestern prehistory have parallels in fields as diverse as linguistics, biology and economics, raising common questions about why systems get more complex and why complex systems disintegrate.
"What I hope for in a conference like this," said Dr. Gell-Mann, "is that it would have some effect on stimulating people to think about complex systems broadly, whether human systems or biological systems or computer models. Another more modest objective is to come out with some ideas of what the archeologists should study next."

HEADLINE: How U.S. Can Pressure Beijing on Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A. M. Rosenthal, in "The Price for Silence" (column, Sept. 28) wisely chides the Administration for failing to hold the Chinese Government accountable for its continued violations of human rights. Unless Beijing knows that we will not tolerate the executions, jailings and other abuses detailed -- and predicted -- in the new Asia Watch report, we are bound to see even greater repressions mainly at the hands of the newly reinvigorated People's Liberation Army.
After years of giving the military the lowest priority on its list of "four modernizations," Beijing has increased its military budget by a whopping 15.2 percent. With the cold war ended and the major powers agreeing to reduce their strategic and conventional forces, and with the Soviet and Vietnamese borders quiet, there are hardly any fresh external threats to warrant the increased emphasis on the military. The only plausible explanation is the post-Tiananmen preoccupation of Beijing's leaders with securing and maintaining control of the country, and their decision to make the army their chief instrument of control.
Until now, army loyalty to the political leadership was not a certainty: some commanders refused to use their troops against the pro-democracy demonstrators at Tiananmen, and afterward there were murmurs of dissension in the ranks over the crackdown's brutality. This apparently led Deng Xiaoping, Li Peng and their colleagues to conclude that they must be assured of the army's absolute loyalty to be sure of maintaining power themselves. Accordingly, they recently placed new emphasis on political and ideological indoctrination: troops must now attend daily one-and-a-half-hour political sessions, and officers through the highest ranks must also attend appropriate classes. Through these measures, and the new infusion of funds to keep the commanders happy, Beijing's leaders expect to have at their command a loyal and powerful military whose main mission will be the suppression of dissent among the Chinese people.
We can do little to prevent the strengthening of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, but we can do things to curb its use. For example, the greater budgetary allotment to the military means fewer allocations for economic development. We can therefore make trade, investments and other aspects of economic cooperation contingent upon the tolerance of dissent and the reduction, if not elimination of arbitrary arrests and executions. We can also stop behaving as if China did us a favor by siding with us in the Middle East crisis: it did so out of desire to better its overall relations with us, and because it did not want to jeopardize its growing ties with Saudi Arabia, which it recently wooed away diplomatically from Taiwan.
We have the ways to put pressure on the Chinese Government to make it observe basic norms of decent human conduct; what we need is the will.
 
LORNA HAHN
Executive Director
Association on Third World Affairs
Washington, Oct. 3, 1990

HEADLINE: Study of Peace Corps Shows Big Demand but Short Supply

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Though its services have never been more in demand, the Peace Corps is hobbled by deficiencies in recruiting and training and is unable to retain its volunteers, according to an assessment by the staff of a Congressional committee made public today.
In an era when the cold war is winding down, fragile democracies are emerging and there is an international push for sustainable economic development, "the Peace Corps has entered an era of unparalleled opportunity for service," the report said. 
 Yet the corps has been reduced by budget cuts and weakened by a lack of administrative commitment over the last 20 years, said Representative John Conyers Jr., chairman of the House Committee on Government Operations, whose staff wrote the report.
"We think the Peace Corps has been seriously undervalued in the last 20 years," Mr. Conyers said.
Initiated by President John F. Kennedy in 1961, the Peace Corps caught the imagination of thousands of idealistic youth infused with more enthusiasm than experience. As volunteerism waned, the Peace Corps went out of fashion.
Today only 10,000 people apply each year for 6,300 places, barely a fifth of the volunteer applications that were received in 1964.
Based on a seven-country review conducted for the committee by the General Accounting Office, Congress's investigative arm, the Peace Corps can fill only 60 percent of the openings for those in scientific and technical fields.
The Peace Corps' record in attracting minority recruits fell far below acceptable levels, according to the report. "While the U.S. population was about 12 percent black in 1988, only 2 percent or about 120 or that year's 6,300 volunteers were black," the report said.
Of those who enter the corps, 30 percent do not finish the entire two years of duty.
Paul D. Coverdell, who was appointed director of the Peace Corps last year, acknowledged the shortcomings noted in the report but insisted that programs have been implemented to address those problems.
The agency mandated that 10 percent of volunteers be minorities in 1990, rising to 15 percent by 1993, Mr. Coverdell said. He said the corps surpassed its target last quarter; 19 percent of the nominees that recently accepted assignments were minorities.
To retain volunteers, efforts have been increased to ensure that the skills of volunteers match the positions they are placed in.
Hundreds of recruits have been sent to Central Europe this year, primarily to teach English. Mongolia, which has been visited by few Westerners, was the latest country to accept Peace Corps volunteers.
A copy of the report, No. 101-824, may be obtained at no cost by writing to the House Document Room Annex 2, the House of Representatives, Washington D.C. 20515.

HEADLINE: China, Reassessing Its Foes, Views Japan Warily

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Japanese proposals to send troops to the Persian Gulf and a territorial dispute about some uninhabited islands are stirring concern here that Japan could emerge in the coming years as China's primary military threat.
The old fears that the Soviet Union might invade China are easing, and few people cast the United States as a military threat. But Japan and China are longtime rivals, and the octogenarians who run China still have vivid memories of the brutal "War of Resistance Against Japan" from 1937 to 1945."Japan's dispatching of troops abroad is a very sensitive issue both in its own country and abroad," the official New China News Agency reported on Saturday, quoting an unidentified "leading official" of the Foreign Ministry. 
 The official asked Japan to consider these matters and act prudently, and added, "Otherwise, the feelings of the Asian people will be unavoidably hurt and it will eventually bring no good to Japan itself."
The Cabinet in Tokyo last week approved a plan to send troops to join the international force confronting Iraq in the first Japanese military forayabroad since the end of World War II. The measure, however, faces considerable opposition in the Japanese Parliament and its prospects are uncertain.
In a renewal of the territorial dispute, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Li Jinhua, last week criticized Japanese claims to a handful of disputed islands 120 miles northeast of Taiwan. Known in Chinese as the Diaoyu Islands and in Japan as the Senkaku Islands, they are claimed by Japan, Taiwan and China.
The spokeswoman was responding to reports that the Japanese Government might give official recognition to a lighthouse that has been constructed onone of the islands by Japanese nationalists. She condemned the building of the lighthouse.
Even before the dispute over the islands and the prospect of Japan's sending troops to the gulf, the Chinese leadership is said to have been re-examining its strategic concerns -- downgrading the Soviet threat and raising the Japanese threat a notch or two.
A well-informed Chinese official said that the military was pressing for additional funds in the five-year plan now being prepared, partly on the ground that China must counter Japan. And an analysis for top officials last year, in the classified publication Neican Xuanpian, portrayed China as an essential force to check Japan militarily and economically in the Pacific.
Chinese officials seem much more suspicious than Americans about Japanese ambitions in the region, and sometimes appear to regard Americans as a bit naive about Tokyo.
While many Chinese are clearly genuinely concerned about Japan, some also believe that the military hopes to make use of such alarm to bolster its influence and budget.
For all the apprehensions here about Japanese militarism, the relationship with Japan is in some respects closer, though perhaps not warmer, than with any other industrialized country. Japanese tourists travel widely in China and Japanese students study at Chinese universities.
Japanese companies have been wary of investing in China, but have established much broader sales networks in China than have European or American companies.

HEADLINE: For Senator Bradley in New Jersey

 BODY:
For a champion of campaign finance reform, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey is setting a prodigal example. He is spending more than $10 million on his bid for re-election. It is true that this is a year in which incumbents elsewhere have been knocked off. And it is true that his Republican opponent, Christine Todd Whitman, is an appealing and worthy challenger.
On the other hand, Senator Bradley enjoys an overwhelming lead in opinion polls -- and he deserves it. On the basis of his conscientious 12-year record in the Senate, Mr. Bradley has earned re-election to a third term. 
 The hottest issue in New Jersey this year is state taxes. Republican candidates are teeing off on the unpopular but needed increases that the new Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, got the Legislature to approve. While state budgets aren't the responsibility of U.S. senators, Mrs. Whitman has successfully tagged Senator Bradley with evasiveness; he refuses to say what he thinks of the Florio taxes.
Mrs. Whitman comes from a well-to-do political family, with a creditable record of her own. In elective office she has served as a county freeholder; by appointment, she was president of the state's public utilities board in the final years of the Kean administration. She is chairman of the executive committee of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency. A self-styled "fiscal conservative," she puts spending cuts ahead of tax increases but wisely says she "would never say never" to raising taxes. Less wisely, she advocates line-item veto power for the President and a reduction in the tax on capital gains.
Senator Bradley's original popularity as a basketball star led to more political popularity. That's true in New Jersey, where he won 65 percent of the vote in his last election, and in the Democratic Party, where he is often thought of as Presidential timber -- though he says he expects to serve a full Senate term if re-elected.
While he has conducted a dull, play-it-safe campaign, his record as a responsible public servant is hard to fault. He more than anyone deserves credit for launching the tax reforms enacted in 1986. He has fought effectively for sensible energy and environmental legislation and has studiously carved out a role in international economic policy.
Mrs. Whitman might make a good senator but in Bill Bradley New Jersey already has an excellent Senator. We endorse his re-election.

HEADLINE: Rail Freight Can Ease Traffic Congestion

 BODY:
To the Editor:
With the New York metropolitan area facing monumental traffic jams because of bridge and highway repairs (news article, Sept. 24), there is a proven method to alleviate congestion: rail freight transportation.
Every rail car bringing goods in or out of New York eliminates the movement of up to four trucks on public roads and bridges. Trains are vastly more fuel efficient than trucks (railroads can haul nearly three times more freight per gallon than trucks) and are therefore less polluting.
Unlike the highway, the region's rail freight network has the capacity to handle additional volume and is in good physical condition. While highways are maintained with public money (the taxes trucks pay do not match the heavy damage they inflict on roads and bridges), private-sector freight railroads like Conrail invest their own funds to maintain rail infrastructure, in addition to paying local and state taxes.
The freight rail renaissance has started in the region. Backed by renewed interest from shippers of recyclable materials, solid waste, bulk commodities, food products, manufactured goods, building products and paper, Conrail is working with several parties, including the newly formed Harlem River Yard Ventures corporation in the Bronx and state and local government to restore unused and underutilized rail freight facilities in the region.
As these efforts by Conrail, connecting railroads (including the Long Island), shippers, independent entrepreneurs and government succeed in moving freight off the highways and onto the tracks, the region will benefit with fewer trucks clogging roads and bridges, more efficient use of fuel for freight transportation, and reduced air pollution.
 
PETER D. COHEN
Area Mgr., Economic Development
Consolidated Rail Corp. (Conrail)
New York, Oct. 12, 1990

HEADLINE: Mendon Journal;
Down on the Farm, Things Are Looking Up

BYLINE: By WILLIAM ROBBINS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MENDON, Mo.

 BODY:
When Shorty Glad bach looks back, 1985 still seems too close for comfort. In that year of national farm crisis, his struggles paralleled those of many young farmers, caught in the clutches of enormous debt and depressed farm prices.
But he also acknowledges that in the five years since then, he and his family have come a long way on their grain, cattle and hog farm in this small farming town in north-central Missouri. 
 Indeed, the Agriculture Department's Economic Research Service recently reported that a broad middle group of farmers have overcome the setbacks of the early 1980's and have now caught up with urban residents in family income.
Hardly anyone, of course, matches national averages, but the experiences of the Gladbach family in large measure typify this group of farmers.
"We went through some pretty tough times, and a lot of people in the same situation we were in didn't make it," Mr. Gladbach said the other day while resting a bit after harvesting a bountiful crop from one of his best fields. "But I feel like we've got a little more control of our own situation now. We're not so tied up in making payments on debts that were really higher than the bankers said our land was worth. It just isn't as stressful."
Lawrence Gladbach, a man of medium height who is now 36 years old but who has been known as Shorty since he was a toddler, was first encountered by a reporter in early 1985. It was a time of deep soul-searching, and he and his wife, Geraldine, acknowledged many a sleepless night of wondering whether to continue the struggle.
They had four children: Johnny, who then 4; Becky, 8; Katie, 9, and Jesse, 10, who was already helping with farm work even though his feet barely reached the pedals of the tractors he operated.
Like many young farm families, the Gladbachs had already traveled a bumpy course. They were married in 1973, when the average farm family income was 47 percent higher than the average for all the nation's families. In the next seven years the Gladbachs built an operation centered on the 100-year-old farmhouse and 200 acres they acquired from Mr. Gladbach's father. In 1980 things looked bright.
But since then theirs has been a story that paralleled the experiences of American agriculture in general, as seen through the study reported in September by Kenneth Deavers and Thomas Carlin of the Economic Research Service.
In three of the next five years they were plagued by poor growing weather, and when prices were high, they had little grain to sell. Instead, they had to buy expensive corn to feed their cattle and hogs.
Like most other farmers the Gladbachs tightened their belts, cut living expenses and paid off debts as fast as they could bring in cash.
By 1986, things were better, and in 1987 better still, with cash returns exceeding outlays on the farm by $66,070. Then came the drought of 1988, which stunted crops across most of the Corn Belt. And last year was not much better, but good prices for cattle and hogs have helped families like the Gladbachs keep going.
Now, after a shaky start when wet fields delayed planting, 1990 is turning out to be another good year. Crops have been good and livestock prices excellent.
Historically, the income of farm families have lagged far behind American households in general. In 1960, for example, they averaged about 60 percent of the incomes of urban residents, according to the Deavers-Carlin study. But they improved steadily until, in the boom year of 1973, farm incomes were about one and a half times the national average. And they were on a par with urban family incomes through the late 1970's.
The farm crisis of the early 1980's knocked them down again, to a level about 20 percent below the average for all American families. But in 1985 they almost reached parity with other Americans, and in 1986 they surged ahead. Finally, in 1988, the last year for which comparative figures are available, the average income for farm families reached $41,558, compared with $34,017 for Americans in general.
Still, things are better now on the nation's farms than they have been in years, and the Gladbach family reflects this improvement.
Jesse, now a high school junior and nearly as tall as his father, has a car and drives himself and Katie to school. Katie is a sophomore, and Mr. Gladbach says he may need to buy yet another car just to keep the peace.
Both Jesse and Katie are looking toward college, a prospect that Mr. Gladbach says he faces with a feeling of assurance.
"We've got equity enough in the farm now," he said. "We can feel pretty sure now, with the student loans they can get to help out, that all of them can go on and get a college education."

HEADLINE: Soviet Lawmen vs. the Black Market

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The leaders of Soviet law enforcement described today how harried and ill equipped they are to deal with the current explosion of black-market crime as the nation drifts uncertainly between Communism and the free market.
"We never expected this scale of organized crime," Vladimir A. Kryuchkov, the chief of the K.G.B., said at a news conference in which officials acknowledged their problems in fighting the rampant growth of illicit entrepreneurship that some day would be legalized, if the nation ever adopts the promised market economy. 
 Justice Minister Veniamin Yakovlev said: "Our American colleagues ask us why we fight speculation, a normal phenomenon in a normal economy. But right now, our criminal code stipulates as illegal things that are normal in a market economy."
Emphasizing the need for new laws and guidance, Interior Minister Vadim V. Bakatin joined his two colleagues in portraying a frayed criminal justice system trying to manage the transition from a police state to the current freewheeling, non-stop crisis atmosphere of attempted national reform.
The officials plaintively described a kaleidoscopic array of challenges that range from a 30 percent rise in crimes against foreigners with hard currency to the separatist pressures for rival police and military forces in the republics; from the destruction of Lenin monuments across the nation to insurgent governments' dismissal of teachers for simply being Communists; from the republics' growing refusal to submit their young men to the national military draft to the police agencies' own dark histories of repression.
On the latter point, Mr. Kryuchkov insisted that the K.G.B. was moving to correct its past. Mr. Yakovlev said the issue of prosecuting abusive police agents in past decades of terror should be considered. But Mr. Kryuchkov said several already had been prosecuted, while many others had died, and the remainder "can be counted on the fingers of one hand."
Mr. Kryuchkov said a development that was particularly alarming was the ascendancy of "rather stable gangs with access to the black market that even have their own investment funds."
"They have the opportunity to accumulate power," he said, adding that more than 900 such groups have been identified. Many have been in operation for more than a year and are seeking ties with organized crime overseas, officials warned.
Mr. Kryuchkov insisted that, unlike organized crime in the United States and elsewhere, what the Soviets loosely call the "mafia" has not reached the level of constituting "a state within a state," although its methods increasingly employ "extraordinarily sadistic" violence.
"We are importing some negative things now, too," he said of the nation's attempt to adapt to the free-market conditions of the outside world.
 
Measure Before Parliament
 The news conference was timed to build support for a bill pending in the national Parliament to tighten penalties on black marketeering. Parliament voted preliminary approval of the bill after considerable criticism that the measure was vague and directed against "actions that in the civilized world are taken as enterprise," as one critic complained.
The Government's supporters countered that black market speculation was affecting basic food supplies at a time when, according to the latest statistical measurements in the stores, only 20 basic goods on a list of 1,100 commodities can be regularly found on the shelves.
The bill's proposed penalties of up to three years in jail plus a fine would be directed against the growing phenomenon of speculators who accumulate subsidized, low-price goods from state stores and resell them for profit in the black market, where desperate consumers are turning more often.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Cutting Pay for Officials And for Himself

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
Trying to show that the highest levels of his administration were willing to share the pain of fiscal belt-tightening, Mayor David N. Dinkins imposed a 5 percent pay cut on himself and nearly 700 other senior administration officials yesterday and froze salaries for 3,800 managerial employees.
But the move, meant to save about $4.5 million in the current fiscal year, was immediately denounced by the heads of two major municipal labor unions, who called it a public-relations gimmick meant to tilt tense contract negotiations to the city's favor. 
 "This is an administration out of control," said Barry Feinstein, president of the 12,000-member Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
 
'A Cheap Shot'
 Mr. Feinstein and Stanley Hill, executive director of the 140,000-member District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, are embroiled in contract negotiations that have been severely complicated by a 5.5 percent wage increase granted to the teachers union and subsequent criticism that it was far too generous.
"We think the pay cut is a cheap shot that is meant to impact on the bargaining table," Mr. Feinstein said. "Stanley and I have insisted on a level playing field, and this is an attempt to skew it to one side. Clearly, it's bargaining in bad faith and we're not going to have any of that. We think this is most unfortunate, an improper turn of events."
Senior administration officials have been aware since Friday of the planned cuts for officials and staff members whose pay falls under the Mayor's control. The announcement appeared to have two immediate purposes: to strengthen the city's position in the labor negotiations and to send a clear signal that the Mayor was willing to take the tough steps to address the city's budget problems.
It also appeared to be intended to put pressure on city officials not under the Democratic Mayor's control -- like borough presidents and district attorneys -- to take similar tough measures.
Some of these officials complained privately that Mr. Dinkins had not solicited their support beforehand.
"I think this really is more of an attempt at public relations than at proving real financial help to our city," said Borough President Guy V. Molinari of Staten Island, a Republican. "It's insignificant in terms of the fiscal problems facing our city. He cannot realistically give a 5.5 percent raise to the teachers and then try to deflect the furor by suggesting he and his staff take pay cuts."
 
'In No Way Theatrics'
 Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary, denied that the pay cuts were meant as a bargaining tool with municipal unions. "He's sending a signal to labor, to management, to taxpayers, to bondholders, to everyone, that we intend to have a balanced budget." he said. "This is in no way theatrics intended to impress labor negotiations."
Some officials quickly agreed with the Mayor's plea to "share the pain" and announced their own pay cuts and cuts in employees' salaries.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, who agreed to take a 5 percent cut for herself and her top staff, said every little bit helped. "Even though it has a slight budgetary impact, if it's the first step to demonstrate that we all have to share the pain, then it's an important first step," she said.
The City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said yesterday that he and five top members of his staff were voluntarily taking a 5 percent pay cut and that the rest of the Council staff salaries would be frozen. Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx, saying he applauded the Mayor's decision, said he would take a 5 percent pay cut and extend a managerial salary freeze put into effect last July.
Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President, said he too was taking a 5 percent cut and reducing his office's personnel budget by 2 percent. Borough President Ruth W. Messinger of Manhattan said that she was taking a 5 percent pay cut and that her office was reviewing the entire budget problem.
The Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, declined to comment on his plans. The Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, said she was still considering her options.
City officials have already slashed the capital budget of some agencies by more than 30 percent, and last week they told city agencies to prepare to cut more than $1 billion in programs and services from their operating budgets over the next 21 months.
The 5 percent wage cut applies to 44 senior-level managers in City Hall, including the Mayor, the five deputy mayors, the city's corporation counsel, the Mayor's counsel and press secretary, the directors of mayoral offices and all other mayoral managerial employees earning at least $70,000 a year.
The cuts also apply to 60 commissioners and 140 deputy commissioners in mayoral agencies and 202 assistant commissioners in those agencies who earn at least $70,000. Also affected are about 250 mayoral agency staff members who hold exempt or noncompetitive management titles and earn at least $70,000 a year. The changes would not apply to employees coverered by collective-bargaining agreements.
The Mayor also ordered a change in salary policy for all managerial employees, starting in the 1992 fiscal year. The change would tie raises to professional performance rather than to the rate of inflation or increases granted to other city employees.
 
Changed His Mind
 Mr. Dinkins said times were so bad that he was initially prepared to order 10 percent cuts. He said he changed his mind because of the likelihood that the Federal Government would impose sharp increases in payroll taxes for many city employees through extension of the Social Security system.
Phil Tacktill, a spokesman for the New York City Managerial Employees Association, representing 2,200 managers in the city, reacted angrily to the Mayor's decision. "The phone has been jumping off the hook with people complaining that is outrageous," he said.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
SAUDI PRINCE HINTS AT DEAL WITH IRAQ FOR KUWAITI PORT

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister, the country's third-ranking official, has raised the possibility of allowing Iraq to have some Kuwaiti territory as an outlet on the Persian Gulf and has urged Arabs to seek a peaceful resolution of the gulf crisis "through all means."
In comments to Arab journalists on Sunday that were widely reported today, the Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, said in an apparent reference to Iraq's claims against Kuwait that "if a sister Arab nation has rights, we all agree these rights can be had, but not by force." 
 Asked about Iraq's demands for an outlet on the Persian Gulf, Prince Sultan, replied, "Saudi Arabia has said, and says now, that giving rights, including territorial brotherly concessions -- given willingly -- is a matter of pride for the Arab nation."
 
Talks of Past 'Brotherhood'
 Prince Sultan, a brother of King Fahd, said: "We in Saudi Arabia have given parts of our land and parts of our territorial waters willingly. But this came through good will, noble manners, and brotherhood" -- a reference to territorial settlements concluded in the past between Saudi Arabia, Iraq and the United Arab Emirates.
The comments by the Prince, considered the official wielding the most influence with King Fahd even though he is second in line to the throne, marked the first time since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 that a ranking Saudi leader has so much as hinted at a territorial compromise with Iraq.
 
Oil Prices Plunge
 The remarks, which helped push oil prices down $5 a barrel, prompted the Saudi authorities to rush today to assure the United States and others that there was no change in the Saudi view that Iraq must heed the United Nations Security Council's demand for a complete withdrawal from Kuwait.
Similarly, the Kuwaiti government in exile rushed to reaffirm its opposition to any compromise with Iraq.
Saudi television, which broadcast Prince Sultan's remarks in full tonight, said the Prince had been "misinterpreted."
Further complicating the situation was the sudden and unexpected arrival here tonight of the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, whose country is closely allied with Saudi Arabia and who has consistently advocated the unconditional withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait.
 
Wider Access to Gulf
 While Egyptian officials said Mr. Mubarak was here to visit Egyptian troops, some diplomats said he may have come to seek clarification of Saudi positions. In a speech at Jidda airport welcoming Mr. Mubarak, King Fahd reportedly reiterated his demand that Iraq withdraw from Kuwait, saying that President Saddam Hussein would not lose face if he rectified his "blunder."
Mr. Mubarak's concern may have been prompted by Arab and other news reports quoting officials of the Soviet Union, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organization as saying that Iraq would be willing to pull its forces from Kuwait provided it could retain Bubiyan and Warbah Islands as outlets on the Persian Gulf.
Bubiyan and Warbah Islands would give Iraq a much wider and much more protected access to the Persian Gulf. Before the invasion, Iraq's access to the gulf went through a narrow canal that passed by the two islands. Iraq had repeatedly and frequently asked Kuwait to lease the two islands for 99 years for the use of its navy.
The strong accent on conciliation and peaceful settlement adopted by Prince Sultan amplified the already existing impression that he is a leading "dove", in the words of an Arab diplomat, among the Saudi leadership.
In the past, Prince Sultan had stated that "no attacks" will be launched from Saudi Arabia against Iraq except in self-defense.
 
'What I Meant to Say'
 Aware of the concerns generated by the reports of Prince Sultan's remarks, the Saudi authorities not only replayed the full text of his comments, but also broadcast a commentary in which Prince Sultan was quoted as saying that Saudi Arabia still insisted on the full withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait.
A Saudi commentator reported that Prince Sultan said, "What I meant to say is that Saudi Arabia was able through good will and good intentions to settle land disputes with Iraq and the United Arab Emirates. However when it comes to aggression on Kuwait, the Saudi Arabian kingdom insists on the reinstitution of the legitimate Kuwaiti authority under the leadership of the Emir of Kuwait and the full withdrawal of Iraqi troops."
In his comments to Arab journalists, Prince Sultan also said that the "law of the jungle" had no place in negotiating border settlements and other disputes.
He also stressed that "the invasion of an Arab country of another Arab country is a deep wound to the Arab nation."
Prince Sultan stressed that Saudi Arabia's opposition to Iraq's conquest of Kuwait is a matter "of principle, and we will never change it no matter what.
"We would adopt the same stand with Iraq if it were subjected to aggression."
 
Full Brother of the King
 Nevertheless, the general tone of the Prince's remarks might appeal to Iraq. Saudi television said that the comments had led to "wrong interpretations" among the Arab reporters. The Prince's conciliatory tone was highlighted by Arab press agencies and news reports.
Among the royal Al Saud family, King Fahd is the supreme ruler, Commander in Chief of the Army and Prime Minister.
Prince Abdullah, the king's half brother, is the Crown Prince and second in line to the throne. He commands the national guard force of about 35,000 and has the title of First Deputy Prime Minister, putting him in charge of running cabinet sessions in the absence of the King.
Prince Sultan, a full brother of the King, is Second Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Defense and Aviation. As a full brother of the King he is believed to be closer to him than Crown Prince Abdullah. He carries enormous influence because of his position overseeing the military establishment.
Since the beginning of the gulf crisis, Prince Sultan has had the responsibility of overseeing the deployment of foreign troops here, coordinating their activities, furninshing logistical support and reviewing any battle plans and field coordination with American and other army commanders.
 
A Most Unusual Episode
 Earlier in the day, as the remarks became an issue and oil prices began to fall, Saudi officials rushed to explain that the Prince's comments should be viewed in the context of a "brotherly chat among Arabs." Later, Saudi television news reports tonight said that the remarks of Prince Sultan were being broadcast in full "to clear up any confusion" they may have caused. The Saudi news media did not publish the earlier, conciliatory accounts.
The whole episode was highly unusual in a country that is intent on projecting an image of steady, calm and controlled decision-making in all its public pronouncements.
Indeed, the Prince's remarks appeared to have raised significant concern within the circles of the Kuwaiti government in exile, illiciting a strong reaction from an unidentified spokesman in Taif, in western Saudi Arabia.
The official Kuwaiti news agency, KUNA, which continues to represent the views of the Kuwaiti government in exile, said today in a dispatch from London that Kuwait will not accept "any territorial compromise" as a pre-condition for the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from occupied Kuwait.
There has been a palpable trend among many senior Saudi officials and notable members of the Saudi business and media establishment. Over the past few days they have expressed a strong aversion to war and a preference for the use of the economic and military embargo imposed on Iraq as the way to deal with the gulf crisis.
 
Purpose of the Embargo
 Even when it came to the embargo, Prince Sultan attempted to signal Iraq that Saudi Arabia was anxious to see it come to an end, noting that the principal purpose behind it was to avert a damaging war and the shedding of Arab blood at Arab hands.
"It hurts us greately that the Iraqi people are under such containment or that any Arab or Islamic country should suffer through such an embargo," he said. "But the purpose of it is to avert bloodshed. All we desire is for the Iraqi people and the great Iraqi army to assert its Arab identity by withdrawing from Arab territory."
Addressing other concerns raised by the journalists, Prince Sultan denied the existence of any differences over the command structure of the estimated 300,000 allied troops gathered in Saudi Arabia to face Iraqi troops in Kuwait.
He said that elaborate measures and agreements have been worked out between all the heads of states of the joint forces to control the decision-making process if things came to war. "But, clearly, once the order to go to battle is given, it is the commanders in the field that will be totally in charge." Responding to a question, he strongly denied Saudi Arabia's intention of "entering into any alliances with a non-Arab country."

An article yesterday about remarks by the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, suggesting a territorial compromise with Iraq, misstated Crown Prince Abdullah's standing in the line of succession tothe throne. He is first in line, not second.
