HEADLINE: White House and Congress on Verge of Tax Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The White House and Congressional leaders seemed today to be within an eyelash of reaching the tax compromise crucial to a new budget.
They have tentatively agreed on a 31 percent top tax rate, up from the current 28 percent. These other elements are more or less locked up: a limit on deductions that could be claimed by people with total incomes above $100,000, a modest rise in the gasoline tax, cuts in Medicare payments, a steep increase in the amount of wages subject to the Medicare payroll tax, luxury taxes on expensive cars, boats, private planes, furs and jewelry, and higher taxes on tobacco products and alcoholic beverages.
 
Real Numbers Not Released
 
 The actual numbers -- for instance the exact size of the gasoline tax -- were being held in abeyance until computer tabulations showed how much money would be raised and exactly who would pay it.
The negotiators, who met until just before midnight, were working to reconcile bills approved last week by the House and Senate.
After waiting all day for computer runs and for the party whips to poll lawmakers on how various proposals under consideration would affect their votes on the entire package, the top negotiators began meeting at 8 o'clock tonight to discuss a new Democratic offer.
 
'We're So Close'
 "Numberwise, we're so close," said Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Finance Committee. "But everybody has given so much on both sides that they think, 'I'm not going to go that last mile.' "
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the Democratic chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said the problem was making final adjustments so the package would be acceptable to the House, which is dominated by Democrats, and the Senate, which is much more conservative.
"What we can pass, they can't; what they can pass, we can't," he said.
The last remaining disagreement on a matter of principle was over, not whether to levy an additional tax on people with incomes of $1 million, but over what form it should take.
Only about 60,000 tax returns are filed each year showing total incomes of more than $1 million. This is not enough people to fill Giants Stadium, much less for their tax payments to have any meaningful effect on total revenues or on the economy.
But these people have become political symbols barely two weeks before the Congressional elections.
Democrats want to show in a way that is easily understood by voters that they are no friends of the Donald Trumps, Leona Helmsleys and Michael Milkens. The Democratic plan is to place a surtax, perhaps 7.5 percent, on all income over $1 million.
Republicans maintain that would be bad policy because the very wealthy would be encouraged to maximize their deductions to keep their taxable incomes down.
Instead, the Republicans advocate placing a stiff limit on the deductions they could claim in a proposal that would raise approximately the same amount of revenue as the Democratic plan and that would have about the same effect on those taxpayers. But what the Republicans do not want is to give to the Democrats the political satisfaction of passing a surtax.
Both plans would have the effect of raising the actual tax rate on incomes above $1 million. For example, with a 7.5 percent surtax on top of a 31 percent top rate and a 4 percent interest limitation, as proposed at one point by the Democrats, the actual tax rate on million-dollar incomes would be 34.66 percent. With no surtax, but an 8 percent cut in deductions, as offered once by Republicans, the rate would be 33.48 percent.
One effect of the plans to raise the top tax rate to 31 percent would be to eliminate the anomaly known as the bubbe. No taxpayers now pay more than 28 percent of their total income in taxes, but families with taxable incomes between about $80,000 and $200,000 pay 33 percent on the income within that range.
 
Effect of 31% Rate
 Depending on how other provisions are worked out, the 31 percent rate could have the effect of raising the taxes of families with incomes above $200,000 but of lowering somewhat the taxes of people whose incomes fall between $80,000 and $200,000.
The tax proposals are designed to raise about $145 billion over five years, an important component of the negotiators' goal of $500 billion over five years. How much of the $40 billion in deficit reduction this year would consist of increased taxes could not be determined until the final plan was presented.
After an outburst against Democrats from President Bush's top advisers on Sunday afternoon, the negotiators made up today. But they spent all day waiting for staff analysts to run the various tax proposals through computers to determine as precisely as possible what the effects would be.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, stomped out of the Capitol on Sunday, accompanied by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, and asserted that the Democrats were not negotiating in good faith.
But this morning, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, played down the blow-up and said the officials simply "left to come back to the White House to give the President a briefing on where things stood."
 
'Back on Track'
 The officials were back in the Capitol this morning. On arriving, Mr. Darman said that they had been "disappointed" Sunday but that "we're back on track."
Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, said, "We got it out of our system last night."
After Mr. Sununu and the others left Sunday, the top lawmakers from both parties returned to the bargaining table and worked until nearly midnight.
They did the kind of work they do well together without the White House looking over their shoulders, reviewing lists of lawmakers and figuring out who would vote which way depending on what the various aspects of the tax package turned out to be.
A Republican vote-counter said today that whatever the nature of the final compromise, no more than 50 of the 176 Republicans in the House would vote for it.
That gave the Democrats considerable political strength in the negotiations, since their votes are the ones needed to pass a compromise in the House.
 
Minding Realities
 On the other hand, the negotiators were mindful of the need to fashion a plan that could pass the more conservative Senate and that could be approved by the White House.
One illustration of how the balance could be upset came tonight when Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican, sought to amend a foreign aid bill with a proposal to prohibit any increase this year in the gasoline tax.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic majority leader, considered it such a contentious issue that he temporarily withdrew the foreign aid bill from consideration. In 1982, Senator Helms led a filibuster against a higher gasoline tax that kept Congress in session until just before Christmas.
Each day, there have been further indications of bad blood between the White House officials and Congressional leaders. At one point today, for example, Mr. Darman was left cooling his heels in a corridor while Mr. Dole and Mr. Rostenkowski met in one office in the Capitol and Representatives Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic majority leader, and Leon E. Panetta of California, the Democratic chairman of the Budget Committee, met in another.
The House measure would raise the top tax rate to 33 percent, impose a 10 percent surtax on people with incomes above $1 million and increase the alternative minimum tax that is paid by wealthy taxpayers with extremely large deductions.
More than two-thirds of the additional taxes would be paid by taxpayers with total incomes over $100,000.
The Senate version, by contrast, would not change tax rates and would more than double the gasoline tax, meaning that barely 40 percent of the new tax bite would be borne by those with total incomes above $100,000.

HEADLINE: Bankers Trust Posts Profit a Year After $1.42 Billion Loss

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that it earned $170 million, or $1.98 a share, in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $1.42 billion in the comparable 1989 period, when the company recorded a $1.6 billion addition to reserves to cover possible losses on loans to third-world nations.
Without the added reserves, quarterly earnings would have declined 5.6 percent, from $180 million, or $2.18 a share, a year ago. 
 Bankers Trust said that despite the general economic slowdown, it had strengthened its ratio of capital to debt, exceeding Federal Reserve requirements. With the sale of $250 million in preferred stock in May 1990, the company raised its risk-adjusted capital ratio to 5.1 percent, well above a 4 percent minimum that takes effect in 1992.
 
 $1.04 Billion in Troubled Loans
 Analysts said earnings were quite strong, with the exception of a rise in nonperforming loans in highly leveraged corporate transactions like buyouts or restructurings. The company said it had stopped accruing interest on $264 million in troubled loans in the quarter, of which $249 million were for highly leveraged transactions and $31 million were secured by real estate. That put total troubled loans in the United States and other industrial countries at $1.04 billion, of which $470 million resulted from highly leveraged deals and $250 million from real estate loans.
The company said holdings of renegotiated bonds declined by $53 million, because of sales to third parties of Mexican Government par bonds.
Bankers Trust said reserves for losses on loans as of Sept. 30 was $2.2 billion, or 11 percent of loans outstanding.
Ronald I. Mandle, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, said that the increase in troubled highly leveraged loans was "the biggest element of disappointment."
Chris Kotowski at Oppenheimer & Company agreed, noting that those loans increased by 29 percent, but added that "otherwise it was a fine quarter."
Bankers Trust stock rose 37.5 cents, to $34 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: American Express Gains Despite Shearson

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
The American Express Company reported a slight increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday. But the company's profits were dampened by a continued poor performance from Shearson Lehman Brothers.
American Express reported that its net income rose 3.6 percent, to $343.8 million, or 74 cents a share, from $331.8 million, or 77 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1989. Revenues fell 6.8 percent, to $6.06 billion from $6.5 billion. The earnings per share were higher in 1989 because of a smaller number of shares outstanding. 
 At Shearson, earnings were hurt by a drop in investment banking, commission, trading and investment advisory activity. The brokerage subsidiary reported third-quarter profits of $13 million, an 80.3 percent decline from the 1989 third quarter, when it earned $66 million. The figure a year ago for Shearson included a one-time gain of $37 million. Revenues for the period declined 24.2 percent, to $2.5 billion from $3.3 billion.
 
 Shearson a Net Loss
 Still, Shearson represented a net loss to American Express, which did not own 100 percent of the brokerage until August 1990. After accounting for dividends paid to the Nippon Life Insurance Company and other minority shareholders, American Express recorded a $5.4 million loss for the period from Shearson.
Shearson reported a $50 million drop in investment banking revenues, a $130 million drop in commission revenues and a $21 million decline in trading and merchant banking revenues. It did not report profits for these businesses individually.
James D. Robinson 3d, the chief executive of American Express, said that the "strengths of our products and services and our diverse revenue streams enabled our businesses to continue to perform well despite the difficult economic environment."
Record third-quarter earnings were reported at three business units: Travel Related Services gained 15 percent, to $277 million; IDS Financial Services 18 percent, to $56 million, and Information Services 24 percent, to $27 million.
American Express's share price rose $1 yesterday, to $19.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Record Fall Puts Oil Below $30

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Oil tumbled below $30 a barrel in a record drop yesterday, as traders discerned more peace overtures from the Middle East. They ranged from statements by the Saudi Defense Minister to reports of a dream in which the Prophet Mohammed appeared to President Saddam Hussein.
A report by a Kuwaiti newspaper in Saudi Arabia that Mohammed had told Mr. Hussein in a dream, "I see your rockets deployed wrongly," found a rapt audience on the floor of the New York Mercantile Exchange, where traders interpreted the report as an attempt to prepare the Iraqi people for giving up Kuwait. 
 The market took the same message from a statement on Sunday by the Saudi Defense Minister, Prince Sultan, that his country was willing to grant Iraq "all its rights."
 
 Technical Factors Cited
 Some analysts said technical factors also played a role.
On the trading floor of the mercantile exchange, crude closed at $28.38, down $5.41, or 16 percent, the biggest one-day drop since trading of the crude oil contract began in 1983. The November contract expired yesterday, so speculators who did not actually want to take delivery of the crude had to sell, and some analysts said that accelerated the decline, but others disagreed. Prices for delivery in later months fell by the limit allowed, $3 a barrel.
In a trend that has fed on itself in recent days, oil prices have fallen 27 percent in the last four trading days, and the November contract was within a few cents of giving up half of its post-crisis gain when it expired.
 
Small Impact on Gasoline
 If the price holds, consumers should see a difference soon in heating oil and other oil products, although the impact on gasoline prices would be small, experts say, because prices at the pump have not risen nearly as rapidly as crude oil prices.
Higher prices for crude oil contributed to large increases in third-quarter profits reported by ARCO and Phillips Petroleum yesterday, despite what they said was their restraining of prices at the pump. Ashland Oil, the nation's largest independent refiner, said its refining profits rose nearly threefold. [Page D14.]
Bigger than the technical factors, market participants agreed, was the market's belief that oil production had reached pre-crisis levels even without Kuwait and Iraq, and its current assessment that a war was unlikely.
Many traders in New York focused on the report yesterday in Al Seyassah, the Kuwaiti newspaper now printed in exile in Saudi Arabia, which was flashed to traders by several different news services. In its Sunday issue, the paper said the dream story was being spread by Iraqi intelligence agents in Baghdad to prepare Iraqis for the idea of a pullout from Kuwait, although the implication of the wrongly deployed rockets is that the enemy is not Saudi Arabia but Israel.
 
View of Saudi Prince
 The statement by Prince Sultan, the Saudi Defense Minister, was also taken by the market to mean that the Saudis would like a territorial compromise by Kuwait. He raised the possibility of allowing Iraq to keep some Kuwaiti territory as an outlet on the Persian Gulf and has urged Arabs to seek a peaceful resolution of the crisis "through all means."
Similarly, in one version of the dream, the Prophet told Mr. Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, except from some coastal islands, which provide Iraq with access to the gulf. "It's convenient that Mohammed told him he could keep the islands," said Thomas P. Blakeslee, an oil analyst at Pegasus Econometric Services of Hoboken, N.J.
"Right now the market is oriented toward an end to the whole crisis," said John H. Lichtblau, the president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York. "It may turn out to be wrong, but that's the market orientation at the moment."
 
'Most Unlikely Scenario'
 At Merrill Lynch, Nauman Barakat, a trader, said, "Two weeks ago war seemed to be the most likely scenario, but at this stage war seems to be the most unlikely scenario."
With the "war premium" coming out of the price, the market will now focus on the suppy and demand for oil, he added, and on that basis, "it's difficult to make a case as to why the market should not be somewhere in the low- to mid-$20's."
Others disagreed, and some cautioned that a return to bellicose rhetoric could push prices back up again.
But if a settlement is reached and the embargo ends, "what happens if Iraq and Kuwait's production comes back on," said Robinson West of the Petroleum Finance Company. "Then the world is flooded with oil."
Consumers, meanwhile, should feel the impact soon, although the gasoline fall may be modest because gasoline never rose high enough to reflect peak crude prices.
In trading for delivery next month, wholsale unleaded gasoline fell 11.41 cents a gallon yesterday, to 76.5 cents, and heating oil dropped 12.42 cents, to 75.98 cents.
 
Slowness in Cuts Seen
 Mr. Lichtblau, of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said that gasoline never rose above a level consistent with $30-a-barrel oil, and that as a result, refiners and distributors had been operating unprofitably in recent weeks. If yesterday's price holds, he said, gasoline prices should fall about 3 cents a gallon, but he predicted that refiners and distributors would be slow to cut prices, in an effort to recoup past losses.
But "unbranded" stations that buy at a price pegged to the mercantile exchange price will once again be able to undercut branded outlets, he added.
Heating oil, which had risen higher, will fall in coming weeks as the peak heating season approaches, Mr. Lichtblau said.
In the meantime, the move downward in crude has meant large losses for anyone who bought at the peak. For the November contract the peak close was $40.40, on Oct. 9. Some companies that use oil buy futures contracts to assure themselves of supplies at a set price.
 
Velocity Increased
 But the desire to limit risk also increases the velocity with which prices change, some experts say. Robert Boslego, an oil analyst in Winchester, Mass., said that a company that had gone "long," buying a contract obligating it to take delivery of 10,000 barrels at $40 a barrel, would watch nervously as the price went to $30.
So the company might try to go "short," by taking out a contract in which it promises to deliver 10,000 barrels at $30, partly canceling out its original contract. Now, said Mr. Boslego, the company's risk is limited. If the price falls to $20, it could buy oil on the open market to meet the obligations of the new contract, and make a profit, so it has no risk of loss beyond the $10.
But the rush of companies trying to limit their risk that way creates a crowd of participants who want to sell oil cheaply, and that helps push prices down, Mr. Boslego added.

 BODY:

Markets
 Oil prices plummeted, with crude off $5.41, to $28.38 a barrel. It was the biggest one-day drop since trading of contracts in crude oil began in 1983. The plunge may have been helped by speculators bailing out as the November contract expired. [Page D1.]
Blue-chip stocks fell slightly, but the rest of the market advanced. The Dow slumped 4.70, to 2,516.09. [D8.]
Most Treasury securities prices were little changed, and a Citicorp auction of preferred stock almost failed. [D18.]
The dollar strengthened against all major currencies. [D19.] Gold prices fell. [D19.]
 
 The Economy
The White House and Congressional leaders seemed to be within an eyelash of reaching the tax compromise crucial to a new budget. [A1.] Any budget agreement is sure to include a big cut in deductions for the wealthy. [A21.]
House and Senate negotiators reached final agreement on changes in clean-air legislation. [A1.] Coal-burning utilities said they did not believe the acid-rain proposal differed markedly from earlier ones, which they called feasible but expensive. [A18.]

HEADLINE: Japanese Markets Rise With the Yen

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Japan's financial markets, battered in recent months by rising interest rates and the leap in oil prices, have received a lift from an unlikely source: a sharp appreciation in the value of the yen.
The rosier sentiment here in reaction to the resurgent yen indicates how much the Japanese have altered their economy since 1985, when the leading industrial nations began a conscious effort to push the dollar lower to ease America's yawning trade deficit. At that time, Japanese companies complained loudly as the yen soared and their products became more expensive overseas, reducing the exports on which the economy thrived.
But today, the markets have focused not on the negative impact a rising yen might have on exports, but on two big benefits: It has reduced Japan's bill for imported oil, which must be paid in dollars, providing considerable relief from soaring world energy prices in the wake of the crisis in the Persian Gulf, and it has permitted interest rates here to fall after a damaging yearlong surge.
 
 Bond Yield Drops
 The dollar has declined from 150 yen in mid-July to as low as 124.40 last Thursday in New York, a 17 percent tumble. Buffeted by fears of a recession and the budget crisis in Washington, the dollar, although up slightly the last two days to close at 126.02 today in New York, is edging toward its record low of 120.45, reached in January 1988.
The yield on Japan's benchmark 10-year Government bond, meanwhile, has plummeted from 8.7 percent a month ago to 7.75 percent today, as the stronger yen has slightly reduced concerns about inflation. There is talk now that commercial banks may reduce their key long-term prime lending rate after steep increases in recent months.
That has revived the deeply troubled stock market, which has been through a severe slide, largely because of the higher cost of borrowing. The Nikkei stock average closed today at 25,070.86, up 2.4 percent, or 589.37 points. That still represents a 36 percent tumble from the beginning of the year, but it is also a steep increase from its low last month of nearly 20,000.
"You don't hear Japanese companies crying out the way they did when the dollar fell before," added Yoshihisa Kitai, aneconomist at the Long Term Credit Bank. "Japanese companies have already restructured their businesses to deal with this, and now you are seeing the result."
Until a few years ago, the weak yen had been a big source of economic strength for Japan, encouraging foreign buyers to purchase Japanese goods.
 
 Concern About the Dollar
 For the last few years, though, the Government has encouraged industries to cultivate the domestic market and invest heavily to increase productivity and to move more plants overseas.
Japanese Government officials are thus sanguine about the yen's strength, worrying only that it might rise too fast and disrupt the markets. "It is very interesting and telling that we hear very few complaints about the exchange rate," said a senior Government economic official. "It reflects the fact that companies have adapted."
Government and industry officials in Japan are more worried by the what the falling dollar signals about the United States. Many people blame the battle in Washington over the Federal budget and fears of a looming recession for an erosion of confidence in the American economy and American policy makers.
The message is that these officials have fewer concerns about their home market. Manufacturers have moved a significant portion of their factories overseas to avoid the impact of currency swings. Toyota, for instance, announced it was building a second auto plant in the United States, just one in a wave of such moves.
The Government has also shown some success in waking up the Japanese consumer and creating a boom at home that has eased further the reliance on exports. Retail sales have been expanding at a nearly double-digit rate this year, for instance. And a record level of capital investment by Japanese companies is providing a big impetus for economic growth.
On top of that, the dollar's tumble has offset part of the huge increase in crude oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.
"If the dollar falls to 110 yen, then you could begin to see some problems, but most companies have already achieved the ability to deal well with the dollar at 120 yen," said Susumu Kato, the chief economist for Goldman Sachs (Japan).

HEADLINE: Connecticut Democrat Fights to Gather Voters

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Oct. 21

 BODY:
Over the blare of a country-and-western band at the Sergeant Sakowicz post of the Polish Legion of American Veterans, Representative Bruce A. Morrison shouted out a short history of Federal immigration law. Too short, as it turns out.
Pulled away by an aide for a dash back to the car and a race to the next campaign appearance, Mr. Morrison left his questioner, Thomas A. Bozek, unsatisfied with a partial answer on a topic about which Mr. Morrison is an acknowledged expert in Congress. 
 "He communicates face-to-face, he eyeballs you, he has command of an issue," Mr. Bozek said about his first encounter with Mr. Morrison, the Democratic nominee for governor. "But he's under pressure, obviously. I think he's crossed the 11th hour."
With only two weeks before the election, Mr. Morrison -- running third in a three-way race, according to opinion polls -- urgently needs to win over longtime Democrats like Mr. Bozek, a New Britain alderman and member of the party's Town Committee who remains uncommitted despite months of appeals.
And while a 10-minute appearance at a party of graying veterans maynot decide the election, neither did it succeed in enlisting the support of Mr. Bozek or his influence in this industrial suburb of Hartford. State party officials concede that such glancing blows have marked the Morrison campaign from the beginning.
"If I could figure out what it was, I would put my finger on it and change it," said the chairman of the party's State Central Committee, John F. Droney Jr. "There's just not as a strong an impression as should be made."
Party leaders insist that Mr. Morrison's message of economic revival and social responsibility, including a universal health-insurance plan that could be the first of its kind in the nation, is appealing to voters once they get a feel for it. The task for the final weeks, they say, is not to find a salable message, but to identify where the message can be driven home.
 
No Drawn-Out Discourse
 Some fault the breakneck pace of the Morrison campaign, which allows little time for dawdling or drawn-out discourse. Mr. Bozek, for example, drove to the next Morrison event to try and continue his discussion, but he was too late.
Mr. Droney said that the campaign's 30-second television spots have also yet to capture "the real Bruce." Mr. Droney said that television -- the crucible of today's campaigns -- may simply not be Mr. Morrison's best medium. The candidate is really "a lot warmer and a lot more likable and impressive," in real life, Mr. Droney said.
Mr. Morrison disputes any suggestion that his own campaign techniques may have done him an injustice by failing to get across his closely reasoned liberal critique of the state's economy and services. That critique differs dramatically from the generally conservative, hands-off approach of the Republican, Representative John G. Rowland, or the broadly stated themes of duty and responsibility that have marked the campaign of former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a Republican who is running under the Connecticut Party banner.
Mr. Morrison argues, for example, that greater social involvement by the state -- especially on health care -- is one of the best ways to retain private employment because it would reduce the costs of doing business. He also favors restrictions on the authority of local communities to act independently of each other, especially on such issues as affordable housing, because he argues, integrated housing is the only way to integrate the schools.
"I had a different picture of him from TV, what I've read and from his own press releases," said George L. Geers, editor of The Chronicle, a small daily in Willimantic that Mr. Morrison visited on Monday to meet the editors and seek the paper's endorsement.
"I felt that there would be more of a formality, and with formality a sense of professional tension, but I didn't feel that," Mr. Geers said. "He was relaxed."
 
An Unaffiliated Voter
 In the Democratic party scenario for victory, people like Roger Gelinas loom large. Mr. Gelinas, a 50-year-old cemetary caretaker from Waterbury, stepped up to Mr. Morrison at the Polish Legion party and said he changed his mind and would vote for Mr. Morrison after all.
"I wasn't for you in the beginning -- I was for Weicker all the way," Mr. Gelinas said. "But Weicker is not opening his mouth about what he's going to do."
Mr. Gelinas, an unaffiliated voter since 1961, said later that he really didn't like some of Mr. Morrison's ideas at all -- especially the one about having a statewide referendum on the question of a personal income tax -- but that the other candidates were worse.
Mr. Morrison distressed some of his longtime liberal enthusiasts earlier this year when he said that an income-tax on wages -- for years a key plank in the progressive agenda -- would not be imposed by his administration unless voters approved a specific plan first. But Mr. Rowland vowed to veto any income-tax plan, as did Mr. Weicker, at least while the economy is in recession.
 
The Core Supporters
 Some other Democrats however, especially among the moderates who were the core supporters of Gov. William A. O'Neill, say that Mr. Morrison has not bowed to the center enough to win those voters to his side.
"We want a sharing, a balance between both ends of our party, liberal and conservative," Mr. Bozek said.
Other politicians say, however, that New Britain, with its strong union membership, political clubs and ethnic enclaves, is not really like much of the rest of the state. People here decide their votes on things other than television, said State Representative Dave Pudlin, a Democrat who represents the city in the General Assembly. Mr. Pudlin's example is that New Britain's voters went overwhelmingly for Michael S. Dukakis, the Democratic nominee for president in 1988.
"If you have to rely on those 15-second commercials, it must drive you nuts," he said. "I've never seen Bruce as an electronic candidate."

HEADLINE: A.T.&T. to Raise Weekend and Night Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A.T.&T. said yesterday that it would raise its rates for night and weekend long-distance telephone calls, which are mostly made by residential customers.
The 2.2 percent price rise is scheduled to take effect on Nov. 2, and follows another small increase in night and weekend rates on Nov. 29 of last year. Together, the increases represent a reversal of a six-year pattern of falling prices for the cheapest long-distance calls, and some experts predict further rises. 
 Average long-distance rates have fallen steadily since the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984, and continue to do so in the highly competitive market for services offered to large business customers.
But residential customers have proved more reluctant than businesses to change long-distance carriers to save money, making it possible for the carriers to shift onto consumers slightly more of the cost of maintaining their equipment.
A.T.&T.'s night and weekend rate is in effect from 11 P.M. to 8 A.M. Sunday through Friday and on weekends until 5 P.M. on Sunday.
The Federal Communications Commission will review the planned rate increase, but approval is virtually automatic under new regulations adopted 15 months ago.
Yesterday's announcement drew immediate criticism from consumer groups, who have said the discount for night and weekend calls should be larger.
"It's being wiped out because A.T.&T. refuses to pass along its savings and the F.C.C. refuses to regulate a market that's not competitive," said Gene Kimmelman, the legislative director and telephone industry analyst at the Consumer Federation of America in Washington. "So we're stuck."
With the price increase scheduled for Nov. 2, the night and weekend rate discount from daytime prices will fall to 45 percent, from 60 percent in the years before and immediately after the breakup. A.T.&T.'s overall costs of providing service are dropping because new technologies have been developed, like fiber-optic cables, which use lasers to transmit many calls simultaneously through hair-thin strands of glass.
 
 60's Rates Held Too Low
 But some industry consultants say that the shrinking discount is justified, and that further increases in night and weekend rates are likely. A.T.&T. set the rates too low in the 1960's, to try to spread telephone traffic evenly between day and night, and has never raised them enough to cover costs fully, said William J. Baumol, a professor of economics at Princeton University and New York University who also does some consulting work for A.T.&T.
Before the breakup, it cost A.T.&T. almost nothing to handle extra calls in the evening and at night because it owned all the telephone network equipment and had few extra operating costs. But now, A.T.&T. must pay a fixed rate to local telephone companies for beginning and completing long-distance calls, and this rate does not vary with the time of day.
Merrill R. Tutton, A.T.&T.'s vice president for consumer services, said of the planned increase, "The change is necessary to bring prices in line with costs."
Mr. Tutton and other A.T.&T. marketing executives declined to discuss the price increase further. James D. Kowalski, a vice president for Federal regulatory affairs at A.T.&T., said the increase was consistent with a competitive marketplace.
 
 Reaching Federal Limit
 A.T.&T. will now be charging consumers the maximum allowed by Federal regulators for long-distance service. By comparison, the company's rates for inbound business calls, which mostly consist of toll-free 800 numbers that corporations rent, are 98.3 percent of the maximum, while outbound business calls are 97.8 percent of the limit, said Robert S. Nersesian, a spokesman.
The MCI Communications Corporation and the U S Sprint Communications Company, which are A.T.&T.'s biggest long-distance rivals, are not subject to price regulation. The companies said they would study A.T.&T.'s move before responding, a process that U S Sprint said would take a week.
 
 5 Cents on a $16 Bill
 The A.T.&T. price rise will increase the company's annual revenues by $39.4 million, and add about 5 cents to the average $16 monthly long-distance telephone bill. But for a college student or other lower-income consumer who waits until after 11 P.M. on weekdays or calls on weekends and has a $50 monthly bill, the difference would be $1.10 a month, or $13.20 a year.
In a report to Congress last week, the F.C.C. defended its system of regulating A.T.&T.'s revenues from several large groups of services instead of regulating the price of each service. The study said that while the rates for some consumer services might have risen, such as weekend and night rates, the average residential consumer's cost of service had dropped 4.4 percent under the new rules.

HEADLINE: Negotiator's Quiet Style Elicits Loud Protest

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
In negotiating his first city labor contract amid the city's worst financial troubles in years, Eric J. Schmertz, New York City's new chief negotiator, placed a premium on avoiding even a hint of incivility. But now Mr. Schmertz, an impartial mediator and arbitrator by training, finds that his nonconfrontational approach has offended just about everyone outside the municipal work force.
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch found the first settlement, with the teachers union, grounds for a personal attack. Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said it produced a contract the city could not afford and should repudiate. Even some administration officials say Mr. Schmertz gave away too much too soon and never forced the union to grapple with the city's yawning budget gap.
 
'Quiet Diplomat'
 
 Some of his critics question whether he has made the transition to partisan negotiator. For his part, Mr. Schmertz said he has no intention of changing his style or strategy. A dignified, soft-spoken man -- friends and doubters alike say descriptions like "quiet diplomat," "civilized" and "quietly cerebral," suit him as well as his tailored clothes and mane of white hair -- he said his unruffled bargaining approach is grounded in history and experience.
"I believe in working with the unions asproblem-solving partners," he said in an interview as he puzzled over the harsh reaction to the teachers' contract, which resulted in wage increases of 5.5 percent. "I don't believe in confrontational or devious bargaining, or sharp bargaining. I believe in honesty and openness. I am not going to radically change my persona."
A former dean of Hofstra University Law School on Long Island and one of the top labor arbitrators in the country, Mr. Schmertz honed his approach while solving more than 8,000 labor disputes.
"His history is essentially as a third-party arbitrator, a fact finder," said Raymond D. Horton, a business professor at Columbia University and research director for the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by the business community. "Whether he has successfully made the transition to management representative: that is the question. The job of the labor negotiator is to represent the Mayor."
According to this view, rather than forcing the lowest cost settlement in a time of fiscal austerity, Mr. Schmertz cast himself as an intermediary. Operating with considerable independence, he set the tone for bargaining, decided what was fair and affordable and convinced Mayor David N. Dinkins to support an agreement over the objections of the city budget director. He said he listened to the unions and the administration voices and tried to find common ground.
"He's the only one in the administration I trust," said Barry Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. In the uproar following the teachers' settlement, Mr. Feinstein complained that the administration repeatedly repudiated settlement figures mentioned by Mr. Schmertz in informal talks.
 
Saw Koch as Confrontational
 Malcolm D. MacDonald, chairman of the New York City Board of Collective Bargaining and a friend, said: "He has a genius for finding the deal."
But his approach also bore the marks of what prompted an earlier brush with city government. Eight years ago, Mayor Koch stripped him of several prestigious and lucrative arbitration posts and blackballed him from appointments for ruling against the city in several high-profile cases.
After that, Mr. Schmertz became increasing uneasy with what he saw as Mr. Koch's confrontational style. When he became chief negotiator, he said, he vowed to do things differently.
Concluding that the city's budget director had too much say in negotiations in the Koch administration, Mr. Schmertz set out to limit that role. One budget official, who for years had sat in on talks, costing out proposals and occasionally raising technical objections, was banned from the table this year by Mr. Schmertz.
 
Within Days, Talk of Layoffs
 "Certainly the negotiator and the Mayor need to know what things cost and what affects the budget," Mr. Schmertz said. "But I don't think the budget director should be the arbiter of how the city bargains, or what the city is ultimately prepared to do."
The deal with the United Federation of Teachers, in the view of many critics, accommodated the narrow concerns of each side but not the broader concerns about the city's fiscal health.
The settlement was reached in late-night bargaining after Sandra Feldman, the teachers union president, set a strike deadline and threatened to shut down the schools.
Asked if the threat was the kind of confrontational bargaining he abhors, Mr. Schmertz said: "Well, it may have been confrontational on her part."
Within days, Mayor Dinkins began discussing layoffs in public, bond-rating agencies sounded alarms, editorials called on the administration to rescind the increase in wages and benefits and Mr. Koch began attacking.
 
Thanks 'for the Schmertz'
 "I have now turned Schmertz into a verb and a noun," the former Mayor said. "If you have been abused, we say you have been Schmertzed. If you get an unwarranted and undeserved payment from the City of New York, you say, 'Thank you Mr. Mayor, for the Schmertz.' "
All this astounded Mr. Schmertz, who believed the settlement had neatly skirted budget concerns. He agreed to increases larger than the 1.5 percent called for in the city budget only if they were financed by other savings.
But the city's outside fiscal monitors said other savings ought to be used to reduce the city's budget gap.
"Maybe we did not do a good public-relations job in its portrayal," Mr. Schmertz said. "If you focus on the expenditure of money from the city budget, this is the least expensive settlement in the history of labor settlements in New York City."
 
Private and Public Unions
 On the budget gap, he said that while he knew the city was in trouble, "I was not completely up to speed on the timing of it."
Mr. Schmertz believes there is a fundamental difference between public and private unions. In the private sector, where strikes are lawful and costs can be passed to consumers, he said, "the economic struggle is part of the bargaining." But in city government, where strikes are prohibited, unions should be seen as the city's partners.
Other experts disagree. "I think the process is the same," said Edward Silver, a labor lawyer and member of the Board of Collective Bargaining.
Mr. Schmertz, who is 64 years old, took on the job as the city's $110,000-a-year Labor Relations Commissioner at a time many other people consider retirement. He had traveled across the country, commanded fees of $600 a day and earned upward of $500,000 a year.
 
Maybe a Diplomat or a Ballplayer
 His return to New York City was a kind of vindication, a return from "suburban exile" at Hofstra, he said.
A founding member of the three-member New York City Board of Collective Bargaining, which was set up in 1967 to oversee contract disputes and impasses, Mr. Schmertz served on the board for 15 years, until Mr. Koch refused to reappoint him. Once, while arbitrating a dispute with the firefighters, Mr. Schmertz worked on a fire truck to better understand their concerns.
Mr. Koch said he forced Mr. Schmertz out because he favored the unions over the city. Mr. Schmertz said he was punished for following his conscience, the law and contract language.
Born in New York City and reared in the suburbs, Mr. Schmertz's first ambition was to be a diplomat, though he might have been an infielder with the Pittsburgh Pirates, who offered him a contract after watching him play at New Rochelle High School.
 
A Different Process
 Instead, after serving in the Navy in World War II, he worked for several unions as a labor relations director for a subsidiary of the General Cable Corporation, went to law school and in 1962 went into private practice as an arbitrator and mediator.
While most of his experience has been as an arbitrator, Mr. Schmertz said he has conducted some negotiations, though never on the vast scale of New York City's collective bargaining.
Despite the outcry over the teachers' settlement, he said, he does not plan to change his approach in continuing talks with two other municipal unions representing workers ranging from cooks to engineers. Before the uproar, Mr. Schmertz had discussed settlements with the other unions only slightly lower than the deal with teachers.
But the process may be different. Mayor Dinkins has assigned the budget director, Philip R. Michael, to sit with Mr. Schmertz as an equal partner at the bargaining table.
"I don't believe the city is going to make an offer without Michael and Schmertz agreeing to it," said Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Cost Trade-Offs On Medical Care

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
PARTICIPANTS in the struggle with balloon ing health-care costs are under pressure to accept some kind of change. Congress is tightening regulation on physicians and considering new controls on private health insurance for the elderly. Many employers who provide health benefits for workers favor special taxes on businesses that do not do so. Advocates of publicly financed health insurance, meanwhile, blame the medical profession and private insurers for the system's problems.
Trying to shape the debate, and perhaps deflect some criticism along the way, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is sponsoring a survey of employers, union executives, health professionals, insurers and Government regulators. Representatives of each group were asked if they would be willing to make sacrifices "as part of a total plan in which everyone made some concessions." 
 The survey, conducted by Louis Harris & Associates, asked doctors, for example, if they would accept lower incomes if there could be less regulation and second-guessing by insurers, and limits on malpractice lawsuits. Unions were asked if they would trade a portion of workers' health benefits for higher wages. Employers were asked if they would accept Government requirements and controls in a national health insurance system.
Hospital executives were asked if they would trade lower revenues for assurances of fewer empty beds. Insurers were asked if they would accept the costs of restoring affordable coverage for uninsured workers and people with pre-existing health conditions. Everyone in the survey was asked about attitudes toward rationing of health care and/or arrangements that limit a patient's choice of doctors, which insurers call managed care. Spokesmen for some of the interested parties generally welcomed the concept of trade-offs and concessions. But perhaps not surprisingly, they had widely varying opinions about who should be asked to make which concessions.
"I see value in the idea of feeling out the major sectors of our society," said John J. Sweeney, president of the Service Workers International Union and chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. national health-care committee. "It is a measure of the momentum that is being created for reform of the health-care system." He added: "We know that employers are going to have a different view than the labor movement. We are not going to give up a basic right that all Americans have to health care."
Sharon Canner, an assistant vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said that most employers opposed Government mandates. But she added: "Looking at economic trade-offs is a very worthwhile and realistic approach. We've been saying that everyone is going to have to give."
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association, said that many doctors would willingly "trade less money for more automony" and reduced regulation by Government and private insurers. If there were less paperwork, he added, doctors would need fewer office assistants and could thus reduce their fees. He said health costs were often inflated when doctors provide care for "extraneous reasons" like concerns about lawsuits, decisions by courts and pressure by special-interest groups.
Edward J. Connors, a former chairman of the American Hospital Association and president of Mercy Health Services in Farmington Hills, Mich., said priority should be given to "access to affordable care for all who need it." Access should take precedence over "other needs and demands or biases of the provider system," he added.
Humphrey Taylor, president of Louis Harris, said the survey was trying "to explore how a consensus might build" on causes and solutions for health-care problems. "If the solution was painless, we wouldn't need a consensus," he added.
"We are going to see some insurance reform, in the small-employer market," said John D. Moynihan, an executive vice president at Metropolitan Life, which paid $500,000 for the survey. "There is a great deal that private employers, unions, doctors have to do. The Government will have to share the load." He said Medicaid for the indigent "is in a shambles."
Ms. Canner of the manufacturers association noted that the survey asked employers, among other things, if they would accept managed care. "Metropolitan is obviously selling managed care," she said. Mr. Moynihan acknowledged that results of the survey, which are due early next year, will have business uses. "The survey might say the American public won't stand for managed care," he said. "If so, we need to know that."
"Everybody seems to agree that the health-care system needs to be fixed," Mr. Moynihan said. "As important and complex as the national health system is, we get nervous when we hear strident voices shrieking for instant reform in Congress. We want to get at the issues and fix them, but not in a crisis mode."

HEADLINE: Careers;
Retainer Fees for Management Recruiters

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
MANY management recruiting firms have been developing a new way to stabilize their revenues, by encouraging client companies to pay retainer fees.
The firms have been doing this quietly in recent years for competitive reasons, but with recession concerns deepening, it is becoming more and more prevalent. 
 Management recruiters want to refashion themselves along the lines of law firms that collect retainer fees from their clients, promoting a close and enduring relationship.
Accountants also work on this principle, with long-term relations helping to produce auditing and tax advisory income on a regular basis. Public relations consultants also rely on retainers.
David M. Richardson, executive vice president of DHR International Inc., a sizable management recruiting firm based in Chicago, with half a dozen offices around the country, calls this growing trend in his business "partnering."
"It amounts to getting some capital and solidifying relationships in these difficult times," he said. "For the client, it can mean putting together a package with lower fees. It brings both closer together." It also can help the client company through more flexible manpower planning.
He named Scientific-Atlanta Inc., an electronics company, as a client with which his firm has had a retainer relationship in the past, as well as Nabisco Brands Inc., the big food unit of RJR Nabisco Inc.
David R. Peasback, president and chief executive officer of Canny, Bowen Inc., a major management recruiter based in New York City that specializes in searches for senior-level executives, confirmed that his firm also had such arrangements, calling the practice a "very good idea" and a growing trend.
Mr. Richardson traces "partnering" as a basic management concept back at least to the early 1980's, when companies with "specific needs for goods or services" tried to make long-term deals about prices and delivery with their suppliers.
However, it probably goes back much earlier, perhaps more than 50 years, to the Sears, Roebuck-type of tradition of contracting to take a large part or all of the production of appliance makers for products to be sold under the Sears label.
Buyers of goods or services, Mr. Richardson said, want long-term price or fee stability, along with guaranteed quality and flexibility as to delivery as well as a better understanding of their continuing needs. Sellers, or providers of services, want longer-term assurance of how much they can sell or how much service they will supply, as well as an awareness of the delivery needs of customers.
Mr. Richardson explained how the approach works in management recruiting: a company might pay an annual retainer of $100,000 to a management recruiting firm for a year's service. For this, the management recruiting firm would not only fill the specific requests from the client firm for executives needed, but also provide additional advisory services, as well as keeping in mind the type of people that would fit well into that organization. To do this, Mr. Richardson said, the recruiter would also be expected to learn as much as possible about the client's overall organization, which can be a significant fact-finding process in this period of downsizings, acquisitions and decentralization.
For example, Mr. Richardson said, a recruiter for a bank might know that even though the bank had no current opening for a certain position, it wanted officers with a particular personality, public image, educational background and experience. In other words, it was interested in meeting potential candidates who would fit into the bank's corporate culture.
When such a candidate appeared or was discovered during a routine search by the firm, the recruiter might suggest that an interview would be useful for both the bank, with the idea that this is "your type person," and for the candidate, with the thought that "this is your type of company." Obviously, this widens the market for some middle managers seeking job changes.
Meantime, the $100,000 would be in the recruiter's bank account assuring the recruiting firm that it could count on that much business from a particular client company during a year.
As searches were completed, the amount on hand would be reduced by the usual fee due for that job Since the fees of recruiters run about 33 percent of salaries received, the $100,000 would cover about three searches a year for managers placed in jobs earning about $100,000, unless special lower fee arrangements were made.
Lester B. Korn, the chairman of Korn/Ferry International, the nation's largest management recruiting firm, talked about the concept of retainers recently at a meeting of consultants, saying that "sophisticated" human resource executives nowadays seek long-term relationships with management recruiters.
He agrees that one reason is to promote "in-depth knowledge" of a client's operation and its particular culture. The retainer idea also ties in neatly with the desire of many recruiting firms to expand into consulting services regarding compensation levels and job fitness.
However, there may be some drawbacks to the idea of retainer fees. For example, large recruiting firms like Korn/Ferry probably can persuade large client companies to pay retainers, but the small, more localized management recruiters probably cannot extract retainers from clients as easily. Often the small firms handle one-shot assignments for smaller companies in their area.

HEADLINE: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
Garden Party: Move Over, Bob Uecker

BYLINE: By George Vecsey

 BODY:
Just when you thought the Reagan years were over, deregulation has reared its avaricious head. The friendly folks from Gulf and Western, or whatever that corporation is calling itself these days, are raising prices right through the renovated rafters.
The management of Madison Square Garden is planning to tell loyal Rangers fans and loyal Knicks fans, who have not been rewarded with a championship since 1940 and 1973, respectively, that their services are no longer required, at least not at anything approaching the current rates. 
 The plan for the 1991-92 season is to sell as many as 2,200 courtside or rinkside seats for as much as $70 per game. This means that "Missed Foul Shots" will soon soar beyond the price range of "Miss Saigon."
Taking a cue from the Left Coast, the Garden may also sell a few front-row "celebrity" seats for $300 apiece to those who like to display their cellular phones and gold watches and designer girlfriends in front of millions.
But let us not conjure up a populist diatribe about real fans being driven out by bloodless richies. Instead, let us envision Jack Nicholson, the Joker, all decked out in yellows and purples and the latest hipster shades, cavorting at courtside at the Forum, which is in the state of Los Angeles. Jack knows the game. And he pays $450 a pop for the right to interact with Magic Johnson.
"Nice socks," Kareem Abdul-Jabbar once told Nicholson in the middle of a roaring fast break.
Nicholson figures he has been worth a game or two over the years, by distracting rabbit-ear coaches like Dick Motta and flashing his malevolent smile, or worse, on the likes of Larry Bird.
In recent years, the Garden has been trying to imitate the celebrity row of the Forum, with a short row of seats that Richard Evans has monitored with the intensity of Jimmy Carter peering out the White House window to see who was using the tennis court.
It is always exciting to see the latest hot singer or the latest boxing contender preening in the front row, and it is fascinating to wonder what Spike Lee and Tom Brokaw would have said if they had spoken while sitting next to each other. ("Love your work." "Oh, no, love your work.")
But the Garden got it wrong. It gave away the celebrity seats. (The lunkheads who misrun the United States Open got it even more wrong. Charismatic Wilt Chamberlain stuck his long body in the front row and the nabobs ran him off.) Still, there is a principle involved here: People do not value what they get for free. If you make 'em pay for it, there's a $300 customer born every minute.
It used to be that big money drove out the good fans. Back when life was normal and the World Series used to be held in the hazy sunshine of Yankee Stadium every October, well-connected gents in camel's hair jackets with pomade lathered on their heads used to frequent the Stadium for the first and only time that season.
They were heavy hitters, but they did not know much about heavy hitting, and would often ooh when they should have ahhed, or sometimes leave in the seventh inning of Don Larsen's perfect game to beat the traffic.
But in this television age, sports have become ever more important. One of the little-known facts about the Garden is that many of the people, if I may generalize, in the upper deck are actually chief executive officers of major corporations.
It's true. They have taken to the blue seats, in raffish camaraderie, chanting vicious diatribes at Denis Potvin (who hasn't played in years, but you never know) and occasionally breaking up the furniture and throwing live fish onto the ice. The anonymity of the blue seats enables these c.e.o.'s to behave as aggressively at the arena as they do in the board room.
Now, however, these big-timers are faced with a serious decision. Even with a recession coming on, it is going to be a matter of prestige to come up with the 300 smackers for the privilege of having Patrick Ewing come hurtling right at them in pursuit of a loose ball. (The danger is not as strong from some of the other Knicks.)
After all, somebody has got to pay for the $200 million renovations at the Garden, which the friendly folks mandated rather than build a threatened new Garden out on the Far West Side, last decade's bad idea.
Unfortunately, the price hike will force many of the humble current $45 patrons to join that legendary recipient of the bad freebies, Bob Uecker, in the upper deck.
There is a positive side to this shakeout. If the Rangers should level off, or one Ewing ankle sprain should turn the Knicks into the Charlotte Hornets, the biggies will not want to be intimately associated with a loser.
At that point, the worldly ushers of our town, as they do at the United States Open and Shea Stadium, will be glad to help you out if you help them out. Back in Odessa, they call it a second economy. In the coming hard times, we may need all the economy we can get.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Are Auto Payouts Likely to Be Cut?

BYLINE: Doron P. Levin

 BODY:
THE depressed state of the Big Three auto makers' shares is sparking a debate among analysts over whether investors now have an opportunity to reap unusually attractive dividends.
The bullish perspective focuses on the relatively strong financial positions and liquidity of General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler as evidence that auto makers will be able to pay dividends, despite prolonged softness in vehicle sales. 
 The bears argue that historical trends pertaining to recessions make dividend cuts inevitable. Indeed, current low share prices suggest that many investors already see dividends as vulnerable.
Late last month, Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. polled 22 analysts about their assessment of dividend cuts by the auto makers. The analysts rated the probability of G.M.'s cutting the dividend at an average of 20 percent; the average odds of a Ford cut were 23 percent. At Chrysler, the weakest of the three, the average odds were 55 percent.
All three stocks are trading just above their year's lows and well under their highs. Ford closed yesterday at 32, compared with a range for the year of 29 3/8 to 49 1/8; G.M. at 38 3/4, compared with 35 to 50 1/2, and Chrysler at 11 5/8, compared with 9 1/8 to 20 3/8. At those prices, G.M.'s yield is 7.9 percent, Ford's is 9.6 percent and Chrysler's is a whopping 10.8 percent. Those yields compare with the 8.75 percent yield on 30-year Treasury bonds and 7.2 percent on short-term Treasury securities.
Analysts agree that a long and fierce Persian Gulf war would have negative consequences for the economy, for energy supplies and, thus, for auto sales, which far outweigh military contractsfor all three companies. The question, insofar as dividends are concerned, is how quickly managements would act to conserve cash.
"In the event of a serious military outbreak, dividends would have to be called into question," said Ronald Glantz, automotive analyst for Dean Witter in San Francisco. "But there won't be many places to hide in the stock market if that happens."
There is general agreement that G.M., as the biggest and financially strongest auto maker, would be the last to cut a dividend. David Healy, automotive analyst for Barclays de Zoete Wedd, rates G.M. stock a buy, partly because its yield compares with the yields of Government securities while offering substantial opportunity for growth. He said he believes dividends are safe unless an economic downturn endures for two years. But he also conceded that investors would face less risk by investing in Treasury bonds.
Analysts agree that Chrysler's stock presents the biggest risk. While adequately financed for the next 18 months, Chrysler's bonds and commercial paper ratings have dropped, making the auto maker potentially more reliant on bank financing in the future. Mr. Glantz said bankers could suggest cutting the dividend as a condition for extending credit lines.
Charles Brady, automotive analyst for Oppenheimer & Company, argued that Chrysler could make a case for keeping its dividend at almost any cost. "The effect on the financial community would be minimal, but the unsophisticated consumermay view this as Chrysler going out of business and not buy a car," he said. "The company could lose 35,000 sales, costing more than it saves if it cuts the dividend."
Ford's dividend should be safe, Mr. Brady added, if the company abides by its own preachings. He said, "A few years ago people were knocking Ford because they weren't paying out more of their earnings, but Ford said, 'We set our dividend policy based on sustainability -- good times, bad times, come what may.' "
Mr. Glantz also contended that Ford's dividend was secure. He pointed out that Ford had reduced the dividend only three times since it became a public company in 1956, each time when its net cash balance -- cash and marketable securities minus debt -- was lower than his forecast for the end of 1991.
But Ann Knight, automotive analyst for Paine Webber, predicted that a recession lasting more than six months would result in a dividend cut at all three auto makers. "Managements are more committed to maintaining dividends, but things aren't so substantially different than they were in the past," she said. She is not recommending any of the Big Three stocks as a buy.
An important clue to a company's dividend policy is the chief executive's latest statement on the subject.
Harold A. (Red) Poling, Ford's chairman, said on Sept. 28: "I would not characterize our dividend as vulnerable. Should a dramatic change happen that we can't foresee today, there might need to be an adjustment."
Lee A. Iacocca, Chrysler's chairman, said in late August that "all good companies go through periods where they don't earn enough to cover the dividend and keep paying it anyway." On May 17, he said Chrysler would maintain the dividend "short of a nuclear disaster."
G.M. declined comment.

HEADLINE: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
Moody's Lowers Its Ratings On American Air and Delta

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Ratings have been lowered on about $6 billion of outstanding debt issued by the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, and Delta Air Lines Inc., Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.
Among the reasons cited by Moody's were higher costs of jet fuel, softer travel demand and heavy investment in modernization and expansion. 
 The lowering of AMR's ratings affects about $3.5 billion in long- and short-term securities. Moody's cited "the expectation for reduced financial flexibility in light of the outlook for lower earnings during a period of very substantial capital spending by the airline subsidiary."
Moody's said that a reduced cash flow would result in a deterioration in the company's credit quality and higher risk for creditors as borrowings and off-balance-sheet lease obligations increase and the coverage of interest rates payments and fixed charges diminish.
 
 Large Investments for Hubs
 Despite the present concern, the rating agency expects American to retain its strong competitive position in the mid-1990's and beyond. In recent years the carrier has invested heavily in establishing domestic hubs for both domestic and international traffic.
AMR's industrial revenue bond rating was lowered to A-3 from A-2 and senior unsecured debt to Baa-1 from A-3. The rating on American Airlines' pass-through certificates, secured equipment certificates and industrial revenue bonds was lowered to A-2 from A-1, while the subordinated debenture rating was reduced to Baa-1 from A-3 and the commercial paper rating to Prime-2 from Prime-1.
The rating change on Delta debt is the result of a deteriorating outlook for earnings caused by higher jet fuel prices, a drop in domestic air travel, and the airline's spending plans to expand in the United States and overseas, the rating agency said.
It expects the airline's expenditures for modernization, fleet expansion and the addition of Asian and European cities to its international routes to place a strain on the debt protection for creditors.
Delta's secured equipment trust certificates and those secured equipment trust certificates that are filed under Rule 144A of the Securities and Exchange Commission, requiring less information, were lowered to A-2 from A-1, while the senior unsecured debt and industrial revenue bond ratings were dropped to A-3 from A-2. The commercial paper rating was also reduced, to Prime-2 from Prime-1.
Despite the downgrading, Moody's analysts said Delta was positioning itself to become a global competitor in the mid-1990's and had allied itself in the last year with other operators like Swissair and Singapore Airlines through a mutual purchase of stock.

HEADLINE: Net Off 39% at Tribune Co.

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Oct. 22

 BODY:
The Tribune Company said today that its third-quarter net income declined 39 percent because of operating losses at its Canadian paper mills and The Daily News in New York.
The company said net income fell to $38.2 million, or 52 cents a share, from $62.7 million, or 81 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. Revenues slipped five-tenths of 1 percent, to $588 million, from $590.7 million a year earlier.
Newspaper operating profit fell 15 percent in the quarter, to $48.4 million, from $56.7 million last year, because of losses at The Daily News. The company attributed the losses at The Daily News to weak economic conditions in the New York market and a "burdensome cost structure" that is the subject of labor negotiations.
Profits for the rest of the newspaper group, which includes The Chicago Tribune and The Orlando (Fla.) Sentinel, were down slightly, the company said.
For the third quarter, the company's Quebec and Ontario Paper Company reported a loss of $8.3 million, compared with a profit of $15.2 million last year. Strikes by paper workers shut down the Quebec newsprint mill for 31 days and the Ontario mill for 47 days.
Beside its newspapers and newsprint operations, the Chicago-based company is engaged in broadcasting and entertainment production. The Tribune Company's stock gained 75 cents today, to $35.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: 'Anti-Incumbent Fever' Threatens Oregon Senator

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 22

 BODY:
Nowhere in the country is the nation's sour political mood being tested more directly this year than in Oregon.
Voters here are struggling to decide whether they are so angry at Washington that they want to throw out of office a Senator they have known and elected for a very long time.
Mark O. Hatfield, who after 24 years in the Senate is the body's second-ranking Republican, is in danger of losing his seat to a businessman named Harry Lonsdale, a newcomer to politics who in this year of political discontent is running the quintessential example of an outsider campaign. 
 With the mild manners of Mr. Smith before he went to Washington and the us-versus-them language of Huey Long, Mr. Lonsdale has used a sophisticated advertising campaign against Mr. Hatfield, describing the Senator as a tool of the timber industry and a defender of dumpers of toxic waste and other special interests who fill his coffers with campaign contributions.
"The rich and powerful are robbing us blind, and the politicians in Washington are not doing a thing to stop them," Mr. Lonsdale says in a television advertisement. "They've taken too many special interest dollars for too long. I'm running for the Senate because it's time for new blood and fresh thinking. It's time someone said no to special interests and fought for the rest of us."
 
'Sound Bites to Survive'
 Mr. Lonsdale's success with this appeal has forced Mr. Hatfield, a 68-year-old bookish iconoclast who had clung to the belief that town meetings were more effective than poll takers and negative advertisements, to do something he never thought he would do: run an aggressive television campaign with commercials attacking Mr. Lonsdale.
"Now, apparently, we have to talk in 30-second sound bites to survive," he told his advertising man, Ron Schmidt, after a screening of Mr. Lonsdale's advertisements a few days ago.
"This is the first major election in anybody's memory in which the virus of negative campaigning that we've seen in other areas has invaded Oregon," Mr. Hatfield said. "It's a new experience for me."
 
Not the First Troubles
 Mr. Hatfield has had troubles before, but has always risen above them. In the midst of his 1984 campaign newspapers disclosed his wife had received a real estate fee from a client with interests before the Senate. But the charge, which might have brought down many other politicians, turned into nothing more than a minor embarrassment after Mr. Hatfield and his wife came to Oregon and apologized.
A number of prominent Oregon Democrats, including Representative Ron Wyden, looked closely a year ago at possibility of challenging Mr. Hatfield and decided they could not beat him. That opened the way for Mr. Lonsdale to take the party's nomination.
An accumulation of criticisms, including one that Mr. Hatfield has not been in the state enough and another that his chief of staff took junkets on tax money, would surely have weakened him this year. But Tim Hibbitts, an Oregon poll taker, said Mr. Hatfield was not really in any danger of losing until he got caught up in the rising anger against Washington in just the last few weeks.
"The fundamental problem is we have got an anti-incumbent fever sweeping the state," he said.
 
Lonsdale Leading in Poll
 Mr. Hatfield said polls by his campaign showed his support had been shored up after he began responding to Mr. Lonsdale's advertisements. But a poll taken by Mr. Hibbitts and broadcast tonight by KATU-TV of Portland found Mr. Lonsdale ahead for the first time, 50 percent to 44 percent.
In that poll, 608 likely voters were surveyed by telephone over the weekend. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points. More than half of those surveyed said they thought Mr. Hatfield should be replaced, but not because they really favored Mr. Lonsdale. Forty-two percent said they still had no clear opinion of Mr. Lonsdale.
By all accounts, Mr. Hatfield, who is widely remembered as an early opponent of the Vietnam War and is still the closest thing mainstream American politics has to a pacifist, was slow to realize how much trouble he was in, or, at least, slow to respond.
"The wake-up call," as a spokesman for Mr. Hatfield called it, came when The Oregonian, the state's largest newspaper, published a poll that was taken after a wave of Lonsdale commercials and showed that Mr. Lonsdale had closed to within a few points of Mr. Hatfield.
 
'From 1965 to 1990'
 Suddenly, one of the institutions of the Senate, the former chairman of the appropriations committee and now its ranking Republican, was faced with the toughest fight of his career.
Mr. Hatfield, who has never spent more than a few thousand dollars on television before, authorized a full-scale counterattack, taking his campaign "from 1965 to 1990 in the space of three weeks," as one member of his political staf described it.
The most compelling illustration of this shift involved some former employees of Mr. Lonsdale's company, Bend Research, a small scientific products company. They had tried to give Mr. Hatfield's office derogatory information about Mr. Lonsdale's company months ago but were turned away. Two weeks ago they were called back by the altered Hatfield campaign and their allegation that the company dumped waste water with toxic chemicals has now been used in a commercial.
While he had been active in an environmental group that sought to preserve the forests, a group Mr. Hatfield's campaign describes as "radical," Mr. Lonsdale was unknown to most state residents six months ago, before his television campaign.
 
Support From Establishment
 The state's political establishment has rallied around Mr. Hatfield. The former chief of staff to Democratic Gov. Neil Goldschmidt moved into the Hatfield headquarters to run the campaign. Bob Packwood, the state's other Republican Senator, sent his chief of staff to help out, too.
This blurring of partisan lines is less remarkable here than it might be in an eastern state where party divisions run deeper. But it is also a testament to the sense that this state's business and political communities have of Mr. Hatfield and his seniority in Washington as an important state resource. Still, this closing of ranks could play into Mr. Lonsdale's hands and Mr. Hatfield acknowledged that his opponent has touched a nerve with that appeal.
In many places around America, this anger at Washington is more an abstraction, something voters can use to vent their anger without really doing anything. But here in Oregon they are being forced to measure their disenchantment against a real person.
Denis Long, a Republican and president of the Kiwanis in North Bend, a timber port on the Oregon coast, said he had known Mark Hatfield since the 1960's, but was sympathetic now to Mr. Lonsdale's criticism of him.
"I've got a big problem with the fact that these guys are back there and it's like a good-old-boys society," said Mr. Long. "You vote yourself a pay raise. You don't really solve problems; you just kind of shuffle it onto some of the junior people that are in your committee. 'Let's have a study and after we're done studying that, let's study the study.' "
 
Abortion and Timber
 But two other issues are also complicating Mr. Hatfield's campaign. One is abortion, which he opposes, although he tries to place his opposition in a broader context of support for family planning, contraception and counseling. Mr. Lonsdale supports access to abortion, clearly the more popular position in the state.
The other issue is timber. Asked why he got into the race, Mr. Lonsdale replies, "The trees." He says he never expected to win, but hoped he could force Mr. Hatfield to embrace much tougher restrictions on logging in the old, mature forests.
Mr. Hatfield has long sought a middle ground that would keep the timber industry in business while calming environmentalists.
But while timber remains a crucial industry here, the number of people directly employed in it has shrunk as high technology industry in the Portland suburbs has boomed.
"The growth has been among people who look at a clear cut and don't see jobs," explained David Sarasohn, associate editor of The Oregonian. That means growing numbers of voters are attracted to Mr. Lonsdale's policy of curbing logging.
 
Anger Not Seen Before
 While timber and abortion are important, this race is turning on the voters' anger. "I've been in the political arena here for 20 years and I've not seen anything like it at all," said Mr. Schmidt, Mr. Hatfield's advertising consultant.
Workers with Mr. Hatfield's campaign said they believed they were in trouble if the choice was, as Mr. Lonsdale presented it, between someone from Washington and someone who is not from Washington. But they said they could win if they could focus the voters on a choice between Mr. Hatfield and Mr. Lonsdale.
So the Hatfield campaign is trying to sow as many doubts about Mr. Lonsdale as quickly as it can. One television commercial cites a series of apparent uncertainties by Mr. Lonsdale about issues and asks, "Could Harry be over his head?" Another quotes the charges from former employees that Mr. Lonsdale's company dumped toxic wastes. In the meantime, Mr. Hatfield says he is philosophical about his struggle to regain the faith of a state he has represented for so long.
"I have to recognize this is a unique period of time with the fear about possible recession, the potential of war hanging over our heads, the demonstration of such paralysis in the Congress," he said. "I'm not going to overreact, to feel the people of Oregon have abandoned me or been seduced by the media."
