HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Small Budget, Small Star, Big Hit

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22

 BODY:
In a year that has been unkind to action movies with big names and big budgets, one movie with neither, "Marked for Death," seems marked for success. Made for a mere $12 million by two independent producers, this violent tale of vengeance has earned $29 million since its release on Oct. 5, including an opening weekend at the box office that was the second best ever for a fall film release.
As a movie, "Marked for Death"is little more than a cavalcade of shooting, stabbing, beheading and bone-cracking. Starring Steven Seagal, a martial arts expert with meager acting experience, the movie has received largely negative reviews. But as a commodity and an exercise in successful formula film making, the movie has quickly earned the admiration and the envy of studio executives here, all of whom are acutely aware they could not possibly have made the movie for the same price. 
 Producers say it costs $25 million on average to make a movie in Hollywood these days. But elaborate special effects and salaries of more than $10 million a picture for proven stars like Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone have driven the cost of the big action-adventure films of 1990, like "Total Recall" and "Robo Cop 2," beyond $40 million and, in some cases, even $60 million.
The big film studios "went crazy this summer," said Martin Baum, a longtime agent at the Creative Artists Agency. "They made a decision that the more you spend, the more business you do, and in all probability, they were wrong," he said. Mr. Baum represents Mark Victor and Michael Grais, the independent producers who wrote and made "Marked for Death" with their company, Victor & Grais Productions.
The strong initial box-office performance of "Marked for Death," Mr. Baum added, teaches that "you don't always have to spend more money to do the business. You can do the same business at a lesser cost factor if you provide the audience with the basic elements it looks for: fun, escapism, likability of the character and killing that is not wanton and gratuitous."
In "Marked for Death," Mr. Seagal, in his trademark ponytail, plays a Federal drug agent who returns to the peace and quiet of his small hometown. Needless to say, it doesn't stay that way for long. A gang of Jamaican crack dealers turns up to sell their wares, much to the hero's annoyance. The movie is rated R. The producers say Mr. Seagal adds a bonus in that he also appeals to women.
 
 Large Risks Taken
 Of course there were considerable risks in building "Marked for Death" around Mr. Seagal, a former martial arts instructor whose students include the chairman of the Creative Artists Agency, Michael Ovitz. Mr. Seagal had acted in only two movies. When Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais met him, Mr. Seagal had only recently put aside the aikido self-defense academy he owns here to make his film debut in "Above the Law," which did only modest business in theaters.
But Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais, who wrote the 1982 hit "Poltergeist" and wrote and produced "Poltergeist II," said they decided to "go for the gold" after seeing "Above the Law" in 1988 and concluding that Mr. Seagal had all the qualities to be a major action-adventure star.
Once it was clear that Mr. Seagal was available for about $1 million -- double his previous fee but a pittance by studio standards -- and a percentage of the film's gross, the producers were confident they could make "Marked for Death" at half the standard cost.
"We don't want to make this movie for $20 million because if we do, I'm never going to see any money in my own pocket," Mr. Victor said. "Beyond that, we only had $10 million, and I didn't want to get another private investor to put up $5 million more, because then I have an owner and another boss involved in the game."
Mr. Victor said he and Mr. Grais, who are both 42 years old and have been friends since their grade school days together in Highland Park, Ill., initially shopped the "Marked for Death" script around to several studios. At least one indicated it would be interested in someone other than Mr. Seagal in the lead role. But most of the established stars of action-adventure movies want big money up front in salary and a guaranteed share of the gross revenues. They are reluctant to accept "back end" profit-sharing deals with smaller independent producers.
"The difficult part is getting access to major stars, because everything is catered to and handled by the studio and the comfort levels are exceedingly high," Mr. Victor said. "When you are having those huge numbers flashed at you it's hard to sit back and say, 'O.K., I'm going to let somebody go and put it together a different way.' "
The same is true of established directors, who can also command huge fees and a percentage off the top. With that in mind, Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais turned to Dwight H. Little, who had directed the low-budget "Halloween 4" and was hoping to advance his career and land something more ambitious.
"A director of stature can go in knowing he can get $3 million to $5 million for his services with a gross deal that kicks in from the first dollar," Mr. Baum said. "He's going to say: 'Why should I gamble? I'm a proven commodity, and there's no reason for me to do this for nothing.' "
 
Impressed by First Film
 With Mr. Seagal under contract, 20th Century Fox proved willing to supply a $10 million advance on foreign theatrical and domestic video rights. Fox executives were impressed that Mr. Seagal's first effort had sold more than 200,000 copies in video, which they saw as proof he had a potential mass audience.
"It was a gut feeling that the marketplace was thirsty for a hero, that it was looking for someone to fill the Arnold Schwarzenegger gap," said Tom Sherak, head of marketing at the studio. "Arnold is the king of that genre, but he is going on to other things, and the audience is looking for a new hero. We had a feeling Steven Seagal was that hero."
Still, Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais were determined to limit formal studio involvement in "Marked For Death," for reasons of both creative and economic control. Their previous experience in making films in a studio setting, with all the featherbedding and profligacy that implies, had convinced them there was an easier and cheaper way to do things.
 
A Deal With the Unions
 "If you're not tied to studio overhead, you save 15 percent right there," Mr. Baum said. Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais "also worked out a deal with the unions that couldn't have been done under the studio aegis," he said.
When Mr. Seagal's second movie, "Hard to Kill," which co-starred his wife, Kelly LeBrock, opened earlier this year, it performed better than his first effort. That immediately made him a more financially attractive leading man. By that time, Mr. Victor said, 20th Century Fox had already asked to put up about $6 million to cover the costs of prints and advertising, in return for which it was to receive a share of box-office receipts. But the studio also agreed to pay a share of an additional $2 million that the producers decided to add directly to the filming.
"We decided after seeing his movie and what worked and what didn't that there were a couple of areas worth spending a little more money in, and that's what moved the budget up to $12 million," Mr. Victor said. "We wanted to beef up hand-to-hand fight sequences, we put more money into the car chase, and we put more money into sound than we had anticipated at the time. All these were things we thought would really appeal to the audience."
 
Moving Out of Reach
 Despite their success, it seems highly unlikely that Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais will soon team up again with Mr. Seagal for a sequel. Mr. Seagal is irritated because the Writers Guild of America rejected his claim for a share of authorship of the screenplay.
"You couldn't remake this movie today at the price we did it," Mr. Victor said. "First of all, Seagal would be making four or five million. You won't see a budget for him under $20 million again."
Nevertheless, the rise in Mr. Seagal's value does not necessarily prevent Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais from trying "to do this again with someone like Seagal," as they put it. "It has to be someone who is not getting his share of the pie but is on the brink of becoming a star," Mr. Baum said. "Or it can be someone in decline but who says: 'There's still life in me and let me prove it.' "
If they should try again, Mr. Victor and Mr. Grais have the assurance that the market for movie mayhem is always there and hungry for new faces. "As Seagal gets bigger and broadens his horizons, there will be a need to fill that void," Mr. Sherak said. "Someone will come along to be the next Steven Seagal."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mark Victor, left, and Michael Grais, the independent producers who wrote and made "Marked for Death." (Bart Bartholomew for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Reach an Accord On Reduction of Air Pollution

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 22

 BODY:
Settling years of regional political disputes, House and Senate negotiators reached final agreement today on changes in clean air legislation that are intended to strengthen and broaden the Government's authority to reduce air pollution. The amendments are the first in 13 years.
 Lawmakers hailed what they characterized as a breakthrough in setting stricter standards and in establishing new timetables for sharply cutting chemical contamination in the air. But many also agreed with environmental leaders that the problem is so vast and the required improvements so expensive that the nation is not likely to breathe much cleaner air until the first decade of the 21st century. 

 
Cost for Industry
 The agreement puts costly new burdens on industry, the Environmental Protection Agency, state environmental agencies and consumers. New equipment would be required for automobiles, possibly adding $500 to the cost of a new car. And the costs of dry cleaning, paint, steel and electricity could also increase.
 Some economists have estimated that compliance could cost $25 billion to $35 billion a year. But environmentalists contend that without the changes, the toll on public health and the environment would result in even greater costs.
 Leading industrial groups, including a coalition of companies and industries that has played an influential role in shaping the present form of the legislation and warding off tougher provisions, said they supported the new amendments.
 
Bush's Approval Expected
 The bill now goes to the House and Senate, which are both expected to approve it later this week. President Bush is expected to approve final legislation.
 Stephen Hart, a spokesman for the White House, said, "We are encouraged by the progress in the conference and we're waiting the see the final language."
 Important provisions include stopping over the next 10 years the production of chemicals that destroy the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere, tighter restrictions on the pollution that causes urban smog, stricter regulations on automobile exhausts starting in the model year 1994, new limits on emissions of cancer-causing compounds by factories and chemical plants by 2003, and new limits on coal-burning power plants that will nearly cut in half emissions of the chemical compounds sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide, which cause acid rain.
 The negotiators also established a $250 million program to compensate workers who may lose their jobs over the next five years as companies begin to comply with the legislation. Members of the House had proposed the program to aid coal miners, chemical workers and others.
 
'Comprehensive and Sweeping'
 "The agreement is without doubt one of the most comprehensive and sweeping environmental laws that Congress has passed in this century," said Senator Max Baucus, the Montana Democrat who was chairman of the House-Senate conference committee. "It will end a long and bitter 10-year battle over Federal clean air policy."
 Originally approved in 1970, the Clean Air Act has been one of the foundations of state and Federal programs to control pollution. Since 1977, when it was last amended, attempts to revise and strengthen the law were repeatedly foiled by rancorous regional disputes over the costs of new regulations, the number of jobs that might be lost in industries that would be affected and the extent of damage to public health and the environment caused by dirty air.
 At a news conference today, Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Senate Republican whip and one of the negotiators, said: "It's a good piece of work. The President will sign it. I'm positive."
 Led by Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader who first proposed legislation to control acid rain nine years ago, the Senate passed its version of the clean air legislation on April 3. In the House, Representatives John D. Dingell of Michigan and Henry A. Waxman of California, both Democrats, pushed a differing version of the legislation. The House vote of approval came on May 23.
 Negotiators began meeting to resolve the differences between the two bills on July 13.
 
Accord Reached Before Dawn
 The final agreement was reached before dawn today and celebrated by the negotiators and their staffs with champagne. The negotiators today credited President Bush with breaking the impasse last year by proposing a package of new amendments, including one reducing emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide.
 "You should have been there," Senator Simpson said of the negotiations. "It was rich, profane, embittered. I learned that Henry Waxman is tougher than a boiled owl."
 The final agreement will push the Environmental Protection Agency to the limits of its technical and managerial abilities. The agency will be charged with writing and enforcing hundreds of new standards, regulations and rules.
 Three offices at the agency's headquarters in Washington, employing about 640 people, will handle all the work the legislation calls for, including setting new limits on toxic chemical emissions from industrial plants and new standards for automobile emissions and reviewing the quality of plans by cities to reduce urban smog.
 In addition, state environmental agencies will also need to prepare new studies of pollution in cities and regions to meet the requirements of the legislation.
 The Bush Administration requested an increase of $52 million in the 1991 fiscal year to enable the Federal environmental agency to hire 190 more technical experts for the Clean Air program, and $38 million for grants to help state and city environmental agencies meet the new requirements.
 "By and large the air doesn't get clean by passing this law," said David D. Doniger, a senior lawyer in Washington for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group based in New York. "It gets clean by the E.P.A. and states carrying out the new law."
 
Weak Record Noted
 Representative Waxman was one of several lawmakers who noted today the Federal environmental agency's weak record in managing complex programs over the last 10 to 15 years. Programs to regulate unsafe pesticides and to clean up hazardous waste dumps have been marred by delays. Mr. Waxman said the negotiators sought to avoid unnecessary delays in implementing the new clean air amendments by establishing specific limits in the legislation for the worst pollutants.
 The rules for controlling acid rain, for instance, which are intended to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxide and sulfur dioxide 12 million to 14 million tons annually by the end of the decade, call for 111 individual plants in 22 states to reduce emissions to specific levels by Jan. 1, 1995, and all utilities to meet an even stricter standard by the year 2000.
 "The air is going to be significantly cleaner 10 years from now than it is today, thanks to this bill," said Daniel Weiss, director of the Sierra Club's environmental quality program in Washington. "Some provisions may be delayed longer than we would like to see, but there is no question this is a major step forward."
New York City's environmental officials said they were dissatisfied with the motor vehicle provisions that emerged from the conference committee.
 "New York City's worst air problem is caused by automobiles and the bottom line of the Clean Air Act is: automobiles, one; clean air, nothing," said Albert F. Appleton, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner.
 Mr. Appleton said Congress did not go far enough in restricting tailpipe emissions and in allowing New York to participate in a California program that requires cleaner-burning fuels. He also said he was concerned about the delays in tightening emissions standards for urban buses and delays in forcing fleets of trucks to use cleaner-burning fuels.
 Thomas C. Jorling, New York State's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, said that the Clean Air Act had been improved "across the board," but that he also felt the negotiators did not go far enough.
 
Effect on Du Pont
 Perhaps no company in the United States will be more affected by the new legislation than E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the nation's largest chemical company based in Wilmington, Del. Du Pont, which had revenues last year of $35 billion, is a major producer of chlorofluorocarbons, the refrigerant and cleaning solvent that destroys the ozone shield that protects the earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation. Chlorofluorcarbons would be phased out in the 1990's and banned in 2000.
 The company also owns Consolidation Coal in Pittsburgh, an important producer of coal that contains high levels of sulfur. The new rules for reducing sulfur emissions from utilities could reduce orders for that kind of coal. Many utilities may switch to cleaner burning coal mined in the West. To soften the blow, provisions in the new bill provide economic incentives for utilities to install scrubbers that would enable them to burn coal with high concentrations of sulfur.
 All of Du Pont's chemical plants would be affected by new rules requiring permits for all sources of atmospheric pollution and by regulations to reduce emissions of 189 chemicals that the Government says cause cancer, birth defects and other medical problems.
 Du Pont's oil company, Conoco Inc., is also likely to be an important supplier of new types of gasoline that burn more cleanly.
 
'Something We Can Live With'
 Mark Nelson, the company's director of legislative affairs in Washington, said Du Pont supports the bill. He said the company has not yet determined the cost of meeting the new requirements.
 "This looks like a tough bill, but it's something we can live with," Mr. Nelson said.
 A representative from the automobile industry said auto makers also supported the amendments.
 "We're part of the problem; we want to be part of the solution," said Timothy C. MacCarthy, director of the Federal liaison department at the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association in Washington. "Only time will tell whether the significant costs match up with the benefits of this bill."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Interest Rates Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates rose and Treasury bond prices fell in light trading yesterday, as dealers sold longer-dated issues after statements by various Congressional leaders made it apparent that further delays in passing a new Federal budget were likely.
Dealers chose to sell bonds after Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, and Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, told reporters in separate interviews they lacked enough votes to pass a budget pact.
Differences were cited on a number of issues, including proposed increases in gasoline taxes and how best to raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans, as the latest reasons for the delay.
 
'Steam Out of the Market'
 Bond prices, which had been up earlier in the session in the wake of a further decline in oil prices, quickly slipped after the budget news flashed across trading screens. "Domenici took all the steam out of the market," said Joseph Liro, a vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg Securities Inc.
Traders said the budget news was bad because the longer the process was delayed, the less time the Government would have to sell an avalanche of new securities. "The auction calendar is going to be compressed into a frighteningly short period of time," Mr. Liro said.
"As things now stand, roughly $95 billion worth of securities will have to be sold between now and the first full week in November, and the longer the Congress delays the shorter the period to pre-sell those issues becomes," he added. "The Government could end up paying for the delay in a big way."
 
Rise in Yields Forecast
 Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International, said that "once a budget pact is announced, the Street will rush to sell securities as a way of preparing for the new supply. I think that yields are going to have to go back up quite severely in order for the markets to take on these new securities."
The Government has enough money to honor its obligations until next Wednesday, but the continued delay in passing a new budget as well as authorizing another increase in the Federal debt ceiling makes it highly unlikely that an auction of new two-year Treasury notes will be held today, dealers said.
Next Wednesday the Treasury is expected to announce the size and timing of its quarterly refunding auctions, which are now expected to take place during the first full week of November.
 
Long-Term Selling Pressure
 Most of the selling pressure in the secondary market for Treasury securities was seen in long-term bonds and notes. Prices of short-term bills and notes were little changed.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent 30-year bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 99 15/32, down 17/32, to yield 8.79 percent, compared with 8.75 percent late Monday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 8 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 19/32 in late trading, down 10/32, to yield 8.65 percent. But the 8 1/8 percent two-year notes showed a rise of 1/32, to a late offered price of 100 17/32, to yield 7.81 percent.
 
Bill Rates Down a Bit
 Short-term Treasury bill rates dipped slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.21 percent, down one basis point, or a hundredth of a point. Six-month bill rates fell by a similar amount, to a late offered rate of 7.16 percent.
In the market for investment-grade corporate bonds, traders said that prices of longer-term Citicorp issues swung wildly yesterday. "The shorter-term stuff is hanging in there," one trader said. "But bids on the longer stuff are all over the place, and no trades are taking place."
Citicorp bonds have been pounded in recent months as worries about the health of major American banks has risen. Confidence in the nation's largest bank holding company took another beating on Monday when a Dutch auction of its money market preferred stock came close to failing. Another auction of Citicorp's 49-day money market preferred is expected to be held today.
Dealers said that prices of most investment-grade corporate issues dipped by about a quarter of a point in very light trading.
 
Backed by Japanese Credit
 In the tax-exempt municipal market, Dean Witter Reynolds acted as lead manager for a negotiated sale of $200 million worth of bonds for the Georgia World Congress Center Authority. The issue, which is backed by a letter of credit from the Industrial Bank of Japan, consists of serial and term bonds.
The bulk of the securities are in term bonds maturing in 2010 and 2020 and carry coupons of 7.80 percent and 7 7/8 percent, respectively.
The issue is rated triple A by both Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TENSIONS;
Saudis' Quandary: Carrot or the Stick for Iraqis?

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The Saudi Defense Minister's conciliatory-sounding remarks addressed to Iraq this week were the latest sign that Saudi strategists and military officials are trying their best to offer President Saddam Hussein more of a carrot and less of a stick to persuade him to pull his 350,000 troops out of Kuwait.
 This approach stems in part from the deep cracks in the Arab world from the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and some second thoughts here about the confrontational attitude that Saudi Arabia has adopted toward Jordan, Yemen, the Palestine Liberation Organization and other Arab supporters of Iraq. 
 Over the last few weeks, Saudi Arabia has cut off oil supplies to Jordan and all financial aid to Yemen, Jordan and the P.L.O. in retaliation for their support of Iraq.
It has adopted measures that may force a million Yemeni expatriate workers -- a quarter of the foreign labor force here -- to leave this country, deeply unhappy after decades of making a comfortable living here. And it has virtually severed its relations with the leadership of the P.L.O.
 
Preference for Consensus
 On the one hand, the Saudis have been uncharacteristically tough in talking of war and in saying that President Hussein has to be destroyed. But more recently, the Saudis -- as underscored by the remarks of the Defense Minister, Prince Sultan -- seem to be looking for a more traditional consensus approach that might avoid war.
The latter approach is more in keeping with the methods of a country that for the last 50 years has tried not to burn bridges even to its enemies.
But the Saudis' preference for low-key politics clashes with their decision in the last two and a half months to say openly that their interest lies with the West, most particularly the United States, ending decades of trying to keep that special relationship something of an illicit affair.
Enough Saudis have become sufficiently alarmed about all these developments to begin searching for a way to return to a lower profile.
"This car is going too fast," said a wealthy Saudi merchant and businessman who supports the view that somehow President Hussein must be gotten rid of but that "this creeping confrontation towards war may not be a way to do it."
 
Impact of Egyptian Support
 While Egypt, the Arab world's most populous country, has given the Saudis strong and unhesitating support, Cairo is burdened with $50 billion in debts and is no match for Iraq's enormous and well-equipped army.
Of equal importance is concern here that as the weeks go by while allied troops prepare for what could be a very costly battle, the fickle ways of Western democracies and their moody public may shift the ground beneath President Bush's Administration, weakening its resolve as well as that of other Western powers and Arab allies to make the decision to go to war.
"Many of the forces deployed against Saddam are not Arabs," a senior Saudi official said today in a briefing to a few reporters about the disposition of Iraqi troops and the allied forces facing them in this country. "There are Westerners whose societies are undergoing a debate that may affect the situation and reflect on the performances of their forces."
Saudi Government officials maintain that comments by Prince Sultan, widely reported on Sunday and Monday, to the effect that the border dispute with Kuwait can be settled in a way that satisfies at least some Iraqi demands for access to the Persian Gulf are not as new as they may sound.
 
Omelette of Unbroken Eggs
 "We have always maintained a conciliatory policy from the start," the Saudi official, who is a senior decision maker in the Saudi royal hierarchy and who insisted that he not be identified, said today.
"The King has always urged Saddam Hussein to minimize bloodshed," the official said. "If that is conciliatory, then it has been consistent. But we also have said we will use whatever force that is necessary."
Indeed, most Saudis seem to believe that the most decisive way to restore stability to this region is not only to liberate Kuwait, but to do away with President Hussein and his entire Baathist Government -- a goal that can only be accomplished by a decisive military blow to Iraq.
But the heady atmosphere that prevailed during much of August, with most Saudis adopting a let's-go-get-them attitude, has evaporated. "I think we are slipping back to the old attitude of wanting the omelette without breaking the eggs," said one prominent Saudi businessman.
On the popular level, there is a palpable anxiety that even if the allied forces prevail over Iraq, they will do so at a cost that will deeply upset the serenity and prosperity that Saudi society has come to accept as a way of life.
 
Unease at Foreigners' Presence
 Although the Saudi Government has done its best to insulate its citizens from the influence and impact of some 300,000 American and other troops that have poured in since August, there is undeniably a fair amount of unease at the presence of so many foreigners. In addition, many Saudis worry that the Americans have come here to defend their oil supplies and that despite repeated assertions that they will leave as soon as the crisis is over, they are planning to stay for a long while.
Finally, there is a conviction that at least some of the things President Hussein are saying are true. Despite assertions by pro-Western Arab governments that Israel's occupation of Arab territories and its perceived denial of Palestinian rights cannot be compared to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, what has become known as linkage is alive and well in many a Saudi mind.
Even Saudis who represent the heart of the conservative and pro-Western business community say they are distressed by the enthusiasm the West has demonstrated in rushing to the defense of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia -- both of which are oil-producing countries and major economic partners for Westerns industrialized democracies -- compared with the apathy they feel the West has shown for what virtually all Arabs agree is a minimum of legitimate rights for the Palestinians under Israeli occupation.
One Yemini intellectual, a Muslim fundamentalist who has lived here for 17 years, expressed this sentiment in a way echoed by many Saudis, in a conversation about Saudi Arabia's decision to withdraw privileges accorded to the Yemini community over the last 40 years, forcing them to leave.
Speaking of Mr. Hussein's threats against Israel and his denunciation of American support for the Israelis, the Yemini intellectual said: "What Saddam Hussein says is logical and reasonable. The only problem is that it comes from him."
All this leaves the Saudis in a quandary about what to do. "Very few Arabs would accept the principle of going into Iraq with armed force," said the senior Saudi official. "The shedding of Arab blood by Arabs is repugnant. But in the process of liberating Kuwait, you can't enter into a boxing match with one hand tied behind your back."

HEADLINE: Schools to Cut Hundreds of Jobs To Save New York $94 Million

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
To satisfy new budget cuts of $94 million demanded by City Hall, the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, is drawing up plans to eliminate hundreds of jobs, including many through layoffs.
He also is strongly considering selling Board of Education television and radio stations valued at a minimum of $15 million.
Mr. Fernandez and Stanley S. Litow, the deputy chancellor for operations, met over the weekend with city budget officials and were told to find ways of slashing this fiscal year's budget by 2 percent, or $94 million, and cutting the budget for the fiscal year starting July 1 by $245 million. Along with other city agencies they are to present their budget-cutting plan to City Hall today.
 
Big Gaps in the City Budget
 Their presentations come about a week after Mayor David N. Dinkins told city agencies to prepare cuts of more than $1 billion from their operating budgets to help close projected city budget gaps of at least $300 million for this fiscal year and $1.4 billion for next year. Most agencies were told to prepare cuts equal to 4 percent of their budgets for the current fiscal year, but the school system was asked to trim about half that amount.
"Obviously there will have to be some cuts in personnel," Mr. Fernandez said yesterday when asked about what reductions he was planning. But he added, "The classroom is the last place we want to hit."
Instead of teacher layoffs, he suggestedthat other job categories would be likelier targets. The Board of Education, school officials said, has already made plans to trim the central board by 350 employees -- about 10 percent of the staff.
Mr. Fernandez derided a report in The Daily News that quoted unnamed sources who said that 2,000 teachers might have to be laid off in January and another 2,000 in September. He called it a leak by someone at City Hall whose "motive is to tie the teachers' contract to this story."
Some city officials and such fiscal monitors as Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, have denounced the contract's 5.5 percent pay increase as far too generous at a time of citywide economic anguish. They are pressing for its abrogation, and Mr. Fernandez suggested that their case would be strengthened by the specter of teacher layoffs.
While substantial savings were achieved last year by letting jobs of departed or retired employees go unfilled, officials in the Chancellor's office said they could not meet all of the new cuts through a hiring freeze alone and would have to consider layoffs. However, laying off teachers after raising teachers' salaries would present a particularly prickly public relations problem for Mr. Fernandez.
Bert Shanas, a spokesman for the United Federation of Teachers, said "the Chancellor's office assures us there are no teacher layoffs in their plans.
"This kind of game-playing goes to the heart of why the City Hall budget people have no credibility with us," he added. Mr. Fernandez, following an example set by Mayor David N. Dinkins, said he also planned to talk to a regular meeting of the seven-member Board of Education today about the possibility of cutting his $195,000 salary and the salaries of his top aides by 5 percent.
 
Problems With Stations
 The contemplated sale of the television and radio stations -- WNYE-TV and WNYE-FM -- would eliminate only 30 jobs, but the Federal Communications Commission licenses and the stations' studio equipment would be regarded as attractive properties on the auction block.
The Board of Education established the radio station in 1940 and the television station, a UHF outlet transmitted on Channel 25, in 1967. During school hours the stations broadcast educational programs with titles like "Newton's Rainbow," "Meet Barney Bookworm" and "The World of Myths and Legends." At other hours they lease time to foreign-language broadcasters and community groups.
The stations have been plagued with serious problems. The television transmitter in downtown Brooklyn has a weak signal that reaches less than half of the city's schools. High schools also find it difficult to mesh class schedules with the station's programs.
Mr. Fernandez made his comments on the budget issues as he waited impatiently to testify at a State Assembly Education Committee hearing in Lower Manhattan on a bill that would give him a greater role in the selection of community school superintendents. The chairman of the committee, Angelo Del Toro, was 45 minutes late for the hearing, saying he had been stalled in traffic.
 
Screening Power Sought
 The bill would require the 32 local boards to submit to the Chancellor evaluations of the top three to five candidiates for a superintendent's position. Mr. Fernandez could disqualify candidates whose records he deemed inferior, forcing the boards to make their selection from the remaining candidiates.
Mr. Fernandez said he wanted to make sure that local boards hired their chief administrators for their educational talents and not out of concern "about what political club they belong to and what kind of patronage they provide." Still, as an apparent inducement to a committee whose members are in some cases politically entangled with the local school boards, Mr. Fernandez said he was exploring the possibility of allowing more local districts to have "co-ownership" in the running of high schools.
Generally local boards govern only elementary and junior high schools, but a handful of high schools, like Truman High in the Bronx, are run jointly by the Board of Education and the local school board.
Mr. Fernandez found himself in a near donnybrook with Edward Griffith, a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn. The Chancellor had urged that the Legislature approve the bill without further studies about decentralization since, he said, most studies end up on shelves.
 
A Sharp Exchange
 Bristling, Mr. Griffith said the initial studies that led to decentralization did not end up on a shelf. He then chided Mr. Fernandez for taking credit for the elimination of the Board of Examiners when Democratic legislators had fought for its abolition for years.
"If there was a fight, I never saw you in it," Mr. Fernandez retorted.
Speakers at the hearing took different positions on the hiring bill. Jeanne Frankl, executive director of the Public Education Association, called it a publicity trick since, she argued, the Chancellor could achieve the same aims with powers he now has. But Msgr. John Powis, co-chairman of East Brooklyn Churches, a coalition of churches that has fought for improvements in education and housing, said the bill was necessary.
Monsignor Powis, an early warrior in the battles that led to decentralization in 1970, argued that too many boards had proved themselves "unaccountable pockets of contracts, favors and employment."

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Campaigning for the G.O.P., Bush Discovers He's an Issue

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 23

 BODY:
It was to have been a routine day of campaigning. Instead, George Bush got an object lesson today in how the budget crisis has disrupted the Republican Party, and how quickly loyalties can shift when a Presidency is weakened and defiance of the White House becomes a political plus.
Stumping through New England on a trip that had been postponed by the budget crisis, Mr. Bush was introduced at a fund-raising event in Vermont by a Republican candidate who made a point of opposing the President's veto Monday of a job-discrimination bill. 
 The candidate, Representative Peter Smith, then tried to solve his campaign problems at the President's expense. He broke with the President on taxes by saying he supported higher rates on the wealthy. At the same time, he reminded his audience that Mr. Bush abandoned the no-new-taxes pledge on which he ran in 1988.
This was clearly not what the White House had expected when John H. Sununu, the President's chief of staff, warned recalcitrant Republicans that Mr. Bush might visit their districts to chastise them for not supporting the President's budget proposals.
 
'Talking About His Pledge'
 Mr. Bush looked grim, wiping the juice of a Vermont apple from his chin and toying with the remnants of his hotcakes-and-maple-syrup breakfast as Mr. Smith went on: "Ask yourselves, why did this President, last May, decide that the issue he had run on and won on now had to be laid on the table as a point of negotiations? We're talking about his pledge on taxes. He did it because he understood that the good of this country had to come first."
The President, who was not warned of Mr. Smith's planned remarks but did not seem surprised, tried to laugh them off before the friendly crowd. "Like all Vermonters, he is a man of independent mind," Mr. Bush said. "I just wish he'd stop reminding me that we do have a few differences out there."
Then, in Manchester, N.H., Mr. Bush had a different problem. He appeared on behalf of another Republican lawmaker, who had stayed in Washington while the President raised money for him.
It is not just in New England that Republican divisions over taxes and other issues have given Mr. Bush's efforts to promote his party's candidates something of the tension between a divorced couple who suddenly find themselves at the same dinner party.
A few months ago, Republican candidates were lining up to become one of the 100 or so Senate, House and gubernatorial candidates who got videotaped endorsements from Mr. Bush. But some of the candidates have been slow to put the advertisements on the air.
 
Fighting Back Gamely
 Mr. Bush gamely fought back today, defending his shifts on taxes and the budget as a necessary evil to gain an acceptable compromise. And he tried to coat himself with some of Ronald Reagan's political Teflon, recalling that his predecessor accepted higher taxes in 1982. "President Reagan had to swallow hard back then," he said. "I had to swallow hard. But the long-term health of the United States of America, of our economy, had to come before self-interest."
But it was a long and difficult day for Mr. Bush. The President stumbled through his speeches, mistakenly declaring at one point that he "favors" the budget deficit. He had to foresake his Marine Corps helicopter at the Westchester County airport because of foul weather and drive 75 minutes through the rain to Waterbury and Stamford.
In Connecticut, at least, Mr. Bush got an enthusiastic welcome. He went there to campaign for Representative John G. Rowland, who is running for Governor against Representative Bruce A. Morrison of Hamden, a Democrat, and Lowell P. Weicker Jr. of Greenwich, a former Republican senator who is campaigning as an independent and has held wide leads in all public polls.
Mr. Rowland represents Connecticut's Fifth Congressional District and lives in Waterbury, but the fund-raising event for him was held in the Republican-rich Fourth Congressional District, considered vital territory.

 
Couldn't Get Home
 Mr. Bush went to Connecticut from New Hampshire, where he raised money for Representative Robert C. Smith's re-election campaign. Mr. Smith did not appear at the event, his wife, Mary Jo, said, because he had to cast "very key" votes in Washington. The lawmaker's office said today that he was casting a ballot on a spending bill for the Commerce, State and Justice Departments.
Mr. Bush began the day in Burlington, Vt., where Representative Peter Smith attended what should have been a pro-forma fund-raising event.
Not this time. Not only has the Vermont Congressman taken a beating over his support for the bipartisan budget agreement that went sour in early October, but he became one of only 10 House Republicans who voted for a Democratic package that would raise taxes on the wealthiest Americans.
Mr. Smith started his remarks today by saying he opposed the President's veto of the Civil Rights Act of 1990. Then he said, "Mr. President, I believe the people of Vermont are ready and willing to support higher tax brackets on the wealthy as an important part of any package to get this country out of deficit spending."
The President recalled how much trouble Mr. Smith's vote on the bipartisan budget deal had caused him. "It wasn't an easy vote," Mr. Bush said. "But he did what he felt he had to do.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush with Representative Peter Smith after arriving at airport in Burlington, Vt. At a Republican fund-raising event later, Mr. Smith made a point of opposing Mr. Bush on the job-bias bill. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE STRUGGLE IN CONGRESS;
Focus Shifts to Rules on Cleaner Air For Car, Chemical and Steel Makers

BYLINE: The following article was reported and written by Barnaby J. Feder, Doron
 P. Levin and Jonathan P. Hicks.

 BODY:
No consumer's wallet will go untouched by the Clean Air Act amendments expected to be enacted within days following compromises in the Senate and House.
Much of the burden will fall initially on several industries that have long expected tighter controls on air pollution, including auto makers, steel producers, the chemical industry and public utilities. How quickly consumers pay for the changes these industries will be asked to make will depend in part on the state of the economy. If the nation tumbles into a recession, as some economists expect, business will have a harder time passing on the costs. 
 In the long run, the bill could cost consumers as much as $50 billion, said David Hale, chief economist for Kemper Financial Services in Chicago. "It will begin to add to the inflation rate in a small way as early as next year," he added.
 
 Worst-Case Scenarios
 Industry executives have tried to envision worst-case scenarios for the impact of the new amendments. Indeed, such theorizing was used to lobby against some of the far-reaching proposals favored by environmental groups. Now that the first round of the battle is over, the conflict will shift to the Environmental Protection Agency, which is charged with drafting regulations putting into effect most of the changes. In the meantime, many executives say, it is hard to make really useful projections without knowing what the E.P.A. intends to do.
But some things are already clear. Coal-burning utilities will bear the brunt of the changes aimed at curbing acid rain. It is widely assumed that the state public utility boards, which set electricity rates, will have no objection to passing the costs for scrubbing equipment on to consumers as soon as it is installed, especially in states like Ohio and Kentucky, where the equipment will allow utilities to continue to use locally mined coal. Utility executives say that the companies with the most work to do might have to seek rate increases of more than 15 percent to cover their costs.
 
 Technical Incapability Feared
 The goals set for auto makers are equally clear, but industry spokesmen are not as sure that their companies are technically capable of meeting those scheduled to take effect in the late 1990's. The steel industry asserts that it, too, may bump up against technology limits.
There is one crucial difference between the two industries that leaves steelmakers feeling especially burdened. The laws about cars will be incorporated in the product, affecting all auto makers at home and abroad that hope to sell vehicles in the United States. The laws affecting steel relate to the steelmaking process, which will add to the cost of American steel but have no impact on foreign companies that export steel to the United States.
Steelmakers might use this difference to argue for tariff barriers, import quotas or other protection from foreign competition in order to make it easier to pass on to consumers the costs of meeting the air pollution laws.
Chemical makers point out that the big industries affected by the new amendments, including their own, tend to be heavy users of electricity. Thus, they will pay both for the costs of new controls on their toxic products and for the higher cost of energy from utilities that pay for scrubbers and other equipment to reduce acid rain.
Following is a closer look at how three major industries are reacting to the new amendments:
 
 Autos
 The provisions affecting auto makers are among the most specific in the clean air agreement. They identify key pollutants emitted at the tailpipe and set targets for reducing them.
The first round of reductions begins in 1994 and, according to the Chrysler Corporation, will cost several hundred dollars a car. They include a requirement that non-methane hydrocarbon emissions be reduced in phases by 1997 to 0.25 gram a mile from 0.41 gram and nitrogen oxide emissions be cut to 0.4 gram from one gram.
The targets will be halved again between the turn of the century and 2004. Auto makers say that meeting those goals, or even those for 1997, may be more than they can cope with technologically at a reasonable price. "We don't know how to meet the provisions that begin in the late 1990's," said a Chrysler spokesman.
The General Motors Corporation also served notice that it had doubts about the technological feasibility of the longer-range requirements.
 
 Challenge for Toyota
 The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car maker, said that meeting the requirements would be a challenge and might be possible only by building cars that got poorer gasoline mileage. The Ford Motor Company said that one positive side of the compromise was that it took into account some of the industry's worries about the timetables set for various changes.
The changes should not only lower tailpipe emissions but lead to more durable pollution control equipment on cars. Auto makers will be required to certify that the equipment will be effective for 10 years or 100,000 miles, double the current standards.
Auto makers also would be compelled to build 150,000 vehicles annually starting in 1996 for an experimental fleet that will operate under stricter California clean air guidelines. That number would rise to 300,000 in 1998.
Starting in 1994, auto makers would be required to install dashboard gauges that tell whether emission control equipment is working properly.
"In rough numbers, cars at the end of this process will pollute one-sixth as much as they do now," said Robert Liberatore, Chrysler's executive director of government policy, summing up the overall impact.
 
 Chemicals
 Chemical manufacturers and trade groups that represent them said yesterday that the compromise clean air legislation offered little relief from requirements they consider expensive and difficult to put into effect.
"It will lead to continued progress in cleaning our nation's air," said Robert A. Roland, president of the Chemical Manufacturers Association, a Washington-based trade group. "The bad news is that this continued progress won't come without a very high price. In fact, the price Americans will pay will be far more than it should be."
Some chemical executives harbor concerns that the requirements that companies use the best available control technology will not be flexible enough to accommodate the wide range of chemicals and processes for dealing with them.
 
 Six-Year Extension Hailed
 Still, some chemical companies hailed provisions in the compromise legislation that would give chemical manufacturers six more years to comply with new emission standards if they reduced their toxic emissions by 90 percent from their 1987 level ahead of the 1994 deadline. (Even a reduction of 90 percent would not meet the new standards.)
Mr. Roland said the cost of putting the legislation into effect would be "somewhere around $40 billion to $50 billion a year, and that will be on top of the $32 billion a year we already spend as a nation on cleaning our air."
 
 Steel
 The American steel industry, which found previous versions of the clean air legislation unpalatable, has been far more amenable to the amendments as completed by the House and Senate conference committee.
Steelmakers were disturbed by a requirement, in earlier versions, that they eliminate virtually all emissions from coke ovens by the year 2020 and in the meantime adopt the best available emissions reduction technology by 1995. Coke ovens are the furnaces that convert coal to coke in making steel.
Steel industry officials contended that meeting the 1995 deadline would cost the industry about $5 billion, which they said they could ill afford.
Under the House and Senate compromise measure, the industry does not have to adopt the best available technology to reduce emissions leakage in coke ovens until 2020 and in the meantime must reduce emissions gradually under guidelines to be formulated by the E.P.A.
 
 More Stringent Standards
 The industry will have to meet progressively more stringent standards in 1993, 1995, 1998 and 2010. But the compromise no longer mandates that virtually all emissions be eliminated by 2020.
David M. Anderson, general manager of environmental affairs at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, said yesterday that the extension until 2020 was crucial to the American steel industry's competitive position. "Without the extension, the legislation could have shut down two-thirds of domestic coke ovens by 2003," he added.
But Milton Deaner, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, the industry trade group, complained that the clean air compromise still created far more stringent requirements for the steel industry than for other industrial groups.

HEADLINE: New York City Seeks to Revoke Licenses of 40 Garbage Haulers

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
New York City moved yesterday to revoke the licenses of almost 10 percent of the private haulers that pick up commercial garbage, in what a Dinkins administration official described as the first step toward cleaning up a corrupt business.
Mark Green, the Consumer Affairs Commissioner, said he would seek to revoke the licenses and impose up to $3.2 million in fines on 40 haulers who have refused to disclose financial information required by the city. 
 The city requires haulers to disclose who has corporate control of their companies, the names of shareholders, the number of customers, the amount and type of waste collected and where it is dumped.
Mr. Green said the information was needed to determine a new maximum rate that haulers could charge the city's 250,000 businesses for garbage pickup.
Businesses pay 475 private haulers more than a $1 billion a year to collect their trash, which accounts for about 40 percent of the garbage generated in the city. The City Sanitation Department collects from residences.
 
Bidding for Routes Studied
 In coming months, Mr. Green said, he would explore ways to bring more competition into a "closed industry" that he said routinely overcharged businesses. Such steps might include a system under which haulers would have to bid for route franchises.
"It is a cartel," Mr. Green said. "Territories are divided up by agreement among carters. Outsiders are afraid to come in and bid for routes because of intimidation.
"Carters are to garbage what OPEC is to oil," he continued. "Each knows not to bid against each other. I don't know if it's done by winks, meetings or codes."
The Department of Consumer Affairs licenses private haulers and sets the maximum rate they can charge, which is currently $14.70 a cubic yard. Mr. Green said he expected to set a new rate next month. An average greengrocer in the city pays $15,000 a year for garbage pickup, while Macy's pays $59,661 a month, he said.
 
'Setting a Fair Rate'
 "If they are overpaying, especially as we are in a recession, it really hurts the economy of the city," he said. "I'm very keen on setting a fair rate."
The haulers now facing license revocation must appear before a department hearing officer, who will determine the amount of the fine and whether the license will be revoked.
Richard C. Laskey, first assistant to the director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force, said the commercial garbage collection industry in New York City was influenced by organized crime, resulting in stifled competition, poorer service and overpayments.
 
Mob Control Denied
 A lawyer for the haulers, Salvatore Spinelli, said that organized crime did not control the business and that there was competition for routes. Because many people in the industry are of Italian descent, he said, the industry was unfairly portrayed as being controlled by organized crime.
"I find it personally offensive," Mr. Spinelli said.
Mr. Green declined to say whether he thought the commercial garbage collection was controlled by organized crime, stating, "I am a regulator, not a prosecutor."
He also said that 90 percent of the private haulers had complied with the disclosure requirements. Mr. Spinelli, who represents the Council of Trade Waste Associations, said some companies that did not provide the information had gone out of business. The council, he said, had encouraged all members to disclose the required data.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Consumer Affairs Commissioner Mark Green said he would seek to revoke licenses of private carting companies refusing to disclose financial information. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Wang Has a Profit; 2 Others Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Wang said yesterday that it returned to profitability in its latest quarter, but two other computer makers, Control Data and Tandy, said their earnings slipped. 
 Following are the details on the earnings of the three companies:
 
Wang

 Wang Laboratories Inc. said it earned $2.6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of $62.1 million in the quarter last year. Revenue in the period, which is Wang's first fiscal quarter, totaled $571.5 million, down from $604.8 million a year earlier.
The Lowell, Mass., company said it had elimitated its debt to its bank group in the quarter. "This debt was $575 million in August 1989, and it is zero today," said Richard W. Miller, chairman and chief executive officer.
Wang's share price rose 25 cents yesterday, to $3.25, in trading on the American Stock Exchange.
 
Control Data
 The Control Data Corporation said it earned $8.5 million, or 20 cents a share, in the third quarter, down 13.2 percent from $9.8 million, or 23 cents a share, in 1989's third quarter. Revenue fell 43 percent, to $434.1 million, from $763 million.
Last year's third-quarter results included revenue and earnings from Imprimis, a disk drive subsidiary that has been sold, and a pretax restructuring gain of $8.5 million, the Bloomington, Minn., company said.
A spokeswoman said the energy management division and the automated wagering unit could experience "substantial" problems in the next quarter that could hurt earnings.
Control Data's share price rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $9.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Tandy
 The Tandy Corporation said it earned $52.2 million, or 65 cents a share, in the quarter ended Sept. 30, down 16.9 percent from $62.8 million, or 73 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue at the Fort Worth, Tex., company totaled $1.09 billion, up 11 percent from $986 million in the period last year, which is Tandy's first fiscal quarter.
Tandy blamed the lower earnings on price cuts of its products. It said it had cleared its Radio Shack retail store inventories of certain discontinued items and computer models prior to the holiday selling season.
The company's share price fell $1.25 yesterday, to $24.75, on the Big Board.

HEADLINE: EARNINGS;
Unexpectedly Low Earnings at Sun

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems Inc., the leading vendor of computer-engineering workstations, unnerved Wall Street today by reporting financial results that were below expectations. It attributed the shortfall to a weaker economy and internal factors.
The results, announced after the close of the stock market, were almost certain to hurt Sun's stock in trading Wednesday and could renew Wall Street's nervousness over high-technology stocks after confidence had been beginning to build again. 
 "We're all a little bit shell-shocked," said Peter Rogers, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company in San Francisco.
 
Analysts' Expectations
 Sun reported net income for its first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 28 of $26.1 million, or 26 cents a share, five times the $5.2 million, or 7 cents a share, recorded a year earlier, when the company was recovering from its first loss. But the earnings per share were well below the 40 cents that both the company and Wall Street analysts had been expecting.
Revenues grew to $677 million, from $538.5 million a year earlier, a gain of 26 percent. But the company and analysts had expected revenues of $700 million to $725 million.
William J. Raduchel, the chief financial officer, said there were several disruptions in the quarter, including a reorganization of the domestic sales force and late shipments because of component shortages and the opening of a new warehouse.
In addition, he said, customers might have postponed purchases in anticipation of new products. On Nov. 5, the Mountain View, Calif., company is expected to introduce its Sparcstation 2, a work station more powerful than its existing machines.
 
Strength Anticipated
 Mr. Raduchel said the company could not determine how much of the earnings shortfall resulted from these factors and how much was because of the weak economy. The sales force still thinks demand is strong for Sun's products, he said.
As previously reported, Sun is cutting costs and has frozen hiring. It is projecting revenue growth of 20 to 30 percent for the rest of the fiscal year, down from 30 to 35 percent last year.
Sun's uncertainty in assessing its future is likely to contribute to weakness in its stock, said Mr. Rogers, the Robertson Stephens analyst. Sun shares fell $2.75 each today, to $20.125, with more than two million shares changing hands in over-the-counter trading.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 27, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the first-quarter earnings of Sun Microsystems Inc. referred incorrectly to the company's recent projections for revenue growth. Sun forecasts growth of 20 to 30 percent for this fiscal year, down from a previous projection, not last year's growth, of 30 to 35 percent. Sun revenues grew 39 percent in its last fiscal year.

HEADLINE: Continental Bankruptcy Study Seen

BYLINE: By ERIC WEINER

 BODY:
Stung by unexpected losses and sharply higher fuel costs, the parent of Continental Airlines prepared to file for bankruptcy protection over the weekend but decided against the move -- at least for now -- at the last minute, a lawyer familiar with the situation said yesterday.
Amid the turmoil, Continental said its president and four top executives would leave the company. The company attributed the move to cost-cutting, but people close to Continental said that its new chairman, Hollis H. Harris, wanted to remove executives who were allied with Frank Lorenzo, who recently stepped down as chairman, or who disagreed with the direction of the airline. 
 The lawyer, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said a team of lawyers worked through the weekend, day and night, to prepare bankruptcy papers to be filed on Monday by the company, Continental Airlines Holdings. Art Kent, a spokesman for Continental, denied the reports. "The company has no intention of filing for bankruptcy protection," he said.
 
Impact of Gulf Crisis
 Continental, which had nearly $500 million in cash reserves in June, reportedly suffered unexpected losses this summer -- normally the industry's most prosperous season -- and has been hit hard by fuel prices that have more than doubled since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. What is more, Continental paid the Pension Benefits Guaranty Corporation, a Federal agency, $80.5 million last month as part of a settlement that will cost the airline about $600 million over several years.
Continental Airlines Holdings, which was called the Texas Air Corporation before last June, operates Eastern Airlines as well as Continental.
More than a dozen lawyers from Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, the New York law firm, worked on the Continental case over the weekend. "They were running flat out," said the lawyer familiar with the situation. "By late Sunday night they were ready to go." He said Continental was still considering a bankruptcy filing along with other options.
The company's board is reportedly split on what to do about the airline's financial crisis. Mr. Lorenzo, who is still a board member, has strongly opposed filing for bankruptcy protection. In August, Mr. Lorenzo left as chairman with $30.5 million, largely from the sale of his stock to the company. Mr. Lorenzo is reportedly concerned that he might lose that money should Continental file for bankruptcy protection. Yesterday, Continental's headquarters in Houston did not return a request for comment by Mr. Lorenzo.
Jan Carlzon, chairman of Scandinavian Airlines System, which now owns 16.8 percent of Continental stock, also opposes filing for bankruptcy, the lawyer said, because the value of S.A.S.'s investment would drop sharply. Continental is also considering widespread layoffs as a means to stem its losses, people familiar with the airline said.
It was not clear which Continental executives or board members favored filing for bankruptcy protection.
 
'Extremely Weak'
 Continental lost $8.7 million in the first half of this year, compared with a loss of $365 million a year earlier. But the company's financial pulse may be weaker than those figures indicate. For instance, the 1990 losses are partly diluted by $61 million in extraordinary credits, and last year's losses reflect liabilities from Eastern, which has been operating under bankruptcy protection since March 1989. What is more, Continental had total liabilities of $1.65 billion as of June.
"Their balance sheet is extremely weak," said Raymond Neidl, an analyst with Dillon, Read. "And they're going into the weak winter season." Mr. Neidl said he expects Continental to report a "marginal" loss for the third quarter.
Continental is no stranger to bankruptcy. Under Mr. Lorenzo, the airline filed for bankruptcy protection in 1982. Using lower-cost nonunion labor, Mr. Lornezo rebuilt the airline.
Among the management changes announced yesterday at Continental: Mr. Harris, the company's recently appointed chairman and chief executive, will replace the current president, Mickey Foret, taking on the additional title. Among the other executives leaving the airline are Clark H. Onstad, a senior vice president for properties and government; Neal Meehan, senior vice president for customer services; Jim Arpey, senior vice president for aircraft programs, and Elliot Seiden, associate general counsel.
 Continental said the executives were leaving as part of a cost-cutting campaign. Mr. Harris cited "radically higher fuel costs" as the reason for the streamlining. The airline's fuel costs were $81 million higher in October than in June.
 But others said the executives were leaving because of their connections with Mr. Lorenzo and because of disagreements over airline strategy.

HEADLINE: Pueblo Parents Feel Generation Gap: Where Shall Children Be Educated?

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FELIPE, N.M.

 BODY:
By the standards of New Mexico's vast, angular landscape, the distance between the elementary school on the San Felipe Indian Reservation and the one in the town of Algodones is trivial, a mere six miles. But for the elders of the reservation, what matters is not miles but millennia.
One school has ties to the Pueblo Indian traditions and the rhythms of a society that was old when the Spaniards came. The other is part of the world outside. 
 But despite a decade of efforts to improve the school for the Indian children at San Felipe, Indian parents are deserting it in droves. As a result, the Tribal Council -- a sovereign government with broad rights to control its land and its members, according to the laws and the treaties of the United States -- is pressuring parents to keep their children on the reservation. The rebellious parents respond that they will send their children to any school they wish.
"We want our kids to learn to adapt to the world out there, rather than the world in here," said Bonnie Candelaria, whose 5-year-old daughter, Valyn, started kindergarten at Algodones this fall, becoming one of 64 San Felipe children in a school with an enrollment of 138.
Tribal Council members, in a recent meeting, accused Ms. Candelaria and the other parents of disloyalty and disrespect, she reported. "They were yelling, 'You don't care for your kids, that's why you send them to Algodones,' " she said.
 
Traditions Are Defied
 Council members have rebuked "disobedient" and "disloyal" parents, and they persuaded the reservation school to adopt a policy that makes transfer of a child's records difficult without approval of the tribal governor. Two council members have told outsiders that the council recently passed a resolution urging all San Felipe parents to keep their children in the reservation school through sixth grade.
A Supreme Court ruling in the late 1970's gave tribes broad authority to determine their own membership, but it is not clear if a tribal government has unlimited power to impose obligations on its members, like dictating what school their children must attend.
For all the bitterness, the Tribal Council's actions may seem mild to an outsider. But such pressures have strong resonance in the context of Pueblo life. On a practical level, the parents now defying the council may one day have to petition it for land or a building permit or a job with the tribal government. On a deeper level, to defy the council is to flout traditions that have kept the community intact through centuries of droughts, wars, interlopers and displacement.
The conflict has echoes all over the state and the Southwest. Islands of ancient culture, trying to keep collective control of their children and their future, are finding themselves challenged by members who assert individual rights.
In New Mexico, schools are the forum for these challenges. Two of the most conservative and isolated groups, the San Felipe Pueblo and the Santo Domingo Pueblo, are pressuring parents to keep their children in primary schools on the reservation. Students in high school and in some cases junior high have gone to school off the reservation for a decade, though this year the tribal governor of the Santo Domingo Pueblo has sought to keep his tribe's students out of the Bernalillo Middle School, not far from Algodones.
 
Reverting to First Language
 But by the time a Pueblo student has completed elementary school on the reservation, he may be seriously handicapped linguistically, said teachers and aides at the Algodones school. Although the language of the classrooms on the reservation is English, the language of the corridors is Keres, a Pueblo language preserved largely by the isolation of the 2,500-member tribe.
"What you get when you put Keres speakers with Keres speakers is Keres speakers," said Sharon Alt, who has been principal at Algodones Elementary for three years.
"Some San Felipe kids come here with pre-primer reading skills in fifth and sixth grade," said one San Felipe parent who works as a teacher's aide at Algodones. Like many involved in the dispute, she requested anonymity, but said that her own daughter had had to repeat third grade after coming to Algodones. "Now she's O.K. I think the integration helped her. What I'm doing is best for my child."
"I want my daughter to be ready to go out in the world on her own," said Ms. Candelaria. A single mother with two children younger than Valyn, she works as a police dispatcher in nearby Bernalillo.
 
A Precarious Economy
 As much as the Keres language and the community traditions link the San Felipe tribe to the past, wire fences, pickup trucks and television radar dishes link it to an economically precarious present. Agriculture, crafts and cattle, mainstays of the tribal economy, are not always a sufficient economic underpinning for the 19 Pueblo tribes sprinkled along the Rio Grande from Taos, near Colorado, to the desert south of Albuquerque.
For a generation or more, some San Felipe tribal members have earned their living off the reservation. But most young children were educated on the reservation. Not until the mid-1980's did large number of families living on the reservation began to move their children to Algodones.
Since she arrived as Algodones principal in 1987, Ms. Alt said, she has sought several meetings with tribal officials to see if the two schools can work together. She was granted only one audience, and the participating tribal officials made no comment on her requests.
Lawrence Trancosa, a tribal spokesman, would not comment on any aspect of the dispute, saying it was an internal tribal matter. But the effects of disobedience have already been felt by some parents.
"They call you Anglo if you do" send your children to Algodones, said the teacher's aide. "They put a label on you. The older people look down on you." She said one woman who came to baby-sit had asked what the family ate and what the house was like, as if dwelling and diet would be radically different from others in the tribe.
 
Money Is at Stake
 Legally, the tribes' authority is circumscribed by the 1968 Indian Civil Rights Act. But, lawyers say, a court decision in the 1970's ceded to the tribes the authority to enforce the that act. In many cases, according to lawyers familiar with Indian issues, Tribal Council members making the laws are the same people called on to judge their constitutionality.
Choices between schools have direct financial consequences for the winning and losing institutions. State and Federal education funding is based on enrollment. Each defection drains $2,500 from San Felipe Elementary, Ed Dolan, principal of the San Felipe School, said.
Eight years ago, there were no San Felipe children at Algodones, and enrollment at San Felipe was more than 350. Now, Mr. Dolan said, defections have cost $150,000 for this school year, 15 percent of his $1 million budget. With barely 300 children remaining, he is cutting art, music and sports programs.
"Some people are waking up and saying perhaps we have to be more aggressive about protecting our way of life," said Sam Montoya, a Pueblo Indian who directs the Southern Puebloes Agency, a subsidiary of the Bureau of Indian Affairs. "We have existed here for hundreds of years, taking care of ourselves, maintaining our values and our infrastructure. There's an awareness now that, yes, there is a challenge to these values.
"I'm not trying to say that any tribe is trying to shut out the outside world. They're trying to strike a balance betweeen what they feel is a way of life that is unique as compared to taking advantage of the new technology and the new opportunities provided by the other world."
But Sharon Alt, the Algodones principal, said: "My feeling is that no one has the right to coerce anyone. Parents should have supreme power over their kids' education."
The dissident families seem to want the best of the two worlds.
"My father's been very supportive," Bonnie Candelaria said. "My parents say, 'Your kids come first.' My father teaches them the Indian way at home. At school they'll get the English way. They can go by both."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "We want our kids to learn to adapt to the world out there, rather than the world in here," said Bonnie Candelaria, who registered her daughter, Valyn, left,at the public school in Algodones, N.M., rather than the school on the Pueblo Indian reservation. With them were Valyn's 2-year-old sister, Jovita.; Almost half the pupils at the Algodones school are from the Pueblo reservation, to the great dismay of tribal leaders. HEADLINE: Strong Words For Bankers

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 23

 BODY:
In a break with the dogged optimism of the American Bankers Association convention here, the Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, chastised the industry today for bringing upon itself a decline in public confidence.
Mr. Clarke, the nation's top bank regulator, told the convention that the industry's reputation was at its lowest level in 50 years.
The meeting is taking place as the industry grapples with a slumping economy, anxiety over loan losses and political fallout from the savings and loan crisis. But banking leaders have maintained that the industry over all is strong.
Mr. Clarke suggested that the industry would have further difficulties if it did not shore up its standing with the general public and legislators.
He said many bankers had lost sight of such basics as sound lending practices and diversification of risks.
"Recent experience has again brought home the lesson that there is no substitute for following the fundamentals," he said. "But, as banking's current reputation proves, profound damage occurs from the failure to follow it."
