HEADLINE: Holtzman Cuts Estimate Of the City's Budget Gap

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman released a report yesterday revising her estimate of New York City's budget gap to $2 billion, from $2.6 billion, for the fiscal year that starts next July, but she warned that the city faced losing from 31,000 to 51,600 workers through layoffs and attrition.
The release of the report was the second time this month that Ms. Holtzman's office had publicly disputed figures put out by Mayor David N. Dinkins's office, but her new estimate comes closer to the Mayor's predictions. On the day Ms. Holtzman made her original estimate, Mr. Dinkins's office estimated the budget gap at about $1.5 billion. His budget director has warned that the work force might have to be cut by 15,000. 
 Ms. Holtzman's first estimate raised questions about the severity of the city's financial problems and the administration's ability to deal with them. It dealt only with the budget gap and not with estimates of job losses.
The new, less-pessimistic estimate is based on the assumption that no wage increases will be granted to municipal unions this year. The earlier estimate assumed that all municipal unions would receive a 5.5 percent wage increase in the current fiscal year, matching the one awarded the teachers' union, and a 5 percent increase in fiscal 1992. It also assumed increases in benefits of 0.3 percent.
 
Criticized as Overly Pessimistic
 Ms. Holtzman warned, however, that if the city kept its pledge to give the teachers a 5.5 percent raise and settled with the other unions at 4.5 percent, it might mean a reduction of 51,583 jobs through a combination of layoffs and attrition. Even if the city reversed the agreement with the teachers and froze all other wages, it would still have to reduce its work force by 30,926, the report said.
The Mayor's Budget Director, Philip R. Michael, said Ms. Holtzman's latest report was overly pessimistic. He said it was too early to make predictions about budget gaps and job reductions beyond his warning that the city might have to cut its work force by 15,000.
The report was dismissed by Barry L. Feinstein, the president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, which is in contract negotiations with the city. The teamsters and the municipal unions have demanded a raise equal to the 5.5 percent given to city teachers.
 
Four Possibilities Cited
 "Liz Holtzman is a fumbling economic forecaster," Mr. Feinstein said. "Two weeks ago, she predicted a budget deficit of $2.6 billion, and today, $2 billion. Maybe next week it will be $1.5 billion, and eventually it will get down to the point where we can reach an agreement. She has lost crediblity in this arena with this kind of behavior."
Ms. Holtzman said her new estimates were conservative, noting that she did not take into consideration the possibilities of cutbacks in Federal and state aid or a further downturn in the local economy.
The report lays out four possibilities that include everything from a wage increase of 4.5 percent for city employees to a wage freeze and a rollback of the teachers' 5.5 percent raise.
Whatever the differences between the new report and the Mayor's forecasts, Mr. Michael conceded that the city's fiscal future was grim. "I believe there is a high likelihood of significant numbers of layoffs," he said.

HEADLINE: Disney Turns to Japanese For Future Film Financing

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23

 BODY:
The Walt Disney Company said today that it would finance most of its future films through a new partnership with Japanese investors and banks.
The deal marks the largest investment yet by the Japanese in American films, aside from the Sony Corporation's $3.5 billion acquisition of Columbia Pictures. 
 The new partnership, which includes Yamaichi Securities, one of Japan's largest investment firms, and a consortium including several large Japanese banks, will initially raise $600 million for Disney, enough to finance at least 30 movies, or more than a year's production. The partnership is expected to raise more money in the future.
The deal is the second in a month to bring Japanese money into Disney. In September, Disney formed a joint venture with Interscope Communications, the production company that made "Three Men and a Baby," and a group that includes Nomura Securities of Japan. Under that arrangement, Japanese investors will provide at least $50 million for Interscope to make a number of films for Disney.
The partnership announced today will replace Disney's film-financing arrangement with Silver Screen Partners, an investment group that has raised more than $1 billion for Disney movies in recent years. Unlike other big studios, Disney has chosen to finance films through outside investors, sharing the rewards when it has a hit but spreading the risk for the flops. Such arrangements allow Disney access to financing without having to put the debt on its own books.
Disney executives said the deal provided significantly better terms for the studio than anything Silver Screen could offer. The Japanese partnership, called Touchwood Pacific Partners I, will provide the financing at a considerably lower interest rate than Silver Screen could offer, taking advantage of the relatively low interest rates in Japan.
The new partnership also agreed not to demand any guarantees of minimum financial performance from Disney films. Under the arrangements with Silver Screen, Disney agreed to guarantee that investors would at least get their principal back if its slate of films performed poorly.
In essence, the deal is a bet by Yamaichi and the other investors that Disney will maintain its consistent success in film making. While the company has had its share of flops, its overall slate of films has ranked at or near the top of the box-office charts for the last five years.
 
'Shared Risk and Reward'
 "The concept of shared risk and reward in our overall movie slate is a very healthy business strategy," said Jeffrey Katzenberg, the head of Disney's film operations. "This is a very, very attractive deal for us and a very attractive deal for them."
Of the initial $600 million to be raised for Disney by Touchwood, $180 million is to come from the sale of limited partnerships in Japan by Yamaichi.
The remaining $420 million will come from loans to Touchwood by Fuji Bank Ltd., the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd., and other international banks including Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Prices Stage Rally As Recession Fears Ease

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of copper futures surged yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange in a powerful rally ignited by fading recession fears and fanned by computer-generated buying.
Copper futures settled 3.55 cents to 5.2 cents higher, with the contract for spot delivery at $1.322 a pound. 
 The rally marked copper's fourth straight daily advance after the spot price touched a three-month low of $1.2315 last Wednesday.
Analysts said the recent decline reflected pessimism about the economy and perceptions that industrial demand for copper would slacken in a recession.
But recession fears have eased as oil prices have fallen, and many speculators who sold copper futures in anticipation of a further decline bought back those contracts yesterday after signs appeared that industrial users were buying copper, analysts said.
"People started thinking the slowdown might not be as bad as formerly thought and demand for copper might not be as adversely impacted," said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with Paine Webber Inc.
Analysts said buying interest was also fueled by the London Metal Exchange's weekly report on warehouse stocks of copper, which showed an unexpectedly large decline of 5,075 metric tons, to 192,424.
The rise in prices prompted large-scale buying by speculative funds whose trading decisions are based on computerized analysis of price charts and other market information, analysts said.
Platinum futures rose sharply for the fifth straight day on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Like copper, prices of platinum, an industrial metal, fell dramatically when recession fears were on the rise.
In addition to a letup in recession worries, "some people are thinking that with oil prices breaking like they have recently, we could see some moderation of interest rates, which might be supportive," said William O'Neill of Merrill Lynch.
Platinum settled $9.90 to $10.10 higher, with October at $422.40 an ounce.
Soybean futures rose moderately on the Chicago Board of Trade in a late technical rally that helped raise corn prices. Wheat futures settled 1 cent lower to 1/2 cent higher.
Strong cash markets took precedence over Monday's bearish Government cattle-on-feed report to lift most cattle futures prices on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Philadelphia Journal;
Planners Offer Vision In Area Without Dream

BYLINE: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23

 BODY:
To most out-of-towners, North Philadelphia is a decrepit Amtrak station, a whistle-stop where conductors openly worry about the safety of the few who disembark. To the people who live there, many of them black, North Philadelphia is a place without a dream.
That was the assessment of a group of urban experts, assembled last weekend from around the country by the American Institute of Architects to evaluate the section and to suggest solutions to its problems. The 11 volunteers slipped into town last Thursday night, and like a SWAT team searching for suspects, they swept through the area, held meetings, took tours and talked to community leaders. 
 The exercise was part of a 23-year-old voluntary program of the institute, Regional/Urban Design Assistance Teams. The institute sifts through applications from local organizations, choosing sites that seem to hold the most promise for change. It then recruits team members from whatever discipline seems appropriate for each project. On average, the institute sends out four teams a year, on projects from public land use in Vancouver, Wash., to growth management in Kansas City, Mo.
"The purpose of Rudat is to get a fresh perspective on a problem from a group of outside professionals who wouldn't be influenced by the local power structure," said Peter C. McCall, an institute spokesman. "The team's recommendations are intended to serve as a catalyst for community action, and we have a successful track record in that regard."
North Philadelphia, once the heart of the city's manufacturing industry, is just north of the city's downtown and sprawls east toward the Delaware River and west toward the Schuylkill. About 17 percent of the city's population, or about 275,000 people, live there; 69 percent of them are black and 15 percent Hispanic.
The area's most important institution is Temple University. Connie Mack Stadium, where the Athletics played baseball until they moved to Kansas City in 1954 and where the Phillies played until they moved to Veterans Stadium in South Philadelphia in 1970, was gutted by fire and demolished in 1976.
"North Philadelphia is the city's largest area of physical decay along with having the most concentrated poverty in the city," said Barbara J. Kaplan, executive director of the City Planning Commission. "But despite all the poverty, it has a significant percentage of homeownership, ranging from about 38 to 60 percent in different areas, and that is a real strength."
Enter the experts. Led by Clifford Graves, a San Diego city planner, team members included Roosevelt Grier, the former Los Angeles Rams lineman who is now a specialist in youth programs; Dale Menkhaus, an assistant police chief of Cincinnati, and Gus Newport, a former Mayor of Berkeley, Calif. The team also included architects, urban planners, a sociologist, an economist and a transportation specialist.
By Monday afternoon the team had finished a detailed report with recommendations for improving many services in the area, including housing, day care, education and transportation. The experts noted that the neighborhood had no fewer than 900 separate assistance programs operating independently.
The report did not offer any instant solutions for financing the reconstruction of North Philadelphia. It did, however, suggest that existing resources could be put to better use.
On Monday night, the team held a town meeting and dreamed aloud about a utopian North Philadelphia, a place with a Crystal Palace for a train station, a glass-sided School for the Creative and Performing Arts and a Grand Civic Plaza.
"The children will have the opportunity to perform in the Grand Civic Plaza," said M. David Lee, an urban designer from Boston and a team member, "at which time there will be food and vegetables and produce and products of the hands and minds of North Philadelphians to sell to each other and to the people from outside who just have to come and find out what all this is about."
In response, the audience of several hundred stood up in the Stanton Elementary School auditorium and began clapping and chanting:
 
We're going to build!
We're going to build North Phila delphia!
We're going to do it ourselves!
We tore it down and we're going to build it back! Amen!

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Prices of Oil Viewed as Stabilized

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices stabilized yesterday after a record drop the day before took futures prices below $30 a barrel.
Crude for December delivery settled at $29.37 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down $1.04 from the previous day's December bid.
But that price was about $1 higher than the mark set by the expired November contract, which plummeted a record $5.41, to $28.38, on its last day of trading on Monday.
 
Limits Imposed by Exchange
 December contracts did not fall as far as November on Monday because of daily limits imposed by the exchange on contracts beyond the near month. The December contract was pressed lower yesterday to narrow that gap, but analysts were not sure whether to characterize the move as an increase or a decrease.
"It's tricky," said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. "Stabilization is the best word."
January and February crude contracts fell along with December, but later contract months were higher.
"We're having a little bit of confusion," said Thomas Blakeslee, an energy analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. "They're not exactly sure where they want to take the market."
 
Peace Called More Likely
 Those analysts following crude prices said the market was definitely viewing peace in the Persian Gulf as more likely than war.
Crude's record fall on Monday occurred as traders responded to reports of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq having a dream in which a prophet told him his rockets were pointed in the wrong direction.
Prices also had fallen on statements from a ranking Saudi official that were construed as indicating Iraq might be able to keep some Kuwaiti territory in a negotiated settlement of the crisis.
 
Some Ground Recovered
 Refined petroleum products recovered some ground from Monday's plunge, moving higher for next-month delivery, with later months mixed.
Home heating oil was 5.08 cents higher at 81.06 cents a gallon for November delivery. Contracts for subsequent months were mixed.
Unleaded gasoline was 3.40 cents higher at 79.90 cents a gallon for November delivery, with later months trading mostly lower.
Natural gas prices were higher yesterday, rising 1.5 cents, to $2.52 for 1,000 cubic feet for December delivery. Other contract months moved up as well.
